These grants and assistance are awarded to other tax-exempt organizations to be used in any way the recipients see fit to further their mission and tax exempt purpose; the use of these funds is not monitored by the Baker College campus.

DAVENPORT UNIVERSITY PROVIDES FUNDING FOR STUDENT SCHOLARSHIPS AND TUITION DISCOUNTS BASED ON MERIT, FINANCIAL NEED, SPECIAL CRITERIA BASED ON RESTRICTED ENDOWMENT FUNDS, AND INFORMATION PROVIDED BY THE STUDENT ON THE SCHOLARSHIP APPLICATION. ALLOCATIONS ARE DETERMINED FOR EACH ACCOUNT BY THE ACCOUNTING AND ALUMNI AND DEVELOPMENT OFFICES AND DISTRIBUTED TO THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICER RESPONSIBLE FOR SCHOLARSHIPS. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE IS RESPONSIBLE FOR COMMUNICATING AWARD GUIDELINES, PROCEDURES, AND REQUIREMENTS, AS WELL AS AWARD AMOUNTS, TO ACCOUNTS RECEIVABLE AND OTHER DEPARTMENTS AS NECESSARY TO ENSURE THE ACCURACY OF THE AWARDS. IN ADDITION, THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ENSURING THAT AWARDS ARE MADE IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE SCHOLARSHIP CRITERIA AND AWARDED IN THE AMOUNT APPROVED BY THE ALUMNI AND DEVELOPMENT OFFICE.

THE UNIVERSITY UTILIZES THE POWERFAIDS FINANCIAL AID MANAGEMENT SYSTEM WHICH REQUIRES THE END USER TO TIE HIGHLY SPECIFIC ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA TO INDIVIDUAL AID PROGRAMS. DURING EXECUTION OF THE AUTOMATED AWARDING MODULE WITHIN POWERFAIDS AID IS ALLOCATED BASED ON THE PRE-ESTABLISHED CRITERIA ENSURING THAT GRANT FUNDS ARE ONLY DISTRIBUTED TO APPROPRIATE, QUALIFIED RECIPIENTS. POST AUTO-AWARDING A SERIES OF MIS INFORMATION REPORTS PERFORM A STUDENT-BY-STUDENT TEST OF AWARD EFFICACY MONITORING THAT STUDENT GRANT AID HAS BEEN APPROPRIATELY DISTRIBUTED. WITHIN THE STUDENT ACCOUNTS SYSTEM AND GENERAL LEDGER STUDENT GRANT PROGRAMS EXPENDITURES ARE ASSIGNED SUB-CODES THAT UNIQUELY IDENTIFY THEM AS SUCH THUS PROHIBITING ANY INADVERTANT OR INAPPROPRIATE DISTRIBUTION. THE UNIVERSITY HAS ESTABLISHED APPROPRIATE CONTROLS THROUGH SEPARATION OF RESPONSIBILITIES AND INTERNAL AUDIT PROCEDURES THAT PRECLUDE ANY ENTITY WITHIN THE ADMINISTRATIVE STRUCTURE FROM DIVERTING STUDENT GRANT AID TO NONQUALIFIED USES.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PART III, COLUMN D
ExplntnTxt: THE "NON-CASH ASSISTANCE" REPORTED ARE CREDITS AGAINST STUDENT TUITION CHARGES.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Grant funds disbursed by the College are predominantly available as merit or need based scholarships. These scholarships are disbursed by the Financial Aid office and are credited directly to the student's account to pay for tuition, room and board. They are then monitored by the Financial Aid Office and the Student Accounts Office, both of whom are notified if the student's enrollment status changes during the semester. These offices monitor whether the grantee is taking the necessary classes and is therefore utilizing the grant as it was intended. If a student's enrollment changes, award adjustments are made. Other grant funds are disbursed by the College through Accounts Payable. Qualification and use of these payments are monitored by the respective departments responsible for the disbursement.

ALL UNIVERSITY STUDENTS ARE CONSIDERED FOR GRANTS AND/OR ASSISTANCE. THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE EVALUATES EACH STUDENT'S FINANCIAL NEED BASED UPON INFORMATION PROVIDED ON THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA). FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MANAGEMENT AWARD MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS WHO QUALIFY BASED UPON DONOR STIPULATIONS AND AWARD FEDERAL, STATE, AND PRIVATE NEED-BASED AWARDS BASED ON FEDERAL OR OTHER GUIDELINES. STUDENTS RECEIVING AWARDS PROVIDE INFORMATION AND PARTICIPATE IN INTERVIEWS TO ENSURE THAT GUIDELINES AND RESIDENCY RULES AND REGULATIONS ARE MET.
FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED BY FINANCIAL PROFESSIONAL IN ACCORDANCE WITH COLLEGE POLICIES.

THE UNIVERSITY ISSUES GRANTS AND OTHER FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO STUDENTS, WHICH ALLOWS STUDENTS TO FURTHER THEIR EDUCATION. GRANTED FUNDS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S UNIVERSITY BILLING ACCOUNT AND APPLIED TO TUITION, FEES, AND OTHER COSTS OF EDUCATION. IN FISCAL YEAR 2014-2015 THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED DOMESTIC FINANCIAL AID TO SUPPORT 1299 STUDENTS
ASSISTANCE IS GIVEN TO INDIVIDUALS IN THE FORM OF CREDITS TOWARD THE COST OF TUITION, AND A RECORD OF THE ASSISTANCE PROVIDED IS RECORDED IN SEPARATE ACCOUNTS MAINTAINED FOR EACH STUDENT/RECIPIENT.

SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS FOR STUDENTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO A STUDENT'S COLLEGE ACCOUNT AND APPLIED TO TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD. ALL FINANCIAL AID IS SUBJECT TO REVISION BASED ON AVAILABILITY, CHANGES IN FAMILY CONTRIBUTION AND/OR CREDIT LOAD. SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS MUST BE MAINTAINED ACCORDING TO STANDARDS PRESCRIBED BY THE COLLEGE. ANNUAL RENEWAL OF FINANCIAL AID IS CONTINUOUS IF INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL NEED REMAINS, ALL REQUIRED DOCUMENTS ARE COMPLETED BY THE PUBLISHED DEADLINE AND SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS IS MAINTAINED CONSISTENT WITH THE COLLEGE'S POLICY.
STUDENTS APPLY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS USING FEDERAL FAFSA APPLICATIONS. SPECIFIC CRITERIA ARE APPLIED TO CONFIRM ELIGIBILITY AND TO ASSURE FAIRNESS TO ALL APPLICANTS.

Disbursements in furtherance of Middlebury's exempt programs are made in accordance with procedures or subject to conditions established by Middlebury's governing board designed to ensure that the individuals receiving disbursements from Middlebury are adequately investigated to ensure that they are qualifying recipients. Grant sub-awardees are required to submit A-133 reports which are reviewed by the Middlebury's grant accountant. All billings are reviewed and approved by the principal investigator and grant accountant before being paid.

The Organization only awards financial assistance or grant-in-aid to individuals who are designated to meet the educational expenses of students attending Fuller Theological Seminary. The Organization has established institutional policies for awarding and monitoring of financial assistance. Each award is done in accordince with the policies and compliance is monitored by senior management, to ensure that the amount and eligibility of individuals is in accordance with established policies.

MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS The College has a fair, equitable and consistent awarding policy that meets federal, state and institutional requirements. Students are offered a combination of federal, state and institutional aid. Packaging parameters are periodically reviewed with the help of an outside consultant to evaluate the MMC grants and scholarship programs offered to all student populations at MMC. MMC's awarding policy is reviewed by an independent auditor each year to ensure our compliance with regulatory requirements at MMC. Students are monitored each semester to ensure they meet the requirements attached to the aid they are receiving. The review includes both enrollment and academic progress components. MMC students must maintain their gpa and complete their credits as described in the College Catalogue under academic satisfactory academic progress standards. Additionally each grant received has unique standards (see college catalogue) which must be maintained for continued awarding. A review is conducted each semester by the financial aid staff under the direct supervision of the Director of Financial Aid.

THE UNIVERSITY MONITORS THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS BY AWARDING THOSE FUNDS ONLY TO ENROLLED STUDENTS TO BE USED FOR STUDENTS' TUITION AND FEES. FEDERAL AWARDS ARE SUBJECT TO AN AUDIT BY AN INDEPENDENT AUDITOR ON AN ANNUAL BASIS PURSUANT TO OMB CIRCULAR A-133.

To remain at Knox, all degree-seeking students are expected to make satisfactory academic progress. Satisfactory progress is defined both in terms of the accumulation of credits toward the degree, and as the maintenance of a gradepoint average consistent with graduation requirements. The Financial Aid Office follows the decisions of the Academic Standing Committee in determining whether a student is meeting the College's satisfactory academic progress standards.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedure for Monitoring Use of Grant Funds In the U.S.
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Grants to Organizations in the U.S. AU PARTNERS WITH OTHER UNIVERSITIES AS NECESSARY TO PERFORM THE SCOPE OF THE WORK OUTLINED IN THE GRANTS AGREEMENTS. PRIOR TO ENGAGING WITH THESE SUB-AWARDEES, AU PERFORMS A RISK ASSESSMENT INCLUDING A REVIEW OF THE MOST RECENT FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AS WELL AS ENSURING THEY ARE NOT LISTED AS A DEBARRED ENTITY WITH ANY FEDERAL AGENCY. AU works to monitor grants and scholarships expended using its processes and controls inherent in AU's system. Before selecting the recipient and periodically as required during the grant or scholarship term, AU imposes its institutional criteria and the donor's (when applicable) to make sure that the funds are used for the intended purposes. This monitoring is done through a collaboration of various departments of the University. Periodic spending reports are pulled to provide additional oversight of scholarships as necessary to report back to donors on the status of their gifts. Grants to Individuals in the U.S. Schedule I, Part III, Line 1 ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE UNIVERSITY'S ASSESSMENT ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND SIMILAR STANDARDS. APPROXIMATELY 75% OF FULL TIME FRESHMEN APPLIED FOR NEED BASED FINANCIAL AID.

FOR FINANCIAL AID GRANTS/SCHOLARSHIPS, THE COLLEGE AWARDS THESE TO STUDENTS EACH SEMESTER BASED ON SEVERAL FACTORS. THE AWARDS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT BALANCE FOR TUITION. FOR FACULTY DEVELOPMENT GRANTS, THE COLLEGE COLLECTS A DETAILED ACCOUNTING OF ALL GRANT RELATED EXPENDITURES ALONG WITH ALL CORRESPONDING RECEIPTS. ALL EXPENDITURES ARE REVIEWED TO ENSURE THAT THEY ARE RELATED TO THE GRANT AND THERE IS PROPER DOCUMENTATION. THE GRANT RECIPIENT ALSO SUBMITS A REPORT TO ACADEMIC AFFAIRS SUMMARIZING THEIR EXPERIENCE.

FOR ALL SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS, FINANCIAL AID HAS ESTABLISHED SPECIFIC CRITERIA FOR ELIGIBILITY AND SELECTION. THE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS ARE DOCUMENTED AND MONITORED FOR COMPLIANCE. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE CREDITED TO STUDENT TUITION BILLS.

PACIFIC LUTHERAN UNIVERSITY OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS TO HELP REDUCE THEIR OUT-OF-POCKET TUITION COSTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE OF THIS FORM MUST MEET SPECIFIC CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS WHETHER PUT IN PLACE BY THE COLLEGE OR BY DONORS OF RESTRICTED FUNDS.

THE COLLEGE MAKES GRANTS TO STUDENTS BASED UPON FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE. THE SELECTION OF GRANT RECIPIENTS IS MADE BASED UPON OBJECTIVE CRITERIA. NO ONE IS DISCRIMINATED AGAINST BASED UPON RACE, RELIGION, GENDER, ETHNIC BACKGROUND, AGE, HANDICAP OR ANY OTHER REASON. THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT ASSESSES AND MONITORS THE ELIGIBILITY AND AWARDING OF GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS. IT IS ASSISTED IN ITS ON-GOING REVIEW BY THE RESOURCES OF THE REGISTRAR AND STUDENT ACCOUNTS DEPARTMENTS.

GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS BASED UPON THE CRITERIA ESTABLISHED WITH EACH GRANT. FINANCIAL AID PERSONNEL MONITOR EACH GRANT ALONG WITH THE TOTAL AID RECEIVED BY EACH STUDENT TO ENSURE THAT INDIVIDUALS AS WELL AS COLLECTIVE AWARDS ARE WITHIN THE GUIDELINES ESTABLISHED BY STATE AND FEDERAL GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES.

EDEN THEOLOGICAL SEMINARY AWARDS TUITION GRANTS TO ITS STUDENTS. THE GRANTS REDUCE THE AMOUNT OF TUITION AND FEES THAT THAT STUDENT IS REQUIRED TO PAY TO THE SEMINARY. THE SEMINARY MAINTAINS RECORDS OF THE GRANTS AWARDED TO THE STUDENTS.

The College follows federal guidelines for determining the financial need of each student attending programs in the United States. The College Board Profile and the FAFSA (Free Application for Federal Student Aid) provide us with information to determine financial need. Grants and scholarships are awarded based on the demonstrated need of each student.

ADMISSIONS IS GIVEN A PERCENTAGE OF GROSS TUITION TO AWARD AS INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS. THE CURRENT PERCENTAGE IS 23%. THE AMOUNT OF THE GRANT IS COMMUNICATED TO THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WHO MAKES IT PART OF THE TOTAL FINANCIAL AID PACKAGE. ONCE THE STUDENT ACCEPTS ADMISSION, THE GRANT IS POSTED TO THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT BY FINANCIAL AID. THE BUSINESS OFFICE MONITORS THE TOTAL AWARDED TO ENSURE THEY ARE WITHIN BUDGET.

REGIS UNIVERSITY MONITORS THE USE OF FUNDS BY ENSURING EXPENSES COMPLY WITH ALL APPLICABLE FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL LAWS, REGULATIONS, AND GUIDELINES INCLUDING, THE DEPT OF EDUCATION'S STUDENT FINANCIAL AID HANDBOOK AND THE COLORADO DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION'S POLICY GUIDELINES AND AUDIT GUIDE.

EXPLANATION: THE ORG. UTILIZES VARIOUS DATABASES TO STORE & MONITOR ALL DATA PERTAINING TO THE AWARDING AND DISBURSEMENT OF GRANTS RECEIVED IN THE U.S. ALL GRANTS RECEIVED ARE PROPERLY APPLIED AS PAYMENTS TOWARD STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS APPROPRIATELY. ALL PARTICIPATING GRANTING ORGANIZAITONS HAVE COMPLIANCE REQUIREMENTS THAT ARE ADHERED TO & AUDITED ANNUALLY IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE OFFICE OF MGT. AND BUDGET (OMB) CIRCULAR A-133, AUDITS OF STATES, LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, AND NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS. AS SUCH, THE ORG. PRESENTS SCHEDULES OF EXPENDITURES OF FEDERAL AND STATE AWARDS SUMMARIZING ALL EXPENDITURES USING THE ACCRUAL BASIS OF ACCOUNTING.

WILKES UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS A COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAM OF FINANCIAL AID TO ASSIST STUDENTS IN THE FINANCING OF THEIR EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS. THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS BOTH MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS AND NEED-BASED GRANTS TO UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS. UNDERGRADUATE MERIT AWARDS ARE BASED ON HIGH SCHOOL ACHIEVEMENT INCLUDING SAT SCORES AND HIGH SCHOOL CLASS RANK. STUDENTS MUST COMPLETE THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID TO HAVE THEIR ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED AID DETERMINED. GRADUATE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS ENROLLED IN THE DISTANT EDUCATION PROGRAM.

ALL HOOD COLLEGE GRANTS, COLLEGE WORK-STUDY AWARDS, PERKINS LOANS AND MOST STAFFORD LOANS ARE BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED. HOOD SCHOLARSHIPS ARE BASED ON ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AS EVALUATED THROUGH THE STUDENT'S HIGH SCHOOL RECORD AND SAT SCORES. MANY SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS' TOTAL FINANCIAL AID PACKAGES ALSO INTEGRATE NEED BASED AWARDS. ALL GRANTS AND AWARDS REQUIRE REPORTING OF FUND USAGE.

FIELDING GRADUATE UNIVERSITY AWARDS TUITION SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY AND ARE IMMEDIATELY APPLIED AGAINST THE STUDENT'S TUITION CHARGES. FIELDING GRADUATE UNIVERSITY AWARDS RESEARCH GRANTS TO FACULTY MEMBERS AND STUDENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY AND REQUIRES WRITTEN REPORTS FROM GRANT RECIPIENTS.

STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE INSTITUTION'S ASSESSMENT, THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS. THE UNIVERSITY DETERMINES WHO QUALIFIES FOR LOANS BASED ON ANALYSIS BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. LOANS ARE AWARDED AS PART OF A PACKAGE CONSISTING OF FEDERAL GRANTS, FEDERAL AND UNIVERSITY LOANS, FEDERAL WORK-STUDY AND UNIVERSITY SCHOLARSHIPS. IN ALL CASES, THOSE WHO RECEIVE LOANS HAVE DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED AND HAVE COMPLETED A FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID APPLICATION FORM. THE AMOUNTS RECEIVED ARE ADDED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT TO OFFSET THE COST OF TUITION AND FEES.
THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS COMPLIANCE WITH GRANT/SCHOLARSHIP CRITERIA ON AN INDIVIDUAL STUDENT BASIS.

FOR ALL SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS, STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES HAS ESTABLISHED SPECIFIC CRITERIA IN REGARDS TO ELIGIBILITY AND SELECTION. THE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS OF THE STUDENTS ARE DOCUMENTED AND MONITORED FOR COMPLIANCE. THE ACTUAL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S TUITION BILLS. NO SCHOLARSHIPS OR GRANTS ARE AWARDED DIRECTLY TO THE RECIPIENTS.
PART I QUESTION 2 GRANTS TO RECIPIENTS IN THE U.S. INCLUDED TUITION ASSISTANCE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS.

EACH GRANTEE IS ONLY GIVEN FUNDS AFTER THEY PROVIDE THE COLLEGE-READY PROMISE WITH A DETAILED ACCOUNT OF WHAT THE FUNDS HAVE EITHER BEEN SPENT ON PREVIOUSLY OR WHAT THEY WILL BE SPENT ON IN THE FUTURE.

Merit Based Scholarship: limited merit aid opportunities to students who have demonstrated high academic achievement, exemplary leadership, and strong citizenship within the community. In order to be eligible for merit aid, students must meet all priority application deadlines and be in the top tier of the admission pool. Merit awards vary in amounts and requirements. Merit aid is renewed each year if the recipient earns a weighted 3.0 or higher GPA and remains in good standing at Saint Mary's School. Need Based Scholarship: is given to students with a demonstrated need who would not otherwise have been able to afford Saint Mary's School. All need-based financial aid awards are reviewed annually. Applicants and returning students who are interested in need-based financial aid must apply each year with current financial information by the published deadlines. Tuition Remission: for the daughters and stepdaughters of all benefitted employees of the School for 50% of the tuition charges at Saint Mary's School.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 - MONITOR THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS:
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY'S GRANTS IN THE US CONSIST OF FINANCIAL AID AWARDS WHICH ARE APPLIED AGAINST STUDENTS' RECEIVABLE BALANCES DUE TO THE UNIVERSITY. THE UNIVERSITY MONITORS THESE GRANTS BY CONTROLLING THE APPLICATION OF GRANTS TO STUDENTS' BALANCES.

STUDENTS INTERESTED IN APPLYING FOR FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE MUST SUBMIT A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) AND CONCORDIA'S APPLICATION FOR FINANCIAL AID. CHURCH-WORK STUDENTS MUST ALSO COMPLETE A DECLARATION OF INTENT FROM THEIR HOME CHURCH. WHEN ALL REQUIRED FORMS HAVE BEEN RECEIVED IN THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES (SFS), SFS COMPUTES THE STUDENT'S ESTIMATED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION (EFC) AND COMPILES AN AWARD PACKAGE OF SCHOLARSHIPS, GRANTS, LOANS AND WORK STUDY PROGRAMS. ELIGIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE REQUIRES THAT A STUDENT BE ACCEPTED FOR ADMISSION OR ENROLLED AND MAINTAIN SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS ACCORDING TO ESTABLISHED STANDARDS.

FINANCIAL AID IS AVAILABLE TO STUDENTS WHO CAN SHOW FINANCIAL NEED, ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, LEADERSHIP/SERVICE, ATHLETICS ABILITY, AND/OR TALENT. ACADEMIC AND LEADERSHIP AWARDS ARE DETERMINED THROUGH THE ADMISSIONS AREA, ATHLETICS AWARDS ARE DETERMINED BY THE RESPECTIVE COACH, TALENT/DEPARTMENTAL AWARDS ARE DETERMINED THROUGH THOSE ACADEMIC AREAS, AND THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE COORDINATES ALL AWARDS WITH FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL NEED-BASED AID.
Scholarships are issued based on financial need and good academic standing. Scholarships are applied against students' tuition account. No cash is distributed to students.

SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 DAVIDSON COLLEGE FOLLOWS FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL GUIDELINES AND METHODOLOGIES FOR DETERMINING ELIGIBILITY AND AWARDING OF NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID. FOR MERIT-BASED GRANTS, DAVIDSON AWARDS THE GRANTS IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE STIPULATIONS OF THE UNDERLYING GOVERNING INSTRUMENT (I.E. DONOR ENDOWMENT AGREEMENTS AND OTHER DONOR DOCUMENTATION). DAVIDSON MAINTAINS DETAILED RECORDS OF COMPLIANCE FOR ALL GRANTS DISBURSED.

HOBART AND WILLIAM SMITH COLLEGES OFFER GRANTS TO STUDENTS ON THE BASIS OF DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED AND/OR ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. STUDENTS AND THEIR FAMILIES SUBMIT STANDARDIZED APPLICATION MATERIALS TO THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID, WHICH OVERSEES THE PROCESS OF AWARDING SUCH GRANTS. ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA FOR THE VARIOUS GRANTS IS ESTABLISHED BY THE COLLEGES. THE COLLEGES CREDIT THE TUITION ACCOUNTS OF THE STUDENTS WHO ARE AWARDED FINANCIAL AID GRANTS.

GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE BASED UPON APPLICATIONS FILED WITH THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID COMMITTEE (FOR RETURNING STUDENTS), AND WITH THE ADMISSIONS DEPARTMENT FOR FIRST SEMESTER ENTERING STUDENTS. THE DETERMINATION AND AWARDING OF SCHOLARSHIPS/GRANTS IS ON A MERIT OR NEED BASIS. THE DETERMINATION IS ALSO BASED UPON AVAILABILITY OF FUNDS AND CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY A DONOR OR THE COLLEGE. THE SOURCES OF FUNDS COME FROM TUITION, ENDOWMENTS (EITHER RESTRICTED BY A DONOR OR RESTRICTED INTERNALLY BY THE COLLEGE), PRIVATE NON-ENDOWMENT GRANTS, OR GRANTS FROM THE STATE OF TEXAS. ACTUAL SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE REVIEWED MONTHLY AGAINST THE BUDGET AND DIFFERENCES ARE ANALYZED AND RECONCILED. AT THE END OF EACH FISCAL YEAR, THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND FEDERAL GRANTS AWARDED ARE AUDITED BY AN EXTERNAL AUDIT FIRM. IN ADDITION, THE STATE GRANTS ARE SUBJECT TO A REVIEW OF PROCEDURES BY THE SAME FIRM.

THE GRANTS MADE BY THE UNIVERSITY PRIMARILY CONSIST OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID FOR SCHOLARSHIPS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED AND MONITORED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS BASED UPON A NUMBER OF DIFFERENT CRITERIA, INCLUDING MERIT, ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, AND FINANCIAL NEED. 1,555 STUDENTS RECEIVED FINANCIAL AID DURING THE CURRENT FISCAL YEAR FROM A COMBINATION OF ALL SOURCES (FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL). OF THE 1,555 STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL AID, 1,555 RECEIVED FUNDING FROM INSTITUTIONAL SOURCES.

Although students and their families bear the primary responsibility for meeting costs, many find they cannot pay the full cost of an education by themselves. In most cases a financial aid package will involve family contributions, acceptance of federal assistance (including grants and loans), and financial aid from John Brown University. These financial assistance programs help fill the gap between the amount a family is expected to pay and the total educational cost. The amount the family is expected to pay is based on information provided on the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA).

SCHOLARSHIPS AND SIMILAR ALLOCATIONS ARE AWARDED BASED ON A VARIETY OF REQUIREMENTS THAT ARE RELATIVE ONLY TO THE PARTICULAR TYPE OF AWARD TO BE GRANTED. VARIOUS SCHOLARSHIPS AND SIMILAR ALLOCATIONS CAN BE AWARDED BASED ON THE FINANCIAL NEED OF THE STUDENT, THE STUDENT'S YEAR IN SCHOOL, OR ANY OTHER REQUIREMENT THAT MAY BE SPECIFICALLY NOTED IN AN ENDOWMENT.

NSU Office of Sponsored Programs maintains a written, formal policy that outlines the procedures and guidelines for monitoring the use of sponsored funds by subrecipients. Prior to entering into a subaward agreement, NSU will assess subrecipient risk based on factors such as financial stability, experience with federal awards, quality of management systems and internal controls, and prior audit results. NSU will determine what type of monitoring activities are warranted based on risk, and develop a subrecipient monitoring plan. NSU will subsequently enter into an subaward agreement with each subrecipient which properly identifies prime award information, compliance requirements, and subrecipient monitoring documents required, as applicable. Throughout the period of performance, the Principal Investigator for the project monitors the programmatic activities of the subrecipient; determining that appropriate progress has been made; receiving, reviewing and retaining copies of required programmatic reports; and reviewing/approving subrecipient invoices prior to submitting to the NSU Office of Sponsored Programs for approval and processing. As part of the initial risk assessment and throughout the period of performance of the subaward, NSU will collaboratively review any deficiencies pertaining to the sponsored award that are identified through audits or other means, and issue a management decision. Schedule I, Part I, Line 2: Institutional grants awarded to students are recorded to individual student accounts and to each college departmental account using specific contra revenue account codes. The number of recipients and amount of awards varies by center and program. Funds set aside for scholarships are budgeted annually and included in the University's budget plan approved by the Board of Trustees.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS - PART I, LINE 2:
ExplntnTxt: THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID, DEVELOPMENT, AND BUSINESS OFFICES TOGETHER ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS. THREE DIFFERENT OFFICES ARE INVOLVED IN THE PROCESS FOR ADEQUATE CHECKS AND BALANCES. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE VERIFIES STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR GRANTS AND AWARDS THE GRANT FUNDS. THE DEVELOPMENT OFFICE CLOSELY MONITORS THE RESTRICTIONS PLACED ON THE GRANT FUNDS FROM THIRD PARTIES. THE DEVELOPMENT OFFICE ENSURES THAT THE GRANTEES SELECTED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE FULFILL THROUGHOUT THE SEMESTER THE RESTRICTIONS ON THESE GRANTS. THE DEVELOPMENT OFFICE USES INTERNAL REPORTS PROVIDED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE TO ASSIST WITH THIS PROCESS. THESE INTERNAL REPORTS PROVIDE BASIC DATA ON STUDENT ELIGIBILITY, SUCH AS MAJOR, GPA, AND EXTRACURRICULAR ACTIVITIES. THE DEVELOPMENT OFFICE REPORTS BACK TO THE APPROPRIATE GRANTORS CONCERNING THE USE OF THE GRANT FUNDS. THE BUSINESS OFFICE POSTS THE DISBURSEMENT OF THE GRANT FUNDS TO THE GENERAL LEDGER UPON RECEIVING CONFIRMATION FROM THE FINANCIAL AID AND DEVELOPMENT OFFICES. ALL GRANT INFORMATION IS KEPT ON A SECURE DATABASE. THIS DATABASE INCLUDES THE NAMES OF THE STUDENTS RECEIVING GRANTS, THE AMOUNT OF THE GRANTS, THE CRITERIA USED TO AWARD GRANTS, AND THE APPLICABLE SEMESTER AND ACADEMIC YEAR.

PROCEDURES FOR APPLYING FOR FINANCIAL AID: WHENEVER POSSIBLE, CATAWBA COLLEGE WILL SUPPLEMENT THE FINANCIAL RESOURCES OF A STUDENT THROUGH MERIT PERFORMANCE-BASED AND NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS. A POTENTIAL STUDENT APPLIES AND IS ACCEPTED TO CATAWBA COLLEGE. AT THE TIME OF THEIR ACCEPTANCE, MERIT AID IS DETERMINED BY THE ADMISSIONS COUNSELOR ACCEPTING THE APPLICATION BASED ON A MATRIX CHART THAT HAS BEEN SET UP WITH REGARD TO GPA AND SAT SCORES, LIVING ON OR OFF CAMPUS, AND A SEPARATE TRANSFER STUDENT MATRIX. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNT AND, THUS, MUST BE USED FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES. WITH REGARDS TO ATHLETICS AT CATAWBA COLLEGE, THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS ALL ATHLETES TO MAKE SURE THEY DO NOT GO OVER CONFERENCE REGULATIONS REGARDING BOOKS AND SUPPLIES. CATAWBA COLLEGE REFERS TO THE NCAA DIVISION II MANUAL FOR POLICIES REGARDING STUDENT ATHLETES. THE FINANCIAL AID DIRECTOR SIGNS OFF ON THE SQUAD LISTS AND CHECKS FOR ELIGIBILITY WITH THE COMPLIANCE DIRECTOR AND, THE ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ENTERING THE ATHLETIC INFORMATION INTO THE CAI SYSTEM. THE CAI SYSTEM IS ALSO USED TO DETERMINE EQUIVALENCY COMPUTATIONS.

THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON THE CRITERIA OF THE DONOR AND/OR THE UNIVERSITY. IF THE STUDENT MEETS THE PROGRAMMED RULES FOR A SCHOLARSHIP AND THE STUDENT IS REGISTERED FOR THE APPROPRIATE NUMBER OF CREDITS, THE FUNDS WILL BE TRANSMITTED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED TO THE DIRECT COSTS OF THE STUDENT, INCLUDING TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO MONITORS THE ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE OF EACH STUDENT TO MAKE SURE THAT HE/SHE IS MEETING THE ACADEMIC REQUIREMENTS FOR EACH SCHOLARSHIP.
ALL GRANTS ARE INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID AND APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT BY THE UNIVERSITY.

THE COLLEGE FOLLOWS FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL GUIDELINES FOR DETERMINING ELIGBILITY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS, PRIZES AND OTHER GRANTS AND AWARDS. THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS RECORDS SHOWING RECIPIENT ELIGIBILITY,HOW FUNDS MAY BE USED, AND ANY RELATED PARTY DISCLOSURES. GRANTS AWARDED BY THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID ARE CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS ACCOUNTS. OTHER GRANTS ARE MONITORED IN VARIOUS WAYS, INCLUDING REIMBURSING ACTUAL SUBSTANTIATED EXPENSES, REQUIRING WRITTEN REPORTS AND /OR VISITING SITES OF ACTIVITIES FUNDED BY COLLEGE GRANTS. THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MAINTAINS ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS AND MONITORS GRANTING OF AWARDS TO STUDENTS AND FOLLOWS U.S. FEDERAL AID REGULATIONS AND ALL STATES' REGULATIONS FOR GRANTS TO ITS STUDENTS.

Scholarships are available to all students meeting the written criteria for the award of the scholarship. All scholarships and discounts are awarded by the financial aid department based on the established policies. Scholarships are directly applied to the student account.

Gannon awards scholarships to freshmen and transfer students who meet eligibility standards for merit based aid such as academic and leadership awards. In addition, need based aid is considered for students who demonstrate financial need by filing the required applications and adhering to deadlines. Award packages are renewed each year to students that remain in academically good standing and continue to meet the required eligibility standards for both types of merit and need based aid. Students need not apply for specific scholarships since they will automatically receive consideration for all funds for which they may be eligible when they submit the FAFSA.

THE UNIVERSITY'S USE OF GRANT FUNDS IS TO PROVIDE FINANCIAL AID TO OUR STUDENTS. WE MONITOR THE USE OF THESE UNIVERSITY FUNDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH ESTABLISHED LEVELS OF AWARDS BASED ON A STUDENT'S MERIT CLASSIFICATION AND ON AN ANNUAL BUDGET. THE UNIVERSITY FOLLOWS ALL REGULATIONS RELATIVE TO THE AWARDING OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE WHICH IS MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

Student financial need is substantiated based on information provided in the Free Application for Federal Student Aid--FAFSA. Additionally, some aid is given based on High School GPA or standardized test (SAT or ACT) scores. Title IV funds are handled in accordance with applicable provisions. The Financial Aid program is audited in compliance with the Federal OMB A-133 guidelines, and no deficiencies were found during the time period covered by this filing.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS TO U.S. AFTER A STUDENT HAS BEEN ACCEPTED TO THE UNIVERSITY OF MOUNT UNION, THEY MUST FILE A FAFSA. MOUNT UNION CONSIDERS ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS, OUTSIDE SCHOLARSHIPS, FEDERAL GRANTS AND STATE ELIGIBILITY IN THAT RESPECTIVE ORDER. IF THE STUDENT NEEDS FURTHER ASSISTANCE, THE COLLEGE OFFERS FEDERAL LOANS, COLLEGE GRANTS AND EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES. FINANCIAL AID BASED ON NEED IS AWARDED ON FAFSA CALCULATIONS AND THE RESULTING FINANCIAL AID THAT IS TO BE MET. ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON HIGH SCHOOL GPA, CLASS RANK AND STANDARD TEST SCORES. NEED-BASED GRANTS CAN BE ALLOCATED TO RETURNING STUDENTS BASED ON PREVIOUS YEARS AS LONG AS FINANCIAL NEED IS STILL PRESENT. ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS CONTINUE BASED ON THE STUDENT'S CUMULATIVE GPA AT THE END OF THE YEAR.

Documentation is maintained and reporting is completed to substantiate grant award uses.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS
ExplntnTxt: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 IN THE UNITED STATES SOKA UNIVERSITY OF AMERICA SERVES AS A CONDUIT TO RECEIVE AND DISBURSE STUDENT AID FUNDS FROM GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES SUCH AS THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION UNDER THE FOLLOWING PROGRAMS: - FEDERAL SUPPLEMENTAL EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITY GRANT - FEDERAL PELL AWARD GRANT PROGRAM - FEDERAL WORK STUDY - GI BILL INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS ARE GIVEN BY SOKA UNIVERSITY OF AMERICA TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS WHO MEET SPECIFIC ACADEMIC AND ACHIEVEMENT CRITERIA. THE PURPOSES OF THESE GRANTS ARE CLEARLY COMMUNICATED TO THE RECIPIENTS AND ARE INTERNALLY USED FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES.

THE COLLEGE OF IDAHO USES A COMBINATION OF FEDERAL METHODOLOGY AND INSTRUCTIONAL POLICY TO PROVIDE A UNIFORM METHOD TO ASSESS A FAMILY'S FINANCIAL STRENGTH AND THE STUDENT'S ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE TO ESTIMATE THE EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION TOWARD THE STUDENT'S COST OF EDUCATION. THE COST OF EDUCATION INCLUDES TUITION, FEES, BOOKS, SUPPLIES, ROOM, BOARD, PERSONAL EXPENSES AND TRANSPORTATION ALLOWANCE.

A SCHOLARSHIP IS AN ACHIEVEMENT AWARD. AWARDS CAN BE BASED ON THE STUDENT'S AFFILIATION WITH A PARTICULAR MAJOR, BEING A PART OF A CLUB/GROUP, OR BASED ON THE STUDENT'S ACADEMIC RECORD. STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS FROM THE UNIVERSITY ARE MONITORED TO ENSURE THAT THEY MEET THE ACADEMIC REQUIREMENTS OR OTHER CRITERIA ASSOCIATED WITH THE AWARD. FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED IS ALSO PROVIDED TO STUDENTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE BASED ON NEED ARE MONITORED TO ENSURE THEY MEET THE ACADEMIC REQUIREMENTS OR OTHER CRITERIA ASSOCIATED WITH THE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE.
RECIPIENTS ARE CHOSEN BASED ON A VARIETY OF FACTORS, SUCH AS FINANCIAL NEED, ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE, AND COURSE OF STUDY, AS STIPULATED BY THE AWARD/ENDOWMENT CRITERIA.

The Office of Financial Aid administers the following policies to assure that institutional grants and scholarships are used for proper purposes: The aggregate of institutional funds that an individual student receives is restricted to an amount equivalent to tuition and fees; Enrollment is confirmed each semester prior to disbursement of institutional funds; Eligibility for academic scholarships is limited to a maximum of eight (8) semesters. Renewal grade point average requirements are checked at the end of each academic year; Eligibility for institutional general grants requires a demonstration of need based on submission of the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FASFA); Endowed scholarships have selection criteria specific to each fund and the Director of Financial Aid oversees the selection of eligible students; when a student withdraws from school, the percentage adjustments made to institutional aid are the same as the percentage adjustments made to tuition as specified in the catalog.

Concordia University Inc. awards scholarships and financial aid to students based on financial need, talent, and/or academic merit and programs. Federal and State programs are awarded based upon respective program requirements. Federal and State programs are compliance tested yearly in conjunction with the independent audit and auditor reports/ newsletters are submitted to all organizations as required by the programs.

THE COLLEGE HAS A NUMBER OF FEDERAL AND STATE GRANTS. WITH THE ISSUANCE OF EACH AWARD A TEMPORARILY RESTRICTED ACCOUNT IS CREATED IN THE DATABASE. AWARD LETTERS ARE KEPT IN A SEPARATE FILE WITH THE PRIMARY CONTACT INFORMATION. IF THE GRANTEE DOES NOT HAVE ELIGIBILITY THE GRANT IS NOT AWARDED. IF THE ELIGIBILITY OF THE GRANTEE HAS CHANGED THE INSTITUTION RETURNS THE AWARDED FUNDS. THE GRANTS ARE BASED ON FAMILY INCOME CONTRIBUTIONS, AND/OR ACADEMIC STANDING, AND/OR ATHLETIC ABILITY, AND/OR INDIVIDUAL TALENT.

The college provides payment of the grants to the student as a credit to the students' receivable account; the grants are not directly paid to the students. For the grant to be available to the student, the college monitors the students enrollment and the student must be enrolled and active for the time period the grant is offered. If the student leaves the program early, the grant is not refunded to the student and the student's account is ratably adjusted to reflect the incomplete period.

Each year Albany Law School awards a number of merit and diversity scholarships funded from restricted and unrestricted endowment funds, annual giving by alumni and friends and other sources. The Admissions Committee awards the scholarships to first year students in the form of three year scholarships in varying amounts. Financial aid personnel, in conjunction with Development and Business Office personnel, are responsible for monitoring compliance with restrictions associated with endowment funds. All scholarships are merit-based and awarded on the basis of academic promise and individual characteristics that strengthen the applicant pool. The Admissions Committee also offers merit-based scholarships to students from diverse backgrounds including those minorities who historically have been under-represented in the legal profession. A scholarship may be retained from year to year without re-application upon achievement of grades set forth as conditions of the award. Monitoring of continued awarding for second and third year students is performed by the Financial Aid Office in conjunction with the Registrar's Office.

No checks are issued to the students directly. The financial aid office monitors the use of the funds to ensure they are used for their intended purpose.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE UNITES STATES: EACH GRANT IS ASSIGNED A GRANTS ADMINISTRATOR WHO MONITORS ALL EXPENDITURES TO ENSURE FUNDS ARE USED IN ACCORDANCE WITH GRANTOR POLICIES AND REGULATIONS. IN ADDITION, AN ACCOUNTANT IS ASSIGNED TO RECORD AND REPORT ALL GRANT REVENUES AND EXPENDITURES TO THE GRANT ADMINISTRATOR AND GRANTOR ON A REGULAR BASIS.
GRANT FUNDS ARE RECORDED IN A PROJECT ACCOUNT SO THAT ALL ASSOCIATED REVENUES AND EXPENSES ARE ACCOUNTED FOR RELATED TO A SPECIFIC GRANT.
A MEMBER OF THE ORGANIZATION'S ADMINISTRATIVE STAFF MONITERS ALL GRANT DISBURSEMENTS.

THE UNIVERSITY'S OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID, ADMINISTERS A WIDE VARIETY OF FEDERAL, STATE, INSTITUTIONAL AND PRIVATE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS. ITS MAJOR OBJECTIVE IS THE EQUITABLE DISTRIBUTION OF FINANCIAL AID TO ALL STUDENTS. THE ORGANIZATION SERVICES IN ORDER TO HELP STUDENTS FINANCE THEIR EDUCATION. RECIPIENTS ARE DETERMINED BY ACADEMIC MERIT, AS WELL AS FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL GUIDELINES. FINANCIAL AID AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED TOWARD TUITION CHARGES ONLY AND RECIPIENTS MUST MAINTAIN CERTAIN ELIGIBLITY REQUIREMENTS TO RECEIVE THEM.

All University spending must be approved by a manager or higher level, depending on the amount of the expenditure. Any expenditure of $1,000 or above would have to be approved by a Dean or other budget center manager. An expenditure in excess of $10,000 must be approved by a Vice President (or that person's designee) or the President. Grants or assistance to outside organizations are segregated in the University's financial accounting system through the use of a separate account code, which allows for review by University's central finance department. Scholarships are provided to students who are required to matriculate in the University, thereby ensuring that the funds are expended for the intended purposes.

ExplntnTxt: Village of South Orange - Construction of South Orange Performing Arts Center. Essex County Park - Improvements to the Ivy Hill Park softball field.

ORGANIZATIONS THAT RECEIVE GRANTS ARE PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS. THE UNIVERSITY'S STUDENTS GAIN PRACTICAL EXPERIENCE WHILE ASSISTING AT THESE ORGANIZATIONS. BECAUSE OF THIS CLOSE RELATIONSHIP, THE UNIVERSITY IS ABLE TO MONITOR THE USE OF THE FUNDS. THE UNIVERSITY APPLIES SCHOLARSHIPS DIRECTLY TO STUDENTS' TUITION ACCOUNTS.

The College offers financial aid to assist students on the basis of full-time enrollment. Factors influencing the amount and type of aid awarded include financial need, academic achievement, leadership and other personal, qualitative attributes. The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA), which helps to establish a student's financial need, serves as the application for financial aid. Files detailing grant and scholarship requirements and criteria are reviewed to ensure individual student eligibility before awards are made. The College does not discriminate against any person on the basis of race, color, religion, national or ethnic origin, age, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, disability, veteran status, or any other legally protected basis.

During fiscal year 2015, Hillsdale College awarded monetary grants/prizes to five institutions based on specified criteria. One prize recognizes one outstanding public or private school teacher with his/her school receiving the funds. The recipient is chosen among the teachers nationally who are implementing the ideas and curriculum contained in a comprehensive educational resource designed by Hillsdale College professors. The school is required to prepare an annual report on the expenditure(s) of the Prize until such funds are entirely expended. Three other grants supported the launch of k-12 charter schools which are based on a classical liberal arts model and which have a strong civics component which will equip students to understand and defend the principles of the American founding. The recipients are required to provide Hilllsdale College documentation on the use of the funds in addition to on-site visits by Hillsdale College staff. The last grant was to provide a fellowship in education.

Hillsdale College awards both scholarships and grants to its students. Students can receive a scholarship at matriculation in the form of merit or performance scholarship. Merit scholarship is awarded by committee based upon an incoming student's high school gpa, standardized test scores, and other, more subjective criteria such as community involvement, interviews, essays, letters of recommendation, and admissions rank. Performance scholarships are awarded by budget managers (typically coaches and fine arts chairs) based upon their own evaluations. Criteria for renewal of merit scholarships generally require students to maintain a 3.0 accumulative gpa. The Financial Aid Office polices this 3.0 requirement and any other scholarship criteria which may be attached to privately funded, named scholarships. Correspondence is sent to students at the end of each semester pertaining to their progress toward scholarship requirements. Students may become eligible for additional scholarship after their freshman year based upon classroom performance and campus involvement. These scholarship decisions are also made by committee after a review of scholarship budgets and criteria. With respect to grants, Hillsdale College students may become eligible for grant monies only by demonstrating significant need on Hillsdale College's Confidential Family Financial Statement (CFFS). All new applicants are required to submit a copy of the most recent signed tax information of parent(s) and student and any other necessary documents to complete verification of eligibility. This needs test must be resubmitted each year for renewal consideration and adjustments to amounts may be made based upon changes in demonstrated need. In addition to demonstrated financial need, grant recipients are required to meet academic standards of progress, exhibit good citizenship and moral character, and be enrolled at least half time. The Financial Aid Office monitors these additional components each semester using information provided by the Dean's Office and Registrar's Office.

THE COLLEGE MONITORS THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS THROUGH CONTROLS WITHIN THE ACCOUNTING AND INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT OFFICES. THE GRANT ADMINISTRATOR RECEIVES, VETS, AND COORDINATES SUBMITTALS FOR GRANTS. THE GRANT ADMINISTRATOR MONITORS THE AWARDS OF FUNDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE GRANT. THE GRANT ADMINISTRATOR AND ACCOUNTING OFFICE MONITOR WORK PERFORMED, BILLING, GRANT CLOSE OUT, AND POST GRANT REPORTING. THE VP OF ACADEMIC AFFAIRS AND THE VP OF FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION OVERSEE AND/OR APPROVE GRANTS.

A LIST OF RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIPS IS ON FILE AT THE COLLEGE. THE RECIPIeNTS ARE SELECTED ON AN EQUAL, OBJECTIVELY DETERMINABLE BASIS WITH OTHER RECIPIENTS. THAT IS, ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE COLLEGE'S ASSESSMENT ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS ESTABLISHED BY THE COLLEGE COMMITTEES THAT JUDGE THE APPLICANTS. THE COLLEGE HAS PROCEDURES THAT ARE DESIGNED TO ENSURE THAT INDIVIDUALS FROM THE COLLEGE QUALIFY TO RECEIVE PAYMENTS. THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE ENSURES THAT GRANTS AND AWARDS ARE IN COMPLIANCE WITH PROCEDURES ESTABLISHED BY THE COLLEGE.

THE COLLEGE DOES NOT GIVE ANY NON-CASH SCHOLARSHIPS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED TO STUDENTS THROUGH CREDITING THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNTS. IN THE EVENT OF EARLY WITHDRAWAL, REFUNDS ARE GRANTED BASED ON THE FOLLOWING SCHEDULE: THE CHARGE FOR STUDENT MEDICAL INSURANCE IS NONREFUNDABLE. ROOM AND BOARD: THE ROOM AND BOARD WILL BE PRO-RATED ACCORDING TO THE NUMBER OF DAYS THE STUDENT WAS ON CAMPUS. TUITION AND FEES: IF A STUDENT WITHDRAWS BEFORE THE FIRST DAY OF CLASS, FEES AND TUITION WILL BE REFUNDED, LESS AN ADMINISTRATIVE FEE OF ONE HUNDRED DOLLARS ($100.00). IF A STUDENT WITHDRAWS AFTER THE FIRST DAY OF CLASS BUT BEFORE THE END OF THE SECOND WEEK OF CLASS, FEES AND TUITION WILL BE CHARGED AT THE RATE OF TWENTY-FIVE PERCENT (25%). IF A STUDENT WITHDRAWS DRUING THE THIRD OR FOURTH WEEK OF CLASS, FEES AND TUITION WILL BE CHARGED AT THE RATE OF SEVENTY-FIVE PERCENT (75%). IF A STUDENT WITHDRAWS AFTER THE FOURTH WEEK OF CLASS, FEES AND TUITION ARE DUE AND PAYABLE IN FULL. ALL REFUNDS WILL BE ISSUED WITHIN TEN BUSINESS DAYS OF A STUDENT'S OFFICIAL WITHDRAWAL DATE. REQUESTS FOR REFUNDS ARE REVIEWED BY THE BUSINESS MANAGER FOR COMPLIANCE WITH ESTABLISHED WITHDRAWAL PROCEDURES. THE EXCEPTION TO THIS IS FOR STUDENTS ELIGIBLE FOR VA BENEFITS. IN ORDER TO REMAIN IN COMPLIANCE WITH VA REGULATIONS, THE FOLLOWING REFUND POLICY APPLIES: VETERANS AND OTHER ELIGIBLE STUDENTS: CROWN COLLEGE OF THE BIBILE HAS A PRO-RATA REFUND POLICY FOR THE REFUND OF THE UNUSED PORTION OF TUITION, FEES AND OTHER CHARGES IN THE EVENT THE VETERAN OR ELIGIBLE PERSON FAILS TO ENTER THE COURSE OR WITHDRAWS OR IS DISCONTINUED THERE FROM AT ANY TIME PRIOR TO COMPLETION. CROWN COLLEGE DOES NOT PARTICIPATE IN THE TITLE IV STUDENT FINANCIAL AID PROGRAMS OF THE UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: NYACK COLLEGE GRANTS FUNDS TO STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS, STUDENT LOANS, AS WELL AS OTHER FINANCIAL AID. FINANCIAL AID IS GRANTED TO STUDENTS BASED ON ELIGIBILITY GUIDELINES AS DEFINED BY THE FEDERAL DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION, THE STATE OF NEW YORK AND NYACK COLLEGE'S SCHOLARSHIP AND GRANT PROGRAMS. NYACK COLLEGE GRANTS FUNDS TO STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF INSTITUTIONAL AID BASED ON MERIT, NEED AND OTHER SPECIFIC CRITERIA AS OUTLINED IN NYACK'S SCHOLARSHIP AND GRANT PROGRAM

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: The office of Financial Aid awards grants to students that are applied to the student's account. Grants are awarded based on need or merit.

Various forms of student financial aid are posted as credits to individual student accounts receivable in accordance with institutional policies, and are funded through unrestricted fund discounts, restricted and endowed scholarships, and publicly funded grants and scholarships through the US Dept of Education, made on the basis of information provided through the FAFSA.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: Scholarships are provided to students based on needs assessments and/or performance. Once the student has been approved to receive the grant, the amount is credited to the student's Baker College account. The College's Financial Aid office monitors the student to make sure the award stays in compliance. If the student does not continue to meet the grant requirements, the student's account may be reduced. Grants and other assistance to organizations in the United States are budgeted each year by the Baker College campus. The campus President determines which organization benefits from a grant based on the community's needs. If the grant exceeds the budget, the Board of Regents must approve the funding. These grants and assistance are awarded to other tax-exempt organizations to be used in any way the recipients see fit to further their mission and tax exempt purpose; the use of these funds is not monitored by the Baker College campus.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: Scholarships are provided to students based on needs assessments and/or performance. Once the student has been approved to receive the grant, the amount is credited to the student's Baker College account. The College's Financial Aid office monitors the student to make sure the award stays in compliance. If the student does not continue to meet the grant requirements, the student's account may be reduced. Grants and other assistance to organizations in the United States are budgeted each year by the Baker College campus. The campus President determines which organization benefits from a grant based on the community's needs. If the grant exceeds the budget, the Board of Regents must approve the funding. These grants and assistance are awarded to other tax-exempt organizations to be used in any way the recipients see fit to further their mission and tax exempt purpose; the use of these funds is not monitored by the Baker College campus.
Students receiving scholarships, grants, or other assistance, are evaluated on the basis of academic achievement, financial need, and other similar standards.

The Chicago School of Professional Psychology gives need-based and merit-based scholarships. Need-based scholarships are monitored through the Department of Education FAFSA form. Students With $0 estimated family contribution (EFC), based on the Department of Education guidelines, will be automatically awarded a need-based scholarship. Merit-based scholarships are granted to students who submit all required admissions documentation by certain deadlines and apply with a 4.0 undergraduate GPA or GRE score of 1300 (test taken prior to August 1, 2011) or a combined GRE score of 314 (test taken on or after August 1, 2011). The Chicago School and its partners award fellowships to students who contribute to the academic community in and outside the classroom. Fellowship recipients dedicate 10 to 15 hours a week of work to the specific department through which the fellowship is offered. Applicants are judged on their ability to demonstrate a commitment to learning, developing, and participating in the programmatic, research, and administrative activities within the department office.
LA SALLE UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS RECORDS TO QUANTIFY THE DOLLAR AMOUNT OF THE STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AWARDED, THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS PER GRANT/SCHOLARSHIP, AND THE SELECTION CRITERIA.

THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE IS RESPONSIBLE FOR DETERMINING THAT A STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE AN AWARD. WHEN FUNDS ARRIVE, THE FINANCIAL AID STAFF DETERMINES THAT THE STUDENT IS ENROLLED FOR THE SAME NUMBER OF HOURS THAT THEY WERE PACKAGED FOR, AND THAT THEY ARE MEETING THE GUIDELINES OF SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE THEN NOTIFIES THE STUDENT ACCOUNTS DEPARTMENT THAT THE AWARD NEEDS TO BE CREDITED TO A STUDENT'S ACCOUNT FOR THAT TRIMESTER.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: THE ORGANIZATION ISSUES GRANTS TO QUALIFIED INDIVIDUALS. THE GRANT FUNDS ARE THEN USED DIRECTLY AGAINST THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT AS PAYMENT TOWARDS THEIR COLLEGE EDUCATION.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: THE ORGANIZATION ISSUES GRANTS TO QUALIFIED INDIVIDUALS. THE GRANT FUNDS ARE THEN USED DIRECTLY AGAINST THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT AS PAYMENT TOWARDS THEIR COLLEGE EDUCATION.

CARTHAGE COLLEGE OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS TO HELP REDUCE THEIR OUT-OF-POCKET TUITION COSTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE OF THIS FORM MUST MEET SPECIFIC CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS WHETHER PUT IN PLACE BY THE COLLEGE OR BY DONORS OF RESTRICTED FUNDS.

GRANT PROPOSALS ARE REVIEWED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S GRANTMAKING COMMITTEE. IF THE PROPOSAL MEETS THE GRANT GUIDELINES THE COMMITTEE DECIDES ON WHETHER TO FUND THE PROJECT. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO THE STUDENTS BASED ON DIFFERENT CRITERIA. THE UNIVERSITY FOLLOWS ALL POLICIES AND REGULATIONS OF FEDERAL AID PROGRAMS WHEN IT AWARDS FINANCIAL AID TO STUDENTS. THE UNIVERSITY REQUIRES THE GRANTEE ORGANIZATIONS TO SUBMIT REPORTS TO SUPPORT THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS.

THE VP OF FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION STAFF OVERSEE THAT THE PROVISIONS OF THE GRANT ARE MET IN ACCORDANCE WITH GUIDELINES OR AGREEMENTS SET FORTH, WHETHER THAT'S USE OF DONOR, GOVERNMENT OR PRIVATE SOURCES.

THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT GIVE ANY NON-CASH SCHOLARSHIPS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED TO STUDENTS THROUGH CREDITING THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNTS. IF THE STUDENT HAS EXCESS SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS AS THE RESULT OF TITLE IV AID, THEN THESE FUNDS ARE AUTOMATICALLY DISBURSED TO THE STUDENT BY CHECK WITHIN 14 DAYS. IF THE EXCESS FUNDS ARE THE RESULT OF SOMETHING OTHER THAN TITLE IV AID, THE STUDENT MUST REQUEST A REFUND AND THESE FUNDS ARE DISBURSED TO THE STUDENT BY CHECK. THE UNIVERSITY'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING GRANT FUNDS IN THE U. S. ARE AS FOLLOWS: THE UNIVERSITY HAS APPOINTED DIRECTORS, WHO REPORT TO THE APPROPRIATE VICE PRESIDENTS, OVER ALL FEDERAL GRANT PROGRAMS. THESE DIRECTORS ARE CHARGED WITH PERFORMING ALL GRANT-RELATED ACTIVITIES INCLUDING APPLICATION, MONITORING OF EXPENDITURES AND REPORTING, WITH THE EXCEPTION OF DRAW-DOWNS OF FEDERAL FUNDS. DRAW-DOWNS ARE PERFORMED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S CONTROLLER AFTER REQUESTS ARE MADE BY THE DIRECTOR TO THE CONTROLLER. THE CONTROLLER REVIEWS THE REQUESTS FOR DRAW-DOWNS, WHICH INCLUDE DOCUMENTATION OF ALL DIRECT AND INDIRECT PROGRAM EXPENSES, BEFORE MAKING THE DRAW-DOWNS. A SINGLE AUDIT IS PERFORMED ANNUALLY BY THE UNIVERSITY'S INDEPENDENT AUDITORS.
The University's financial aid department monitors and maintains records regarding all financial aid awards.

PART I, LINE 2 Each fiscal year the amount of University funded scholarships and discounts for the year is determined in conjunction with the University's budget-setting process. Actual financial aid awards are based on different criteria and are tracked within the approved budget. The administration of financial aid is handled by the student finance office and such aid awarded is credited directly to the student's account. Each student applies for financial aid by filling out the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA). The award is based on information provided in this application. Students can also apply for grants and scholarship based on eligibility.
THE UNIVERSITY OF TULSA FOLLOWS ALL WRITTEN PROCEDURES AS OUTLINED IN ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA.

THESE FUNDS REPRESENT FINANCIAL AID ISSUED TO STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF FEDERAL AND STATE GRANTS, SCHOLARSHIPS, TUITION DISCOUNTS, AND INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID. STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS FROM FRANCISCAN UNIVERSITY ARE MONITORED TO ENSURE THEY MEET THE ACADEMIC REQUIREMENTS OR OTHER CRITERIA ASSOCIATED WITH THE RESPECTIVE AWARD. ALL AID IS PROCESSED THROUGH THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND IS POSTED TO THE STUDENTS' RECEIVABLE ACCOUNTS.

PROCEDURE FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS INSIDE THE U.S. The College offers a wide variety of merit and need-based scholarships and awards to matriculating students. Merit awards are given in recognition of various achievements as specified in donors' correspondence and documents, or by College policy. Need-based awards are provided based on the income level, availability of awards offered elsewhere and similar standards. The College's Financial Aid Office uses various methods for the fair disbursement of grant funds within the requirements set by each grant source to monitor compliance. The College primarily makes scholarship grants that help offset tuition and other educational costs of the students, with most directly credited against the applicable student account, which assures proper use. The amount of the grant is adjusted by the Financial Aid Office, as necessary, based on any subsequent changes affecting the student's original eligibility.

MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S. THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS SEPARATE ACCOUNTS FOR EACH GRANT THAT WE RECEIVE. ON AN ANNUAL BASIS, WE RECEIVE AN AUDIT, IN ACCORDANCE WITH OMB CIRCULAR A-133 AND GOVERNMENT AUDITING STANDARDS. THE COLLEGE HAS PROCEDURES IN PLACE FOR MONITORING GRANTS TO ENSURE PROPER COMPLIANCE. CHAMPLAIN OFFERS BOTH MERIT AID AND NEED-BASED AID. MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE RENEWED ANNUALLY PROVIDED THE STUDENT IS ENROLLED FULL-TIME AND MEETS ALL ACADEMIC STANDARDS. NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE RENEWED ANNUALLY BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED; THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) FORM MUST BE COMPLETED IN ORDER TO BE CONSIDERED FOR THESE AWARDS. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS STUDENTS TO ENSURE CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY FOR THE TYPE OF AID THEY ARE RECEIVING. AT THE END OF EACH SEMESTER (FALL, SPRING, SUMMER), EVERY FINANCIAL AID RECIPIENT'S PROGRESS IS REVIEWED BY THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID. STUDENTS ARE MEASURED USING BOTH QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE STANDARDS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS REVIEW IS TO MEASURE WHETHER A STUDENT IS MAKING SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS TOWARDS GRADUATION. THESE STANDARDS APPLY TO ALL TYPES OF FINANCIAL AID: FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL AID. STUDENTS WHO FAIL TO MEET THE SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS REQUIREMENTS MAY BECOME INELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE FINANCIAL AID UNTIL THEY ARE IN COMPLIANCE WITH THESE REQUIREMENTS.

The Chicago School - Washington, D.C., Inc. gives need-based and merit-based scholarships. Need-based scholarships are monitored through the Department of Education FAFSA form. Students with $0 estimated family contribution (EFC), based on the Department of Education guidelines, will be automatically awarded a scholarship. Merit-based scholarships are granted to students who submit all required admission documentation by certain deadlines and apply with a 4.0 undergraduate GPA or GRE score of 1,300 (test taken prior to August 1, 2011) or a combined GRE score of 314 (test taken on or after August 1, 2011). The Chicago School and its partners award fellowships to students who contribute to the academic community in and outside the classroom. Fellowship recipients dedicate 10 to 15 hours a week of work to the specific department through which the fellowship is offered. Applicants are judged on their ability to demonstrate a commitment to learning, developing, and participating in the programmatic, research, and adminstrative activities within the department or office.

THE UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS RECORDS TO ENSURE FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS BASED ON CRITERIA IN INDIVIDUAL SCHOLARSHIPS, AS WELL AS FEDERAL REGULATIONS, OR DONOR RESTRICTIONS. FEDERAL GRANTS ARE AWARDED BASED ON FAFSA INFORMATION.

SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS FOR STUDENTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO A STUDENT'S GRINNELL COLLEGE ACCOUNT AND APPLIED TO TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD. ALL FINANCIAL AID IS SUBJECT TO REVISION BASED ON FUND AVAILABILITY, CHANGES IN FAMILY CONTRIBUTION AND/OR CREDIT LOAD. SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS MUST BE MAINTAINED ACCORDING TO STANDARDS PRESCRIBED BY GRINNELL COLLEGE. ANNUAL RENEWAL OF FINANCIAL AID IS CONTINUOUS IF INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL NEED REMAINS, ALL REQUIRED DOCUMENTS ARE COMPLETED BY THE PUBLISHED DEADLINE AND SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS IS MAINTAINED CONSISTENT WITH GRINNELL COLLEGE POLICY. STUDENTS AWARDED OTHER FUNDS MAKE VARIOUS REPORTS AND PRESENTATIONS ON THEIR RESEARCH OR STUDY AS REQUIRED BASED ON INDIVIDUAL REQUIREMENTS OF THE FUNDING. THE COLLEGE AWARDS GRANTS TO LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS WHICH ARE ADMINISTERED THROUGH THE OFFICE OF COMMUNITY ENHANCEMENT AND ENGAGEMENT. APPLICATIONS ARE REVIEWED BY A COMMITTEE OF FACULTY, STAFF AND GRINNELL COLLEGE STUDENTS FROM THE LOCAL AREA. ALL FINANCIAL CONTRIBUTIONS FOCUS ON THE STRATEGIC PRIORITIES OF STRENGTHENING CULTURAL, RECREATIONAL, AND EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES IN THE LOCAL AREA AS WELL AS INITIATIVES THAT ENHANCE THE SAFETY, BEAUTY, AND ECONOMIC VITALITY OF OUR SURROUNDINGS. GRINNELL COLLEGE HAS ASSEMBLED A DIVERSE SELECTION COMMITTEE TO EVALUATE NOMINEES FOR THE GRINNELL COLLEGE INNOVATOR FOR SOCIAL JUSTICE PRIZE. APPOINTED BY THE COLLEGE'S PRESIDENT, THE SELECTION COMMITTEE MEMBERS ARE ALL RECOGNIZED INDIVIDUALS WHO WORK FOR SOCIAL CHANGE IN VARIOUS CAPACITIES. THEIR BACKGROUNDS, ACCOMPLISHMENTS, AND EXPERIENCES REFLECT THE DIVERSITY IN BOTH GRINNELL AND THE STATE. THESE MEMBERS INCLUDE ONE REPRESENTATIVE EACH FROM THE COLLEGE'S FACULTY, STUDENT BODY, ALUMNI, STAFF AND TRUSTEES, PLUS PROMINENT INDIVIDUALS NOT FORMALLY AFFILIATED WITH GRINNELL.
GETTYSBURG COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS ARE DESCRIBED ON SCHEDULE F, PART V.

CMU DISTRIBUTES LIMITED FINANCIAL AID AND GRANT FUNDS TO INDIVIDUALS AND ORGANIZATIONS IN THE U.S. BASED ON A STATISTICAL MODEL THAT TAKES INTO ACCOUNT A STUDENT'S INTENDED COLLEGE MAJOR, ACADEMIC AND ARTISTIC TALENTS, NON-ACADEMIC TALENTS AND ABILITIES, AS WELL AS FINANCIAL NEED. FOR STUDENTS, SUCH FUNDS ARE TYPICALLY APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THEIR INDIVIDUAL ACCOUNTS IN FURTHERANCE OF THEIR EDUCATION AT CMU. OTHER TYPES OF GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE MIGHT INCLUDE, FOR EXAMPLE, RECIPIENTS OF PRIZES AND AWARDS WHO HAVE MET THE SPECIFIC CRITERIA FOR THE PARTICULAR PRIZE OR AWARD TO BE SELECTED. IN THE CASE OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS, THE RECIPIENT IS OFTEN REQUIRED TO UTILIZE THE FUNDS IN FURTHERANCE OF THEIR EDUCATION AND RESEARCH AT CMU. GRANTS ARE ALSO MADE IN THE CONTEXT OF ACADEMIC OR RESEARCH PROGRAMS AND RECIPIENTS SPEND THEIR GRANT FUNDS UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE PROGRAM FOR THE USE OF THE FUNDS. SPONSORED PROJECT FUNDS ARE PASSED THROUGH TO SUB-GRANTEE ORGANIZATIONS BY CARNEGIE MELLON WHEN SUCH SUB-GRANTEE ARRANGEMENTS ARE APPROVED BY THE PRIMARY GRANT SPONSOR. THESE FUNDS ARE MONITORED BY THE OFFICE OF SPONSORED PROJECTS AND SPONSORED PROJECTS ACCOUNTING.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: The College awards scholarships using established policies on the basis of both need and scholarship merit. Awards to students with need are based on the students' financial information contained in the financial aid profile filed with the college scholarship services and the free application for financial aid filed with the federal processor. All aid is objectively determined and awarded on an equal basis to recipients with similar attributes.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: The College awards scholarships using established policies on the basis of both need and scholarship merit. Awards to students with need are based on the students' financial information contained in the financial aid profile filed with the college scholarship services and the free application for financial aid filed with the federal processor. All aid is objectively determined and awarded on an equal basis to recipients with similar attributes.

THE TECHNOLOGY BUSINESS PLAN AND ENTREPRENUERIAL CHALLENGE AWARD CHECKS ARE WRITTEN BY THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO (UNM) TO THE COMPETITION WINNERS, USING DONATIONS DEPOSITED IN AN ACCOUNT AT UNM FOR THE ANDERSON FOUNDATION. THE WASHINGTON CAMPUS SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO SUBMITTED APPLICATIONS ALONG WITH THEIR TUITION RECEIPT. ALL OTHER AWARDS ARE MADE BY A SELECTION COMMITTEE TO STUDENTS BASED UPON THE APPLICATION PROCESS.

An institutional agreement is signed between McMaster and the grantee stating that the grantee institution is responsible for following the policies, procedures and regulations of the granting agency. At a minimum, an annual statement of expenditures is provided to McMaster and is reviewed for ineligible/non-compliance issues. McMaster can require an audit at any time, if necessary.

procedure for monitoring use of grants to organizations in the united states The university actively monitors all federally sponsored research grants through both its Office of Sponsored Programs (OSP) and its research accounting office. OSP is responsible for monitoring pre-award activities and certain post-award activities, such as human subject participation guidelines, animal research guidelines and export restrictions, among others. The research accounting office monitors all post-award financial activity, including allowability of costs and preparation and submission of federal agency reports on grants. procedure for monitoring use of grants to individuals in the united states The university requires all students seeking need-based financial aid and scholarships to complete a financial aid application and the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) form. The university's financial aid staff are trained in the requirements of awarding Title IV funds to students and are required to adhere to these requirements. The university also undergoes an independent A-133 audit to ensure compliance with these requirements.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: MIT PROVIDES SEVERAL TYPES OF GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS AND ORGANIZATIONS. FOR PRIZES AND AWARDS, THE INDIVIDUAL OR ORGANIZATION MUST HAVE MET THE SPECIFIC CRITERIA TO BE SELECTED FOR THE PRIZE OR AWARD. IN THE CASE OF FELLOWSHIPS AND SCHOLARSHIPS, THE INDIVIDUAL IS REQUIRED TO UTILIZE THE FUNDS IN FURTHERANCE OF THEIR EDUCATION AT MIT. MIT MAKES GRANTS TO SEVERAL LOCAL CHAPTERS OF NATIONAL FRATERNITIES, SORORITIES AND INDEPENDENT LIVING GROUPS. THESE ORGANIZATIONS ARE COMPRISED OF MIT STUDENTS, AND HOUSE THESE STUDENTS. GRANTS ARE MADE TO SUPPORT THE OPERATIONAL COSTS OF THE EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES OF THE HOUSES (SO THAT THE HOUSES STAY CONSISTENT WITH MIT'S MISSION). IN ORDER FOR AN ORGANIZATION TO RECEIVE AN INDEPENDENT RESIDENCE DEVELOPMENT FUND (IRDF) GRANT, THEY MUST GO THROUGH A RIGOROUS APPLICATION PROCESS. MIT GENERALLY DOES NOT MAKE DISBURSEMENTS TO INDIVIDUALS OR ORGANIZATIONS FOR CHARITABLE PURPOSES, EXCEPT THROUGH THE MIT COMMUNITY SERVICE FUND. THIS FUND'S RESOURCES COME PRIMARILY FROM CONTRIBUTIONS FROM MEMBERS OF THE MIT COMMUNITY. MIT DISBURSES THESE FUNDS FOR CHARITABLE PURPOSES INCLUDING SMALL GRANTS, INSUBSTANTIAL IN THE AGGREGATE, TO LOCALLY BASED CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS FOR THE PURPOSE OF FOSTERING BETTER COMMUNITY RELATIONS. PROCEDURES OF THE INSTITUTE WITH RESPECT TO ADMISSIONS, SCHOLARSHIPS, FELLOWSHIPS, AND STUDENT LOANS ARE PUBLICIZED IN THE INSTITUTE BULLETIN WHICH CONSTITUTES ITS CATALOGUE. GRANTS ARE MADE IN THE CONTEXT OF ACADEMIC OR RESEARCH PROGRAMS: RECIPIENTS SPEND THEIR GRANT FUNDS UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE PROGRAM AND ARE ACCOUNTABLE THROUGH THE PROGRAM FOR THE USE OF THE FUNDS.

UNIVERSITY OF PIKEVILLE MONITORS THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS BY ENTERING EACH STUDENT AND THEIR INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIP ON THE UNIVERSITY'S ACCOUNTING SOFTWARE, DATATEL. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GRANTED BASED ON CRITERIA SET FORTH BY THE UNIVERSITY ADMINISTRATION AND FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 ScholaRships are awarded by Allen University to students based on their academic achievement, specific talents and participation in intercollegiate athletics with awards based on their performance levels. Students are also awarded need-based scholarships and grants based on their need as established by completing the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) and, if applicable, by specific criteria and guidelines for other federal and state programs.
THE COLLEGE MONITORS ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE AWARDS BY ASSESSING STUDENT RECORDS, FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE. SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE REVIEWS APPLICATIONS FOR AWARDS.

SEVERAL PROCEDURES AND REPORTS ARE USED ANNUALLY TO MONITOR FINANCIAL AID INCLUDING. THE UNIVERSITY HAS IN PLACE INTERNAL CONTROLS TO ENSURE AMOUNTS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO CONTINUE TO MEET AND MAINTAIN ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS. THESE INTERNAL CONTROLS ARE ADMINISTERED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE, INDEPENDENT AUDITORS COMPLETE THE A-133 AUDIT RELATING TO FEDERAL STUDENT AID, THE FISAP REPORT FOR THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION, COMMON DATA SET (CDS) WHICH IS A SET OF STANDARDS AND DEFINITIONS AMONG THE HIGHER EDUCATION COMMUNITY & PUBLISHERS AS REPRESENTED BY THE COLLEGE BOARD, PETERSON'S, US NEWS & WORLD REPORT & THE WINTERGREEN ORCHARD HOUSE.

THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE IS CHARGED WITH DETERMINING ELIGIBILITY, ALLOCATIONS OF GRANT FUNDS, AND MONITORING OF STUDENT ACCOUNTS. FINANCIAL NEED IS DETERMINED AFTER AN ANALYSIS OF THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) IS COMPLETED. THE COLLEGE ALSO OFFERS ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS, WITHOUT REGARD TO NEED, TO ENTERING NEW AND TRANSFER STUDENTS WITH OUTSTANDING ACADEMIC RECORDS. ALL FINANCIAL AID IS CHARGED DIRECTLY AGAINST THE STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: STUDENTS ARE AWARDED SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON AN EVALUATION OF NEED AND ELIGIBILITY FOR SPECIFIC AWARDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH ANY DONOR STIPULATIONS. THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MAKING SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS AND FOR MONITORING ONGOING ELIGIBILITY (E.G. MAINTENANCE OF SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS.)

Grants and assistance in furtherance of the institution's exempt programs are made in accordance with procedures or are subject to conditions established by the institution's governing board designed to ensure that individuals receiving grants are adequately investigated to ensure that they are qualifying recipients. Students receiving scholarships and grants are judged worthy by the institution's assessment on the basis of academic achievement, financial need, and other similar standards.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2:
ExplntnTxt: CAMPBELL UNIVERSITY PARTICIPATES IN BOTH FEDERAL AND STATE GRANT PROGRAMS. ALL GRANT PROGRAMS INCLUDE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS, REPORTING REQUIREMENTS AND FUND MANAGEMENT REGULATIONS AND GUIDELINES. STUDENTS ARE AWARDED ACCORDING TO EACH PROGRAM'S GUIDELINES ONCE ELIGIBILITY HAS BEEN DETERMINED FOR THAT FUND. ELIGIBILITY IS REVIEWED BEFORE TRANSMITTAL/DISBURSEMENT TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. EACH FEDERAL AND STATE PROGRAM HAS PREDETERMINED REPORTING GUIDELINES AND STANDARDS. THE FUNDS ARE RECONCILED AND FUND BUDGETS ARE REVIEWED MONTHLY.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS: SCHOLARSHIPS AND PRIZES ARE AWARDED BASED ON NEED AND MONITORED ANNUALLY BASED ON STUDENTS' ACADEMIC PROFILES AND GUIDELINES AS PROVIDED TO STUDENTS. THESE GUIDELINES ARE ALSO AVAILABLE TO STUDENTS ON THE SKIDMORE COLLEGE WEBSITE.

THE PROCESS FOR MONITORING THE USE OF TUITION DISCOUNT OR GRANTS/SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS AT MARS HILL COLLEGE INCLUDES THE USE OF A MATRIX THAT LIMITS AND DETERMINES THE AMOUNT OF ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIP AWARDED WITH A MAXIMUM OF $7000. THE DEAN OF ADMISSIONS AND FINANCIAL AID AND THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID MEET MONTHLY TO REVIEW THE CURRENT AMOUNT OF TUITION DISCOUNT OR GRANTS/SCHOLARSHIPS BEING AWARDED TO ENSURE THAT THE COLLEGE STAYS WITHIN BUDGET. TUITION DISCOUNT, GRANT AND SCHOLARSHIP REPORTS ARE SUBMITTED TO THE PRESIDENT ON A REGULAR BASIS. THE BUDGET FOR THESE GRANTS IS APPROVED BY THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES ON AN ANNUAL BASIS. THE DEAN OF ADMISSIONS AND FINANCIAL AID AND THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID MONITOR ALL TUITION DISCOUNT FINANCIAL AID AWARDS PRIOR TO THE AWARD LETTER BEING MAILED. ATHLETIC GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY COACHES AND THE ATHLETIC DIRECTOR WITH STRICT GUIDELINES ESTABLISHED BY NCAA. THE ATHLETIC DIRECTOR REPORTS REGULARLY TO THE PRESIDENT OF THE COLLEGE THE AMOUNT OF TUITION DISCOUNT ATHLETIC GRANTS AWARDED BY EACH TEAM PER YEAR.

INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE IS AWARDED BASED ON BOTH A FINANCIAL NEED AND MERIT BASIS. FINANCIAL NEED IS DETERMINED BY THE SUBMISSION OF THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID AND SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS AND THE USE OF THE FEDERAL METHODOLOGY NEED ANALYSIS FORMULA AND THE INSTITUTIONAL METHODOLOGY NEED ANALYSIS FORMULA. MERIT AID IS AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO MEET CERTAIN ACADEMIC CRITERIA WHO MAY OR MAY NOT ALSO HAVE FINANCIAL NEED FOR ASSISTANCE. CAMPUS BASED FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FROM FEDERAL AND STATE SOURCES IS AWARDED BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS AS STIPULATED BY FEDERAL OR STATE GUIDELINES. FINANCIAL NEED IS DETERMINED BY THE SUBMISSION OF THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID AND SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS AND THE USE OF THE FEDERAL METHODOLOGY NEED ANALYSIS FORMULA.

STUDENTS MUST MEET THE REQUIREMENTS SPECIFIED IN THE SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAM IN ORDER TO RECEIVE THE SCHOLARSHIP. THE REQUIREMENTS INCLUDE CRITERIA, SUCH AS FINANCIAL NEED, OBTAINING/MAINTAINING THE REQUIRED GRADE POINT AVERAGE, STUDYING IN A CERTAIN ACADEMIC DISCIPLINE, ETC. IF THE SCHOLARSHIP IS AN ONGOING ONE, THE STUDENT MUST CONTINUE TO MEET THE SCHOLARSHIP REQUIREMENTS IN ORDER TO BE AWARDED A SCHOLARSHIP IN SUBSEQUENT YEARS. FINANCIAL NEED, GRADE POINT AVERAGES AND OTHER SCHOLARSHIP CRITERIA ARE MONITORED TO DETERMINE WHETHER THE STUDENT MEETS THE CRITERIA. THERE ARE A LIMITED NUMBER OF GRADUATE ASSISTANTSHIPS THAT ARE AWARDED TO INDIVIDUALS PURSUING A MASTERS DEGREE AT ITHACA COLLEGE. LIKE SCHOLARSHIPS, THE STUDENT MUST MEET THE APPLICABLE REQUIREMENTS IN ORDER TO BE AWARDED A GRADUATE ASSISTANTSHIP, SUCH AS OBTAINING/MAINTAINING THE REQUIRED GRADE POINT AVERAGE, STUDYING IN A CERTAIN ACADEMIC DISCIPLINE, ETC.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN U.S.: GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE AWARDED TO INDIVIDUALS IN THE U.S. REPRESENT STUDENT FINANCIAL AID. STUDENT FINANCIAL AID AWARDS ARE DETERMINED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S ASSESSMENT OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS. STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES CONTINUOUSLY MONITORS STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE AWARDS. STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES IS RESPONSIBLE FOR REGULATORY COMPLIANCE. STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES ENSURES EQUITY BY APPLYING ALL NEED ANALYSIS FORMULAS CONSISTENTLY ACROSS THE INSTITUTION'S POPULATION OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID APPLICANTS AND PROVIDES SERVICES THAT DO NOT DISCRIMINATE ON THE BASIS OF RACE, GENDER ETHNICITY, SEXUAL ORIENTATION, RELIGION, DISABILITY, AGE, OR ECONOMIC STATUS. THE UNIVERSITY RECEIVES VARIOUS FORMS OF FINANCIAL AID FROM THE GOVERNMENT TO SUPPORT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PROVIDED TO THE STUDENTS. THE TYPES OF GOVERNMENT ASSISTANCE THE UNIVERSITY RECEIVES INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: FEDERAL PELL GRANT FEDERAL SUPPLEMENTAL EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITY GRANT (SEOG) FEDERAL ACADEMIC COMPETITIVENESS GRANT (ACG) FEDERAL NATIONAL SMART GRANTS (NSMART) FEDERAL DIRECT LOAN PROGRAM FEDERAL WORK STUDY PROGRAM NYS DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION THE UNIVERSITY RECEIVES GOVERNMENT FUNDING TO SUPPORT ITS ORGANIZED RESEARCH PROGRAMS. THESE GOVERNMENTAL GRANTS HELP TO FURTHER THE UNIVERSITY'S MISSION BY SUPPORTING ORGANIZED RESEARCH EFFORTS IN THE AREAS OF EDUCATION, TRAINING, AND PUBLIC SERVICES. THE PUBLIC AGENCIES THAT SUPPORT THE UNIVERSITY'S RESEARCH ACTIVITIES ARE: NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF HOUSING & URBAN PROTECTION UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE THE NATIONAL ENDOWMENT FOR THE ARTS THE NATIONAL ENDOWMENT FOR THE HUMANITIES

THE COLLEGE FIRST INSPECTS CHARGES TO ENSURE THAT THEY ARE APPROPRIATE AND ALLOWABLE. THIS INCLUDES CHECKING CLERICAL ACCURACY, REVIEWING BALANCES, AND CHECKING COMPLIANCE WTIH APPLICABLE AGENCY AND FEDERAL GUIDELINES. THE COLLEGE ALSO MAKES SURE THAT THE EXPENSE FALLS WITHIN THE REQUIRED CATEGORY AND BUDGETARY AMOUNT. THIS INCLUDES REVIEWING EXPENSE CATEGORIES, REBUDGETING OR TRANSFERRING EXPENSES AS NEEDED, AND DETERMINING IF THE AWARD WILL BE UNDERSPENT AT THE END OF THE BUDGET OR GRANT PERIOD.

Every student who receives financial aid from the University must complete an annual Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) form and make satisfactory academic progress in order to retain their aid. Reviews are also conducted on each student to ensure that their grades, academic standing, and major continue to qualify them for the financial aid. These review processes are conducted annually at the end of the University's spring term, prior to the renewal of financial aid packages for the students.

PART II - THE OFFICE OF THE CHIEF OPERATING OFFICER MONITORS ALL FUNDS ALLOCATED TO EXTERNAL ORGANIZATIONS. PART III- THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES ASSISTANCE IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS THAT ARE ALL APPLIED TO STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS RECEIVABLE BALANCES AT THE BURSAR'S OFFICE.

LAGRANGE COLLEGE AWARDS BOTH MERIT-BASED (NON-NEED-BASED) AND NEED-BASED AID TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS. MERIT-BASED AID IS AWARDED BASED ON CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE, LEADERSHIP, AND TALENT. NEED-BASED AID IS AWARDED BASED ON DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED AS DETERMINED BY FAMILY INCOME AND ASSET INFORMATION REPORTED ON THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA). CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY IS DETERMINED ANNUALLY BY A REVIEW 0F A STUDENT'S COMPLIANCE WITH SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS STANDARDS, GRADE POINT AVERAGE FOR THE CONTINUATION OF MERITBASED AID, AND SUBMISSION OF A RENEWAL FAFSA IN AWARDING 0F NEED-BASED AID. THERE WERE 810 STUDENTS AWARDED INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS IN 2014-2015.

GRANTS CONSIST OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE REVIEWS SCHOLARSHIP CRITERIA AND ELIGIBILITY EACH SEMESTER FOR EVERY STUDENT. WITHDRAWALS FROM CLASSES REQUIRE THE STUDENT TO HAVE A FORM SIGNED BY THE ACADEMIC OFFICE, THE BUSINESS OFFICE, AND THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. THE AMOUNT OF SCHOLARSHIPS GRANTED IS PRO-RATED BASED ON FEDERAL REGULATIONS.
