The College follows federal, state, donor, and institutional guidelines for determining eligibility for scholarships, prizes, and other grants and awards. The College maintains records showing the selection criteria, recipient eligibility, how funds may be used, and any related party. Before paying grants to other entities, the College obtains documentation showing the recipient is eligible to receive deductible charitable contributions. Grants awarded by the Office of Financial Aid are credited directly to student accounts. Other grants are monitored various ways, including reimbursing actual substantiated expenses, requiring written reports, and/or visiting sites of activities funded by the College grants.
ALL GRANTS ARE INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID AND APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT BY THE UNIVERSITY.

The primary responsibility for financing a university education rests with the student. Financial aid from the University and other sources is viewed only as supplementary to the efforts of the student and the student's family. Students requesting financial aid are expected to contribute toward their educational expenses through summer or university employment and/or loans in any reasonable combination. Financial aid is an important factor for many students, and 100 percent of Manchester University students receive some combination of grants, scholarships, loans, and work. Student Financial Services will determine a student's eligibility for financial aid by using the results of the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA); the estimated family contribution (EFC) and review of edit (c-codes), as well as the student's academic records and funds available. Manchester University utilizes an awarding matrix based on a combination of academic and financial need criteria referenced above. Student Financial Services administers financial aid from federal, state, and institutional resources utilizing the federal guidelines established by the U.S. Department of Education. The following steps must be taken by a student to receive a financial aid package from Manchester University: 1. Apply for admission and be admitted to Manchester University. Eligibility for academic scholarships from the University is determined through the admission process. 2. Submit a FAFSA. Eligibility for federal, state and institutional need based grants and loans is determined through this process. The student must designate the results be sent to Manchester University, and Indiana students must have a receipt date between Jan.1 and March 10 to be considered for state grant eligibility. 3. Submit any additional documentation requested by Student Financial Services. Enrollment Requirements. Students receiving financial aid must maintain full-time enrollment, (a minimum of 12 semester hours) in each of the fall and spring semesters. There are circumstances in which part-time students demonstrating need may be awarded financial aid depending on the guidelines and availability of federal, state and institutional funding. Part-time students must enroll in a minimum of six hours to maintain eligibility for institutional funds and loans. Degree Requirements. Students must be working toward their first baccalaureate degree to be eligible for federal, state or institutional grants and scholarships. Students who have completed a baccalaureate degree are eligible for loans only.

SCHOLARSHIPS & GRANTS ARE PROVIDED BASED THE COLLEGE'S ASSESSMENT OF THE RECIPIENTS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER STANDARDS ESTABLISHED BY THE COLLEGE. APPLICATIONS ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT.

THE INSTITUTE'S OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID MONITORS ALL RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS TO DETERMINE BOTH INITIAL AND CONTINUING ELIGIBILITY BASED ON THE CRITERIA FOR EACH TYPE OF AWARD, WHICH MAY INCLUDE ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE, FINANCIAL NEED, CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY DONORS OF ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS, ETC.

Moravian College follows state and federal regulation in administering scholarship and grants as well as institutional policy when administering college funds. Moravian follows federal methodology to determine financial need for awarding federal funds and institutional methodology in awarding need-based institutional funds. All students applying for financial aid follow an annual application process completing the free application for federal student aid (FAFSA) and an institutional application. Files are reviewed for conflicting information and to complete required verification of application data. Moravian credits all financial aid awards directly to students' receivable account offsetting charges for tuition and fees. Changes in student enrollment status are reviewed to ensure that students remain eligible for financial aid and awards are adjusted as necessary. Any refunds from student accounts are done in compliance with state and federal regulations.

The College follows federal, state, and institutional policies and regulations to monitor grants and funds: (1) the student applies for the grant; (2) grants are awarded from the various funding sources depending on need and/or academic standing; (3) the students eligibility is verified through federal, state, and institutional requirements, matriculation, registration, attendance, and academic progress; (4) grants and awards are processed onto the student's account; (5) where loans are involved, the College follows up with the regulatory requirements after graduation. The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) is an integral part of this process.

The College's Financial Aid Office is responsible for establishing and maintaining effective internal control over compliance with the requirements of laws, regulations, contracts, and grants applicable to federal programs. Monitoring of federal and foundation grants supporting College operating activities is coordinated between the Financial Aid Office, the Chancellor's office, the Controller's office and the VP of Institutional Advancement. These offices and individuals ensure that appropriate controls are established and that grant requirements for documentation, tracking, expenditure of funds and reporting are met. PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S.: MARIAN UNIVERSITY IS SUBJECT TO THE COMPLIANCE AND INTERNAL CONTROL REQUIRYMENTS OF OMB-A133 AND FOLLOWS ALL APPLICABLE GUIDELINES. INSTITUTIONAL AND PRIVATELY FUNDED FINANCIAL AID IS DETERMINED ON A CASE-BY-CASE BASIS BASED ON MERIT, NEED, AND EXTRACURRICULAR ACTIVITIES.

SCHOLARSHIPS/GRANTS ARE PROVIDED TO STUDENTS THROUGH FINANCIAL AID, BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED AND FEDERAL OR STATE MANDATED REGULATIONS. DONOR RESTRICTED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE ALSO MONITORED AND DISTRIBUTED THROUGH FINANCIAL AID PROCESSES TO COVER EDUCATIONAL EXPENSES ESTIMATED OR CHARGED BY THE UNIVERSITY.

A student's eligibility for need-based financial aid is determined on the basis of their annual cost of attendance, which is calculated in accordance with Federal regulations, minus Expected Family Contribution, which is determined in accordance with Federal regulations and University standards. In the event that total aid awarded exceeds direct costs (i.e., costs that are billed by the University), the excess funds are provided to the student and are applicable to educationally-related expenses. The University does not require the student to provide proof (e.g., receipts, cancelled checks, etc.) as to how the funds were used.

PIT STAFF (BUSINESS OFFICE, GRANT ADMINISTRATOR, PRESIDENT AND ACADEMIC DEAN) HAVE MONTHLY MEETINGS TO REVIEW GRANT DISBURSEMENTS. THE GRANT ADMINISTRATOR GOES TO CONFERENCES AS SCHEDULED. WHEN THE GRANT IS AWARDED TO STUDENTS, THEN FINANCIAL AID AND STUDENT SERVICES VERIFY STUDENT ELIGIBILITY. THE BUSINESS OFFICE KEEPS COPIES OF ALL DISBURSEMENTS AND PROVIDES COPIES TO GRANT ADMINISTRATORS. BUSINESS OFFICE STAFF TRACK ALL SALARIES COVERED BY GRANTS.

FUNDS ARE DISTRIBUTED TO STUDENTS BASED ON NEED AND MERIT. STUDENT AID IS HANDLED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT AND CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNT. EACH STUDENT APPLIES FOR FINANCIAL AID BY FILLING OUT A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA). THE AWARD IS BASED ON THE INFORMATION IN THIS APPLICATION. STUDENTS CAN ALSO APPLY FOR GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON ELIGIBILITY. THERE IS AN AWARD ELIGIBILITY CALCULATOR ON THE HEIDELBERG WEBSITE TO SEE IF YOU QUALIFY.

ExplntnTxt: Awards to undergraduates are based primarily on financial need determined by documented financial aid eligibility. Loans are awarded to eligible students based on need. Over $19 million was paid directly to students (Form 990, Part III, line 4a) with the remainder applied internally to tuition, fees, and room and board.

Students' eligibility to receive financial assistance from Concordia University Chicago is determined by policy approved by the Board of Regents. On a basis of careful analysis of the financial statements, the Director of Financial Aid determines the amount of aid available from various sources. Next, the amount that the student and his or her family can reasonably be expected to provide is calculated. The difference is called "demonstrated need." Financial assistance is awarded based on the student's demonstrated need for that year. Concordia-Chicago provides scholarships. All recipients are unrelated expect for tuition benefits provided under Concordia-Chicago's tuition grant program to eligible employees, their spouses, and dependents. This tuition grant program is in accordance with IRC section 117(d). Concordia University Chicago also provides student assistance through work-study.

THE COLLEGE SUPPORTS A NEED BASED FINANCIAL AID POLICY THAT IS REPRESENTATIVE OF ITS ACADEMIC AND SPIRITUAL GOALS AS AN UNDERGRADUATE, JESUIT LIBERAL ARTS COLLEGE. THE COLLEGE ACCEPTS STUDENTS REGARDLESS OF THEIR ABILITY TO PAY NEED-BLIND ADMISSIONS AND THEN MEETS 100 OF THEIR NEED, AS CALCULATED ACCORDING TO NATIONALLY RECOGNIZED FINANCIAL AID CRITERIA.

THE COLLEGE USES A CONSERVATIVE NEEDS ANALYSIS, INSTITUTIONAL METHODOLOGY WHICH IS AGREED UPON BY MORE THAN 2,000 MEMBERS OF THE COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIP SERVICE ASSEMBLY. ALL STUDENTS ARE ENCOURAGED TO APPLY REGARDLESS OF THEIR SOCIO-ECONOMIC BACKGROUND. APPROXIMATELY SIXTY-ONE PERCENT OF ALL STUDENTS RECEIVE SOME FORM OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE.

A LIST OF RECIPIENTS WHO RECEIVE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE IS MAINTAINED BY THE COLLEGE. THERE MAY BE SOME RECIPIENTS WHO ARE RELATED TO OFFICERS, TRUSTEES, OR OTHER DISQUALIFIED PERSONS SUCH RECIPIENTS ARE SELECTED ON AN EQUAL OBJECTIVELY DETERMINED BASIS WITH OTHERS.

THE COLLEGE PROVIDES GRANTS TO CERTAIN CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS WITHIN THE WORCESTER, MA AREA. THESE GRANTS ARE CLOSELY TIED TO PROMOTING THE COLLEGES CHARITABLE AND EDUCATIONAL MISSION AND CONTRIBUTE TO THE ENRICHMENT OF THE GREATER WORCESTER AREA. SINCE THESE GRANTS ARE MADE TO CHARITIES, THE COLLEGE DOES NOT MONITOR THE USE OF THE GRANT FUNDS.

The college's Office of Financial aid is responsible for awarding and monitoring all college, federal and state grant assistance. More than 60% of Wheaton students receive some form of financial aid and most students who demonstrate need receive aid. Financial assistance at Wheaton is awarded on the basis of demonstrated need and academic performance. "Need" is determined by the financial information that a student and his/her family provides on the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) and PROFILE forms which capture the data required to determine eligibility based on federal and/or state regulations. A need-based package may include a merit scholarship, grants, loans or work award. When funds are awarded, student eligibility is monitored through the college's operational system financial aid module to ensure there are no changes in status that might affect their ongoing eligibility. Total grant funds awarded are tracked to ensure compliance with budgeted amounts.

STUDENTS AWARDED WITH AN HONOR SCHOLARSHIP MUST BE PART OF THE UNIVERSITY'S HONOR PROGRAM AND THIS PROGRAM HAS SPECIFIC REQUIREMENTS THAT THE STUDENTS MUST MEET EVERY TRIMESTER IN ORDER TO RECEIVE THE SCHOLARSHIP. STUDENTS AWARDED WITH AN ATHLETIC SCHOLARSHIP MUST MEET CERTAIN REQUIREMENTS ESTABLISHED BY THE ATHLETIC DEPARTMENT. STUDENTS ARE SELECTED BY A COMMITTEE PART OF THE VICE PRESIDENCY OF STUDENTS AFFAIRS.

The University assigns responsibility for monitoring the use of grant funds within the United States to the Office Of Post Award Financial Operations. This office monitors all grant making activity, including COMPLIANCE WITH all applicablE regulations. Expenses are accounted for on an accrual basis. Schedule I, Part III Boston University makes every effort to assist students with calculated financial eligibility and high academic achievement, measured against the credentials of other accepted students. A student's academic record is an important factor in determining eligibility for Boston University scholarships and need-based grants. Key indicators such as high school grade point average (GPA), rank in class, and standardized test scores are considered, as well as the strength of the student's academic program and extracurricular activities.

MONITOR THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN U.S. ALL GRANT FUNDS ARE MONITORED WITH AT LEAST TWO DIFFERENT DEPARTMENTS WHICH CREATES CHECKS AND BALANCES TO ENSURE THAT THE FUNDS ARE TRACKED, REPORTED AND USED AS REQUIRED IN THE GRANT LANGUAGE. TITLE IV GRANT FUNDS ARE AWARDED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND APPLIED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT VIA FINANCIAL AID TRANSMITTAL. AS STUDENTS COMPLETE THEIR REQUIREMENTS FOR RECEIVING AID, WEEKLY TRANSMITTALS ARE RUN AND STUDENTS, WITH THE PROPER CODING ARE SELECTED TO RECEIVE AID. THE TRANSMITTAL GENERATES A LISTING OF EACH AWARD, BY TYPE WITH TOTALS, AND IS USED TO RECORD THE GRANT EXPENSE TO THE GENERAL LEDGER. FEDERAL AWARDS AND GRANTS ARE VERIFIED TO A RECEIVABLE IN THE GENERAL LEDGER THAT IS RECORDED FROM AN AUTHORIZATION LETTER AND TO THE AVAILABLE BALANCE IN THE G5 PAYMENT MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. IF THE AVAILABLE BALANCE IS SUFFICIENT, THE FUNDS ARE DRAWN DOWN THROUGH THE G5 PAYMENT MANAGEMENT SYSTEM INTO THE FEDERAL FUNDS CHECKING ACCOUNT. A BANK ACH REPORT IS GENERATED TO VERIFY THAT THE FUNDS ARE RECEIVED. THE GENERAL LEDGER ACCOUNTS ARE VERIFIED TO GRANTS BY TYPE ON THE FINANCIAL AID SYSTEM AND BILLING TRANSACTIONS ON THE BILLING FILE. THESE SYSTEMS ARE RECONCILED TO EACH DRAW DOWN.

THE OFFICES OF ENROLLMENT MANAGEMENT AND FINANCIAL AID OVERSEE THE AWARDING OF BOTH NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID AND MERIT-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS. ONCE A STUDENT HAS COMPLETED THE FINANCIAL AID APPLICATION PROCESS AND IS FOUND ELIGIBLE FOR NEED-BASED AND/OR MERIT BASED AID, THE STUDENT WILL RECEIVE A FINANCIAL AID PACKAGE DETAILING THE COMBINATION OF SOURCES USED TO PROVIDE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. GRANT FUNDS AWARDED TO STUDENTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNTS. USAGE IS MONITORED BY VIRTUE OF DIRECT ACCOUNT POSTING.
NICHOLS COLLEGE PARTICIPATES IN TITLE IV FUNDING. STUDENTS MUST COMPLETE THE FAFSA FORM TO APPLY FOR AID.
All assistance is in the form of grants and scholarships. These funds are applied directly to the student's account.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: Grants and Other Assistance to Individuals in the United States: Scholarships and fellowships that are awarded to students are paid through the students' accounts and/or a payment through the Payroll Office and are administered based upon merit and/or need. Baylor's Financial Aid Office reviews the students' cumulative grade point averages every year and awards/reviews academic scholarships and fellowships if the required grade point average level is satisfied. Scholarships for financial need are awarded annually based upon whether the need criterion/level is established or maintained per the completed Application for Federal Student Aid. The scholarship awards cannot exceed the cost of a student to attend the University. Travel Grants - Travel grants are awarded to students to offset travel expenses used for educational purposes such as attending a conference, presenting a paper, etc. The awarding of travel grants is based upon an application process and meeting a set of criteria that establish the benefits to the students' educational endeavors. Research Grants - The Office of the Vice Provost for Research (OVPR) publishes guidelines for each of the internal grant programs that provide the general conditions of the award, as well as guidance on the expenses that may be charged to the award. Each grant is set up as a separate project in the University's financial system based on the award amount and budget categories approved by the OVPR and administered through the Office of Sponsored Programs. The financial system provides real time access to a Budget Summary Report for the project that provides a comparison of budgeted expenditures to cumulative actual expenditures by expenditure category. This report can be accessed by the Project Manager and others with administrative and financial oversight responsibilities. Expenditure transactions under internal grant programs are subject to internal controls for approval and processing similar to other University expenditure transactions. The system does not allow expenditures to be processed in excess of or outside of the approved budget categories. Student Awards - These awards are provided to students for winning educational competitions. The purpose of the competitions is to further the education of students. Grants and Other Assistance to Governments and Organizations in the United States: The University enters into a contract with the grant recipient that describes the recipient's responsibilities for the use of the grant funds. Under the terms of the contract, recipients are required to submit quarterly and final written progress reports to the principal investigator ("PI") or project director for the grant, and funds are paid to the recipient on a cost reimbursable basis. When the grant recipient submits an invoice for reimbursement, the PI reviews the invoice to ensure the expenditures are consistent with the established budget and with the work completed to date, prior to approving the amount for payment. Grant recipients subject to the U.S. Office of Management and Budget Circular A-133 Audits of States, Local Governments, and Non-Profit Organizations are also required to provide certification of their compliance with the financial audit requirements of those guidelines prior to receiving funds. Thereafter, the University requires an annual certification of continuing compliance and a copy of their most recent audit report. If any of the above processes indicate an area of concern, site visits may be conducted by the University to review the programmatic and/or financial records. Charitable organizations that receive contributions from the University are carefully selected and must be approved through the Vice President for Constituent Engagement & Chief of Staff. The contribution must support the University's interest and be consistent with the University's core values.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING THE USE OF GRANTS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 SU PROVIDED APPROXIMATELY $289 MILLION IN INSTITUTIONAL AID TO UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS IN THE FISCAL YEAR ENDED JUNE 30, 2015. THE AID PROVIDED CONSISTS OF A COMBINATION OF NEED-BASED AND MERIT-BASED GRANTS. STUDENTS MUST APPLY FOR THESE FINANCIAL AID AWARDS BY COMPLETING TWO FORMS THAT ESTABLISH ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED AID: THE COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIP SERVICE FINANCIAL AID PROFILE; AND THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID. THESE ARE STANDARD FORMS USED IN HIGHER EDUCATION FOR THIS PURPOSE. BOTH NEED-BASED AND MERIT-BASED AID PROVIDED TO STUDENTS IS APPLIED BY THE UNIVERSITY DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT TO ENSURE THAT THE GRANTS ARE USED FOR THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE. MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GENERALLY LIMITED TO THE AMOUNT OF TUITION. STUDENTS REACHING THE TUITION LIMIT ARE INELIGIBLE FOR ADDITIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS FROM THE UNIVERSITY. NEED-BASED AID CAN BE USED FOR ALL EDUCATIONAL RELATED EXPENSES IN ADDITION TO TUITION.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: GRANTS TO ORGANIZATIONS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: PART II THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO THE NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF BASKETBALL COACHES, AND RECEIVED ACKNOWLEDGMENT THAT MONIES REPRESENT CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS FOR THE ORGANIZATION'S EXEMPT PURPOSE. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO THE WESTCOTT COMMUNITY CENTER, AND RECEIVED ACKNOWLEDGMENT THAT MONIES REPRESENT CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS FOR THE ORGANIZATION'S EXEMPT PURPOSE.

PART III, COLUMN B THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS WHO RECEIVED SCHOLARSHIPS WAS DERIVED BY QUERYING THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENT DATABASE IN THE STUDENT RECEIVABLE SYSTEM FOR ACADEMIC TERMS WITHIN THE FISCAL YEAR ENDED JUNE 30, 2015. THE QUERY LOOKED FOR TUITION DISCOUNT (FINANCIAL AID) AND OTHER ASSISTANCE USING THE DEFINITION OF SUCH ITEMS AS REPORTED IN THE UNIVERSITY'S AUDITED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS. THIS PRODUCED A REPORT OF ALL STUDENTS WHO RECEIVED AID. RECOGNIZING THAT A STUDENT COULD BE RECEIVING AID IN MORE THAN ONE ACADEMIC TERM, THE INFORMATION WAS THEN SORTED BY INDIVIDUAL AND THE STUDENT WAS COUNTED ONLY ONCE PER FINANCIAL AID TYPE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: All grant expenditures are reviewed by the Grant Accountant for reasonableness, allowable expenditures, and compliance to the grant regulations and criteria. All scholarships and assistance are provided as a credit to the student's tuition account.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: All grant expenditures are reviewed by the Grant Accountant for reasonableness, allowable expenditures, and compliance to the grant regulations and criteria. All scholarships and assistance are provided as a credit to the student's tuition account.

Scholarships/grants to students are determined by the Student Financial Service office. Each student file is reviewed in accordance with the designated eligibility requirements of the scholarships or grants. Scholarships and grants are then monitored by disbursing funds from the SFS office into the respective student accounts.

Valparaiso University is committed to providing resources necessary to help students complete their education. In selecting the students to receive this assistance, the University places primary emphasis on the student's academic achievement and financial need. Awards are determined by the University Scholarship Committee. Upon enrollment verification, the awards are used to offset the cost of attendance.
NATIONAL UNIVERSITY IDENTIFIES ELIGIBLE GRANTEES RELATED TO EDUCATIONAL AND COMMUNITY PURPOSES. GRANTEES ARE MONITORED AS APPROPRIATE THROUGH PERIODIC REPORTS AND SITE INSPECTIONS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: FORM 990, SCH. I, PART II, LINE 1
ExplntnTxt: SAINT ANNE'S SHRINE THE CONTRIBUTION TO SAINT ANNE'S SHRINE WAS MADE TO PROVIDE SUPPORT OF THEIR MISSION TO SERVE AS A WELCOMING PLACE OF PEACE AND HOPE MINISTERING TO ALL GOD'S PEOPLE THROUGH PRAYER, DEVOTION, HOSPITALITY AND SPIRITUAL RENEWAL. THE SHRINE WAS DEVELOPED AND MAINTAINED FOR THE PAST 100 YEARS BY THE SOCIETY OF SAINT EDMUND, WHO IS ALSO THE FOUNDER OF SAINT MICHAEL'S COLLEGE. THE COLLEGE SHARES A SIMILAR MISSION TO CONTRIBUTE THROUGH HIGHER EDUCATION TO THE ENHANCEMENT OF THE HUMAN PERSON AND THE ADVANCEMENT OF HUMAN CULTURE IN THE LIGHT OF THE CATHOLIC FAITH. THE COLLEGE BENEFITS FROM USE OF THE FACILITIES AT THE SHRINE FOR CURRICULUM ENHANCEMENT, STUDENT AND STAFF RETREATS AND WORSHIP. WOMEN HELPING BATTERED WOMEN THE CONTRIBUTION TO WOMEN HELPING BATTERED WOMEN WAS MADE TO PROVIDE GENERAL SUPPORT TO THEIR BELIEF THAT ALL ADULTS AND CHILDREN HAVE THE RIGHT TO LIVE WITHOUT FEAR OF ABUSE - SEXUAL, PHYSICAL, EMOTIONAL OR FINANCIAL. THEY PROVIDE A 24-HOUR HOTLINE, SHELTER AND HOUSING SERVICES, A LEGAL PROGRAM, SUPPORT GROUPS, EDUCATION AND OUTREACH, CHILDREN'S SERVICES, ECONOMIC JUSTICE AND TRANSITIONAL HOUSING, AND A SAFE AT WORK NETWORK. THE COLLEGE HAS INCORPORATED THIS ORGANIZATION INTO ITS PROGRAMMING IN TWO WAYS IN THE PAST YEAR. THE FIRST IS THROUGH ITS CLOTHESLINE PROJECT-A PROJECT THAT AIMS TO BRING ATTENTION TO SEXUAL VIOLENCE. THE PROJECT PROVIDES A PUBLIC SPACE TO DISPLAY T-SHIRTS WITH MESSAGES OF SURVIVAL OF SEXUAL VIOLENCE, AS WELL AS MESSAGES OF SUPPORT FOR SURVIVORS. THE SECOND IS A CONSENT WORKSHOP ON CAMPUS LED BY AN EDUCATION ADVOCATE FROM WOMEN HELPING BATTERED WOMEN. DURING THE WORKSHOP, THE ADVOCATE DISCUSSED THE IMPORTANCE OF CONSENT, WHAT IT LOOKS LIKE, AND HOW TO NAVIGATE DISCUSSIONS ON CONSENT.

THE COLLEGE RECOGNIZES THE HIGH COST OF A PRIVATE EDUCATION AND ATTEMPTS TO ADDRESS AS MUCH AS WE PRACTICALLY CAN TO CLOSE THE GAP BETWEEN THE COST OF ATTENDANCE AND FAMILY RESOURCES USING A VARIETY OF SOURCES, INCLUDING FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL (COLLEGE) FUNDING. THE THREE TYPES OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE WE EMPLOY INCLUDE GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS, LOANS AND STUDENT EMPLOYMENT. IN 2014-2015, THE COLLEGE ADMINISTERED OVER $58 MILLION IN ASSISTANCE, OF WHICH APPROXIMATELY $39 MILLION WAS PRIMARILY COLLEGE FUNDED AID SCHOLARSHIPS OR GRANTS. THE FIVE YEAR AVERAGE (2010-2014) OF UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS RECEIVING COLLEGE FUNDED AID WAS 94.52%. THE COLLEGE PRACTICE hAS BEEN TO AWARD AID BASED ON MERIT AND/OR NEED TO ALL STUDENTS ACCEPTED FOR ADMISSION. THE AVERAGE NEED BASED SCHOLARSHIP OR GRANT FOR THE FALL 2014 INCOMING CLASS WAS APPROXIMATELY $23,995. THE AMOUNT OF AID A STUDENT RECEIVES UPON INITIAL ENROLLMENT GENERALLY IS AWARDED FOR EACH YEAR HE/SHE ATTENDS SAINT MICHAEL'S COLLEGE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PART I, LINE 2 - MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS:
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS FINANCIAL AID GRANTS ONLY TO ENROLLED STUDENTS. GRANTS ARE CREDITED TO THE RECIPIENTS' ACCOUNTS FOR TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD.
THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS RECORDS WITHIN ITS FINANCIAL AID SOFTWARE TO ACCOUNT FOR ALL GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO EACH STUDENT.

TO ENSURE OUR GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE USED FOR THE PROPER PURPOSES THE EDGEWOOD COLLEGE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE PERFORMS REGULAR MAINTENANCE AND RECONCILIATIONS WITH OUR BUSINESS OFFICE MONITORING THAT ALL FUNDS AWARDED TO A PARTICULAR STUDENT ARE BEING PROPERLY CREDITED TO THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNT. ANY CHANGES OR ADJUSTMENTS TO ORIGINAL AWARDS THAT AFFECT GRANT AND SCHOLARSHIP FUNDING ARE MADE WITHIN POWERFAIDS, THE FINANCIAL AID SOFTWARE PROGRAM. THESE CHANGES TO AWARDS ARE ELECTRONICALLY TRANSMITTED AT LEAST WEEKLY TO THE BUSINESS OFFICE. THE RESULTING CHANGES ARE THEN DISPLAYED ON THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNT. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE HAS THE ABILITY TO GENERATE REPORTS AS NEEDED FOR MONITORING AND RECONCILIATION PURPOSES. THESE REPORTS ARE COMPARED TO REPORTS GENERATED BY THE BUSINESS OFFICE TO ENSURE THAT ALL PROGRAM AMOUNTS ARE ACCURATELY REFLECTED. ADDITIONALLY, WE HAVE A YEARLY AUDIT PERFORMED BY AN OUTSIDE ACCOUNTING FIRM GUARANTEEING WE ARE STAYING IN COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL POLICIES AND PROCEDURES AS WELL AS ASSURING FUNDING IS BEING USED AS INTENDED.
The Business Office receives a copy of all grant contacts and reconciles project expenses monthly.
ALL GRANTS ARE GIVEN TO STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS, THEREFORE A DETAILED MONITORING PROCESS IS NOT NECESSARY FOR THE UNIVERSITY.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS TO ENROLLED STUDENTS. GRANTS ARE CREDITED TO THE RECIPIENTS' ACCOUNTS FOR TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS TO ENROLLED STUDENTS. GRANTS ARE CREDITED TO THE RECIPIENTS' ACCOUNTS FOR TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD.

THE UNIVERSITY OFFERS NEED-BASED AND MERIT-BASED AWARDS. THE NEED-BASED AWARDS ARE BASED ON THE FAFSA FORM THAT IS SUBMITTED BY UNIVERSITY STUDENTS AND AWARDED ACCORDING TO THEIR FINANCIAL NEED. MERIT-BASED AWARDS ARE BASED ON SAT, GPA, AND OTHER TEST SCORES. UNIVERSITY AWARDS ARE CREDITED TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS. THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS INSTITUTIONAL FUNDS TO STUDENTS ACCORDING TO UNIVERSITY POLICIES. FUNDS ARE MANAGED BY THE OFFICES OF STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND FINANCIAL AFFAIRS TO COMPLY WITH ALL APPLICABLE COMPLIANCE REGULATIONS.
CASH GRANTS ARE CREDITS TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

The University may make occasional grants to another exempt organization whose exempt purposes are consistent with those of the University. The recipient organization is not a related organization for 990 reporting purposes. Certain members of the Board of Directors and management of the University also serve on the Board of Directors and/or management of the recipient organization and, through their involvement, closely monitor the use of grant funds.

The University also provides scholarships to individuals to attend the University. Scholarship recipients are selected based on a written application which is reviewed by the Financial Aid Department and/or scholarship committee. Scholarships are awarded based on a combination of student financial need and merit and are applied directly to the student's account as a reduction in tuition and fees. The University monitors each recipient student to ensure that he/she remains an active, enrolled student and satisfies the academic and other criteria for maintaining the scholarship. If the student withdraws from the University or fails to meet the scholarship criteria, any remaining scholarship funds are returned to the funding program to be awarded to another student.

THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE HAS A SET OF CRITERIA BY WHICH COLLEGE AID IS AWARDED TO STUDENTS. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MAINTAINS RECORDS OF ALL STUDENT AID AWARDED AND SUBSTANTIATION FOR THE AWARDS.

THE COLLEGE REVIEWS ALL OF AMERICAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA'S EXPENDITURES FOR WHICH ITS GRANTS ARE INTENDED. ASSISTANCE FOR INDIVIDUAL STUDENTS IS PROVIDED THROUGH FEDERAL, STATE AND COLLEGE PROGRAMS AND EXTERNAL AGENCIES. THE COLLEGE ADMINISTERS THESE PROGRAMS. TYPICALLY, FINANCIAL AID FUNDS ADMINISTERED BY THE COLLEGE ARE AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF FINANCIAL NEED (AS DETERMINED BY THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT, DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION, STATE AGENCIES, THE COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIP SERVICES, AND BARD COLLEGE), ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, AND PROMISE. THE COLLEGE'S OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID IS RESPONSIBLE FOR AWARDING AND MONITORING FEDERAL AND STATE FINANCIAL AID DISTRIBUTIONS. STUDENTS APPLY FOR FINANCIAL AID BY COMPLETING A FAFSA FORM WHICH DETERMINES ELGIBILITY. STUDENT ELIGIBILITY IS PERIODICALLY MONITORED TO ENSURE THAT GRANT AWARDS ARE USED FOR THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE.

EACH TRANSACTION INVOLVING GRANTS, SCHOLARSHIPS, OR FINANCIAL AID IS MONITORED THROUGH THE STUDENT ACCOUNT. IN ADDITION, THE UNIVERSITY UNDERGOES ANNUAL AUDITS OF ITS FINANCIAL AID PROCESSES AND PROCEDURES. THE AUDITORS TEST THE UNIVERSITY'S COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE RULES AND REGULATIONS.

THE COLLEGE'S DEPARTMENT OF FINANCIAL AID REVIEWS AND APPROVES THE PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE FUNDS. THE CONTROLLER AND DIRECTOR OF STUDENT ACCOUNTS MONITOR THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS AND APPLY GENERAL ACCOUNTING PROCEDURES IN BOOKING THE FUNDS ON FINANCIAL RECORDS.
ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE MONITORED FOR APPROPRIATE USE BY MONITORING REGISTRATION AND SATISFACTORY COMPLETION OF COURSES AND PROGRAMS TOWARDS EDUCATIONAL REQUIREMENTS.
PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE US: GRANTS ARE MADE TO ACCREDITED SCHOOLS AND SEMINARIES. BOTH FINANCIAL AND NARRATIVE REPORTS OF GRANT ACTIVITIES ARE REQUIRED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: PIU EVALUATES ELIGIBILITY BY RECEIVING WRITTEN REPRESENTATIONS AND FROM REVIEW OF A STUDENTS FILE. ITEMS TO BE CHECKED INCLUDE PIUS APPLICATION, HIGH SCHOOL DIPLOMA, DROP/ADD FORMS, AND WITHDRAWAL FORMS. ONCE A STUDENT HAS COMPLETED THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) APPLICATION, PIU SUBMITS IT ELECTRONICALLY TO ED. ONCE IT IS PROCESSED THE STUDENT WILL RECEIVE A STUDENT AID REPORT AND THE SCHOOL WILL RECEIVE AN ISIR. THE ISIR IS KEPT IN THE STUDENTS FINANCIAL AID FILE. THE ISIR CONTAINS THE EFC AMOUNT, WHICH IS THE AMOUNT THE STUDENT IS EXPECTED TO PAY, THE COST OF ATTENDANCE IS FOUND ON WORKSHEETS GENERATED BY WEBER. THE EFC AND COA ARE BOTH USED TO CALCULATE FINANCIAL NEED. THE ISIR ALSO PROVIDES FINANCIAL AID HISTORY, MATCHES SOCIAL SECURITY DATA, SELECTIVE SERVICE DATA AND CHECKS CITIZENSHIP. FFEL- CHECKS FROM LOAN INSTITUTIONS ARE REQUESTED FROM STUDENTS THROUGH LOAN APPLICATIONS. LOAN APPLICATIONS ARE CERTIFIED BY PIU AND SENT BY STUDENT FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. MONEY IS DEPOSITED INTO A SEPARATE BANK ACCOUNT USING ACH/EFT SYSTEM. ONCE PIU RECEIVES THE DISBURSEMENT RECORD FROM THE LENDER, THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE BATCHES THE LOANS AND SENDS THEM TO THE BUSINESS OFFICE. THE BUSINESS OFFICE VERIFIES FUNDS AND THEN CREDITS THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT. SOMETIMES CHECKS ARE SENT IN THE STUDENTS AND PIUS NAME. THESE ARE DEPOSITED SEPARATELY INTO THE BANK ACCOUNT BY THE BUSINESS OFFICE. CHECKS ARE SIGNED BY THE STUDENT, AND PIU POSTS CHECKS TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. LOANS COME IN TWO DISBURSEMENTS - GENERALLY ONE FOR FIRST SEMESTER AND ONE FOR SECOND. THE WHOLE DISBURSEMENT IS APPLIED TO THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT. COST OF ATTENDANCE IS ALWAYS GREATER THAN LOAN PROCEEDS AND ALL OTHER FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. ANY EXCESS CAN BE WITHDRAWN BY THE STUDENT FOR LIVING EXPENSES. PELL, SEOG & FWS - PIU IS GIVEN AN INITIAL AUTHORIZATION FOR FUNDS BY THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION FOR WHICH IT CANNOT EXCEED. PIU CALLS DOWN THE FUNDS THROUGH GAPS AND THE MONEY IS ELECTRONICALLY DEPOSITED INTO A SEPARATE FEDERAL FUNDS ACCOUNT AT LEXINGTON STATE BANK, THEN THEY ARE SWEPT INTO AN INVESTMENT ACCOUNT EACH NIGHT BY THE BANK. THE FUNDS ARE ONLY REQUESTED AFTER DISBURSEMENT TO STUDENTS ACCOUNT, PER FWS, FUNDS ARE PAID TO THE STUDENTS THROUGH PIU PAYROLL AS EARNED.

Grant applications are reviewed and approved by the appropriate financial aid professionals. Upon approval, funds are applied directly to the student's account as an offset against charges such as tuition and fees. Grants cannot exceed the student's Cost of Attendance (COA). In the event that the COA is reduced due to a decrease in the student's course load or other circumstances impacting School charges, the related grant is accordingly reduced.
Financial aid is awarded based on numerous criteria,such as athletic ability, musical talent, SAT or ACT scores, and financial need.

FOR SCHOLARSHIPS, THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT REVIEWS AND MATCHES THE REQUIREMENTS TO THE RECIPIENT. FOR GRANTS, A DIRECTOR FOR THE GRANT AUTHORIZES EXPENDITURES. FOR GOVERNMENT GRANTS, THE UNIVERSITY REVIEWS THE GOVERNMENT'S "DO NOT USE-VENDOR LIST" TO QUALIFY PROSPECTIVE VENDORS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PROCEDURE OF MONITORING USE OF GRANTS TO GOVERMENTAL AGENCIES & GOVERMENTS
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 The University maintains its grant funds in individual grant accounts and is required to be audited annually (A-133). In addition, the University has established research policies and procedures as guidelines to principal investigators in managing their grant at Brandeis University.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PROCEDURE OF MONITORING USE OF GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 The University provides grants and scholarships to students and applies the financial aid directly crediting each student's account.

THE COLLEGE (PRIMARILY THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT) MONITORS STUDENTS' FILES TO ENSURE THAT THEY RECEIVE THE NECESSARY FINANCIAL AID ASSISTANCE BASED ON GRADES, COURSE OF STUDY, FINANCIAL NEED, ETC. STUDENT FILES ARE REVIEWED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS TO ENSURE THAT THEY MEET ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS.

THE COLLEGE HAS ESTABLISHED POLICIES, PROCEDURES, AND CONTROLS OVER THE AWARDING, DISBURSING, AND MONITORING OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID OR ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUAL STUDENTS IN COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL AND STATE OF NEW YORK REGULATIONS AND REQUIREMENTS.

THE SCHOOL'S STUDENTS SCHOLARSHIPS (GRANTS) ARE NON-CASH TUITION DISCOUNTS APPLIED DIRECTLY TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS AND CANNOT BE DIVERTED FROM INTENDED USES. THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS REPORTED ABOVE WAS COMPILED FROM SCHOLARSHIP DISBURSEMENT RECORDS FOR THE REPORTED FISCAL YEAR. THE SCHOOL'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS ALL RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS TO DETERMINE BOTH INITIAL AND CONTINUING ELIGIBILITY BASED UPON THE CRITERIA FOR EACH TYPE OF AWARD.

AS GIFTS AND GRANTS ARE RECEIVED, INDIVIDUAL FUNDS ARE ESTABLISHED IN OUR GENERAL LEDGER SYSTEM TO PROCESS THE GRANT REVENUE AND EXPENSE. A FINANCIAL MANAGER IS ASSIGNED TO REVIEW AND OVERSEE THE ACTIVITY OF THE FUND. IN ADDITION, OTHER ADMINISTRATIVE DEPARTMENTS ALSO PROVIDE SERVICES TO PROCESS, REPORT AND REVIEW THE GRANT INFORMATION. IN THE CASE OF PRIVATE GRANTS, THE UNIVERSITY FOLLOWS A FORMALIZED GRANT APPLICATION PROCESS TO VERIFY THAT THE UNIVERSITY UNDERSTANDS THE GRANT OBLIGATION AND PURPOSE BEFORE THE APPLICATION IS SENT TO THE GRANTOR ORGANIZATION. MANY PRIVATE AND GOVERNMENT GRANTS ARE RECEIVED FOR STUDENT FINANCIAL AID. OUR ENROLLMENT SERVICES DEPARTMENT FOLLOWS A DETAILED POLICY AND PROCEDURES MANUAL THAT DESCRIBES HOW EACH SCHOLARSHIP IS AWARDED, INCLUDING SELECTION CRITERIA. THESE PROCEDURES FOLLOW GUIDELINES SET BY THE UNIVERSITY'S SENIOR LEADERSHIP. STUDENT FINANCIAL AID IS PROCESSED UNDER INDIVIDUAL GRANT FUNDS WITHIN OUR ACCOUNTING SYSTEM (AS DESCRIBED ABOVE), AND THE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID IS ALSO PROCESSED UNDER EACH INDIVIDUAL STUDENT ACCOUNT. THIS APPROACH TO RECORD FINANCIAL AID BY FUND AND BY STUDENT ACCOUNT, PROVIDES A DETAILED RECORD OF HOW THE FUNDS ARE SPENT ACCORDING TO DONOR AND GOVERNMENTAL REQUIREMENTS. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS STUDENT ACCOUNT ACTIVITY TO VERIFY THE STUDENT'S ENROLLMENT AND USE OF THE FUNDS ACCORDING TO THE GRANT REQUIREMENTS. GRANTS ARE PROVIDED TO ESTABLISHED ORGANIZATIONS THAT ARE EDUCATIONAL AND/OR CHARITABLE AND THE UNIVERSITY IS IN CONTACT WITH THOSE ORGANIZATIONS TO ENSURE THE GRANTS FUNDS ARE EXPENDED APPROPRIATELY.

Description of Organization's Procedures for Monitoring Use of Grants: Individuals requesting any form of financial aid must complete personal financial statements and if they are dependents, they must also provide parental or guardian financial information. Only individuals who are enrolled in the school at the time of disbursements are considered for financial aid.

SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS OFFERED AT GRADUATE SCHOOL OF BANKING (GSBC): 1. GSBC OFFERS GENERAL SCHOLARSHIPS THROUGH VARIOUS STATE BANKER ASSOCIATIONS IN WHICH CANDIDATES FILL OUT A GENERAL SCHOLARSHIP FORM (INCLUDED) WITH THE SUPPORT OF A SUPERVISOR AND THE SCHOLARSHIP IS REVIEWED BY THE STATE ASSOCIATION AND GSBC. IN MOST CASES, ONE GENERAL SCHOLARSHIP PER STATE WHERE IT IS OFFERED IS AWARDED TO A NEW STUDENT EACH YEAR. 2. GSBC ALSO OFFER SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS TO TOP GRADUATES OF THE INTERMEDIATE LEVEL STATE ASSOCIATION SCHOOLS SUCH AS THE KS/NE ADVANCED SCHOOL OF BANKING; IOWA SCHOOL OF BANKING; MISSOURI SCHOOL OF BANK MANAGEMENT; ETC. IF THE TOP GRADUATE DOES NOT ACCEPT, SOMETIMES IT IS OPENED UP FOR ALL GRADUATES TO APPLY OR THE SECOND-HIGHEST GRADUATE, THIRD HIGHEST, AND SO FORTH.
NEED-BASED GRANTS AWARDED BASED ON FINANCIAL AID NEEDS ANALYSIS. OTHER GRANTS/SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED BASED ON MEETING REQUIREMENTS SET FORTH BY THE DONOR.

ELIGIBILITY FOR GRANT AID IS DETERMINED BY A FORMAL APPLICATION PROCESS (FAFSA) AND GUIDED BY FEDERAL AND STATE REGULATIONS. COLLEGE PERSONNEL CONFIRM EACH RECIPIENT'S PAST AND CURRENT AID VIA FEDERAL (NSLDS) AND STATE PROVIDED SOFTWARE. COMPLIANCE AUDITS BY AN INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTING FIRM ARE CONDUCTED ANNUALLY.

FOR RECIPIENTS OF GRANTS THAT ARE ORGANIZATIONS, SIMMONS COLLEGE PASSES THROUGH FEDERAL GRANTS TO THESE SUBRECIPIENTS. THE SUBRECIPIENTS ARE REQUIRED TO SPEND THE FUNDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE GRANT AND, IN SOME CASES, ARE REQUIRED TO OBTAIN AN AUDIT UNDER OMB CIRCULAR A-133. FOR INDIVIDUAL RECIPIENTS OF GRANTS, ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE AND DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED ARE USED TO DETERMINE EACH STUDENT'S FINANCIAL AID. THE FINANCIAL AID CONSISTS OF ANY COMBINATION OF GRANTS AND LOANS AND ARE REVIEWED EACH YEAR BASED ON A STUDENT'S ACADEMIC RECORD AND/OR DEMONSTRATED NEED. THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID, WHICH HELPS TO ESTABLISH A STUDENT'S FINANCIAL NEED, SERVES AS THE APPLICATION FOR TUITION SCHOLARSHIPS.

THE STUDENT GRANTS AND AWARDS ARE FINANCIAL AID FUNDS WHICH THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE HAS DETERMINED EACH STUDENT WAS ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE. THE BUSINESS OFFICE REVIEWS THEIR LIST, PRIOR TO ENTERING THE AWARDS DIRECTLY ON EACH STUDENT'S TUITION ACCOUNT, AS PAYMENT. FINANCIAL AID OFFICE IS PROVIDED MONTHLY REPORTS AS THESE AWARDS ARE EXPENSED OUT OF THE FINANCIAL AID BUDGET. STUDENTS ARE AWARE OF THESE AWARDS THROUGH VARIOUS PUBLICATIONS. STUDENTS HAVE DIRECT ACCESS TO ALL DETAILS OF THEIR TUITION ACCOUNT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: The Financial Aid Office and Business Office operate together to ensure grants are used for educational purposes. Grants are applied to students' accounts by the Business Office after the grants are approved and disbursed by the Financial Aid Office.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: The Financial Aid Office and Business Office operate together to ensure grants are used for educational purposes. Grants are applied to students' accounts by the Business Office after the grants are approved and disbursed by the Financial Aid Office.

FINANCIAL AID INFORMATION IS PUBLISHED IN THE COLLEGE FOR CREATIVE STUDIES ADMISSIONS MATERIAL, WHICH IS GIVEN TO EACH STUDENT CANDIDATE, AS WELL AS ON THE CCS WEBSITE, WWW.COLLEGEFORCREATIVESTUDIES.EDU. ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID IS DETERMINED BY AN ANALYSIS OF FAMILY RESOURCES FOR THE MOST RECENT CALENDAR YEAR TO ASSESS A FAMILY'S ABILITY TO CONTRIBUTE TO COLLEGE COSTS. ADJUSTMENTS TO AN APPLICATION CAN BE MADE BECAUSE OF A MAJOR CHANGE IN CIRCUMSTANCE, SUCH AS DEATH, DIVORCE, OR LOSS OF EMPLOYMENT/BENEFITS. TO RECEIVE FEDERAL OR STATE FINANCIAL AID FROM CCS, STUDENTS MUST DEMONSTRATE FINANCIAL NEED, BE ACCEPTED FOR ENROLLMENT IN A DEGREE-SEEKING PROGRAM, BE ENROLLED AT THE COLLEGE, MAINTAIN A SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS, AND BE A U.S. CITIZEN OR PERMANENT RESIDENT. IN ADDITION, A STUDENT MUST BE REGISTERED WITH SELECTIVE SERVICE (OR BE EXEMPT) AND CANNOT OWE A REFUND ON PREVIOUS TITLE IV FUNDS RECEIVED OR BE IN DEFAULT ON ANY STUDENT LOAN. ALL STUDENTS MUST COMPLETE THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) TO BE CONSIDERED FOR NEED-BASED AID. THIS FORM IS AVAILABLE ON-LINE AT FAFSA.ED.GOV OR HIGH SCHOOL GUIDANCE OFFICES, OR ANY COLLEGE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. THE RECOMMENDED FILING DEADLINE FOR HIGH SCHOOL SENIORS RESIDING IN THE STATE OF MICHIGAN WHO ARE CONSIDERING STATE AID IS MARCH 1ST. TRANSFER AND CONTINUING STUDENTS SHOULD SUBMIT THEIR APPLICATION BY MARCH 1ST AS WELL. THE FINANCIAL AID CYCLE FAVORS THOSE STUDENTS WHO FILE IN A TIMELY FASHION AND COMPLETE THE REQUIRED DOCUMENTATION EARLY. CCS' TITLE IV CODE IS 006771. GRANT/SCHOLARSHIP AMOUNTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO STUDENT'S TUITION ACCOUNTS.

Haverford College scholarships are based solely on need. The College does not award any grant aid based on merit. Applicants can be asked to file the College Board Profile and the FAFSA. If eligible for federal aid, parent and student personal and business taxes must be provided. Supplements for businesses and forms for non-custodial parents may also be required based on circumstances. Students may appeal award decisions to the Financial Aid committee made up of the Dean of Admissions, the Dean of the College and the VP of Finance and Chief Administrative Officer. Haverford scholarships are credited directly to the student's account for tuition, room, board, fees and other billed charges. Supplemental Education Opportunity Grants (FSEOG) are awarded based on family contribution. Eligibility is determined by the FAFSA and regulations determined by the U.S. Department of Education. Per the Department of Education regulations, students who receive Pell grants must be provided FSEOG funds first. If the student is selected to receive these awards other verification forms may be required including the Verification Statement, parent and student tax returns and non-tax filer statements. FSEOG awards are credited directly to the student's account for tuition, room, board and other billed charges. FSEOG awards are audited annually by the College's outside auditors in conjunction with the A-133 federal funds audit. Student internships are awarded through an application and committee review process. The internship awards are paid directly to the student for travel, room, board and other fees. This assistance enables the students to engage in unpaid internships in a variety of domestic and international locations. Some of the areas of study include Humanities, Sciences, Global Citizenship and Entrepreneurship.

Awarded grants and scholarships are directly credited against the student's tuition balance. The Financial Aid Office tracks the amounts awarded and periodically runs reports to check for changes in eligibility for all outside grants or scholarships. Grants to the Newberry College Foundation Board of Visitors are monitored by the common management between Newberry College and the organization.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIPS, FELLOWSHIPS, AND OTHER STUDENT RELATED FINANCIAL AID MUST BE USED FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES. SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE CREDITED DIRECTLY TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS THROUGH AN AUTOMATED SYSTEM AUTHORIZED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID AND SCHOLARSHIPS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part III NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY ESTIMATES THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS FROM RECORDS MAINTAINED IN OUR FINANCIAL AID (SCHOLARSHIPS) AND ACCOUNTS PAYABLE SYSTEM (GRADUATE RESEARCH ASSISTANCE STIPENDS AND FELLOWSHIPS) WHICH HAVE BEEN CLASSIFIED BY THE TYPE OF ASSISTANCE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIPS, FELLOWSHIPS, AND OTHER STUDENT RELATED FINANCIAL AID MUST BE USED FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES. SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE CREDITED DIRECTLY TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS THROUGH AN AUTOMATED SYSTEM AUTHORIZED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID AND SCHOLARSHIPS.

EACH ACADEMIC YEAR THE OFFICE OF INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT PROVIDES THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID A DETAILED LIST OF THE COLLEGE'S ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIPS, ALONG WITH THE CURRENT MARKET VALUE OF EACH SCHOLARSHIP, AND STATED CRITERIA RESTRICTIONS, IF ANY, REQUIRED FOR RECIPIENTS OF THOSE SCHOLARSHIPS. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID, FROM THAT LIST PROVIDED BY THE OFFICE OF INSTITUTIONAL AID, MATCHES STUDENTS WHO RECEIVE INSTITUTIONAL AID WITH THOSE ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIPS TO WHICH THEY ARE ELIGIBLE. THE LIST OF MATCHES IS THEN RETURNED TO THE OFFICE OF INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT.
GRANTS ARE GIVEN IN THE FORM OF TUITION SCHOLARSHIPS TO CURRENT STUDENTS.

THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES ITS STUDENTS WITH SCHOLARSHIPS THAT ARE AWARDED BASED ON VARIOUS CRITERIA. EACH STUDENT'S ELIGIBILITY IS VERIFIED PRIOR TO AWARDING A SCHOLARSHIP. THE UNIVERSITY POSTS THE GRANT DIRECTLY TO EACH STUDENT'S OUTSTANDING ACCOUNT BALANCE TO ENSURE THE PROPER USE OF AWARDED FUNDS.
GRANTS CAN BE USED FOR TUITION ONLY.

THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MAINTAINS THE RECORDS RELATED TO THE GRANTS APPLICATION. THE PROCEDURE IS AS FOLLOWS: THE STUDENTS APPLY ANNUALLY FOR GRANTS BASED ON THEIR FAMILIES' FINANCIAL CIRCUMSTANCES. EACH APPLICATION IS THEN REVIEWED TO DETERMINE THE AMOUNT OF GRANT THAT IS NEEDED. THE GRANTS ARE PROVIDED FROM APPROPRIATE SOURCES AND APPLIED TO EACH STUDENT'S BILL FOR TUITION, FEES, ROOM, BOARD AND OTHER CHARGES.

THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES GRANTS FOR SCHOLARSHIPS, FELLOWSHIPS, AND STUDENT LOANS USING GUIDELINES ESTABLISHED BY THE ORGANIZATION'S BOARD OF TRUSTEES TO ENSURE THEY ARE MADE BASED ON NEED AND OR MERIT. SCU MAKES FINANCIAL AID GRANTS TO STUDENT ACCOUNT TO OFFSET AMOUNTS THAT STUDENTS OWE THE UNIVERSITY FOR TUITION AND FEES.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE IN THE UNITED STATES
ExplntnTxt: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 The college provides scholarships to students matriculating at the University; these scholarships may only be used by students to defray the costs of tuition and/or room and board. Since the students may not exercise any discretion on how the funds are spent, the college is not required to monitor the grants (other than to ensure that the student is fulfilling the requirements for earning the scholarship).

EACH YEAR APPLICANTS ARE REQUIRED TO COMPLETE AN ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIP APPLICATION. THE FINANCIAL AID STAFF VERIFY THE INFORMATION REPORTED ON THE APPLICATION AND AWARD EACH SCHOLARSHIP TO A QUALIFIED CANDIDATE. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE DOES NOT AWARD ANY AID TO A STUDENT WHO IS NOT ENROLLED. EACH SEMESTER A LIST OF ENROLLED STUDENTS IS COMPARED TO A LIST OF STUDENTS WHO HAVE BEEN AWARDED ANY TYPE OF FINANCIAL AID.
THE COLLEGE HAS POLICIES AND PROCEDURES TO DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY FOR STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE.

THE UNIVERSITY REPORTS ALL GRANT RECIPIENTS, INCLUDING SUB-GRANTEES, OF WHICH IT IS AWARE. THIS INCLUDES SUB-RECIPIENT AWARDS, PRIMARILY FOR RESEARCH, TO GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, ORGANIZATIONS EXEMPT UNDER 501(C)(3) AND FOR-PROFIT ENTITIES FOR WHICH NO AUTHORITY FOR EXEMPTION IS PROVIDED.

CORNELL UNIVERSITY PROVIDED NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID TOTALING $277,590,732 TO APPROXIMATELY 14,724 STUDENTS IN THE FISCAL YEAR ENDING JUNE 30, 2015. IN ADDITION TO CORNELL ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIPS, ANNUAL GIFTS AND TUITION-FUNDED GRANTS OF $252,513,004, THIS AMOUNT INCLUDES SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS FROM FEDERAL, STATE, AND EXTERNAL SOURCES TOTALING $25,077,728.

THE COLLEGE HAS A LIMITED AMOUNT OF FUNDS AVAILABLE EACH YEAR TO BE USED FOR STUDENT AID IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS. EACH SCHOLARSHIP HAS CLEARLY DEFINED ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS. SOME SCHOLARSHIPS SUCH AS ACADEMIC MERIT ARE AUTOMATICALLY AWARDED IF ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA ARE MET. IN OTHER CASES STUDENTS MAKE APPLICATIONS FOR EACH SCHOLARSHIP THEY WISH TO BE CONSIDERED. THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID AND/OR FINANCIAL AID COMMITTEE REVIEWS SCHOLARSHIP APPICATIONS AND AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS.

THE COLLEGE AWARDS FEDERAL AND STATE GRANTS BASED UPON FINANCIAL NEED. COLLEGE FUNDED INSTITUTIONAL AND ENDOWED GRANTS/SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED UPON FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC MERIT. THE COLLEGE MONITORS THESE GRANTS AND AWARDS BY SEMESTER TO VERIFY THAT RECIPIENTS ARE MAINTAINinG THE MINIMUM STANDARDS REQUIRED TO RECEIVE THE GRANT OR AWARD.

The University provides funding to faculty and students for research and other projects. Expenses must be substantiated under the Accountability Plan to ensure proper use of funds. Students must meet the requirements specified in the respective award program in order to receive the award. The requirements include criteria such as financial need, obtaining/maintaining the required grade point average and studying in a certain academic discipline, etc. If the scholarship is ongoing, the student must continue to meet the scholarship requirements in order to be awarded a scholarship in subsequent years. Financial need, grade point averages and other scholarship criteria are continually monitored to determine whether the student meets the criteria.

Bay Path University receives grant money from federal and state government agencies for student financial aid. This grant money is disbursed to student accounts as it is received by the University. Student awards are based on the federal and state guidelines for each type of grant. Grants to charitable organizations are made in accordance with established financial policies and procedures.
THE COLLEGE RECONCILES GRANTS AWARDED AND DRAWDOWNS OF FUNDS. GRANT PROGRAMS ARE AUDITED BY INDEPENDENT AUDITORS DURING THE ANNUAL INDEPENDENT AUDIT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: The institution awards both need based and merit based funds and are distributed in a fair and equitable basis. Funds are awarded based on the institution's packaging policies and awarding criteria. Students must complete the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) on a yearly basis to apply for need based institutional assistance. The FAFSA results are used to determine eligibility for need based awards based on the established institutions packaging policies. Special circumstances may be considered when awarding need-based funds and are considered on an individual basis. Student records/files are kept for 4 years from the date of last enrollment---files will include FAFSA's and all supporting documentation for determining eligibility. The college maintains control of these funds by applying them directly to a students billing instead of awarding them directly to the student ensuring proper use..

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: The institution awards both need based and merit based funds and are distributed in a fair and equitable basis. Funds are awarded based on the institution's packaging policies and awarding criteria. Students must complete the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) on a yearly basis to apply for need based institutional assistance. The FAFSA results are used to determine eligibility for need based awards based on the established institutions packaging policies. Special circumstances may be considered when awarding need-based funds and are considered on an individual basis. Student records/files are kept for 4 years from the date of last enrollment---files will include FAFSA's and all supporting documentation for determining eligibility. The college maintains control of these funds by applying them directly to a students billing instead of awarding them directly to the student ensuring proper use..
STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE INSTITUTION'S ASSESSMENT ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS.

The College provides individual scholarship assistance to enrolled students in order to defray the cost of tuition and fees. This assistance is provided through direct credit to the student's account with the college, ensuring funds are utilized for their intended purpose. Depending on the source of funds, there may be donor stipulations which students may need to adhere to in order to maintain eligibility of funds. In the event of such, ongoing monitoring is performed by the College's Financial Aid department.

All Scholarships are awarded upon specific criteria maintained by the Financial Aid Office. Requirement for receiving scholarships depends on other factors such as grade point average, family income, or economic need. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors guidelines to ensure compliance. The College also undergoes the required OMB A-133 annually.

MARYGROVE COLLEGE ASSISTS STUDENTS ON THE BASIS OF FINANCIAL NEED, STUDENT ACCOMPLISHMENT AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. ALL STUDENTS REQUESTING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE MUST COMPLETE THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID. THIS INFORMATION IS REVIEWED MARYGROVE COLLEGE FINANCIAL AID STAFF. GRANT AWARDS ARE CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

DONATIONS ARE MADE TO NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS WHOSE PURPOSES ARE CONSISTENT WITH THE RELIGIOUS AND EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES OF LIBERTY UNIVERSITY. LIBERTY UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS CONTACT WITH ORGANIZATIONS TO ENSURE THE USE OF THE FUNDS ARE APPROPRIATE. GOVERNMENT FUNDED SCHOLARSHIPS FOR STUDENTS ARE MADE BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED AS PRESCRIBED BY FEDERAL AND STATE REGULATIONS. PRIVATE AND INSTITUTION FUNDED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON PROGRAM CRITERIA, WHICH INCLUDED SCHOLASTIC MERIT, ATHLETIC EXCELLENCE, ARTISTIC PERFORMANCE, FINANCIAL NEED, HIGH SCHOOL ATTENDED, AND FIELD WORKED.

THE METHODS USED TO MONITOR FUNDS INCORPORATE THE FOLLOWING CORE CONCEPTS: A) EXPECTATIONS ARE DOCUMENTED, B) A BUDGET IS ESTABLISHED, C) WRITTEN REPORTS ARE REQUIRED, D) THE COLLEGE BUDGET OFFICER REVIEWS REPORTS AND MONITORS THE RELATED BUDGET, E) THE COLLEGE BUDGET OFFICER CONTACTS OVERSEAS ORGANIZATIONS TO VERIFY THAT THE RECIPIENT IS ENGAGED AS PLANNED. METHOD 2: IN CASE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID, ACADEMIC PROGRESS IS MONITORED.
All assistance is in the form of grants and scholarships. These funds are applied directly to the student's account.

THE UNIVERSITY OF SAN FRANCISCO OFFERS STUDENT FINANCIAL AID IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS, GRANTS, LOANS, AND EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES. FINANCIAL AID IS PROVIDED BY: THE UNIVERSITY OF SAN FRANCISCO; FEDERAL AND STATE GOVERNMENTS; SOCIAL, FRATERNAL, PROFESSIONAL, AND COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS; EMPLOYERS, BOTH PRESENT AND PROSPECTIVE; AND FRIENDS AND GRADUATES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF SAN FRANCISCO. GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS CAN BE USED TO PAY FOR TUITION AND FEES,ROOM AND BOARD, TRANSPORTATION AND PERSONAL EXPENSES; GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO DEMONSTRATE ELIGIBILITY BY SUBMITTING A FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID APPLICATION, COMPETE IN INTERCOLLEGIATE ATHLETICS, ARE ACADEMICALLY ELIGIBLE, OR ARE READY TO COMMIT THEIR TIME AND SKILLS AFTER GRADUATION TO THE U.S. ARMED FORCES.

SCHOLARSHIPS GIVEN ARE A COMBINATION OF MERIT AID AND NEED-BASED AID. MERIT BASED SCHOLARSHIPS RECOGNIZE ACHIEVEMENT IN ACADEMICS AND THE POTENTIAL TO CONTRIBUTE TO CAMPUS LIFE. OVER 80% OF APPLICANTS TO THE UNIVERSITY TYPICALLY QUALIFY FOR SOME SORT OF MERIT AWARD. NEED-BASED AWARDS ARE AVAILABLE TO FULL-TIME STUDENTS WHO DEMONSTRATE NEED AS DETERMINED BY THE FAFSA. THESE AWARDS ARE GRANTED IN CONJUNCTION WITH FEDERAL, STATE, PRIVATE OR INSTITUTIONAL ASSISTANCE AND CANNOT EXCEED STUDENT'S FINANCIAL NEED. THESE AWARDS ARE DETERMINED ANNUALLY BASED ON FAFSA DATA.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS: TEXAS WESLEYAN UNIVERSITY'S OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID ADMINISTERS MULTIPLE FEDERAL, STATE, PRIVATE, AND UNIVERSITY GRANTS, SCHOLARSHIPS, LOAN AND WORK STUDY AWARDS. FEDERAL AND STATE PROGRAMS ARE ADMINISTERED ACCORDING TO THE U.S. LAW AND REGULATIONS PROMULGATED BY THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AND THE U.S. DEPARTMENT HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES AS WELL AS THE REGULATIONS OF THE STATE OF TEXAS. UNIVERSITY SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE ADMINISTERED ACCORDING TO THE POLICIES OF THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID IN SUPPORT OF THE UNIVERSITY'S STRATEGIC PLAN. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE USES THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) AND A NUMBER OF SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS OF VERIFICATION TO DETERMINE A STUDENT'S ELIGIBILITY FOR ALL NEED BASED PROGRAMS. ADDITIONALLY, STUDENTS' ELIGIBILITY IS DETERMINED BASED UPON ACADEMIC QUALIFICATIONS, SPECIAL TALENTS, AND DONOR STIPULATED REQUIREMENTS. POLICIES AND PROCEDURES ENSURE THAT THE DETERMINATION OF AID ELIGIBILITY AND THE SUBSEQUENT DELIVERY OF AID IS DELIVERED IN A FAIR AND EQUITABLE MANNER.
Grants received are applied directly to student tuition invoices. The grants are used to gap the bridge between financial aid and the full amount of tuition due.

THE COLLEGE ISSUES SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS WHO ARE REQUIRED TO MATRICULATE AT THE COLLEGE. THE STUDENT DOES NOT HAVE ANY DISCRETION ON HOW FUNDS ARE USED; ALL FUNDS ARE USED TO DEFRAY THE COSTS OF PARTICIPATING IN THIS PROGRAM, THEREFORE, THE COLLEGE IS NOT REQUIRED TO FURTHER MONITOR THE USE OF THE FUNDS. THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS A COMPUTERIZED SYSTEM WITH INTEGRATED CONTROLS TO ENSURE THAT SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDS ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH ESTABLISHED CRITERIA AS APPROVED BY SENIOR MANAGEMENT AND FEDERAL AND STATE AUTHORITIES, AS APPROPRIATE. A SERIES OF REPORTS HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED AND ARE USED BY MANAGEMENT TO IDENTIFY AND ADDRESS ANY EXCEPTIONS. ANNUALLY, THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID AWARDING PROCESS IS AUDITED BY AN INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTING FIRM. GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO GOVERNMENTS AND ORGANIZATIONS IN THE UNITED STATES ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY THE COLLEGE'S PRESIDENT AND CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER. IN EACH CASE, THE COLLEGE IS AWARE OF THE CHARITABLE USE OF THE FUNDS, WHICH IS TYPICALLY FOR THE GENERAL PURSUIT OF THE RECEIVING ORGANIZATION'S EXEMPT PURPOSES AND NOT EARMARKED FOR A SPECIFIC USE. THE COLLEGE BELIEVES IN EACH INSTANCE THAT THESE FORMS OF ASSISTANCE ARE IN THE COLLEGE'S BEST INTEREST IN PROMOTING ITS IMAGE AND THE PURSUIT OF ITS EXEMPT PURPOSE.

Need based financial aid comprises the larger part of the grants described in Part III. these grants are awarded for a maximum of eight semesters upon annual reapplication, subject to satisfactory academic and social standing. Merit based aid comprises the remainder of grants and assistance and requires maintenance of a minimum grade point average of 3.0.

THE UNIVERSITY OF DENVER HAS A UNIVERSITY WIDE SCHOLARSHIP AND GRANT ALLOCATION SYSTEM THAT DISTRIBUTES GRANT AND SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS TO ALL DIVISIONS OF THE UNIVERSITY. THE PURPOSE AND ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA ARE ESTABLISHED AT THE FUND LEVEL. THE EXPENDITURE OF THIS FINANCIAL RESOURCE IS MONITORED THROUGH A COMPREHENSIVE SOFTWARE SYSTEM WHICH ALLOWS FOR RECONCILIATION, ELIGIBILITY CHECKS, AND PREVENTS OVER EXPENDITURE. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO PARTICIPATES IN ANNUAL INDEPENDENT FINANCIAL AUDITS TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO DOMESTIC AND FOREIGN RECIPIENTS ARE DIRECTLY APPLIED TO THE RECIPIENTS' TUITION AND FEE RECEIVABLE ACCOUNT AND IS APPLIED TO ANY OUTSTANDING CHARGES PRIOR TO DISBURSEMENT OF ANY EXCESS AMOUNTS.

For all scholarship funds, student financial services has established specific criteria in regards to eligibility and selection. The eligibility requirements of the students are documented and monitored for compliance. The actual scholarships are credited to the student's tuition bills.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Financial Aid Office follows Dept. of Education and other applicable regulations, subject to yearly A133 audit.
Hiram College awards aid per the regulations set forth. The aid is administered by professionals and the programs comply with all regulations as attested in the A-133 audit.
The grants and/or financial assistance provided to the students are applied directly to the student's account, ensuring that the funds are used as intended.

ALL GRANT FUNDS ARE DETERMINED AND AWARDED BY THE OFFICE OF ENROLLMENT MANAGEMENT AND STUDENT FINANCIAL AID CONSISTENT WITH THE UNIVERSITY'S POLICIES AS WELL AS FEDERAL AND STATE GUIDELINES. GRANTEES MUST MAINTAIN PREDETERMINED ACADEMIC LEVELS IN ORDER TO QUALIFY FOR SUBSEQUENT GRANTS.

The College review the fund balances for the endowed scholarships annually and the Board approves proposed amounts to award from the endowment scholarship funds each year. Other institutional scholarships and grants are included in the College's budget that is approved by the Board. Each scholarship or grant awarded has written criteria used to determine how the funds are awarded. College scholarships and grants awarded mus first be applied to tuition, fees and housing charges (if applicable) before it can be disbursed to the student.

THE ORGANIZATION HAS SET PROCEDURES IN MONITORING AND DETERMINING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS. ELIGIBLE STUDENTS ARE CHOSEN AS GRANT RECIPIENTS BASED ON CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND FINANCIAL NEED.
THE COLLEGE RECORDS AND TRACKS GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE.

Young Harris College develops financial aid awards based upon a combination of factors, including the student's demonstrated financial need as determined by the FAFSA or other family financial indicator as accepted by the College, high school GPA, and SAT or ACT scores. Aid is to be awarded in the manner which best serves the greatest number of students and which is in keeping with the intent of the various campus programs. All institutional financial aid awards are made in accordance with the student's ability to maintain satisfactory academic progress. The Financial Aid Department monitors the students' satisfactory academic progress annually for institutional aid to determine continued eligibility. Standards are set on qualitative and quantitative progress.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: BY INSTITUTIONAL POLICY, TCU'S OFFICE OF SCHOLARSHIP AND FINANCIAL AID ACTS AS THE FINAL APPROVAL AUTHORITY FOR ALL FINANCIAL AID ELIGIBILITY DETERMINATION. EACH STUDENT'S AWARD PACKAGE IS REVIEWED TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS, AND IN THE CASE OF RESTRICTED INSTITUTIONAL FUNDS, WITH THE DONOR'S INTENT AND WISHES. ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIP ELIGIBILITY IS BASED ON A SCORING MATRIX THAT EVALUATES AN INDIVIDUAL STUDENT'S SUCCESS USING NATIONAL TEST SCORES, RANK IN CLASS, AND HIGH SCHOOL GPA. THOSE WHO HAVE EXCELLED ACADEMICALLY ARE GENERALLY GIVEN THE LARGEST SHARE OF UNIVERSITY FUNDED DOLLARS. INSTITUTIONALLY FUNDED NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID PROGRAMS ARE BASED ON ELIGIBILITY ESTABLISHED BY THE FAFSA. STUDENTS APPLYING FOR NEED-BASED GRANTS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT THE CSS PROFILE APPLICATION. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE ALSO WORKS CLOSELY WITH THE DONOR RELATIONS DIVISION OF UNIVERSITY ADVANCEMENT TO ENSURE THAT OUR DONORS' WISHES ARE MET WHEN MATCHING FUNDS TO STUDENTS. ALL DONORS OF ENDOWED AWARDS ARE PROVIDED WITH A "SCHOLARSHIP AGREEMENT" OUTLINING THE UNIVERSITY'S UNDERSTANDING OF THE DONOR'S INTENT. THESE AGREEMENTS MUST BE APPROVED BY BOTH THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID, AND THE VICE-CHANCELLOR FOR ADVANCEMENT, TO ENSURE THAT THE UNIVERSITY HAS THE CAPABILITY TO IDENTIFY APPROPRIATE RECIPIENTS. IN ADDITION TO INSTITUTIONALLY FUNDED GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS, TCU MANAGES AND ACCEPTS FIDUCIARY RESPONSIBILITY FOR A VARIETY OF FEDERAL AND STATE FUNDED FINANCIAL AID PROGRAMS. ELIGIBILITY FOR TITLE IV FEDERAL FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND STATE FUNDED NEED-BASED AID PROGRAMS IS DETERMINED USING FEDERAL METHODOLOGY AND REQUIRES THE SUBMISSION OF THE FAFSA. PRIOR TO DISBURSEMENT, EACH RECIPIENT MUST PASS A VARIETY OF EDIT CHECKS, OR "DISBURSEMENT RULES" TO ENSURE THAT THE STUDENT IS ENROLLED IN CLASSES AND HAS SUBMITTED ALL REQUIRED DOCUMENTATION NEEDED TO SATISFY PROGRAM ELIGIBILITY. AFTER DISBURSEMENT, STUDENT AID RECIPIENTS ARE REVIEWED AT THE END OF THE 100% TUITION REFUND PERIOD FOR A FINAL ENROLLMENT STATUS DETERMINATION. STUDENTS WHO RECEIVED AID BASED ON PROJECTED FULL-TIME ENROLLMENT, BUT WHO HAVE DROPPED BELOW 12 CREDIT HOURS, ARE SUBJECT TO AN ADJUSTMENT OF THEIR AID PACKAGE. AT THE END OF THE 25%, AND FINAL REFUND PERIOD, STUDENTS ARE AGAIN REVIEWED AND SUBJECT TO AID ADJUSTMENT BASED ON FINAL COSTS FOR THE TERM. AID RECIPIENTS ARE MONITORED ON A REGULAR BASIS THROUGHOUT THE ACADEMIC YEAR. FILES ARE REVIEWED WEEKLY TO IDENTIFY UPDATED FAFSA APPLICATIONS FROM THE FEDERAL PROCESSOR AND ADJUSTMENTS ARE MADE WHEN REQUIRED. REPORTS ARE SUBMITTED TO THE TEXAS HIGHER EDUCATION COORDINATING BOARD PERIODICALLY FOR REVIEW OF STATE AID RECIPIENTS, AND THE UNIVERSITY IS SUBJECT TO PERIODIC AUDITS AND REVIEWS FROM BOTH ENTITIES. ACADEMIC SUCCESS IS THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF ALL AID PROGRAMS, AND SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS IS REVIEWED AT THE END OF EACH TERM. AT A MINIMUM, FULL-TIME STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO COMPLETE AT LEAST 24 CREDIT HOURS AND OBTAIN A 2.00 GPA TO MEET RENEWAL REQUIREMENTS. MOST TCU FUNDED AWARDS REQUIRE A MINIMUM GPA OF 2.50. ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS REQUIRE A 3.25 GPA. ONCE POSTED TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS, THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES ALSO MONITORS AWARD AMOUNTS IN RELATION TO SPECIFIC CHARGES. AWARD AMOUNTS THAT APPEAR TO BE OUT OF NORM ARE REFERRED BACK TO THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE FOR REVIEW.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: BY INSTITUTIONAL POLICY, TCU'S OFFICE OF SCHOLARSHIP AND FINANCIAL AID ACTS AS THE FINAL APPROVAL AUTHORITY FOR ALL FINANCIAL AID ELIGIBILITY DETERMINATION.
