INDIVIDUALS: GRANT FUNDS AWARDED TO STUDENTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNTS. USAGE IS MONITORED BY VIRTUE OF DIRECT ACCOUNT POSTING. ELIGIBILITY AND AWARDING OF THE GRANTS IF DETERMINED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Based on financial need.

GGU DISBURSES FUNDS FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES WITHIN THE MEANING OF IRC SECTION 170(C)(2). DISBURSEMENTS TO INDIVIDUALS ARE AWARDS OF SCHOLARSHIPS TO QUALIFYING STUDENTS IN FURTHERANCE OF THEIR EDUCATIONAL PURSUITS. SEE GGU'S SCHOLARSHIP POLICY: HTTP://WWW.GGU.EDU/ENROLLMENT/FINANCIAL-AID/SCHOLARSHIPS-AND-GRANTS

THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS RECORDS TO ENSURE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS BASED ON FEDERAL REGULATIONS OR DONOR RESTRICTIONS. THE COLLEGE AWARDS GRANTS TO STUDENTS BASED ON CRITERIA SET FORTH IN THE INDIVIDUAL SCHOLARSHIPS. "NEED BASED" FEDERAL GRANTS ARE AWARDED BASED ON INFORMATION OBTAINED FROM THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL AID (FASFA).

Students receiving scholarships are judged worthy by the institution's assessment on the basis of academic achievement, financial need and other similar standards. Scholarships are awarded on a non-discriminatory basis.
THE ORGANIZATION AWARDS TUITION SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS OF THIS INSTITUTION AND ARE IMMEDIATELY APPLIED AGAINST THE STUDENT'S TUITION CHARGES.
STUDENTS RECEIVE SCHOLARSHIPS AS CREDITS AGAINST TUITION. THESE SCHOLARSHIPS CAN BE BASED ON NEED AND/OR ON ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE.

PURSUANT TO THE MASS SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT BETWEEN GRANTING AGENCIES AND PLANTIFFS, THE BUILDINGS AND EQUIPMENT GRANTED TO WEST VIRGINIA UNIVERSITY COULD NOT BE SOLD BECAUSE THEY WERE BUILT AND/OR PURCHASED USING GRANT FUNDS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: STUDENT SCHOLARSHIP, FELLOWSHIPS AND STUDENT LOANS- SCHEDULE I, PART IV
ExplntnTxt: STUDENTS WHO RECEIVE SCHOLARSHIPS, FELLOWSHIPS AND STUDENT LOANS FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF ROCHESTER ARE SELECTED AND THE AMOUNT OF GRANTS OR LOANS DETERMINED BY OBJECTIVE AND NON-DISCRIMINATORY PROCESSES APPLIED TO ALL SIMILARLY SITUATED INDIVIDUALS. THE DECISIONS ARE MADE ON A CASE BY CASE BASIS THROUGH EVALUATING THE ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND FINANCIAL NEED OF THE APPLICANT IN LIGHT OF THE FUNDS AVAILABLE FOR THIS PURPOSE. --------------------

IN FURTHERANCE OF ITS RESEARCH ACTIVITIES, THE UNIVERSITY OF ROCHESTER MAKES SUB-AWARDS TO OTHER ORGANIZATIONS THAT PERFORM RESEARCH IN CONNECTION WITH RESEARCH GRANTS AWARDED TO THE UNIVERSITY. THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT CATEGORIZE THESE SUB-AWARDS AS "GRANTS" FOR FORM 990, SCHEDULE I REPORTING, SINCE THE RECIPIENT ORGANIZATIONS PERFORM RESEARCH SERVICES FOR THE UNIVERSITY AND ARE CONSIDERED INDEPENDENT CONTRACTORS WHICH SERVE THE DIRECT NEEDS OF THE UNIVERSITY.

Marshall University Research Corporation submits proposals to funding agencies and awards scholarships, stipends, and sub-grants in a pass through capacity. The recipients are in accordance with grant award documents.

SALEM GRANTS FUNDS IN THE WAY OF SCHOLARSHIPS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS IN ITS ACADEMY AND COLLEGE. SALEM MAINTAINS RECORDS ON ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL AID IN THE FORM OF SALEM GRANTS OR FROM OTHER SOURCES. SALEM COLLEGE COMPLIES WITH ALL APPLICABLE FEDERAL RULES AS IT RELATES TO COLLEGE FINANCIAL AID.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PART III, COLUMN B:
ExplntnTxt: THE VAST MAJORITY OF SALEM'S COLLEGE STUDENTS RECEIVE SOME FORM OF SCHOLARSHIP FROM THE COLLEGE. SALEM PROVIDES THIS ASSISTANCE THROUGH ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIPS AND INSTITUTIONAL REMISSION (DISCOUNT). SALEM COMPLIES WITH ALL FEDERAL AND STATE REGULATION REGARDING THE REWARDING OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID AND FILES THE REQUISITE INFORMATION WITH FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES AS IT PERTAINS TO ITS STUDENTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: 1. PERFORM A RISK ASSESSMENT ON SUB-RECIPIENTS; 2. PERFORM SITE VISITS TO REVIEW FINANCIAL AND PROGRAMMATIC RECORDS; 3. ENSURE THAT PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR HAS REGULAR CONTACTS; 4. ENSURE A CURRENT CERTIFICATION OR AN A-133 AUDIT IS PERFORMED AND THE RELATED REPORT RECEIVED AND REVIEWED.
The College has policies and procedures in place that are followed in order to award students institutional aid.

THE TRANSFERS TO THE COLLEGE FOR HCC RENOVATIONS, FESTOCPCC, THEATER TECHNOLOGY UPGRADES WERE FACILITATED AND MONITORED VIA PROCESSES BY DESIGNATED CPCC DEPARTMENT MANAGERS. DEPARTMENTAL EXPENSES FUNDED BY COLLEGE COURSEWARE ROYALTIES ARE REQUESTED BY THE DEPARTMENT HEADS FOR SPECIFIC USE AND ARE APPROVED BY MICHAEL MOSS (VP FINANCE), KEVIN MCCARTHY (VP INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT) AND QUINCY FOIL WHITE (AVP SERVICES CORP).
FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE IS IN THE FORM OF REDUCTION OF TUITION. THE FELLOW PROGRAM SPANS OVER 2 YEARS AND THE ORGANIZATION PROVIDES INSTRUCTIONAL MODULES THROUGHOUT THE DURATION OF THE PROGRAM.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PROCEDURE FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS INSIDE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Washington College awarded $24,936,067 in scholarships for 6/30/15. Washington College offers several types of financial aid to help qualified full-time undergraduate students meet their college expenses. College-sponsored tuition scholarships, tuition grants, and work/study are available to full-time undergraduate students who demonstrate financial need and who meet the College's admission criteria. In addition to College-sponsored financial aid, eligible students can receive assistance from federal, state, and independent aid programs. Grant and scholarship assistance from all sources is first applied to full-time tuition charges. Grant and scholarship assistance in excess of tuition is then applied to direct college charges for fees, and on campus room and board. The Federal Government makes FFELP funds available to undergraduate students to attend post-secondary institutions. Eligibility is based on financial need, and application is through the normal financial aid application process of Washington College.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedure for Monitoring Use of Grant Funds Inside U.S.
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Baldwin Wallace University awards scholarships and makes need-based financial aid grants only to its own enrolled students. The awards constitute part of the cost of attending. Additional need-based aid usually consists of Federal Direct Student Loans and College Work Study for jobs on campus. The Student Financial Aid Office makes need-based grants on the basis of demonstrated financial need using nationally accepted forms and methods. The same office awards merit scholarships using Baldwin Wallace criteria. The University disburses the grants as credits to student receivable accounts, offsetting amounts billed for tuition and other fees.

MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS ALL GRANTS AWARDED ARE BASED ON NEED AND CONFORM TO FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL REGULATIONS. ELIGIBILITY IS BASED ON A THOROUGH REVIEW AND VERIFICATION OF A FAMILY'S INCOME, ASSETS, SIZE AND NUMBER OF DEPENDENTS ENROLLED IN COLLEGE. ANNUAL EXPENDITURE REPORTS ARE SUBMITTED TO THE FEDERAL AND STATE GOVERNMENTS FOR REVIEW. THE EXPENDITURES ARE REVIEWED FOR COMPLIANCE IN AN ANNUAL AUDIT CONDUCTED BY AN INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTING FIRM.

THE ACADEMIC PROGRESS OF FINANCIAL AID RECIPIENTS IS MONITORED A MINIMUM OF ONCE EACH ACADEMIC YEAR. STUDENTS SHOULD CONTACT THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WITH QUESTIONS REGARDING THE INTENT AND/OR INTERPRETATION OF THESE STANDARDS. COMPLETION RATE AND GRADE POINT AVERAGE (GPA) REQUIREMENTS FULL-TIME STUDENTS (STUDENTS ATTEMPTING 12 OR MORE CREDIT HOURS EACH SEMESTER) MUST PROGRESS ACCORDING TO THE FOLLOWING SCHEDULE: MINIMUM CREDITS MINIMUM REQUIRED SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETED CUMULATIVE GPA YEAR 1 24 1.70 YEAR 2 48 2.00 YEAR 3 72 2.00 YEAR 4 96 2.00 YEAR 5 123 2.00 THESE CREDIT HOURS MUST BE EARNED DURING THE ACADEMIC YEAR (FALL, WINTER AND SPRING). HOWEVER, IF A STUDENT DOES NOT MEET THESE REQUIRED HOURS, THEY MAY BE EARNED DURING THE FOLLOWING SUMMER SESSION(S). FAILURE TO ACHIEVE THIS STANDARD BY THE END OF THE SUMMER WILL RESULT IN THE LOSS OF FINANCIAL AID ELIGIBILITY UNTIL THE COMPLETED CUMULATIVE HOURS MEET THE MINIMUM STANDARDS. LOSS OF AID IS NOT THE SAME AS ACADEMIC SUSPENSION, WHICH IS HANDLED BY THE VICE PRESIDENT OF ACADEMIC AFFAIRS. PART-TIME STUDENTS MUST SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETE ONE-HALF OF THE CREDIT HOURS THEY ATTEMPT. COMBINED STUDENTS (STUDENTS BLENDING TERMS OF FULL- AND PART-TIME ENROLLMENT) MUST ACHIEVE A CUMULATIVE TOTAL THAT SATISFIES THE COMBINED FULL- AND PART-TIME STANDARDS. STUDENTS WHO DO NOT ACHIEVE THE MINIMUM CUMULATIVE GPA ARE GRANTED ONE PROBATIONARY SEMESTER IN WHICH TO RAISE THEIR CUMULATIVE GPA TO THE MINIMUM. FAILURE TO ACHIEVE THIS STANDARD AT ANY POINT FOLLOWING THE PROBATIONARY SEMESTER RESULTS IN THE LOSS OF FINANCIAL AID ELIGIBILITY UNTIL THE CUMULATIVE GPA MEETS THE MINIMUM STANDARDS.

All scholarships are awarded based upon specific criteria maintained by the financial aid office. Requirements for receiving scholarships depend upon other factors, such as grade point average, family income or economic need. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors the eligibility guidelines to ensure compliance. The College also undergoes the required OMB A-133 audit annually.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING GRANTS THE UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS A POLICY OF OFFERING QUALIFIED UNDERGRADUATE APPLICANTS ADMISSION TO THE UNIVERSITY WITHOUT REGARD TO FINANCIAL CIRCUMSTANCE. THIS POLICY PROVIDES FINANCIAL AID TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF DIRECT GRANTS AND EMPLOYMENT DURING THE ACADEMIC YEAR. THE UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS AN ALL-GRANT POLICY WHEREBY ANY QUALIFIED UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT WITH DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED RECEIVES A LOAN-FREE AID PACKAGE. STUDENTS MAY STILL BORROW AT THEIR DISCRETION TO AN UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT MAY ALSO BE ELIGIBLE FOR FACULTY/STAFF TUITION REMISSION AS A RESULT OF A PARENT BEING ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE THIS BENEFIT AS A CONDITION OF THEIR EMPLOYMENT. GRADUATE/PROFESSIONAL FINANCIAL AID CAN BE AWARDED BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED, SERVICE (TEACHING FELLOWSHIPS, RESEARCH ASSISTANTSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS) OR OTHER CRITERIA SUCH AS MERIT/ACADEMICS. PHD STUDENTS GENERALLY RECEIVE MULTI-YEAR AWARDS COVERING THEIR FULL EDUCATIONAL COSTS. A GRADUATE/PROFESSIONAL STUDENT MAY ALSO BE ELIGIBLE FOR FACULTY/STAFF BENEFIT AS DESCRIBED ABOVE.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS BASED ON EITHER THE SPECIFIC CRITERIA OF THE SCHOLARSHIP FUNDING, ACADEMIC MERIT, OR TALENT. THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS SCHOLARSHIP FUND AVAILABILITY, MAKES SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS, AND MAINTAINS AN ON-GOING AWARENESS OF STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS.
THE SCHOLARSHIPS/FINANCIAL AID AWARDED TO STUDENTS IS APPLIED AGAINST THEIR TUITION ACCOUNTS.

INDIVIDUALS IN THE U.S. ARE DEFINED AS THOSE LIVING IN THE U.S. AT THE TIME THE AID WAS AWARDED. THE ABOVE IS A BEST ESTIMATE BASED ON CERTAIN ASSUMPTIONS REGARDING WHERE PERSONS WERE LIVING WHEN THE AID WAS AWARDED AND DOES NOT REPRESENT THE DEGREE TO WHICH AID IS AWARDED TO INTERNATIONAL STUDENTS.

Subrecipient grants - Lehigh University maintains a policy defining its procedures for monitoring the use of sponsored funds by subrecipients who are performing a portion of a sponsored project externally awarded to Lehigh. The policy provides guidance to ensure that subrecipients conduct their portions of sponsored projects in compliance with laws, regulations, terms and conditions of awards and subawards, and that reimbursed costs incurred by subrecipients are allowed. Other Assistance - Assistance offered from instititional funds by Lehigh to our students is awarded on the basis of merit and/or financial need. The selection criteria is based on the calculated expected family contribution, which is derived by using complex formulas involving families' income, assets, and household sizes. The student financial aid office administers and monitors these grants using system-generated reviews, along with cross checks on an ad hoc basis. Results from these reviews are regularly evaluated. Subsequently, follow-up corrective actions are taken when appropriate, and potentially include award revisions or cancellations. These provisions are designed to help ensure that student assistance funds are awarded to eligible recipients, in accordance with applicable federal, state, institutional, and other program legislation, as well as relevant internal university policies and operational guidelines.
GRANT FUNDS ARE MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND ACCOUNTING OFFICES.
ALL GRANTS ARE INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID AND APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT BY KANSAS CITY ART INSTITUTE.

Award Once the award letter is received in the Accounting Office, a location for the new grant is created in the general ledger within 3 business days. The budget is entered within three business days of receipt of the approved budget narratives. The Grants Accountant reviews the contract for any restrictions on the grant and compliance on financial reporting. The grant is entered in the summary database listing reporting and reimbursement requirements. Expenditures and Monitoring St. Thomas University follows Circular A-21, EGAR, the Florida State, Dade County and any other institution's policy with whom STU has a sponsored relationship. All sponsored project expenses need to be approved by the Principal Investigator, the supervising Dean, the Provost (when applicable), the Accounts Payable Representative, and the Grants Accountant or Accounting Manager. The Grants Accountant is the last review before payment, therefore she verifies the expense is supported by the budget narrative, all the signatures have been gathered, and debarment has been printed for each vendor. Debarment verification is checked at https://www.sam.gov. Budget reallocations usually require written approval from the funding agency unless the reallocation of funds within existing categories is small, do not change the scope of the project and follow the federal guidelines, for example, the 10% EDGAR rule. Expenditures on a sponsored agreement can occur only within the specified performance period. If there are unspent funds beyond the performance period and goals of the sponsored project have not been fully accomplished, carryover of unspent fund can occur upon receipt of a No-Cost Extension approval. The PI/PD reconciles with the Grant Accountant the unspent funds before filing the no-cost extension. Project Directors and Budget Officers have real-time access to the general ledger accounts created by the Accounting Department via web-advisor. Web-advisor reports contain detailed information on budgets and expenses by account number. It is the responsibility of the PI/PD to monitor the accuracy of all the expenses posted to their accounts. When the PI/PD keeps sub-ledger records, the Grant Accountant reconciles such records with the general ledger periodically. The PI/PD keeps track of matching requirements or in-kind donations separately. PI/PD provides these figures to the Grants Accountant for review and reporting purposes. Time and Effort reporting is required for all employees working on funded projects. The form is completed at the end of every semester. The form can be found at http://www.stu.edu/Portals/0/personnel.pdf. Sub-awards St. Thomas University sub-awards funds to other organizations when specified in the approved budget narratives. An agreement is signed between St. Thomas University and the sub grantee stating the terms of the contract. St. Thomas University expects the sub grantee to follow the same regulations governing the sponsoring agency and comply with any request for information from St Thomas University's accounting office. The Grants Accountant verifies reimbursement requests submitted by the sub-grantee against the approved budget, checks the supporting documentation and prepares a check request. The check request is reviewed by the Accounting Manager and submitted for approval to the Principal Investigator, the immediate Dean, and the Provost (when applicable) and subsequently to the Accounts Payable office for processing. A Single Audit Report in Accordance with OMB Circular A-133 is requested from each sub grantee at the end of each fiscal year. When St. Thomas University is the sub-grantee in sponsored agreements, it follows the specifications of the contract signed with the fiscal agent. St. Thomas University also follows the same federal and institutional policies as if the award was a direct award to our institution. Reimbursement St. Thomas University requests reimbursement of sponsored agreement expenses on a monthly or quarterly basis. The Grants Accountant / Accounting Manager follow the reimbursement guidelines of the cognizant agency. Audit St. Thomas University undergoes an external audit annually. As part of the audit, the external auditor prepares the Single Audit Report in Accordance with OMB Circular A-133 and Section 10.650, Rules of the Auditor General of the State of Florida. The Accounting Office prepares the Schedule of Federal Expenditures, which is the basis for the Single Audit Report. Grant award notices are received by the Office of Financial Affairs from various State and Federal Agencies. Each Notice of Award (NOA) identifies the CFDA or CSDA number(s) from which the grant is funded. These catalog numbers are entered on to the Schedule of Federal Expenditures. From the University's fund accounting system, a report of total expenditures by location is run for the fiscal period being audited. The totals are verified to the financial statements by the Grants Accountant and become part of the Schedule of Expenditures for Federal Awards (SEFA) supporting documentation. St. Thomas University is on an expense reimbursement basis for most of the grants. Therefore, as of June 30, a receivable is reported for most of the grants. The only exceptions are grants run by the Human Rights Institute. This institute administers the Refugee and Entrant Assistance grant passed through the Department of Children and Families (DCF). This grant reimburses St. Thomas University based on "fee for service." The Grants Accountant verifies reimbursement received with DCF. Since the grant has more than one CFDA number for each contract, the percentage of reimbursement received by CFDA as provided by DCF is applied to expenses per general ledger. All other non ARRA grants are funded with only one CFDA or CSDA, and we assume that 100% of expenditures are derived from the single Catalog number. The SEFA is reviewed for reasonableness by the Accounting Manager.

St. Thomas University acts as the fiscal agent. University of Pittsburgh submits reimbursement requests to St. Thomas University. The request is reviewed to ensure expenses incurred are in line with the approved budget narrative.

THE UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS A SEPERATE GRANT DEPARTMENT WHICH INCLUDES A DIRECTOR AND MULTIPLE GRANT ANALYSTS. THE GRANTS DEPARTMENT IS RESPONSIBLE FOR COMPLIANCE WITH ALL CONTRACTUAL AND FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS. THE DEPARTMENT IS ALSO RESPONSIBLE FOR MAKING DETERMINATIONS REGARDING ELIGIBILITY FOR AWARD RECIPIENTS AND SUB-GRANTEE RECIPIENTS.

SCHOLARSHIP CANDIDATES MUST MEET BASIC MINIMUM GPA REQUIREMENTS, ATTEND IN FULL-TIME STATUS, AND MUST MAINTAIN SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS IN THEIR DEGREE PROGRAM. NEW STUDENTS COMPLETE AN APPLICATION ALONG WITH AN ESSAY. ALL ELIGIBLE CANDIDATES ARE INTERVIEWED BY AT LEAST TWO MEMBERS OF THE ADMISSIONS AND STUDENT AID COMMITTEE. AT THE END OF MARCH, THE COMMITTEE MEETS TO SELECT THE AWARD WINNERS. RETURNING STUDENTS WHO WERE NOT AWARDED SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS WILL HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO APPLY FOR SCHOLARSHIP IF THEY MEET THE MINIMUM GPA REQUIREMENT IN THEIR STUDIES AT MTSO. THEY MUST PROVIDE THE ASAC SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE WITH AN ESSAY AND TWO COURSE EVALUATIONS. THESE REVIEWS ALSO TAKE PLACE AT THE MARCH SCHOLARSHIP SELECTION MEETING. WE MONITOR THE ACADEMIC PROGRESS AND GPA OF SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS ON AN ANNUAL BASIS. IF CRITERIA IS NOT MET, ONE SEMESTER OF SCHOLARSHIP PROBATION IS ENFORCED GIVING THE STUDENT AN ATTEMPT AT IMPROVEMENT BEFORE THE AWARD IS REVOKED.

AWARDING OF INSTITUTIONAL AID IS DRIVEN BY THE AWARD THE STUDENT RECEIVES UPON ENTRANCE TO KEUKA COLLEGE. COMING IN AS A NEW STUDENT, THE ADMISSIONS AND FINANCIAL AID SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE FIRST DETERMINES IF THE STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE FOR MERIT BASED AWARDS. THESE AWARDS ARE BASED ON ACADEMIC AND CO-CURRICULAR ACTIVITIES. EACH STUDENT IS THEN COMPARED TO A FINANCIAL AID AWARDING MATRIX WHICH IS COMPRISED OF VARYING NEED LEVELS FOR GRANT FUNDING, CAMPUS BASED AID AND CAMPUS EMPLOYMENT. STUDENTS ARE PLACED ON THIS GRID BY USING THE ADMISSION'S SCHOLARSHIP CRITERIA TO DETERMINE THEIR RATING AND THEN THEIR FINANCIAL NEED FACTOR AS DETERMINED BY THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) FOR THAT ACADEMIC YEAR. STUDENT AWARDS ARE REVIEWED ON A YEARLY BASIS TO DETERMINE THEIR ELIGIBILITY. TYPICALLY A STUDENT AWARD WILL NOT CHANGE UNLESS FINANCIAL NEED OR ACADEMIC PROGRESS CHANGES. TUITION BASED AWARDS WILL INCREASE/DECREASE WITH THE VALUE OF TUITION EACH YEAR. INSTITUTIONAL AID IS PLACED ON THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT TYPICALLY IN TWO EQUAL DISBURSEMENTS (FALL AND SPRING). THESE DISBURSEMENTS ARE NOT RELEASED UNTIL ALL REQUIRED DOCUMENTATION IS COMPLETE IN THE STUDENT'S FILE. DISBURSEMENTS ARE MADE 10 DAYS PRIOR TO THE START OF CLASSES EACH SEMESTER. INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO TRADITIONAL UNDERGRADUATE, INTERNATIONAL STUDENTS AND A LIMITED NUMBER OF STUDENTS IN THE GRADUATE AND ACCELERATED STUDY PROGRAM.

DISBURSEMENTS TO STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FINANCIAL AID ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH INSTITUTIONAL PROCEDURES TO ENSURE THAT THOSE RECEIVING AID ARE QUALIFYING RECIPIENTS. FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID AND/OR ASSISTANCE FROM GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES IS DISTRIBUTED AND MONITORED IN ACCORDANCE WITH FEDERALLY APPROVED NEED ANALYSIS CRITERIA OR OTHER AGENCY PROVIDED CRITERIA. THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS TO INDIVIDUALS ARE MONITORED THROUGH UNIQUE GENERAL LEDGER ACCOUNTS FOR EACH GRANT. EXPENDITURES FOR EACH GRANT ACCOUNT ARE REVIEWED AND ANALYZED USING AD-HOC REPORTS TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS - PART I, LINE 2:
ExplntnTxt: THE COLLEGE AWARDS AID TO MEET 100% OF A STUDENT'S DEMONSTRATED NEED. ALL AID IS CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. IF THE STUDENT WITHDRAWS FROM WELLESLEY, THE AID IS ADJUSTED ACCORDINGLY. FOR INTERNSHIPS, THE COLLEGE IS IN CONTACT WITH THE ORGANIZATIONS PROVIDING THE INTERNSHIP TO ENSURE THAT HIGH-QUALITY PROGRAMS ARE PROVIDED TO THE STUDENTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: GRANTS ARE PUT INTO A SEPARATE AND UNIQUE FUND AND THE EXPENDITURES ARE MONITORED AGAINST THE PROPOSAL AND AWARD. THE COLLEGE MANAGES AN EXTENSIVE FINANCIAL AID PROGRAM TO ENSURE THAT A HIGHLY QUALIFIED AND DIVERSE POPULATION IS ABLE TO MATRICULATE AND CONTINUE TO GRADUATION. THE ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS TAKE TWO MAJOR FORMS: MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS AND NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID. THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT MONITORS THE AMOUNTS GIVEN BY THE GRANT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: GRANTS ARE PUT INTO A SEPARATE AND UNIQUE FUND AND THE EXPENDITURES ARE MONITORED AGAINST THE PROPOSAL AND AWARD. THE COLLEGE MANAGES AN EXTENSIVE FINANCIAL AID PROGRAM TO ENSURE THAT A HIGHLY QUALIFIED AND DIVERSE POPULATION IS ABLE TO MATRICULATE AND CONTINUE TO GRADUATION. THE ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS TAKE TWO MAJOR FORMS: MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS AND NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID. THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT MONITORS THE AMOUNTS GIVEN BY THE GRANT.

CORNELL MONITORS ALL GRANT RESOURCES THROUGH FEDERAL, STATE, AND INSTITUTIONAL AUDITS AS WELL AS FEDERAL, STATE, AND INTERNAL POLICY AND PROCEDURES AS WELL AS PERIODIC AUDITING BY AND REPORTING TO THE FEDERAL DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION, AN INDEPENDENT AUDIT FIRM COMPLETES AN ANNUAL AUDIT OF ALL GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE CORNELL'S MANAGEMENT TAKES THE NECESSARY STEPS TO INSURE CORNELL IS IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE MANY FEDERAL REGULATIONS RECIPIENTS OF GRANT AND OTHER ASSISTANCE ARE SELECTED ON AN EQUAL OBJECTIVELY DETERMINABLE BASIS WITH OTHER RECIPIENTS.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS ALL SWARTHMORE COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED/POSTED ELECTRONICALLY (AND INTERNALLY) DIRECTLY TO EACH STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. FURTHERMORE, STUDENTS RECEIVING SAID GRANT FUNDS ARE UNABLE TO WITHDRAWAL SUCH FUNDS FROM THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

THE RESEARCH FOUNDATiON AWARDS GRANTS TO THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA IN SUPPORT OF THE RESEARCH AND SCHOLARLY ACTIVITIES AT THE UNIVERSITY. UNIVERSITY FACULTY MEMBERS ARE ENCOURAGED TO SUBMIT PROPOSALs DETAILING THEIR RESEARCH OBJECTIVES. PROPOSALS MEETING THE PREDETERMINED CRITERIA ARE APPROVED FOR FUNDING BY A SELECTION COMMITTEE. INDIVIDUAL GRANT ACCOUNTS ARE ESTABLISHED FOR EACH PROPOSAL AWARDED WHICH ARE USED TO ACCUMULATE AND TRACK GRANT EXPENDITURES. GRANT EXPENDITURES ARE REVIEWED BY FOUNDATION STAFF MONTHLY. PAYMENTS TO THE UNIVERSITY ARE ON A MONTHLY COST-REIMBURSEABLE BASIS, AND ONLY COVER ACTUAL COSTS INCURRED. UPON COMPLETION OF THE RESEARCH, PROGRESS REPORTS ARE SUBMITTED TO FOUNDATION MANAGEMENT DETAILING RESEARCH HIGHLIGHTS, ACCOMPLISHMENTS AND ACHIEVEMENTS.
THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS AN OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID, WHICH IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MONITORING OF GRANT FUNDS AWARDED TO THE COLLEGE AND STUDENTS.

SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO MEET THE FINANCIAL REQUIREMENTS AS DEMONSTRATED BY THE RESULTS FROM FEDERAL FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID. ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS ALSO MEET THE SPECIFIC CRITERIA AS IDENTIFIED BY THE DONORS.

THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID MAINTAINS RECORDS OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS AWARDED TO NCU STUDENTS IN THE POWERFAIDS DATABASE. THIS SYSTEM TRACKS ENROLLMENT AND AID ELIGIBILITY AND ENSURES THAT STUDENTS ARE NOT AWARDED AID THAT EXCEEDS THEIR COST TO ATTEND COLLEGE. IN ADDITION THESE SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE ALWAYS APPLIED TO THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNT IN OUR ACCOUNTING SYSTEM TO ENSURE AWARDED FUNDS GO FIRST TO COVER TUITION AND OTHER INSTITUTIONAL CHARGES.

Our financial aid office awards scholarships to students based on submitted FAFSA data and academic performance. The financial aid office is responsible for ensuring compliance with all relevant state and federal requirements relative to grant-based aid.

SUPPLEMENTAL INFORMATION THE COLLEGE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS BASED ON SCHOLARSHIP CRITERIA. THE NUMBER OF SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED IN PART III, COLUMN(B) IS ACTUAL SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED DURING THE YEAR.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Form 990, SCH I, Part I, line 2
ExplntnTxt: Monitoring the use of grants The Office of Financial Aid processes all students' financial aid awards based on guidelines set forth by federal, state and local governments. These awards are included in the student financial package and are applied to the students' accounts once all eligibility requirements are met. The Office of Financial Aid reconciles all federal funds to the US Department of Education Common Origination and Disbursement system on a monthly basis. In addition, the Controller's Office reconciles the award disbursement activities posted to the Institute's General Ledger account to the Students' Accounts receivable ledgers and Financial Aid awards reports. The Controller's Office also processes the reimbursement requests, reconciliation of funds received and monitor the spending level to ensure that actual disbursements does not exceed the authorized government grant.
The scholarships are awarded to Spertus students and are used to offset their tuition costs.
THE ASSISTANCE IS IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS WHICH ARE REVIEWED ANNUALLY BASED ON THE STUDENTS MEETING CERTAIN GPA LEVELS AND CUMULATIVE CREDIT HOURS.
THE COLLEGE AWARDS FINANCIAL AID PRIMARILY BASED UPON ACADEMIC MERIT. THE FUNDS ARE AWARDED VIA ADHERENCE TO A MATRIX WHICH DETERMINES THE AMOUNTS BASED UPON GRADE POINT AVERAGE AND SAT SCORES.
Stetson University ensures each scholarship is used for its intended purpose by applying the award amount directly to the recipient's student ledger.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Potential grant recipients complete application forms specific to particular grant funding sources. The Financial Aid office reviews applications to assure that eligibility requirements such as GPA, credit hours, residency and enrollment status are met. Student applicants receive an award letter identifying the funding programs and award amounts are applied as non-cash credit to student accounts receivable to further assure that proceeds are utilized for the intended purposes. The Registrar's office provides information such as withdrawal notices to facilitate the Financial Aid office in periodically monitoring eligibility criteria and assuring that funds not utilized for the intended purpose are returned to the original funding program.

BOSTON COLLEGE AWARDS NEED BASED FINANCIAL AID, INCLUDING GRANTS AND LOANS TO STUDENTS BASED ON ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS SUCH AS FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC PROGRESS. AID IS ADMINISTERED BY THE STUDENT SERVICES OFFICE. STUDENTS AND THEIR PARENTS COMPLETE EXTENSIVE APPLICATION MATERIALS, SUBMIT TAX RETURNS AND OTHER DOCUMENTS TO SUPPORT THEIR CLAIM FOR FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. IN ADDITION, THE COLLEGE MAKES A LIMITED NUMBER OF SCHOLARSHIPS AVAILABLE BASED ON ACADEMIC OR ATHLETIC ACHIEVEMENT. PART III, COLUMN (C) THE CASH GRANT IS REFLECTED ON STUDENTS ACCOUNTS. SOME OF THE GRANTS LISTED MAY HOWEVER, BE PAID DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT VIA ACCOUNTS PAYABLE AS A MONTHLY 'NON SERVICE STIPEND'. THE GRANTS ALSO INCLUDE BOOK VOUCHERS, LOAN FORGIVENESS AND CHILDREN'S CENTER AID.

GRANTS ARE AWARDED IN THE FORM OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TOWARDS THE PAYMENT OF TUITION AND FEES IN WHICH CASE THE GRANT AMOUNTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. OTHER GRANTS ARE AWARDED FOR VARIOUS REASONS TO STUDENTS, FACULTY AND STAFF FOR EDUCATIONAL OR WORK RELATED ACTIVITIES. IN THESE CASES EXPENSE VERIFICATION IS REQUIRED IN THE FORM OF RECEIPTS AND OTHER APPROPRIATE DOCUMENTATION.

A student's eligibility for need-based financial aid is determined on the basis of their annual cost of attendance, which is calculated in accordance with Federal regulations, minus Expected Family Contribution, which is determined in accordance with Federal regulations and University standards. In the event that total aid awarded exceeds direct costs (i.e., costs that are billed by the University), the excess funds are provided to the student and are applicable to educationally-related expenses. The University does not require the student to provide proof (e.g., receipts, cancelled checks, etc.) as to how the funds were used.

GRANTS ISSUED BY IMMACULATA UNIVERSITY ARE PRIMARILY IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIP AND GRANTS AWARDED AS PART OF FINANCIAL AID. FINANCIAL AID GRANTS AWARDED TO STUDENTS ARE DIRECTLY APPLIED BY THE UNIVERSITY TO OFFSET BILLED AMOUNTS (I.E. TUITION) ON THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT, THEREBY REDUCING THE NET BALANCE DUE TO THE UNIVERSITY. STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS ARE ASSESSED ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENTS, FINANCIAL NEEDS, AND SIMILAR STANDARDS.

GRANTS AWARDED TO INDIVIDUALS IN THE UNITED STATES CONSIST OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID MONITORS STUDENTS' ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE FUNDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE UNIVERSITIES' POLICIES AND PROCEDURES AS WELL AS LAWS AND REGULATIONS.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE ESTABLISHED AND APPROVED BY THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES. SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS CAN BE INCREASED THROUGH CONTRIBUTIONS OR BY A BOARD RESOLUTION TO ADD A PORTION OF ANY SURPLUS IN A GIVEN YEAR TO A FUND.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITOR THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 GRANTS TO ORGANIZATIONS IN THE U.S. THE ALLOCATION OF GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS AND MUNICIPALITIES IS DETERMINED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS BY THE SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT FOR FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION & TREASURER. GRANTS TO INDIVIDUALS IN THE U.S. ELIGIBILITY FOR BOWDOIN GRANT ASSISTANCE IS "NEED BASED," DETERMINED THROUGH ANALYSIS OF INCOME, ASSET AND TAX INFORMATION SUBMITTED ON THE COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIP SERVICE/FINANCIAL AID PROFILE, FEDERAL FAFSA AND FEDERAL INCOME TAX RETURNS. THE COLLEGE DOES NOT OFFER MERIT BASED SCHOLARSHIPS OTHER THAN SCHOLARSHIPS TO NATIONAL MERIT SCHOLARS. THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS A FINANCIAL AID OFFICE TO ENSURE THAT AWARDS ARE IN COMPLIANCE WITH ESTABLISHED POLICIES AND PROCEDURES.
THE COLLEGE FOLLOWS THE GUIDELINES FROM THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION
Student eligibility data was matched against scholarship and grant award criteria prior to awarding of funds.

Bryn Mawr College has several sub-recipients of government funds. The College complies with the provisions of Circular A-133 and any statutes governing sub-awards made by and to not-for-profits entities
Students seeking financial aid must file a FAFSA to determine their eligibilityand need for grant and scholarship aid.

THE AMOUNT OF FUNDS DISTRIBUTED IS COMPARED WITH INDIVIDUAL STUDENT ACCOUNTS TO INSURE A BALANCE OF FUNDS. STUDENT FINANCIAL NEED IS EVALUATED TO INSURE STUDENTS DO NOT RECEIVE AN OVER AWARD ACCORDING TO THE GUIDELINES OF THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT. STUDENTS RECEIVING GRANT FUNDS ARE MONITORED FOR ACADEMIC PROGRESS CONCERNING GRADE POINT AVERAGE AND COMPLETED NUMBER OF COURSES ONCE A YEAR.
APPLICATIONS ARE RECEIVED AND GRANTS ARE AWARDED FOR NEED BASED ELIGIBLE STUDENTS AND FOR ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: ALL DISBURSEMENTS MADE BY THIS INSTITUTION IN FURTHERANCE OF ITS EXEMPT PROGRAMS ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY AUTHORIZED COMMITTEES OR INDIVIDUALS. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS AND STUDENT LOANS ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY HARVARD'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICES. IN ADDITION, HARVARD UNIVERSITY IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE PROGRAMMATIC AND FINANCIAL MONITORING OF ITS SPONSORED RESEARCH AWARD SUBRECIPIENTS. PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS AND PROJECT STAFF PERFORM ONGOING REVIEWS OF PROJECT ACTIVITIES. IN ADDITION, ON AN ANNUAL BASIS, UNIVERSITY RESEARCH ADMINISTRATORS REVIEW ALL ACTIVE SUBCONTRACTS AND INQUIRE FURTHER INTO THOSE THAT ARE DEEMED TO REQUIRE CLOSER SCRUTINY IN LIGHT OF A VARIETY OF ATTRIBUTES. UPON IDENTIFICATION OF SUBRECIPIENTS THAT MANDATE CLOSER SCRUTINY, HARVARD IMPLEMENTS ADDITIONAL MONITORING ACTIONS TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH SUBAGREEMENT PERFORMANCE, FINANCIAL TERMS AND CONDITIONS, AND WITH ALL APPLICABLE FEDERAL RULES AND REGULATIONS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: ALL DISBURSEMENTS MADE BY THIS INSTITUTION IN FURTHERANCE OF ITS EXEMPT PROGRAMS ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY AUTHORIZED COMMITTEES OR INDIVIDUALS. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS AND STUDENT LOANS ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY HARVARD'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICES. IN ADDITION, HARVARD UNIVERSITY IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE PROGRAMMATIC AND FINANCIAL MONITORING OF ITS SPONSORED RESEARCH AWARD SUBRECIPIENTS. UPON IDENTIFICATION OF SUBRECIPIENTS THAT MANDATE CLOSER SCRUTINY, HARVARD IMPLEMENTS ADDITIONAL MONITORING ACTIONS TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH SUBAGREEMENT PERFORMANCE, FINANCIAL TERMS AND CONDITIONS, AND WITH ALL APPLICABLE FEDERAL RULES AND REGULATIONS.
ALL FINANCIAL AID THAT IS AWARDED IS CREDITED TO THE TUITION BILLING FOR THE STUDENT. ALL AID IS USED TO REDUCE THE TUITION PAYABLE.

BERKELEY DIVINITY SCHOOL MAINTAINS CERTAIN RESTRICTED ENDOWMENTS AND IS THE BENEFICIARY OF CERTAIN THIRD-PARTY TRUSTS FOR THE PURPOSE OF PROVIDING SCHOLARSHIP AID TO STUDENTS. THE INCOME FROM THESE FUNDS IS PAID DIRECTLY TO YALE UNIVERSITY PER THE TERMS OF THE AFFILIATION AGREEMENT. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE OF YALE DIVINITY SCHOOL IS RESPONSIBLE FOR DETERMINING THE FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC MERIT OF STUDENTS, AND FOR MAKING ALL SCHOLARSHIP/FINANCIAL AID AWARDS. GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO FACULTY AND STUDENTS FROM OUTSIDE AGENCIES AND THE FUNDS ARE SENT DIRECTLY TO THE UNIVERSITY TO BE MANAGED. ORIGINAL RECEIPTS ARE SUBMITTED TO PROVIDE SUBSTANTIATION OF EXPENSES AND FINAL REPORTS ARE FORWARDED TO THE SPONSORS. SEE SCHEDULE O.
Financial aid assistance is awarded based on US Federal, State, and Private guidelines as required by the corresponding type of assistance.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: Scholarships are provided to students based on needs assessments and/or performance. Once the student has been approved to receive the grant, the amount is credited to the student's Baker College account. The College's Financial Aid office monitors the student to make sure the award stays in compliance. If the student does not continue to meet the grant requirements, the student's account may be reduced. Grants and other assistance to organizations in the United States are budgeted each year by the Baker College Campus. The Campus President determines which organization benefits from a grant based on the community's needs. If the grant exceeds the budget, the Board of Regents must approve the funding. These grants and assistance are awarded to other tax-exempt organizations to be used in any way the recipients see fit to further their mission and tax exempt purpose; the use of these funds is not monitored by the Baker College campus.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: Scholarships are provided to students based on needs assessments and/or performance. Once the student has been approved to receive the grant, the amount is credited to the student's Baker College account. The College's Financial Aid office monitors the student to make sure the award stays in compliance. If the student does not continue to meet the grant requirements, the student's account may be reduced. The Campus President determines which organization benefits from a grant based on the community's needs. If the grant exceeds the budget, the Board of Regents must approve the funding. These grants and assistance are awarded to other tax-exempt organizations to be used in any way the recipients see fit to further their mission and tax exempt purpose; the use of these funds is not monitored by the Baker College campus.

GRANTS TO INDIVIDUALS COVER TUITION FOR STUDENTS ATTENDING THE COLLEGE. TRANSPORTATION AND MEDICAL EXPENSES ARE GENERALLY PAID DIRECTLY ON BEHALF OF GRANTEES. STUDENTS WHO MEET ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS ARE PROVIDED GRANTS FOR DAILY ESSENTIALS. GRANTS TO DOMESTIC ORGANIZATIONS ARE MADE ON A REIMBURSEMENT BASIS AFTER SUBMISSION OF RECEIPTS.
IPS monitors its students to ensure the funds are appropriately used.
THE SCHOOL PROVIDES GRANTS IN THE FORM OF CREDITS AGAINST TUITION INVOICES. GRANT FUNDS ARE NOT ACTUALLY DISBURSED FROM THE SCHOOL.

THE COLLEGE FIRST INSPECTS CHARGES TO ENSURE THAT THEY ARE APPROPRIATE AND ALLOWABLE. THIS INCLUDES CHECKING CLERICAL ACCURACY AND CHECKING COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE AGENCY AND FEDERAL GUIDELINES. THE COLLEGE ALSO MAKES SURE THAT EXPENSE FALLS WITHIN THE REQUIRED CATEGORIES AND BUDGET AMOUNTS. THE COLLEGE SETS UP A SEPARATE GENERAL LEDGER ACCOUNT FOR EACH GRANT THAT IS RECEIVED IN ORDER TO PROVIDE COMPLETE DOCUMENTATION AND TRACK EXPENSES.

THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIP ASSISTANCE TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS THROUGH THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID MONITORS THE APPROPRIATENESS OF THE AWARDS AND THESE AMOUNTS ARE APPLIED TO EACH STUDENT'S ACCOUNT.

WITH RESPECT TO SPONSORED PROJECT ACTIVITY SUBCONTRACTED TO OTHER ENTITIES, THE UNIVERSITY'S POLICY AND PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING SUB RECIPIENT AWARDS ("SUBWARDS") ARE INTENDED TO ESTABLISH APPROPRIATE AND EFFECTIVE MECHANISMS TO PROMOTE COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL AND NON-FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS AND CONTRACTUAL ARRANGEMENTS, INCLUDING THE PROPER MONITORING AND STEWARDSHIP OF AWARDED FUNDS. PROPER MONITORING OF A SUBAWARD ENSURES THAT AWARDED FUNDS ARE USED FOR AUTHORIZED PURPOSES, PERFORMANCE GOALS ARE MET AND THE SUB RECIPIENT IS IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF THE SUB RECIPIENT AGREEMENT. SUB RECIPIENT MONITORING PROCEDURES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES: A FORMAL PRE-QUALIFICATION PROCESS FOR SUB RECIPIENTS, PRE-AWARD AND POST-AWARD MONITORING OF SUB RECIPIENTS TO REVIEW THE FINANCIAL STATUS AND MANAGEMENT CONTROLS, COMPLIANCE CERTIFICATIONS, REVIEW OF COMPLIANCE WITH REGULATIONS RELATIVE TO THE USE OF HUMAN SUBJECTS AND ANIMALS, IDENTIFICATION AND MANAGEMENT OF ANY CONFLICT OF INTEREST WITH A SUB RECIPIENT ENTITY, AND A REVIEW OF PERTINENT OTHER ORGANIZATION INFORMATION. IN ACCORDANCE WITH THESE PROCEDURES, THE UNIVERSITY REVIEWS THE SUB RECIPIENT'S ADMINISTRATION, FINANCIAL STATEMENTS, BILLINGS, SCIENTIFIC PROGRESS, TECHNICAL REPORTS AND DELIVERABLES OF AN ACTIVE SUBAWARD REGULARLY AND CONDUCTS ON-GOING RISK ASSESSMENTS AS WELL AS QUARTERLY QUALITY ASSURANCE REVIEWS ON RANDOMLY SELECTED SUBAWARDS. IN ADDITION TO A MONTHLY DEPARTMENTAL REVIEW, THE UNIVERSITY MONITORS A SUB RECIPIENT'S COMPLIANCE WITH THE TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF THE SUBAWARD ANNUALLY AND UPON CLOSEOUT OF THE SUB RECIPIENT AGREEMENT. IF ANY OF THESE MONITORING PROCEDURES RESULT IN FINDINGS, THE UNIVERSITY WILL TAKE CORRECTIVE ACTION AS NECESSARY. THE PROCEDURES SERVE TO ENSURE THAT THE SUBAWARDS ARE USED FOR PROPER PURPOSES AND NOT DIVERTED FROM THEIR INTENDED USE.
A SUBAWARD IS AN AWARD OF FINANCIAL SUPPORT FROM THE UNIVERSITY TO A QUALIFIED THIRD PARTY PRIMARILY TO PERFORM RESEARCH AND OTHER RELATED PROGRAMMATIC EFFORTS UNDER A SPONSORED RESEARCH PROJECT.

THE AMOUNTS REPORTED IN PART III REPRESENT AN ESTIMATE OF TOTAL AWARDS FOR THE FISCAL YEAR ENDED JUNE 30, 2015 BASED ON INFORMATION PROVIDED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S UNDERGRADUATE, GRADUATE AND PROFESSIONAL SCHOOLS. SOME STUDENTS RECEIVED MORE THAN ONE AWARD DURING THE FISCAL YEAR ENDED JUNE 30, 2015.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS BASED ON SUPERIOR ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED. INDIVIDUALS RECEIVING AWARDS FROM JOHN CARROLL UNIVERSITY ARE CHOSEN BASED UPON OBJECTIVE AND NON-DISCRIMINATORY CRITERIA WHICH ARE CONSISTENT WITH THE OVERALL TAX-EXEMPT PURPOSE OF THE UNIVERSITY.

APPLICANTS FOR FINANCIAL AID MUST FILL OUT THE FEDERALLY MANDATED FAFSA FORM. THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION ESTABLISHES A LEVEL OF NEED FOR AID BASED ON THE FAMILY'S TOTAL FINANCIAL SITUATION. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AT COLORADO HEIGHTS UNIVERSITY DETERMINES A STUDENT'S FINANCIAL AID AWARD AFTER REVIEWING THE RESULTS OF THE FAFSA APPLICATION. APPLICATIONS ARE REVIEWED AS THEY ARE COMPLETED AND FUNDS ARE AWARDED ON A FIRST-COME, FIRST-SERVED BASIS TO STUDENTS WITH THE GREATEST NEED. FINANCIAL AID AWARDS MAY INCLUDE A COMBINATION OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS. FINANCIAL AID IS CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S BILL EACH TERM AFTER THE REGISTRAR CONFIRMS ENROLLMENT STATUS AND THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE DETERMINES ELIGIBILITY.

THE COLLEGE HAS A LIMITED AMOUNT OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE THAT IS AVAILABLE TO QUALIFYING STUDENTS THROUGH ITS SCHOLARSHIP FUND. AWARDS ARE MADE ANNUALLY AND ARE DIVIDED OVER THE FALL AND SPRING TERM ENROLLMENTS. GENERAL QUALIFICATION REQUIREMENTS OF SOME OF THE GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED BY THE COLLEGE ARE AS FOLLOWS: CHRISTIAN WORKERS GRANT - FULL-TIME STUDENTS WHOSE PARENTS ARE IN FULL-TIME CHRISTIAN MINISTRY ARE ELIGIBLE FOR THIS GRANT. TRINITY COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIP - NEW FULL-TIME STUDENTS WHO HAVE A MINIMUM ACT COMPOSITE SCORE OF 19 OR A MINIMUM COMBINED SAT SCORE OF 950 ARE ELIGIBLE FOR THIS SCHOLARSHIP. TRINITY COLLEGE GRANT - THIS GRANT IS AWARDED TO NEW OR CONTINUING FULL-TIME STUDENTS ON THE BASIS OF NEED. PAST OR EXPECTED STUDENT LEADERSHIP IS CONSIDERED. THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS RECORDS DOCUMENTING THE SCHOLARSHIP CRITERIA, THE RECIPIENT SELECTION PROCESS, THE AMOUNT REWARDED, AND THE QUALIFIED EXPENSES FOR WHICH THE FUNDS ARE USED FOR EACH SCHOLARSHIP GRANTED.

The College awards merit-based scholarships to incoming freshmen as well as continuing students. Scholarships awarded to freshmen are determined by the admissions committee. Eligibility for these scholarships is determined through a combination of undergraduate cumulative science GPA, ranking of the college attended and the score achieved on the MCAT, a standardized medical school admissions test. For continuing students, the top five students with a cumulative GPA of 3.7 or higher for each grade, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th year students, receive these scholarships. The College does not need to monitor the use of scholarship funds as those amounts are directly spent to defray the cost of tuition. There is no opportunity for the funds to be directed to another purpose.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE UNITED STATES THE DEVELOPMENT OFFICE SERVES AS THE COORDINATING DEPARTMENT FOR ALL TYPES OF FUND RAISING PROGRAMS AND FOR SOLICITATION OF GIFTS. SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS/RESTRICTIONS ARE MADE AND MONITORED BY ADMISSIONS OFFICE AND DEANS. THE ACCOUNTING STAFF RECORDS THE TRANSACTIONS IN SEPARATE GENERAL LEDGER ACCOUNTS.

The College has established programs for each type of scholarship and awards funds according to the parameters of each program and as funding is available. The scholarships and grants are awarded to students to be used for educational expenses at the College including tuition, fees, and books. The awards are allocated directly to each student's account.
Grants awarded based on merit.

ORGANIZATION'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANTS FUNDS INSIDE THE US SCHEDULE I, PART IV PART I, LINE 2, THE UNIVERSITY OF CHICAGO FOLLOWS THESE PROCEDURES TO MONITOR THE USE OF GRANTS FUNDS IN THE UNITED STATES. THE UNIVERSITY WILL PERFORM A RISK ASSESSMENT AT THE PROPOSAL STAGE BEFORE FUNDING IS APPROVED. UNIVERSITY DEPARTMENT ADMINISTRATORS AND THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR WILL REVIEW INVOICES AND CERTIFY AS TO ALLOWABILITY AND APPROPRIATENESS OF CHARGES. CENTRAL SPONSORED AWARD ACCOUNTING WILL ALSO PERFORM A REVIEW THAT THE EXPENDITURES FALL WITHIN THE CONTRACT AMOUNT AND PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE.

ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID IS DETERMINED BY FEDERAL DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION REGULATIONS AND UNIVERSITY POLICIES GOVERNING FINANCIAL AID PROGRAMS. USING THE INFORMATION PROVIDED ON THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA), THE CSS PROFILE AND OTHER REQUIRED DOCUMENTATION, THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID WILL CALCULATE THE AMOUNT OF FAMILY RESOURCES A FAMILY IS EXPECTED TO CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS A STUDENT'S EDUCATIONAL COSTS. THESE RESOURCES, KNOWN AS THE EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION (EFC), ARE SUBTRACTED FROM A STANDARD BUDGET OF EDUCATIONAL EXPENSES, OR COST OF ATTENDANCE. THE COST OF ATTENDANCE INCLUDES DIRECT COSTS, FOR WHICH THE STUDENT RECEIVES A BILLING STATEMENT (TUITION, FEES AND ON-CAMPUS ROOM AND BOARD) AS WELL AS ESTIMATED INDIRECT COSTS NOT BILLED BY THE UNIVERSITY (BOOKS, SUPPLIES, PERSONAL EXPENSES, TRANSPORTATION AND OFF-CAMPUS ROOM AND BOARD). THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN THE EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION (EFC) AND THE COST OF ATTENDANCE (COA) IS THE FAMILY'S MAXIMUM ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED ASSISTANCE. TO REMAIN ELIGIBLE FOR FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID, A STUDENT MUST MEET THE MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS OF SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS AS PUBLISHED IN THE UNDERGRADUATE CATALOG.

The Need-based Grant is funded by Alaska Bible College and utilized to assist students with a financial need. To qualify, a student must be enrolled full-time (12+ credits) in a degree or certificate program, must maintain a 2.0 GPA, and must maintain a current financial account with the Business Office. Students complete and submit an application along with financial information to help a committee determine each student's financial need. Decisions are made by the committee and awards are given after the 6-week grade check each semester.

ALL GRANTS ARE INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID AND APPLIED DIRECTLY TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS. IT IS A CONTINUAL PROCESS IN WHICH WE AWARD STUDENT AID WITHIN FEDERAL GUIDELINES AT THE INITIAL AWARDING TIME PERIOD. IF ANY CHANGES TO A STUDENT'S STATUS OCCUR, WE REVIEW THE STUDENT'S AID PACKAGE COMPONENTS TO ENSURE THAT ANY/ALL ADJUSTMENTS MADE MAINTAIN COMPLIANCE WITH TITLE IV FUND RULES. WE ALSO PERFORM SPOT CHECKS THROUGHOUT THE SEMESTER TO DOUBLE CHECK THAT AID ELIGIBILITY CALCULATIONS ARE MET.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedure for Monitoring Use of Grant Funds Inside U.S.
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 THE UNIVERSITY GRANT POLICY IS CONTAINED IN ALL ADMISSIONS MATERIAL, IN THE UNIVERSITY CATALOG, AND CAN ALSO BE FOUND ON THE UNIVERSITY'S WEBSITE. The University uses a matrix model to award merit-based scholarships aid at the time a student is admitted to the University. The amount awarded is based on the student's highest SAT or ACT scores and weighted cumulative grade point average. Additional financial aid awards are determined in conjunction with a student's academic and the family's financial information to determine the exact size and composition of the final financial aid packages. The typical financial aid package consists of scholarships, grants, loans, and an opportunity to participate in a work study program which supplements each family's contribution to the total cost of education. The awards are determined based upon the results of the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) containing information provided by the student and parents.

Shorter Univerity participates in the student financial assistance programs through the U.S. Department of Education. Funds are awarded and applied to student accounts based on the Department of Education guidelines set forth by the Title IV programs.

NORTHWEST NAZARENE UNIVERSITY MONITORS THE USE OF ITS GRANT FUNDS AS REQUIRED BY THE INDIVIDUAL GRANT PROGRAMS AND DONOR CRITERIA ESTABLISHED AT THE TIME OF THE ORIGINAL DONATION. THESE ARE MONITORED THROUGH THE ANNUAL AUDITING PROCESS AS WELL AS THROUGH FEDERAL AND STATE REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. ISIR/FAFSA AND HIGH SCHOOL TRANSCRIPTS SHOWING ELIGIBILITY FOR GRANTS ARE MAINTAINED IN THE STUDENT'S FILE FOR A PERIOD OF 7 YEARS AFTER THE STUDENT WITHDRAWS OR FINISHES THEIR PROGRAMS. GRANT AMOUNTS APPEAR ON THE AWARD LETTER IN THE FILE AS WELL AS ON THE INDIVIDUAL'S FINANCIAL AID RECORD IN THE DATABASE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY'S MONITORING PROCEDURES INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING STEPS: 1, PERFORM A RISK ASSESSMENT ON SUB-RECIPIENT 2, PERFORM SITE VISITS TO REVIEW FINANCIAL AND PROGRAMMATIC RECORDS 3, ENSURE THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR HAS REGULAR CONTRACTS 4, ENSURE A CURRENT CERTIFICATION OR A-133 AUDIT IS PERFORMED AND THE RELATED REPORT RECEIVED AND REVIEWED.

ALL STUDENTS APPLYING FOR FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID ("FAFSA"). THE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID OFFICE REVIEWS THE RESULTS OF THE FAFSA, WHICH DICTATES WHAT AND HOW MUCH FEDERAL FUNDING THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE FOR. IF THE STUDENT IS DETERMINED TO BE IN COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FEDERAL REGULATIONS, AS DETERMINED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION, THE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS THE STUDENT THE APPROPRIATE FUNDING. STUDENT FILES REGARDING ELIGIBILITY ARE MAINTAINED BY THE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S.: SCHOLARSHIPS AND OTHER TYPES OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE ARE MONITORED BY PROCEDURES THAT INSURE INDIVIDUALS RECEIVING DISBURSEMENTS ARE QUALIFIED TO RECEIVE THE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE BASED ON THE INSTITUTION'S ASSESSMENT OF FINANCIAL NEED, ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, AND OTHER SIMILAR NEEDS.

THE ORGANIZATION SPONSORS THE COURAGEOUS JOURNEY PROGRAM ESTABLISHED BY MICHIGAN ASSOCIATION OF SCHOOL ADMINISTRATORS WITH AN ANNUAL FIXED CONTRIBUTION AMOUNT TO BE USED EXCLUSIVELY FOR THE PROMOTION OF THE PROGRAM. THE ORGANIZATION IS CLOSELY INVOLVED WITH THE EXECUTION OF THE PROGRAM.

Our financial aid office awards scholarships to students based on submitted FAFSA data and academic performance. The financial aid office is responsible for ensuring compliance with all relevant state and federal requirements relative to grant-based aid.

A budget based on the grant proposal is entered into the accounting system. Purchases are monitored and approved by the controller and assistant controller. Wages paid are supported by time and effort reports. The grants coordinator reviews grant expenditure reports monthly. Quarterly financial reports are submitted for federal grants.
SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GENERALLY APPLIED TO STUDENT ACCOUNT BALANCES THROUGH THE COLLEGE'S BURSAR'S OFFICE.

There is a publication of available scholarships and the criteria to qualify for each one. Students complete an application indicating which scholarship(s) they are applying for. These applications are reviewed by the registrar's office during the registration process and qualifying students are determined. Of the $121,674 of financial assistance awarded during the FYE 5/31/15, $120,574 were scholarships which were applied as a credit against the students' tuition. The remaining $1,100 of financial assistance was distributed as cash to students who qualified for scholarships funded by outside sources.

Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 The University awards need-based and merit-based grants and scholarships, as well as various federal, state, and private scholarship, loan, and student work programs as part of its overall financial aid program. The University Financial Aid office is responsible for management of all financial aid programs.

BETHANY LUTHERAN COLLEGE OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS TO HELP REDUCE THEIR OUT-OF-POCKET TUITION COSTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE OF THIS FORM MUST MEET SPECIFIC CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS WHETHER PUT IN PLACE BY THE COLLEGE OR BY DONORS OF RESTRICTED FUNDS.

Monitoring the use of grant funds Y The assistance provided to governmental entities is in the form of donations in-lieu of real estate taxes. The amounts are intended to help fund services normally provided by the entities.

All scholarships are awarded based upon specific criteria maintained by the financial aid office. Requirements for receiving scholarships depend upon other factors, such as grade point average, family income or economic need. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors the eligibility guidelines to ensure compliance. The College also undergoes the required OMB A-133 audit annually.

IN ORDER TO BE AWARDED INSTITUTIONAL FUNDS, STUDENTS MUST BE ENROLLED FULL-TIME AND MAKING SATISFACTORY PROGRESS. UNDERGRADUATE ON-CAMPUS STUDENTS COMPLETE A CROWN FINANCIAL AID APPLICATION TO HELP DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS, GRANTS AND DISCOUNTS. SCHOLARSHIPS, GRANTS AND DISCOUNTS ARE AWARDED BASED ON MERIT AND SPECIFIC CRITERIA. THE CROWN GRANT IS NEED-BASED USING PERCENTAGES AND MINIMUM AWARD ADAPTED FROM NOEL-LEVITZ.

All grants represent internal transfers of funds from endowment or other accounts to a revenue account for tuition payments. No funds are distributed directly to individuals. Merit Scholarships and SMU Grant levels are based on the student's entering GPA and need. For incoming freshmen, test scores are also a factor. Provided that each student maintains the required GPA, does not exceed the maximum timeframe for institutional aid and submits either a FAFSA or FAFSA waiver by the March 1st deadline, the student will be eligible for his/her merit scholarship or SMU grant.

ExplntnTxt: A list of scholarship recipients is on file at the institution and is available upon request. Although there may be recipients who are related to persons having an interest in the institution, such recipients are selected on an equal, objectively determinable basis with other recipients. Saint Mary's College is committed to making it possible for qualified students to enroll at the college regardless of financial circumstances. As part of this commitment, Saint Mary's College offers various levels of academic scholarships, need-based scholarships and institutional grants. Academic scholarship recipients are selected at the time of admission, on the basis of their academic achievements in high school. Need-based scholarships are named for a specific donor or group, and are awarded as part of need-based institutional grant assistance, in accordance with the specific requirements of the scholarship donor. Institutional grants are awarded primarily on financial need as the College is committed to making a Saint Mary's education a possibility for students who demonstrate financial need; each student who applies for financial aid receives consideration for grant assistance. All students receiving scholarships are judged worthy by the institution's assessment on the basis of academic achievement, financial need or other similar standards. Criteria for all scholarships is published and made available to all students and their families. Grant funds/scholarships are credited directly to a student's account to ensure they are used appropriately and for their intended purpose.

STUDENTS MUST SUBMIT THEIR FAFSA FEDERAL FORM TO DOCUMENT THEIR NEED FOR FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID. SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2: GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE REPRESENT STUDENT FINANCIAL AID. WHEN AWARDIng AID, CHAPMAN UNIVERSITY FOLLOWS ALL LAWS AND REGULATIONS OF FEDERAL AND STATE OF CALIFORNIA AID PROGRAMS. FOR MORE INFORMATION, VISIT OUR WEBSITE AT WWW.CHAPMAN.EDU.

THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MAINTAINS ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS AND MONITORS GRANTING OF AWARDS TO STUDENTS AND FOLLOWS U.S. FEDERAL AID REGULATIONS AND ALL STATES' REGULATIONS FOR GRANTS TO ITS STUDENTS.

EACH GRANT IS ASSIGNED A SEPARATE DEPARTMENT ACCOUNT NUMBER. REPORTS ARE THEN PRINTED WHICH SHOW ALL FUNDS RECEIVED AND DISBURSED. THESE GRANT REPORTS ARE PRINTED ON A MONTHLY BASIS BY THE PERSON RESPONSIBLE FOR THE GRANT. THE ACCOUNTING DEPARTMENT ALSO PRINTS GRANT REPORTS ON A MONTHLY BASIS AS A CHECK THAT DISBURSEMENTS ARE NOT GREATER THAN FUNDS RECEIVED AND THAT FUNDS ARE BEING DISBURSED FOR GRANTS APPROVED.
ALL SCHOLARSHIPS & GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS ATTENDING STERLING COLLEGE. THESE SCHOLARSHIPS & GRANTS ARE NON-CASH AWARDS, REQUIRING THE AWARDS TO BE USED AS A DIRECT REDUCTION IN TUITION COST.
- A committee is assigned to consider student applicants and assign scholarships on a non-discriminatory basis.

A LIST OF SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS IS ON FILE AT THE INSTITUTION AND IS AVAILABLE ON REQUEST. ALL RECIPIENTS ARE SELECTED ON AN EQUAL, OBJECTIVELY DETERMINABLE BASIS ACCORDING TO THE REQUIREMENTS FOR EACH SCHOLARSHIP AND/OR AID FOR WHICH THE RECIPIENT IS APPLYING. THAT IS, ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE INSTITUTION'S ASSESSMENT ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS AND FINANCIAL AID HAVE ACADEMIC REQUIREMENTS WHICH THE RECIPIENTS NEED TO MAINTAIN TO CONTINUE RECEIVING AID. STUDENTS DO NOT RECEIVE CASH GRANTS. RATHER, ALL FINANCIAL AID IS TREATED AS A REDUCTION TO TUITION.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: THE GRANTS ARE SUBJECT TO FEDERAL REGULATIONS. THE ORGANIZATION HAS A MONITORING POLICY FOR THE GRANTS, WHEN THEY ARE AWARDED A BUDGET IS APPROVED ESTABLISHING THE ALLOWABLE EXPENSES UNDER THE GRANT. IN THE CASE THAT FUNDS WERE ASSIGNED TO ANOTHER PERSON OR ENTITY THROUGH SUBCONTRACTING, WE HAVE A WRITTEN POLICY ESTABLISHING HOW TO MONITOR THE AGREEMENT WITH THE OTHER ENTITY OR PERSON. ALONG THE MONITORING WE PERFORM, WE ENSURE THAT SUB-RECIPIENTS HAVE MET THE REQUIREMENTS TO PERFORM AN INDEPENDENT FINANCIAL AUDIT IN ACCORDANCE WITH OMB CIRCULAR A-133. UNDER THE AFOREMENTIONED STANDARDS THE SUB-RECIPIENT WILL NEED TO PROVIDE US A DOCUMENT INDICATING THAT THEY MEET THE REQUIREMENTS ESTABLISHED AND PROVIDE A COPY OF THE AUDITOR'S REPORT FROM SUCH A-133. WE ALSO PERFORM SITE VISITS, REQUIRE THE SUB-RECIPIENT TO SUBMIT REPORTS AMONG OTHER MONITORING TECHNIQUES WE ENFORCE IN ORDER TO MONITOR PERFORMANCE. FURTHERMORE, WE HAVE A COMPLIANCE OFFICE THAT APPROVES EVERY DISBURSEMENT AFTER VERIFYING THAT IT MEETS REGULATIONS. AFTERWARDS, THE BUDGET DEPARTMENT IS IN CHARGE OF APPROVING EXPENSES, ACCORDING TO THE PREVIOUSLY APPROVED BUDGET BY THE AGENCY THAT GRANTS THE FUNDS.

THE STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE DETERMINED BY THE COLLEGE ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER OBJECTIVE STANDARDS. ALL AWARDED FUNDS ARE TREATED AS REDUCTIONS TO TUITION. NO FUNDS ARE DISBURSED TO INDIVIDUALS.

ExplntnTxt: SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2: GRANTS ARE PUT INTO A SEPARATE AND UNIQUE FUND AND THE EXPENDITURES ARE MONITORED AGAINST THE PROPOSAL AND AWARD. WESTERN UNIVERSITY MANAGES AN EXTENSIVE FINANCIAL AID PROGRAM TO ENSURE THAT A HIGHLY QUALIFIED AND DIVERSE POPULATION IS ABLE TO MATRICULATE AND CONTINUE TO GRADUATION. THE ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS TAKE TWO MAJOR FORMS: MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS AND NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID. THE STUDENT FIRST APPLIES FOR ASSISTANCE, AND THEN BASED ON THE GRANT CRITERIA (FINANCIAL AND ENROLLMENT), THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT MONITORS THE AMOUNTS GIVEN BY THE GRANT. GRANT AND SCHOLARSHIP AWARD COMMITTEES AWARD THE RECIPIENTS.

THE UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS A SEPERATE GRANT DEPARTMENT WHICH INCLUDES A DIRECTOR AND MULTIPLE GRANT ANALYSTS. THE GRANTS DEPARTMENT IS RESPONSIBLE FOR COMPLIANCE WITH ALL CONTRACTUAL AND FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS. THE DEPARTMENT IS ALSO RESPONSIBLE FOR MAKING DETERMINATIONS REGARDING ELIGIBILITY FOR AWARD RECIPIENTS AND SUB-GRANTEE RECIPIENTS.
The University of the Incarnate Word determines whether an individual qualifies for scholarships or grants by an application process that does not discriminate.

NEED BASED AID IS AWARDED BASED ON FEDERAL AND/OR STATE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS AND INSTITUTIONAL AID IS AWARDED ACCORDING TO INSTITUTIONAL POLICY. AMOUNTS OF AID AWARDED ARE IN COMPLIANCE WITH GOVERNING REGULATIONS OR INSTITUTIONAL POLICY. IN COMPLIANCE WITH TITLE IV REGULATIONS, TOTAL AID FROM ALL SOURCES CANNOT EXCEED NEED OR THE ANNUAL COST OF TUITION, REGARDLESS OF THE LEVEL OF NEED. GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO A STUDENT ACCOUNT AND FUNDS ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED DIRECTLY TO STUDENTS. OVERPAYMENT OR CREDIT BALANCES OF STUDENT ACCOUNT BALANCES ARE ANALYZED PRIOR TO DISTRIBUTING REFUNDS TO STUDENTS TO ENSURE THAT GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE PROPERLY AWARDED AND UTILIZED FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES.

ALL FINANCIAL AID RECIPIENTS ARE SELECTED ON AN EQUAL OBJECTIVELY DETERMINABLE BASIS WITH OTHER RECIPIENTS. THAT IS, ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BASED ON THE UNIVERSITY'S ASSESSMENT OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS. A LIST OF RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS IS MAINTAINED IN THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.
THE MONIES ARE CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNTS AND NEVER EXCEED THE COSTS CHARGED.

THE COLLEGE HAS A FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT WHICH FOLLOWS THE FEDERAL LAWS REGARDING STUDENT FINANCIAL AID ELIGIBILITY. RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED FOR ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING AID AND COLLEGE GRANTS. STUDENT GRANTS ARE POSTED TO STUDENT BILLING ACCOUNTS AS A PART OF THEIR FINANCIAL AID PACKAGE. THE COLLEGE DOES NOT PROVIDE GRANTS TO ANY OTHER ORGANIZATIONS OR INDIVIDUALS.

The financial aid planning office requires students to complete the free application for federal student aid (FAFSA) form to determine eligibility for federal, state and institutional grants, scholarships and loans. This is an equitable formula that measures all assets consistently. In addition to this form, the institution does require some other guidelines in the event that funds are offered based on certain academic credentials or performance in a university sponsored activity or athletic event. These credentials are clearly stated in the university catalog and the university website. Enrollment and eligibility are monitred by the university.
ALL SCHOLARSHIPS & GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS ATTENDING MCPHERSON COLLEGE. THESE SCHOLARSHIPS & GRANTS ARE NON-CASH AWARDS, REQUIRING THE AWARDS TO BE USED AS A DIRECT REDUCTION IN TUITION COST.

Stipends and research fellowships are funds paid to offset living expenses for trainees while they further their education at Rockefeller. These amounts are not considered salary or wages given in consideration for specific job duties nor are they grants given in anticipation of specific scientific achievements on the individuals parts. There is no restriction on the use of the funds once they are received by the trainees.

FOR FEDERAL AND STATE FINANCIAL AID GRANTS, INDIVIDUAL FAFSA AND PERSONAL TAX RETURNS ARE VERIFIED FOR RECIPIENT ELIGIBILITY. SEVERAL LAYERS OF SUPERVISORY APPROVALS ARE BUILT INTO THE INTERNAL FINANCIAL AID PROCESS. FOR OTHER FEDERALLY FUNDED GRANTS (NIH, ETC.), ACTIVITY IS ADMINISTERED BY A DEDICATED EMPLOYEE, SUBJECT TO SEVERAL LAYERS OF SUPERVISORY REVIEW AND APPROVAL. PAYROLL COSTS AND OTHER ALLOCATED EXPENDITURES ARE DOCUMENTED AND REVIEWED BY THE FINANCE DEPT. AS WELL AT EXTERNAL AUDITORS.

INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. ELIGIBILITY IS EVALUATED USING THE FAFSA AS WELL AS SAT AND ACT SCORES FOR NEW INCOMING STUDENTS, OR GPA FOR TRANSFERRING STUDENTS. PAPER COPIES OF THE FAFSA, SAT AND ACT SCORES, AND GPAS ARE KEPT IN PAPER FORMAT FOR ONE YEAR BEFORE BEING STORED PERMANENTLY IN AN ELECTRONIC FORMAT.

EACH STUDENT IS REVIEWED BY TWO OR THREE INDIVIDUALS IN THE AWARDING PROCESS. STUDENTS ARE THEN AWARDED GRANT FUNDS BASED ON FEDERAL, STATE, AND INSTITUTIONAL REGULATIONS, GUIDELINES AND INSTITUTIONAL MATRIX. PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING FUNDS ARE ALSO BUILT INTO THE COMPUTER AWARDING SOFTWARE.
Grants are administered through the Office of Financial Aid for all Federal, State and Institutional aid programs.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: ORGANIZATION'S PROCEDURE FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 THE COLLEGE'S OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID IS RESPONSIBLE FOR AWARDING AND MONITORING ALL FEDERAL AND STATE GRANT ASSISTANCE. STUDENTS APPLY FOR FINANCIAL AID BY COMPLETING A FAFSA FORM WHICH CAPTURES THE DATA REQUIRED DETERMINING ELIGIBILITY BASED ON FEDERAL AND/OR STATE REGULATIONS. DOCUMENTATION TO SUPPORT ELIGIBILITY IS KEPT FOR EACH INDIVIDUAL STUDENT ON FILE IN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. WHEN FUNDS ARE AWARDED, STUDENT ELIGIBILITY IS MONITORED THROUGH THE COLLEGE'S OPERATIONAL SYSTEM AID MODULE TO ENSURE THERE ARE NO CHANGES IN STATUS THAT MIGHT AFFECT THEIR ONGOING ELIGIBILITY. TOTAL GRANT FUNDS AWARDED ARE TRACKED TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH AUTHORIZED AMOUNTS FROM THE FUNDING AGENCY. THE COLLEGE ALSO IS REQUIRED TO SUBMIT AN ANNUAL INDEPENDENT A-133 AUDIT TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FEDERAL REGULATIONS FOR GRANT ASSISTANCE. THE SCHOLARSHIP OFFICE IS RESPONSIBLE FOR AWARDING AND MONITORING ALL INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIP ASSISTANCE. CONTINUING STUDENTS APPLY FOR SCHOLARSHIP AID BY COMPLETING A SCHOLARSHIP APPLICATION FORM WHICH CAPTURES THE DATA REQUIRED TO DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY BASED ON INSTITUTIONAL GUIDELINES. ENTERING STUDENTS ARE AUTOMATICALLY CONSIDERED FOR SCHOLARSHIP BASED ON THE COLLEGE'S AUDITION AND INTERVIEW PROCESS. DOCUMENTATION TO SUPPORT ELIGIBILITY IS KEPT FOR EACH INDIVIDUAL STUDENT ON FILE IN THE SCHOLARSHIP OFFICE. WHEN FUNDS ARE AWARDED, STUDENT ELIGIBILITY IS MONITORED THROUGH THE COLLEGE'S OPERATIONAL SYSTEM SCHOLARSHIP MODULE TO ENSURE THERE ARE NO CHANGES IN STATUS THAT MIGHT AFFECT THEIR ONGOING ELIGIBILITY. TOTAL SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS AWARDED ARE TRACKED TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH BUDGETED AMOUNTS. THE SCHOLARSHIP OFFICE REVIEWS ALL AWARDS EACH SEMESTER TO DETERMINE THAT THE STUDENT IS STILL ELIGIBLE FOR THE SCHOLARSHIP.
