THE AWARDS ARE APPLIED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT.THE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED AND USED TO PAY FOR THE EDUCATIONAL COSTS AS DESCRIBED BY THE ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS.
The college manages Federal Tile IV grant funds in accordance with Title IV regulations. The college undergoes an annual A-133 audit to monitor the use of the funds.

THE UNIVERSITY'S SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE IS CHARGED WITH THE RESPONSIBILITY OF ADVERTISING AVAILABILITY OF SPECIFIC SCHOLARSHIPS, REVIEWING APPLICATIONS AND AWARDING SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON NEED, MERIT OR OTHER SPECIFIC REQUIREMENTS PUT IN PLACE BY DONORS OF THE FUNDS OR THE UNIVERSITY'S POLICIES.

THE STUDENTS MUST APPLY FOR THE GRANTS AND MEET THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE VARIOUS GRANTS. THE PROCESS BY WHICH EACH GRANT IS AWARDED AND MONITORED IS FORMALIZED IN A POLICY WHICH IS UPDATED BY THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID.
CONTINUALLY MONITOR SATISFACTORY PROGRESS AND VERIFY AGAINST ORIGINAL SCHOLARSHIP DOCUMENTS.
College financial aid is administered and awarded for students attending Roanoke College by the college's Financial Aid office using the college's policies and procedures.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING OF SCHOLARSHIPS - THE BUSINESS OFFICE NOTIFIES THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE OF AMOUNTS AVAILABLE TO AWARD TO STUDENTS EACH ACADEMIC YEAR. FINANCIAL AID OFFICE SELECTS RECIPIENTS BASED UPON CRITERIA ESTABLISHED FOR EACH TYPE OF FUNDING. FINANCIAL AID OFFICE NOTIFIES THE BUSINESS OFFICE OF EXPENDITURES FOR EACH TERM DURING THE ACADEMIC YEAR. AT YEAR-END, FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND BUSINESS OFFICE RECONCILE ACCOUNTS FOR ALL FUNDS. FOR DONOR-CONTRIBUTED SCHOLARSHIPS (ENDOWED OR ANNUALLY FUNDED), THE DEVELOPMENT OFFICE PROVIDES ANNUAL REPORTS TO THE DONORS REGARDING THE USE OF THOSE FUNDS. PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING RESEARCH GRANTS - THERE ARE SEVERAL DIFFERENT DEPARTMENTS THAT OFFER RESEARCH GRANTS AT WILLAMETTE. EACH DEPARTMENT HAS DIFFERENT MONITORING PROCEDURES FOR THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS. HOWEVER, THE MONITORING PROCEDURES TYPICALLY INVOLVE THE FOLLOWING: A WRITTEN AND/OR VERBAL REPORT ON THE RESEARCH PROJECT MUST BE SUBMITTED DURING AND/OR AT THE CONCLUSION OF THE PROJECT; RECEIPTS MUST BE SUBMITTED FOR REIMBURSEMENT OF PROJECT EXPENDITURES. FINAL PAYMENT OF GRANT FUNDS IS OFTEN CONTINGENT ON THE AFOREMENTIONED ITEMS. THE DEPARTMENT THAT AWARDS THE GRANTS HANDLES THE RELATED MONITORING OF THOSE GRANT FUNDS. PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING OTHER AWARDS AND PRIZES - AWARD/PRIZE RECIPIENTS ARE DETERMINED BY CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY THE RESPECTIVE DEPARTMENTS. DEPARTMENTS WORK WITH THE ACCOUNTING OFFICE TO MAKE SURE THAT THE AWARD FUNDS ARE DISBURSED TO THE CORRECT STUDENT OR FACULTY MEMBER.

PRESBYTERIAN COLLEGE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS, GRANTS, AND LOANS TO ITS STUDENTS. THE PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF THE FUNDS ARE PART OF THE FINANCIAL AID GUIDELINES AND THEY ARE UTILIZED TO DETERMINE THE QUALIFICATIONS OF THE RECIPIENT. THE GUIDELINES ARE PUBLISHED IN THE PRESBYTERIAN COLLEGE ACADEMIC CATALOG AND COMPLY WITH THE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS PUBLISHED BY THE US DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AND THE SC DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE. COMPLIANCE AUDITS ARE ALSO COMPLETED ANNUALLY BY AN INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTING FIRM. THE GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS.

ALL SWARTHMORE COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED/POSTED ELECTRONICALLY (AND INTERNALLY) DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT. FURTHERMORE, STUDENTS RECEIVING SAID FUNDS ARE UNABLE TO WITHDRAWAL IT FROM THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNT.
The grants are distributed to the student's accounts as payment of offset tuition costs.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIPS, GRANTS AND LOANS ARE AWARDED BASED ON NEED (AS DETERMINED BY A STANDARDIZED FINANCIAL AID FORM), ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND/OR LEADERSHIP. RECIPIENTS ARE CHOSEN BASED ON OBJECTIVE CRITERIA WHICH ARE CONSISTENT WITH THE OVERALL TAX-EXEMPT PURPOSE OF THE UNIVERSITY. THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT DISCRIMINATE ON THE BASIS OF SEX, RACE, COLOR, OR NATIONAL OR ETHNIC ORIGIN IN THE ADMINISTRATION OF ITS FINANCIAL AID PROGRAMS. ANY ESTIMATES UTILIZED ARE BASED ON CALCULATED AVERAGE AWARDS EXTENDED TO COMPARABLE GROUPS. ALL AWARDS ARE DISBURSED DIRECTLY TO THE UNIVERSITY AND NOT TO THE RECIPIENT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIPS, GRANTS AND LOANS ARE AWARDED BASED ON NEED (AS DETERMINED BY A STANDARDIZED FINANCIAL AID FORM), ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND/OR LEADERSHIP. RECIPIENTS ARE CHOSEN BASED ON OBJECTIVE CRITERIA WHICH ARE CONSISTENT WITH THE OVERALL TAX-EXEMPT PURPOSE OF THE UNIVERSITY. THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT DISCRIMINATE ON THE BASIS OF SEX, RACE, COLOR, OR NATIONAL OR ETHNIC ORIGIN IN THE ADMINISTRATION OF ITS FINANCIAL AID PROGRAMS. ANY ESTIMATES UTILIZED ARE BASED ON CALCULATED AVERAGE AWARDS EXTENDED TO COMPARABLE GROUPS. ALL AWARDS ARE DISBURSED DIRECTLY TO THE UNIVERSITY AND NOT TO THE RECIPIENT.

MERIT BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AND NEED BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO ENROLLED STUDENTS ARE CREDITED TO STUDENTS' ACCOUNT TO COVER TUITION AND FEES. GRADE REPORTS ARE GENERATED FOR EACH TERM AND EACH INDIVIDUAL STUDENT IS REVIEWED TO INSURE THEY ARE MAKING SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS TO MAINTAIN THEIR GRANT OR SCHOLARSHIP FUNDING. NOTIFICATIONS ARE SENT BY THE DEAN OF THE COLLEGE TO ALERT DEPARTMENTS OF WITHDRAWALS. ALSO, FINANCIAL AID RUNS ENROLLMENT REPORTS EACH TERM TO CHECK THE NUMBER OF CREDIT HRS FOR EACH STUDENT. THIRD PARTY SOFTWARE IS ALSO CODED TO PREVENT THE CREDIT OF FUNDS TO A STUDENT WITHOUT ENROLLED HOURS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS - PART I, LINE 2:
ExplntnTxt: GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO ADMITTED STUDENTS BASED ON AN EVALUATION OF THEIR ACADEMIC PROFILE AND A CAREFUL ANALYSIS OF THEIR DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED. STUDENTS AWARDED GRANT FUNDS MUST MAINTAIN SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS AND REMAIN ENROLLED AT THE UNIVERSITY ON A FULL TIME ACADEMIC BASIS. AT THE END OF EVERY TERM, EACH STUDENT'S ACADEMIC STATUS (I.E., GPA) IS MONITORED TO DETERMINE CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY FOR ALL GRANT FUNDS RECEIVED. FOR MONITORING PURPOSES, ELECTRONIC REPORTS GENERATED FROM OUR DATABASE ARE UTILIZED FOR THE AWARD DETERMINATION AND STATUS REVIEW PROCESS. THE UNIVERSITY ENSURES THAT ITS GRANT FUNDS ARE USED FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES BY CREDITING THE SCHOLARSHIPS AND OTHER FINANCIAL AID DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS RATHER THAN ISSUING CHECKS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITOR THE USE OF GRANTS FUNDS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 SMITH COLLEGE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIP GRANTS AND LOANS TO STUDENTS WHO ARE ABLE TO DEMONSTRATE FINANCIAL NEED. EACH STUDENT IS REQUIRED TO SUBMIT A PARENT'S CONFIDENTIAL QUESTIONNAIRE WHICH BECOMES THE BASIS OF DETERMINING NEED. GUIDELINES ISSUED BY THE COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIP SERVICE ARE USED IN ASCERTAINING THE FINANCIAL REQUIREMENT OF THE STUDENTS. THE FINANCIAL NEED IS GENERALLY MET THROUGH A COMBINATION OF LOANS AND GRANTS. BOTH ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S SEMESTER BILL THUS REDUCING THE PAYMENT DUE TO THE COLLEGE. THE COLLEGE ALSO AWARDS A RELATIVELY SMALL NUMBER OF MERIT-BASED GRANTS. THE COLLEGE FUNDS INTERNSHIPS THAT MEET RIGOROUS ACADEMIC CRITERIA. OTHER FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE IS PROVIDED TO MEET EMERGENCY TYPE AID ON A CASE-BY-CASE BASIS. THE COLLEGE MONITORS ALL GRANTS TO INDIVIDUALS TO ENSURE THAT FUNDS ARE UTILIZED APPROPRIATELY. FOR GRANTS APPLIED TO COVER TUITION AND OTHER FEES, ACADEMIC PROGRESS IS REQUIRED TO ENSURE CONTINUED FUNDING. INTERNSHIPS REQUIRE PROOF OF PARTICIPATION AND SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC CONTENT. OTHER FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE REQUIRES DEMONSTRATED NEED. GRANTS TO ORGANIZATIONS ARE ONLY MADE TO THOSE RECOGNIZED BY THE INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE AS BEING DESCRIBED IN INTERNAL REVENUE CODE SECTION 501(C)(3).

THE MAJORITY OF GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE AWARDED ARE ADMINISTERED ACCORDING TO THE POLICIES OUTLINED BY THE FUNDING SOURCE. TYPICALLY, GRANT MONEY IS RECEIVED BY THE COLLEGE AND IS APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. THE FEDERAL WORK-STUDY PROGRAM DOES ALLOW FUNDS TO BE DISTRIBUTED DIRECTLY TO THE RECIPIENT STUDENT. GIFTS TO ORGANIZATIONS ARE CHARITABLE IN NATURE AND DO NOT REQUIRE FORMAL MONITORING OF THE USE OF FUNDS.

All Federal financial aid administered by Barnard College is based on demonstrated financial need as determined by the Federal Methodology formula. However institutional aid is determined using a Barnard Need Analysis formula which takes into consideration all sources of income and all assets. Barnard does not provide merit scholarships. The College believes that the primary responsibility for financing educational cost rests with each student's family, and all college aid is supplementary to family resources. Once need has been established, Barnard makes every effort to meet the need of all eligible students with a combination of grants, loans and employment opportunities. A student who is admitted to Barnard with financial aid cannot be guaranteed college grants for future years. Awards are for one academic year only. A student can receive Barnard aid for a maximum of eight semesters. Each semester a student is enrolled is counted towards the eight semesters of eligibility whether or not aid was received. No financial aid is given for summer study. If a student has room in her academic year financial aid package and has not already borrowed the maximum loans, these funds may be borrowed during the academic year to be used for classes the following semester. For financial statement purposes, the Pell grant awards of $2,185,399 are excluded.

THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS BASED ON ESTABLISHED FEDERAL AND COLLEGE POLICIES. AWARDS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNT AT THE COLLEGE AS CREDITS TO TUITION AND OTHER FEES.

BENEDICTINE UNIVERSITY'S OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID ADMINISTERS FEDERAL TITLE IV, STATE, PRIVATE AND INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS IN THE FORM OF STUDENT SCHOLARSHIPS, GRANTS, WAIVERS AND AWARDS. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID FOLLOWS SPECIFIC GRANT PROGRAM CRITERIA TO: DETERMINE STUDENT ELIGIBILITY AND SELECTION; MONITOR APPROPRIATE HANDLING OF FUNDS, AND; MEET REPORTING AND RECORD RETENTION REQUIREMENTS. DOCUMENTATION OF ALL STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FUNDING IS MAINTAINED IN THE STUDENTS AID FILE AND UNIVERSITY COMPUTER SYSTEM.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY EXECUTES SUBAWARD AGREEMENTS WITH THE GRANTEES THAT OUTLINE AWARD EXPECTATIONS. GRANTEES SUBMIT DETAILED INVOICES THAT ARE APPROVED FOR PAYMENT BY THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS AND THE OFFICE OF FISCAL AFFAIRS AND ADMINISTRATION. PAYMENT IS MADE ON A REIMBURSEMENT BASIS ONLY. GRANTEES ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT PROJECT REPORTS PERIODICALLY TO PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS. GRANTEES RECEIVING FEDERAL FUNDS AS SUBRECIPIENTS ARE REQUIRED TO PROVIDE AN OMB CIRCULAR A-133 COMPLIANCE LETTER ANNUALLY, ALONG WITH A COPY OF AUDIT REPORTS.

GRANTS AND FINANCIAL AID ARE AWARDED TO STUDENDS. THESE FUNDS ARE THEN USED FOR TUITION AND OTHER EXPENSES RELATED TO EDUCATION (BOOKS, LAB EQUIPMENT, ETC). FUNDS ARE GENERALLY NOT ACTUALLY RELEASED TO THE STUDENTS, BUT ARE USED TO OFFSET TUITION COSTS BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.
OF THIS AMOUNT, $29,300 ARE FOR AWARDS THAT ARE RELEASED DIRECTLY TO STUDENTS.
Financial aid department maintains records to substantiate all amounts given in financial aid.
THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS STUDENTS ADHERENCE TO ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIP REQUIREMENTS SUCH AS GPA AND SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS.

ALAYA PRESCHOOL HAS CHILDREN WHO RECEIVE SOME SCHOLARSHIP SUPPORT IN THE FORM OF TUITION REDUCTION IN ADDITION TO OTHER CHILDREN THAT RECEIVE SUPPORT VIA CCCAP (COLORADO CHILD CARE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM). THIS IS A STATE FUNDED PROGRAM FOR LOW INCOME FAMILIES. WE DO NOT GET FULLY REIMBURSED FOR THE REGULAR COST OF CARE SO SCHOLARSHIPS ARE USED TO FUND THE DIFFERENCE FOR THESE FAMILIES.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING THE USE OF GRANTS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED TO STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF MERIT-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS, NEED-BASED GRANTS, WORK-STUDY AND STUDENT LOANS. ELIGIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL AID VARIES BASED ON THE CRITERIA OF EACH AWARD. MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT SUCH AS HIGH SCHOOL GRADE POINT AVERAGE, SAT OR ACT SCORE AND CLASS RANK, AND/OR EXTRA-CURRICULAR ACTIVITIES AND RECOMMENDATIONS. NEED-BASED GRANTS ARE OFFERED TO STUDENTS WHO COMPLETE A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) AND AN EMMANUEL COLLEGE APPLICATION FOR FINANCIAL AND WHO, BASED ON THIS INFORMATION, MEET THE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS FOR THE GRANT OR NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIP. ALL FIRST-YEAR STUDENTS WHO QUALIFY FOR NEED-BASED FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND ALL OTHER STUDENTS WHO ARE SELECTED FOR VERIFICATION BY THE CENTRAL PROCESSING SYSTEM (CPS) MUST ALSO SUBMIT VERIFICATION OF THE INFORMATION PROVIDED ON THE FAFSA. NEED-BASED GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS INCLUDE THE FEDERAL PELL GRANT AND FEDERAL SUPPLEMENTAL EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITY GRANT (SEOG), THE FEDERAL ACADEMIC COMPETITIVENESS GRANT, THE FEDERAL SMART GRANT, STATE GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS, AND EMMANUEL COLLEGE GRANT AID. IN ADDITION TO NEED-BASED GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS, STUDENTS WHO APPLY FOR FINANCIAL AID AND DEMONSTRATE FINANCIAL NEED MAY ALSO RECEIVE FEDERAL WORK STUDY AND NEED-BASED FEDERAL AND STATE STUDENT LOANS. THE LOAN PROGRAMS OFFERED BY EMMANUEL COLLEGE ARE THE FEDERAL STAFFORD LOAN, THE FEDERAL PERKINS LOAN AND THE MASSACHUSETTS NO-INTEREST LOAN. PRIOR TO DISBURSING ANY FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE, STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR EACH GRANT, SCHOLARSHIP, WORK-PROGRAM OR STUDENT LOAN IS CERTIFIED. TO RECEIVE NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID STUDENTS MUST APPLY FOR FINANCIAL AID EACH ACADEMIC YEAR.
GRANTS TO INDIVIDUALS ARE MONITORED ANNUALLY IN CONJUNCTION WITH ACADEMIC ADVISING FOR STUDENTS.
Student financial aid is credited to the individual student accounts and their net balances are monitored by the Business Office.
Financial Aid monitors all the scholarships that are awarded to the students to make sure they fall within the required guidelines.

Subrecipient grants - Vanderbilt University maintains a formal policy defining its procedures for monitoring the use of sponsored funds by subrecipients who are performing a portion of a sponsored project externally awarded to Vanderbilt. The policy provides guidance to ensure that subrecipients conduct their portions of sponsored projects in compliance with laws, regulations, terms and conditions of awards and subawards, and that reimbursed costs incurred by subrecipients are allowed. The policy addresses the roles and responsibilities of central offices and academic departments of the University and describes the monitoring procedures for each area. The full text of Vanderbilt's subrecipient policy is available online at the following web address: http://www.vanderbilt.edu/ocga/vupolicies/subrecipient /SubrecipientMonitoringGuidelinesfinal.pdf Other Assistance - Assistance offered from institutional funds by Vanderbilt to our students is awarded on the basis of merit and/or financial need. Such assistance helps students and their families support the cost of attendance which includes tuition, mandatory fees, room & board, books, other course materials/supplies, and allowances for personal/miscellaneous and travel expenses. Merit-based awards are competitively awarded in recognition of academic achievement, leadership, commitment to community service, contributions to society, and other forms of accomplishment. Need-based assistance is awarded on the basis of documented financial need, resulting from a need analysis evaluation accomplished in accordance with relevant and applicable federal, state, and/or institutional programs, policies, and eligibility requirements. Financial Aid - The units responsible for administering student financial aid at Vanderbilt regularly initiate system-generated reviews, as well as other cross-checks on an ad hoc basis. Results from these reviews, along with recurring management reports, are regularly evaluated. Subsequently, follow-up corrective actions are taken when appropriate and potentially include award revisions or cancellations. These provisions are designed to help ensure that student assistance funds are awarded to eligible recipients, in accordance with applicable federal, state, institutional, and other program legislation, as well as relevant internal University policies and operational guidelines/criteria.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITOR THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO THE MASSACHUSETTS CONFERENCE FOR WOMEN THAT PROVIDES CONNECTION, MOTIVATION, NETWORKING, INSPIRATION AND SKILL BUILDING FOR THOUSANDS OF ASPIRING BUSINESS WOMEN EACH YEAR. DOZENS OF EXPERT SPEAKERS LEAD WORKSHOPS AND SEMINARS ON THE ISSUES THAT MATTER MOST TO WOMEN, INCLUDING PERSONAL FINANCE, BUSINESS AND ENTREPRENEURSHIP, HEALTH, WORK/LIFE BALANCE AND MORE. THE CONFERENCE OFFERS INCREDIBLE OPPORTUNITIES FOR BUSINESS NETWORKING, PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT, EDUCATION, AND PERSONAL GROWTH. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIP ASSISTANCE TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS. MANY SCHOLARSHIPS ARE BASED ON CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC STRENGTH, ATHLETIC ABILITY, LEADERSHIP, OR COMMUNITY SERVICE. NON-NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIP FUNDING IS AWARDED THROUGH THE ADMISSIONS PROCESS AND USUALLY HAS A GRADE POINT AVERAGE (GPA) OR OTHER REQUIREMENT FOR RENEWAL IN SUBSEQUENT YEARS. TYPES OF MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS INCLUDE THE TRUSTEE SCHOLARSHIP, THE PRESIDENT'S SCHOLARSHIP AND THE INTERNATIONAL SCHOLARSHIP. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO OFFERS GRANT FUNDS THAT ARE AWARDED BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED AND DO NOT HAVE TO BE REPAID. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE DETERMINES THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF A STUDENT'S NEED-BASED GRANT FUNDING ACCORDING TO FEDERAL AND INSTITUTIONAL FORMULAS. TYPES OF NEED BASED GRANTS INCLUDE BENTLEY SCHOLARSHIPS, AS WELL AS FEDERAL AND STATE SOURCES. ALL SCHOLARSHIP AMOUNTS ARE AUTOMATICALLY CREDITED TO THE INDIVIDUAL'S STUDENT ACCOUNT.

Funds are credited to the students accounts for tuition and fees, room and board, books and other supplies. The Office of Student Financial Services consists of both Financial Aid and Bursar functions, who work closely together to ensure proper usage of grant funds.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANTS HAWAI`I PACIFIC UNIVERSITY'S OFFICES OF FINANCIAL AID AND SCHOLARSHIPS OVERSEE FEDERAL AND UNIVERSITY GRANT, SCHOLARSHIP, LOAN AND WORK-STUDY PROGRAMS. FEDERAL PROGRAMS ARE ADMINISTERED ACCORDING TO THE LAWS, RULES AND REGULATIONS ISSUED BY THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION, THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES, OR OTHER GRANTING AGENCY. UNIVERSITY SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE ADMINISTERED ACCORDING TO THE POLICIES AND PROCEDURES IMPLEMENTED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE TO SUPPORT THE UNIVERSITY'S ENROLLMENT PLAN. THE OFFICES AWARD AID BASED ON THE FEDERAL FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) AND SUPPORTING DOCUMENTATION TO VERIFY A STUDENT'S ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED BASED PROGRAMS AND SCHOLARSHIPS WHERE NEED IS A CRITERIA. IN ADDITION, STUDENTS ARE REVIEWED BASED ON ACADEMIC AND TALENT QUALIFICATIONS FOR MERIT BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS IN AREAS SUCH AS DANCE, ATHLETICS, MUSIC, DEBATE AND OTHER AREAS. PRESIDENT'S SCHOLARS SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON MERIT, GRADE POINT AVERAGE AND RECOMMENDATIONS. FINANCIAL AID AND THE SCHOLARSHIPS OFFICES MONITOR THE CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY OF STUDENTS FOR AWARDS. OCEANIC INSTITUTE FOLLOWS ITS SUBCONTRACTING POLICIES AND PROCEDURES TO MONITOR THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS. PROGRAM MANAGER, GRANT SPECIALIST AND CONTROLLER REVIEW ALL SUBCONTRACTOR INVOICES AND SUPPORTING RECEIPTS. GRANT SPECIALIST COMPARES ACTUAL EXPENSES WITH BUDGETED EXPENSES AND REVIEWS SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS TO DETERMINE IF COSTS CLAIMED ARE ALLOWED, REASONABLE AND CONSISTENT WITH TECHNICAL PROGRESS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: The majority of grants and assistance provided by the university is in the form of scholarships and financial aid to offset the cost of tuition, room and board for its students. These funds are awarded through the university's financial aid office based on a combination of merit and need and are disbursed directly to the student's billing account with the university. In addition, the university makes a limited number of grants to other organizations. The university's Sponsored Programs Office monitors grants made to other organizations to ensure funds are used for their intended purpose.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: The majority of grants and assistance provided by the university is in the form of scholarships and financial aid to offset the cost of tuition, room and board for its students. These funds are awarded through the university's financial aid office based on a combination of merit and need and are disbursed directly to the student's billing account with the university. In addition, the university makes a limited number of grants to other organizations. The university's Sponsored Programs Office monitors grants made to other organizations to ensure funds are used for their intended purpose.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: THE COLLEGE PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS MATRICULATING AT THE COLLEGE, ALL FUNDS ISSUED TO STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO DEFRAY THE COST OF TUITION AND NO STUDENT MAY USE THE FUNDS FOR OTHER THAN EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES. SINCE THE STUDENTS HAVE NO DISCRETION IN THE USE OF THE FUNDS, THE COLLEGE DOES NOT NEED TO MONITOR THE GRANTS ONCE ISSUED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: THE COLLEGE PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS MATRICULATING AT THE COLLEGE, ALL FUNDS ISSUED TO STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO DEFRAY THE COST OF TUITION AND NO STUDENT MAY USE THE FUNDS FOR OTHER THAN EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES. SINCE THE STUDENTS HAVE NO DISCRETION IN THE USE OF THE FUNDS, THE COLLEGE DOES NOT NEED TO MONITOR THE GRANTS ONCE ISSUED.

Grants to governments and organizations are made and monitored by College personnel in support of local community relations. College's Grants to individuals are made and monitored in accordance with Federal and Institutional Financial Aid policies. Amounts are applied to student accounts as credits to the bill at the bursar's office to offset academic charges.

ALL STUDENTS APPLYING FOR FEDERAL FUNDS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID ("FAFSA"). THE OFFICE REVIEWS THE RESULTS OF THE FAFSA, WHICH DICTATES WHAT AND HOW MUCH FEDERAL FUNDING THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE FOR. IF THE STUDENT IS DETERMINED TO BE IN COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FEDERAL REGULATIONS, AS DETERMINED BY THE DEPT. OF ED., THE AID OFFICE AWARDS THE STUDENT THE APPROPRIATE FUNDING. STUDENT FILES REGARDING ELIGIBILITY ARE MAINTAINED BY THE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

THE COLLEGE'S SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE IS COMPRISED OF INDIVIDUALS FROM THE DIFFERENT DIVISIONS OF THE COLLEGE. THIS COMMITTEE DEVELOPS SCHOLARSHIP REQUIREMENTS FOR EACH TYPE OF SCHOLARSHIP AVAILABLE FROM THE COLLEGE. COMMITTEE-DEVELOPED APPLICATIONS ARE REQUIRED FROM ALL APPLICANTS. THE COMMITTEE REVIEWS ALL APPLICATIONS RECEIVED BY DEADLINE, AND SCORES EACH APPLICATION BASED ON A RUBRIC DEVELOPED FOR EACH SCHOLARSHIP. BASED ON THE RUBRIC SCORES, IT SELECTS INDIVIDUALS FOR THE INTERVIEW PROCESS. THOSE APPLICANTS ARE INTERVIEWED AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED. PELL GRANT AMOUNTS ARE DETERMINED USING THE CHARTS PROVIDED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION. CODES ARE ENTERED INTO THE COLLEAGUE SOFTWARE BASED ON THOSE CALCULATIONS AND THE SOFTWARE ASSIGNS AMOUNTS BASED ON THOSE CODES.

Explanation: The Federal and State funds provided for financial aid to students of Rose-Hulman follows all regulations. Each year the regulations are evaluated to verify that all regulations are being followed based on each funds criteria.

SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2: THE UNIVERSITY MANAGES AN EXTENSIVE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAM TO ENSURE THAT A HIGHLY QUALIFIED AND DIVERSE POPULATION IS ABLE TO MATRICULATE AND CONTINUE TO GRADUATION. THE ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS TAKE THREE MAJOR FORMS: MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS, NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID, AND FINANCING ALTERNATIVES. THE STUDENT FIRST APPLIES FOR ASSISTANCE, AND THEN BASED ON THE GRANT CRITERIA (FINANCIAL AND ENROLLMENT), THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT AWARDS THE GRANT MONIES. THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT MONITORS THE TOTAL AMOUNTS GIVEN BY GRANT.

SUB-RECIPIENTS ARE PAID ON A COST-REIMBURSABLE OR FIXED PRICE BASIS. IN BOTH INSTANCES, THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR REVIEWS AND APPROVES INVOICES FOR PAYMENT. THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR IS ALSO THE INDIVIDUAL WHO RECEIVES AND REVIEWS TECHNICAL PROGRESS REPORTS FROM SUB-RECIPIENTS. EDUCATIONAL GRANTS TO STUDENTS ARE POSTED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT IS REVIEWED BY WVU STUDENT AFFAIRS TO DETERMINE IF ANY MONEY IS OWED BY THE STUDENT OR OWED TO THE STUDENT AS A REFUND. STUDENTS ALSO REVIEW THEIR OWN ACCOUNTS TO ENSURE THAT THEY AGREE WITH THE ACTIVITY POSTED TO THEIR ACCOUNTS.

THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID DETERMINES ELIGIBILITY OF EACH STUDENT WHO APPLIES FOR FINANCIAL AID, USING FORMULAS AND CRITERIA PROMULGATED BY VARIOUS FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTAL BODIES, AS WELL AS MARYWOOD'S INTERNALLY ESTABLISHED RULES AND PROCEDURES.

ALL STUDENTS APPLYING FOR FEDERAL FUNDS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID ("FAFSA"). THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE REVIEWS THE RESULTS OF THE FAFSA, WHICH DICTATES WHAT AND HOW MUCH FEDERAL FUNDING THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE FOR. IF THE STUDENT IS DETERMINED TO BE IN COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FEDERAL REGULATIONS, AS DETERMINED BY THE DEPT. OF ED., THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS THE STUDENT THE APPROPRIATE FUNDING. STUDENT FILES REGARDING ELIGIBILITY ARE MAINTAINED BY THE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

Budgeted amounts are awarded to eligible students who apply for financial aid (selected by committee or using packaging rules). Awarded students are checked to ensure that they are still eligible to receive these funds during the course of the academic year.
Use of grant funds is monitored through student financial aid and billing process.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: The Foundation only makes grants to its closely-affiliated organizations. The close connection between all three organizations ensures appropriate and intended use of grant funds.

The University is contributing funds to charitable oganizations in accordance with endowment agreements that govern the distribution of the underlying funds. The University also verifies that the grants given to the charitable organization are for the benefit of individual students for scholarships.
Student awards, grants and loans are awarded on basis of need. Scholarships are awarded based upon need and academic or special achievements.
- The Institutions scholarship committee awards scholarships on a non-discriminatory basis, considering academic qualifications or distinctive scholarship criteria.

THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT ISSUES AND MONITORS STUDENT FINANCIAL AID AWARDS. THE FINANCE DIVISION MONITORS THE SCHOLARSHIPS AND DISCOUNTS REFLECTED ON STUDENT BILLING. STUDENT AID IS AWARDED ACCORDING TO THE COLLEGE'S PROCEDURES. STUDENT AID IS AWARDED BASED ON MEETING ESTABLISHED CRITERIA WHICH INCLUDE ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND FINANCIAL NEED.

IN AS MUCH AS ALL GRANTS ARE FOR NON-CASH ASSISTANCE FOR STUDENT RECIPIENTS' TUITION, ROOM, BOARD OR BOOKS, WHEN SUCH REMISSION OCCURS, IT IS A DIRECT REDUCTION OF THE STUDENTS FEES TO THE UNIVERSITY. SINCE NO GRANT FUNDS ARE IN DIRECT CONTROL OF THE RECIPIENT, THE RECIPIENT IS NOT IN A POSITION TO DIVERT THE GRANT FROM ITS INTENDED USE. FOR ATHLETIC SCHOLARSHIPS, THE ATHLETIC DIRECTOR AND DIRECTOR OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES, TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH NAIA RULES, MUST MONITOR SCHOLARSHIP EXPENDITURES FOR EACH STUDENT AND PROGRAM.

The college's financial aid office monitors all recipients of scholarship awards to determine both initial and continuing eligibility based upon the criteria for the type of award. Various criteria may include, but is not limited to, academic performance, financial need, or other criteria established by donors of scholarship funds.

THE OFFICE OF ADMISSIONS AWARDS ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON HIGH SCHOOL GRADES AND ACT/SAT SCORES. A FRESHMAN WITH A 3.0 CORE GPA AND A 25 ACT, OR ABOUT A 1700 SAT, WILL QUALIFY FOR AN ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIP. TRANSFER STUDENTS WITH LESS THAN 30 COLLEGE CREDIT HOURS WILL HAVE BOTH HIGH SCHOOL GRADES AND COLLEGE GRADES CONSIDERED FOR ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIP. A TRANSFER STUDENT WITH MORE THAN 30 COLLEGE HOURS WILL NOT NEED TO SUBMIT HIGH SCHOOL TRANSCRIPTS AND ONLY COLLEGE TRANSCRIPTS WILL BE EVALUATED. TRANSFER STUDENTS MUST HAVE A 3.0 CORE GPA TO QUALIFY. THE RANGE IS FROM $2,000 UP TO HALF-TUITION PER YEAR: THE HIGHER THE SCORES, THE HIGHER THE SCHOLARSHIP AMOUNT. THE OFFICE OF ADMISSIONS COORDINATES THE AWARDING OF DEPARTMENTAL SCHOLARSHIPS. THESE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AVAILABLE TO NEW STUDENTS WHO SUBMIT REQUIRED PROJECTS TO DEPARTMENT CHAIRS FOR JUDGING. DEPARTMENT SCHOLARSHIPS RANGE FROM $1,000-$5,000 PER YEAR. FOR ALL SCHOLARSHIPS, STUDENTS ARE NOTIFIED BY PHONE AND BY MAIL WITH AN OFFICIAL LETTER. THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE SENDS AN AWARD LETTER TO NOTIFY THE STUDENT OF ALL AID OFFERED TO THEM. MOST SCHOLARSHIPS (THE MERIT SCHOLARSHIP FOR CURRENT STUDENTS IS AN EXCEPTION) ARE RENEWABLE FOR FOUR YEARS AS LONG AS SPECIFIC ACADEMIC MINIMUMS ARE MAINTAINED. O'MORE WORK STUDY AND THE O'MORE GRANT ARE THE ONLY INSTITUTIONAL NEED-BASED FUNDS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE. O'MORE WORK STUDY IS CREDITED TO STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS LIKE A GRANT. THE SCHOOL DETERMINES RECIPIENTS BY A FORMULA THAT IDENTIFIES NET NEED AFTER CALCULATING GROSS NEED (DIRECT COST-EFC) AND THEN CREDITING FEDERAL/STATE GRANTS, INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS/GRANTS, AND STUDENT LOANS. THIS INFORMATION IS MAILED TO THE STUDENT IN A LETTER AND A COPY IS KEPT IN THEIR FINANCIAL AID FOLDER.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: RECORDS MAINTAINED FOR GRANTS OR ASSISTANCE
ExplntnTxt: SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 The University has agreements with various government agencies regarding annual contributions. Also, Each year the University makes numerous small contributions to community organizations. THE UNIVERSITY'S Department of Community and Regional Affairs reviews requests from local non-profits, and looks to provide program support for organizations in the Princeton area who provide important services and resources to the community. All Contributions are evaluated to assure that they support the Princeton community at large. The University's Pace Center for Civic Engagement provides grant and support efforts by students, faculty, staff, and alumni to identify and address issues of public concern, to be actively engaged citizens, and to practice effective public leadership for the purpose of building stronger communities and societies throughout the world. THE UNDERGRADUATE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT MAINTAINS THE RECORDS RELATED TO THE UNDERGRADUATE NEED-BASED GRANTS. THE PROCEDURE IS AS FOLLOWS: THE STUDENTS APPLY ANNUALLY FOR GRANTS BASED ON THEIR FAMILIES' FINANCIAL CIRCUMSTANCES. EACH APPLICATION IS THEN REVIEWED TO DETERMINE THE AMOUNT OF GRANT THAT IS NEEDED. THE GRANTS ARE PROVIDED FROM APPROPRIATE SOURCES AND APPLIED TO EACH STUDENT'S PRINCETON BILL FOR TUITION, FEES, ROOM, BOARD AND OTHER CHARGES. At the time of admission, graduate student fellowships are awarded on the basis of a combination of academic merit and financial need. All students must remain in good academic standing in order to receive funding. Students in certain programs receive research grants after their first year of study, While other students receive fellowships for the duration of their program. Graduate student fellowships are funded through a combination of university resources including endowment, general university funds, and/or departmental resources.

Schedule I, Part II In furtherance of its research activities, Princeton University makes sub-awards to other institutions that perform research in connection with research grants awarded to Princeton University. Princeton University does not categorize these sub-awards as "grants and other assistance" for Form 990 reporting, since the recipient organizations perform research services for the University and are considered independent contractors which serve the direct needs of the University. During the year ended June 30, 2015, Princeton University made sub-award payments to 248 recipient organizations totaling $25,332,879.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: For all scholarship funds, financial aid has established specific criteria for eligibility and selection. The eligibility requirements are documented and monitored for compliance. Scholarships are credited to student tuition bills.

SAINT LOUIS UNIVERSITY OFFERS A NUMBER OF INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS. EACH PROGRAM HAS SPECIFIC AWARDING CRITERIA AND INDIVIDUAL RULES FOR AWARDING SET UP IN THE BANNER (ERP) SYSTEM. INITIALLY, AWARDS ARE DETERMINED BY THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES OR THE DEPARTMENT ADMINISTRATORS WILL DETERMINE AND NOTIFY THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES. AWARDS ARE THEN POSTED ACCORDINGLY AND DISBURSED ONTO A STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. STUDENTS REGISTERED IN THE BANNER (ERP) SYSTEM WILL BE AWARDED AND PAID USING THE STUDENT INFORMATION SYSTEM DISBURSEMENT RULES. CONTROLS ARE IN PLACE TO MONITOR OR DESIGNATE IF CHARGES AND RESULTING PAYMENT OF AID IS APPLICABLE TO THE TYPE OF PROGRAM OR FEE BY USE OF SEPARATE DETAIL CODES FOR EACH PROGRAM.

Keck Graduate Institute of Applied Life Sciences awards scholarships only to individual graduate students enrolled at the Institute. The scholarships are awarded in the admissions process based upon academic merit, financial need, and availability of funds. The Institute monitors that each student receiving a scholarship maintains satisfactory academic progress. In awarding donor-funded scholarships, the Institute also monitors that students selected for those scholarships meet any donor stipulations as to academic preparation or field of study.
ALL GRANT AND CONTRACT ACTIVITY IS MONITORED TO ASSURE THAT IT IS IN COMPLIANCE WITH ALL APPLICABLE REGULATIONS. ALL EXPENDITURES ARE REVIEWED ON A WEEKLY BASIS FOR ALLOWABILITY.
The College's financial aid department monitors and maintains records regarding all financial aid awards.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: TJU monitors subrecipients by reviewing financial and performance reports submitted by the recipient and regular contact with the subrecipient and inquiries concerning programmatic activities, including quarterly certifications by principal investigators that work is progressing according to scope and that deliverables are being met.

AWARDING OF INSTITUTIONAL AID IS DRIVEN BY THE AWARD THE STUDENT RECEIVES UPON ENTRANCE TO DAVIS COLLEGE. COMING IN AS A NEW STUDENT, THE ADMISSIONS AND FINANCIAL AID SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE FIRST DETERMINES IF THE STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE FOR MERIT BASED AWARDS. THESE AWARDS ARE BASED ON ACADEMIC AND CO-CURRICULAR ACTIVITIES. EACH STUDENT IS THEN COMPARED TO A FINANCIAL AID AWARDING MATRIX WHICH IS COMPRISED OF VARYING NEED LEVELS FOR GRANT FUNDING, CAMPUS BASED AID AND CAMPUS EMPLOYMENT. STUDENTS ARE PLACED ON THIS GRID BY USING THE ADMISSIONS SCHOLARSHIP CRITERIA TO DETERMINE THEIR RATING AND THEN THEIR FINANCIAL NEED FACTOR AS DETERMINED BY THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) FOR THAT ACADEMIC YEAR.

THE UNIVERSITY FOLLOWS PACKAGING GUIDELINES IN AWARDING FUNDS. AID IS PAID ACCORDING TO THE STUDENT ACADEMIC LOAD (I.E. 100% FOR FULL-TIME, 75% FOR 3/4 TIME). AID IS ADJUSTED ACCORDING TO POLICY IF A STUDENT WITHDRAWS. STUDENT'S ACADEMIC PROGRESS IS ALSO MONITORED TO DETERMINE IF AID SHOULD BE ADJUSTED.

GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS ARE PROVIDED IN THE FORM OF STIPENDS TO RESIDENTS, POST-DOCTORAL, AND GRADUATE STUDENTS. THE STIPENDS ARE SUBJECT TO ALL OF THE PAYROLL SYSTEM CONTROLS, TIME SHEETS, TIME AND EFFORT REPORTING AND OTHER PAYROLL CONTROLS. THE REMAINING GRANTS USE TUITION SCHOLARSHIPS WHICH ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO TUITION AND FEES WITHIN THE ACCOUNTING SYSTEM TO WHICH THE STUDENT HAS NO ACCESS.

As federally mandated, the School prepares annually a student cost of attendance budget, which includes tuition, room and board, and an estimate for the cost of books, supplies, transportation and personal expenses. The School then awards federal, state and institutional aid based upon the cost of attendance and the family's expected contribution, as determined by the federal need analysis formula. Students do not receive funding in excess of the cost of attendance and in cases where outside grants are received, student self-help aid (i.e. loans and work-study) is reduced first to ensure that aid is not over-awarded. Student must document additional educationally-related expenses in order to receive funding above their unmet need.

GRANTS AWARDED TO INDIVIDUALS BY THE UNIVERSITY OF RICHMOND CONSIST OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING THESE GRANTS ARE DETERMINED TO BE WORTHY ON THE BASIS OF THE UNIVERSITY'S ASSESSMENT OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR CRITERIA. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID MONITORS STUDENTS' ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE FUNDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH INSTITUTIONAL POLICIES AND STANDARDS. GRANTS MADE TO ORGANIZATIONS LOCATED IN THE UNITED STATES WERE MADE PURSUANT TO THE UNIVERSITY'S POLICIES AND PROCEDURES FOR GRANT SUBAWARDS. SUBAWARD ACTIVITY IS MONITORED PRIMARILY BY THE GRANTS ACCOUNTING OFFICE. SUBAWARD DOCUMENTATION, INCLUDING INVOICES, RECEIPTS, PAYMENT REQUESTS, AND SIMILAR RECORDS, IS REVIEWED BY GRANTS ACCOUNTING TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH INSTITUTIONAL POLICIES, OMB CIRCULAR A-21, AND THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE GRANT AGREEMENT, AND APPROVED BY THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR.

DEPENDING ON THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE FUND SOURCES, FINANCIAL AID AND ALL TITLE IV AND STATE REGULATIONS ARE MONITORED, RECONCILED AND FOLLOWED DAILY BY TRAINED AND EXPERIENCED PROFESSIONAL STAFF THAT STAY UP TO DATE ON ANY CHANGES IN REGULATION THOUGH PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRAINING.

VANGUARD UNIVERSITY AWARDS MERIT AND NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO TRADITIONAL UNDERGRADUATES AND MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO GRADUATE STUDENTS. AWARDS ARE BASED ON ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA INCLUDING ACADEMIC, TALENT AND PARTICIPATION, AND INCENTIVE INCLUDING DENOMINATION, MINISTRY/MISSIONARY DEPENDENT. CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY INCLUDING MAINTENANCE GPA IS MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. NEED-BASED AWARDS REQUIRE DEMONSTRATED NEED AS DETERMINED BY THE FAFSA AND REQUIRES FILING THE FAFSA BY THE MARCH 2 PRIORITY DEADLINE EACH YEAR AND CONTINUED DEMONSTRATION OF NEED. THE MAJORITY OF THE AWARDS ARE FUNDED BY THE INSTITUTIONAL AID BUDGET BUT SMALL NUMBER ARE FUNDED BY THE ENDOWMENT AND HAVE DONOR SPECIFIC CRITERIA. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WORKS WITH UNIVERSITY ADVANCEMENT AND FISCAL MANAGEMENT TO AWARD THESE FUNDS.

In the interest of partnering with non profits within the US in cross-cultural service, WCIU enters into Memorandums of Understanding with many of them. One benefit is that scholarships are offered to their members. Applicants referred to WCIU by the director or leader of those non profits receive scholarships according to the amount agreed to in the Memorandum of Understanding. Credits are issued to student accounts for tuition discounts and therefore, no cash has changed hands.

AS PART OF OUR MISSION, SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON SELECTION BY A COMMITTEE UPON SUBMISSION OF AN APPLICATION TO BE USED TOWARDS THE COST OF ATTENDANCE. THESE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED ON A TRIMESTER BASIS. ADDITIONALLY, TUITION LEVERAGE AWARDS ARE OFFERED BASED ON MERIT. THESE AWARDS ARE FOR TUITION ONLY AND FOLLOW THE STUDENT FOR THEIR PERIOD OF ENROLLMENT AS LONG AS THEY MAINTAIN GOOD STANDING.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: Adler-Funded Scholarship, students must have applied for admission to the School. Admission Scholarships are reserved for full-time U.S. or Canadian students. To maintain eligibility, students must show satisfactory progress and a GPA of 3.25 in psychology coursework at the time of application. Additionally, Adler also grants scholarships to employees pursuing degree programs. To qualify, employees have to obtain prior manager's approval. They receive up to 6 credit hours of scholarship each semester. Relatives of faculty members and the school founders are also eligible for the same type of scholarship.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: Adler-Funded Scholarship, students must have applied for admission to the School. Admission Scholarships are reserved for full-time U.S. or Canadian students. To maintain eligibility, students must show satisfactory progress and a GPA of 3.25 in psychology coursework at the time of application. Additionally, Adler also grants scholarships to employees pursuing degree programs. To qualify, employees have to obtain prior manager's approval. They receive up to 6 credit hours of scholarship each semester. Relatives of faculty members and the school founders are also eligible for the same type of scholarship.
SCHEDULE I, PART 1, LINE 2: ANNA MARIA COLLEGE PARTICIPATES IN TITLE IV FUNDING. STUDENTS MUST COMPLETE THE FAFSA FORM TO APPLY FOR AID.

GRANTS ARE SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS. QUALIFICATIONS INCLUDE DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED PER THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION'S FAFSA, AND/OR MERIT-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS. FAFSA INFORMATION IS ANNUALLY UPDATED. MERIT-BASED SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS ARE MONITORED FOR GRADE-POINT AVERAGE, PROGRESS TOWARD THE DEGREE OBJECTIVE, AND OTHER SIGNALS OF ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE. SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH DONOR RESTRICTIONS WHERE THOSE EXIST. THE PROCESS IS MANAGED BY THE SCHOOL'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICER WHO DETERMINES AMOUNTS, AND A SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE WHO ASSIGNS THE SCHOLARSHIPS.

The University follows guidelines set by the Department of Education, and State Governments, to ensure that grants to students are awarded to eligible recipients. All documentation regarding the awarding of these grants is maintained in the student file.

SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES FINANCIAL AID TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS, GENERALLY IN A "PACKAGE" THAT INCLUDES LOANS, COMPENSATION UNDER WORK-STUDY PROGRAMS, AND/OR GRANT AND SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS. THE LOANS ARE PROVIDED PRIMARILY THROUGH PROGRAMS OF THE UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT (INCLUDING DIRECT AND GUARANTEED LOAN PROGRAMS) UNDER WHICH THE UNIVERSITY IS RESPONSIBLE ONLY FOR CERTAIN ADMINISTRATIVE DUTIES. THE GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS INCLUDE AWARDS PROVIDED THROUGH GIFTS AND GRANTS FROM PRIVATE DONORS OR FROM INCOME EARNED ON ENDOWMENT FUNDS RESTRICTED FOR STUDENT AID, AS WELL AS GENERAL FUNDS SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS. ROUGHLY 80 PERCENT OF STEVENSON UNIVERSITY STUDENTS RECEIVE SOME SORT OF FINANCIAL AID. ALL INDIVIDUALS RECEIVING DISBURSEMENTS FROM STEVENSON UNIVERSITY QUALIFY TO RECEIVE SUCH PAYMENTS BASED ON SCHOLASTIC ACHIEVEMENT AND/OR FINANCIAL NEED. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES NEED-BASED GRANTS, WHICH ARE DETERMINED BASED ON THE STUDENTS'S FAFSA SCORE. THE STUDENT MUST MAINTAIN A GPA OF 2.0 OR GREATER AND BE A FULL-TIME STUDENT. DISBURSEMENTS TAKE THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIP OR GRANTS. GRANTS ARE DISBURSED BASED ON THE GUIDELINES SET FORTH BY THE PARTY FUNDING THE GRANT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedure for Monitoring Use of Grant Funds Inside U.S.
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 A report is run at the end of each semester to review each student's cumulative GPA and progress toward their degree. Students receiving merit awards who fail to achieve good academic standing are reviewed for alternative institutional funding. Every effort is made to find alternative funding for students not meeting good academic standing.

SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS FOR STUDENTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO A STUDENT'S UNIVERSITY ACCOUNT AND APPLIED TO TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD. ALL FINANCIAL AID IS SUBJECT TO REVISION BASED ON AVAILABILITY, CHANGES IN FAMILY CONTRIBUTION, HOUSING STATUS, AND/OR CREDIT LOAD. SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS MUST BE MAINTAINED ACCORDING TO STANDARDS PRESCRIBED BY THE UNIVERSITY. ANNUAL RENEWAL OF FINANCIAL AID IS CONTINUOUS IF INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL NEED REMAINS, ALL REQUIRED DOCUMENTS ARE COMPLETED BY THE PUBLISHED DEADLINE AND SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS IS MAINTAINED CONSISTENT WITH THE UNIVERSITY'S POLICY.
SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS ARE ADMINISTERED AND MONITORED BY THE UNIVERSITY. SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS FOR FYE 6/30/15 WERE APPLIED TO STUDENT BALANCES OWED TO THE UNIVERSITY.

The Institute assigns responsibility for monitoring the use of grant funds to its office of sponsored research. This office monitors all grant-making activity including all applicable compliance regulations. Monitoring includes periodic reviews of budget to actual reports by both the office of sponsored research and the principal investigator to ensure funds are used according to the agreement. Expenses are accounted for on an accrual basis.

MONITORING PROCEDURES PART II: GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE TO GOVERNMENTS AND ORGANIZATIONS IN THE UNITED STATES: THE UNIVERSITY HAS ESTABLISHED POLICIES AND PROCEDURES FOR FINANCIAL AFFAIRS. RESPONSIBILITY CENTER HEADS WITHIN THE UNIVERSITY ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR MONITORING THE GENERAL USE OF UNIVERSITY FUNDS FOR APPROVED USES. DISBURSEMENT REQUESTS FOR GRANT FUNDS MUST BE APPROVED BY THE FINANCIAL ACCOUNTING INFORMATION SYSTEM (FAIS) ACCOUNT ADMINISTRATOR OR THE HEAD OF THE RESPONSIBILITY CENTER. WHEN THE REQUESTOR IS ALSO THE FAIS ACCOUNT ADMINISTRATOR OR THE HEAD OF THE RESPONSIBILITY CENTER, THE GRANT FUNDING REQUEST MUST BE SIGNED BY THE NEXT HIGHER LEVEL ADMINISTRATOR. THE UNIVERSITY'S DISBURSEMENT PROCESS IDENTIFIES AND RECORDS PAYMENTS TO BOTH U.S. AND FOREIGN INDIVIDUALS/ENTITIES. THE UNIVERSITY EMPLOYS APPROPRIATE MEASURES TO REDUCE THE RISK THAT ANY GRANT FUNDING PROVIDED IS NOT USED FOR NON-CHARITABLE PURPOSES OR EXPLOITATION BY TERRORIST ORGANIZATIONS, INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, UNIVERSITY ATTENDANCE AND/OR PARTICIPATION AT SPONSORED EVENTS AND ONGOING REVIEWS OF THE SPECIALLY DESIGNATED NATIONALS LIST PUBLISHED BY THE US DEPARTMENT OF THE TREASURY. FOR RESEARCH SUBCONTRACTS,THE INITIAL DETERMINATION OF ELIGIBILITY AND APPROPRIATENESS OF THE ENTITY LIES JOINTLY BETWEEN THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR (PI)/DEPARTMENT AND THE OFFICE OF RESEARCH. THE PI/DEPARTMENT IDENTIFIES THE ENTITY USUALLY BASED UPON THE UNIQUE NEEDS OF THE PI EVIDENCED IN THE SCOPE OF WORK. DOCUMENTATION IS OBTAINED FROM THE ENTITY WHICH IS REVIEWED. UPON SUBMISSION, THE OFFICE OF RESEARCH LOOKS FOR THIS DOCUMENTATION SO THAT IT MEETS SPONSOR AND UNIVERSITY REQUIREMENTS. IF AND WHEN THE PROJECT IS FUNDED, THE DEPARTMENT INITIATES A SUBCONTRACT REQUEST. SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2: MONITORING PROCEDURES PART III GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS IN THE UNITED STATES: THE INSTITUTION DOES MAINTAIN RECORDS TO SUBSTANTIATE THE AMOUNT OF GRANTS OR ASSISTANCE. THE RECORDS, ELIGIBILITY AND SELECTION CRITERIA ARE MAINTAINED BY EITHER THE OFFICE OF ADMISSIONS AND FINANCIAL AID, THE STUDENTS' SCHOOL DEPARTMENT, THE BENEFITS SECTION OF HUMAN RESOURCES, OR THE FACULTY RECORDS OFFICE. GRANT FUNDS THAT ARE RESTRICTED IN THEIR USE AND ARE NOT REFUNDABLE IN CASH TO THE STUDENTS ARE MONITORED THROUGH THE UNIVERSITY'S STUDENT SYSTEM. GRANTS THAT ARE NOT RESTRICTED IN THEIR USE AND ARE REFUNDABLE TO THE STUDENTS ARE NOT MONITORED.
THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS REFLECTS THE ACTUAL NUMBER OF STUDENTS AND EMPLOYEES WHO RECEIVED THE ASSISTANCE.

THE SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE ADMINISTERS ALL OF THE INSTITUTIONAL AND PRIVATE SCHOLARSHIPS. THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT MANAGES ALL GRANTS. IN ALL CASES NOTICES OF GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE POSTED OUTSIDE THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AS WELL AS LISTED IN VARIOUS INTERNAL PUBLICATIONS AND THE UNIVERSITY WEBSITE. RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED IN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: grants or other assistance in the united states
ExplntnTxt: form 990, schedule i, part i, line 2 Elizabethtown College provides scholarships to students matriculating at the College. Students receiving scholarships are not permitted any discretion on how to spend those funds as all amounts are used to satisfy tuition costs. Accordingly, all funds granted are used to defray the cost of tuition and no further monitoring of the grants is required.

FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 ADMISSION TO POMONA COLLEGE IS ON A NEED BLIND BASIS. THIS POLICY IS MAINTAINED TO ACCOMPLISH DIVERSIFICATION OF THE STUDENT BODY REGARDLESS OF THE FINANCIAL STATUS OF THE APPLICANTS. A PERMANENT FILE OF ALL STUDENTS WHO ARE RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS IS MAINTAINED IN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE OF POMONA COLLEGE. AN ACCOUNTING SYSTEM TRACKS ALL AWARDS TO INDIVIDUAL STUDENTS FOR TUITION AND OTHER COSTS OF ATTENDING THE COLLEGE.

The aid provided is in the form of scholarships and discounts awarded to students. The University has a well developed system of internal controls for Admissions, Financial Aid, Registration, Student Accounts and Accounting. The system is monitored by experienced staff who ensure the use of aid is in compliance with all governing laws, regulations and policies.

SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO ENROLLED STUDENTS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS TO COVER TUITION AND FEES. GRADE REPORTS ARE GENERATED FOR EACH TERM, AND EACH INDIVIDUAL STUDENT IS REVIEWED TO ENSURE THEY ARE MAKING SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS TO MAINTAIN THEIR GRANT/SCHOLARSHIP FUNDING. ALSO, FINANCIAL AID RUNS ENROLLMENT REPORTS EACH TERM TO CHECK THE NUMBER OF CREDIT HOURS FOR EACH STUDENT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: GEORGETOWN UNIVERSITY IS NOT A "GRANTMAKER" PER SE IN THAT ITS FUNDAMENTAL MISSION, AND PURPOSE FOR TAX-EXEMPTION, RELATES TO EDUCATION AND RESEARCH. HOWEVER, IN THE COURSE OF THESE MISSION-related ACTIVITIES, THE UNIVERSITY DOES MAKE PAYMENTS THAT MEET THE CRITERIA FOR "GRANTMAKING" AS DEFINED BY THE INSTRUCTIONS TO SCHEDULE I OF THE FORM 990. THESE PAYMENTS FALL INTO TWO CATEGORIES: (1) STUDENT FINANCIAL AID - THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED BASED EITHER ON FINANCIAL NEED OR ACADEMIC MERIT; THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES (THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE) DETERMINES STUDENTS' ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED AID. VARIOUS ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY FOR MERIT-BASED AID; and (2) CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS - CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH UNIVERSITY POLICY.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: GEORGETOWN UNIVERSITY IS NOT A "GRANTMAKER" PER SE IN THAT ITS FUNDAMENTAL MISSION, AND PURPOSE FOR TAX-EXEMPTION, RELATES TO EDUCATION AND RESEARCH. HOWEVER, IN THE COURSE OF THESE MISSION-related ACTIVITIES, THE UNIVERSITY DOES MAKE PAYMENTS THAT MEET THE CRITERIA FOR "GRANTMAKING" AS DEFINED BY THE INSTRUCTIONS TO SCHEDULE I OF THE FORM 990. THESE PAYMENTS FALL INTO TWO CATEGORIES: (1) STUDENT FINANCIAL AID - THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED BASED EITHER ON FINANCIAL NEED OR ACADEMIC MERIT; THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES (THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE) DETERMINES STUDENTS' ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED AID. VARIOUS ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY FOR MERIT-BASED AID; and (2) CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS - CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH UNIVERSITY POLICY.
THE SCHOOL PROVIDES FINANCIAL AID GRANTS THAT MAY BE USED FOR TUITION AND FEES ONLY.

ORGANIZATION PROVIDES NEEDS BASED SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS. STUDENTS APPLYING FOR SCHOLARSHIPS MUST PROVIDE EVIDENCE OF NEED. EACH APPLICATION IS REVIEWED BY A COMMITTEE TO DETERMINE THE AMOUNT OF SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO EACH STUDENT.ORGANIZATION PROVIDES FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE BASED ON NEED OF INDIVDUAL.

ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 URSINUS COLLEGE PROVIDED GRANTS TOTALING $98,970 TO 130 URSINUS COLLEGE STUDENTS IN GOOD ACADEMIC STANDING FOR CAMPUS HOUSING, PRIMARILY FOR SUMMER RESEARCH. THE GRANTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS AT URSINUS COLLEGE. URSINUS COLLEGE PROVIDED GRANTS TOTALING $41,276,297 TO 1,596 URSINUS COLLEGE STUDENTS IN GOOD ACADEMIC STANDING FOR TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD FOR THE ACADEMIC YEAR 2014-15. THE GRANTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS AT URSINUS COLLEGE. URSINUS COLLEGE PROVIDED GRANTS TOTALING $221,390 TO 84 URSINUS COLLEGE STUDENTS IN GOOD ACADEMIC STANDING FOR STIPENDS WHILE ENGAGED IN SUMMER RESEARCH PROJECTS ON CAMPUS. THE STIPENDS ARE DISBURSED VIA PAYROLL TO THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENTS. URSINUS COLLEGE PROVIDED GRANTS TOTALING $713,147 TO 42 FOREIGN STUDENTS FOR TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD TO ATTEND URSINUS COLLEGE. FOREIGN STUDENTS ARE AWARDED GRANTS BASED ON MERIT AND NEED PRIOR TO ARRIVING AT URSINUS COLLEGE. THESE GRANTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNT AT URSINUS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: DESCRIPTION OF ORGANIZATION'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANTS
ExplntnTxt: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I THE UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS A WRITTEN POLICY THAT GOVERNS THE MONITORING OF THE USE OF SPONSORED PROJECT GRANT FUNDING BY SUBRECIPIENTS. THE POLICY MANDATES MONITORING IN TWO AREAS: (A) SUBRECIPIENT INSTITUTION COMPLIANCE WITH THE AUDITING REQUIREMENTS OF OMB CIRCULAR A-133, AND (B) SUBRECIPIENT INSTITUTION'S APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT OF SUBAWARD. THE UNIVERSITY'S SPONSORED PROJECTS FINANCE GROUP COLLECTS A-133 REPORTS FROM SUBRECIPIENT INSTITUTIONS, AND THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS CARRY OUT THE SECOND TYPE OF MONITORING, PRINCIPALLY BY: - ROUTINELY GATHERING AND REVIEWING TECHNICAL PERFORMANCE REPORTS; - ROUTINELY REVIEWING INVOICES AND EXPENSES RELATIVE TO BUDGET; - CONDUCTING PERIODIC ON-SITE VISITS, WHEN NECESSARY; AND - INITIATING AUDITS, WHEN NECESSARY.

Grants are awarded to students based on eligibility requirements which are determined on the basis of financial need academic ability and (or) special abilities. Need based financial aid is determined using federal regulations. Students must also maintain satisfactory academic progress which is monitored at the end of each semester. All grants are applied to tuition and fee accounts.

The College monitors the use of grant funds by verifying student enrollment records maintained by the Office of the Registrar and the Office of Student Accounts. Enrollment verification is performed prior to awarding of grant funds and throughout the academic year. The Office of Financial Aid monitors the College's compliance with grant agreement requirements throughout the academic year, and keeps current with compliance requirements by participating in professional development workshops and reviewing federal compliance updates from the Department of Education and NASFAA.
Grant funds are credited to student accounts in the form of need-based financial aid that reduce the comprehensive fee.

In providing financial aid to students, Trinity Christian College adheres to federal and state guidelines as well as internal criteria such as academic progress, financial need and other criteria established for particular scholarships. The federal FAFSA form is used. Student accounts are directly credited for scholarships awarded and therefore, no cash changes hands.

SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 Scholarships and fellowships are awarded by Queens University of Charlotte to students based on their academic achievement, talent in the fine arts, and participation in intercollegiate athletics. The awards are based on their performance levels. Students are also awarded need-based scholarships and grants based on their need as established by completing the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) and, if applicable, by specific criteria and guidelines for other federal and state programs.

STUDENT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS. STUDENTS CAN APPLY FOR CERTAIN GRANTS AND CAN ALSO BE NOMINATED FOR GRANTS BY FACULTY. EACH STUDENT HAS INDIVIDUAL ACCOUNTS WITH THE AMOUNT OF THEIR GRANTS; REIMBURSEMENTS ARE APPROVED AND THEN GIVEN TO THE STUDENT. TRAVEL AND STUDENT RESEARCH GRANTS REQUIRE SUBSTANTIATION.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PART III: ACCOUNTING FOR CASH AND NONCASH ASSISTANCE:
ExplntnTxt: PAYMENTS/REIMBURSEMENTS DIRECTLY TO RECIPIENTS ARE CONSIDERED CASH ASSISTANCE. PAYMENTS TO VENDORS TO BENEFIT RECIPIENTS, OR THE PURCHASE OF NONCASH ITEMS TO BE GIVEN TO RECIPIENTS, ARE CONSIDERED NONCASH ASSISTANCE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PART III, COLUMN B: NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS:
ExplntnTxt: THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS FOR STUDENT SCHOLARSHIPS IS BASED ON THE FINANCIAL AID RECORDS OF RECIPIENTS. THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS FOR PRIZES AND AWARDS IS ESTIMATED BASED ON THE NUMBER OF PAYEES (CASH PRIZES/AWARDS), AND THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS BENEFITTED BY THE NUMBER OF ITEMS PURCHASED (NONCASH PRIZES/AWARDS). THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS FOR STUDENT RESEARCH AND TRAVEL GRANTS IS ESTIMATED BASED ON THE NUMBER OF PAYEES (CASH GRANTS); AND/OR THE NUMBER OF RESEARCH PROJECTS FUNDED (CASH AND NONCASH GRANTS).

GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO GOVERNMENT AND ORGANIZATIONS (INCLUDING SUBAWARD TO INDIVIDUAL): GW MAINTAINS A FORMAL SUBRECIPIENT MONITORING POLICY FOR USE OF SPONSORED FUNDS. THE POLICY APPLIES TO SUBRECIPIENTS WHO ARE PERFORMING A PORTION OF THE SPONSORED PROJECT WORK EXTERNALLY AND CONFORMS TO THE APPLICABLE FEDERAL RULES AND REGULATIONS REQUIRED BY VARIOUS OMB CIRCULARS. GW HAS INTERNAL PROCEDURES ASSESSING RISK RELATED TO LOW, MEDIUM, AND HIGH RISK SUBRECIPIENTS BEFORE A SUBAWARD IS DRAFTED AND SUBSEQUENTLY EXECUTED. PROCEDURES FOR EARLY RISK ASSESSMENT AND DURING THE AWARD MONITORING ARE DEFINED BY ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES AT GW AND INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO, THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR, HIS/HER DEPARTMENT ADMINISTRATORS, CENTRAL RESEARCH, AND FINANCIAL OFFICES WITHIN GW. GW HILLEL ONLY - THE ORGANIZATION PRESENTED PLANS FOR THE RENOVATION, MAINTENANCE, FURNISHING, AND ENDOWMENT OF GW HILLEL'S FACILITIES LOCATED ON THE GW CAMPUS. DETAILS, SUCH AS BUDGETS, ARE PROVIDED TO GW ON REQUEST IN CONNECTION WITH ITS REVIEW. A REPORT WILL BE PROVIDED TO GW UPON COMPLETION OF THE RENOVATION. MEDICAL FACULTY ASSOCIATES, INC. JOINT FUNDRAISING CAMPAIGN ONLY - MFA AGREES TO SPEND PHILANTHROPICALLY RAISED FUNDS CONSISTENT WITH DONOR INTENT AND TO PROVIDE ANNUAL REPORTS ON THE USE OF EXPENSED FUNDS AND RELATED DETAIL TO GW. GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS: THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE KEEPS RECORDS ON ITS INTEGRATED SOFTWARE SYSTEM THAT SUBSTANTIATES THE AMOUNT GRANTED TO EACH STUDENT, THE ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA FOR EACH STUDENT, AND THE SELECTION PROCESS USED IN AWARDING ASSISTANCE. THE UNIVERSITY'S GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE ARE INITIALLY CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT IN ITS INTEGRATED SOFTWARE SYSTEM IN ORDER TO PAY FOR TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD, AND/OR TEXTBOOK CHARGES. A CHANGE IN ENROLLMENT STATUS RESULTS IN WEEKLY REPORTS THAT FINANCIAL AID STAFF REVIEW FOR POSSIBLE ADJUSTMENTS. THE BALANCE OF AID IN EXCESS OF THE ABOVE CHARGES CAN BE REFUNDED TO THE STUDENT FOR LIVING EXPENSES. THE SYSTEM CHECKS THAT THE STUDENT IS STILL ENROLLED BEFORE ISSUING THE REFUND. AT THE GRADUATE LEVEL, AWARDS ARE INITIATED, CHECKED TO ENSURE ELIGIBILITY AND APPROVED BEFORE AWARDS ARE OFFERED TO A STUDENT AND A STUDENT MUST ACCEPT THE AWARD BEFORE PAYMENT PROCESSES BEGIN. QUALIFICATIONS FOR ENDOWMENT AWARDS ARE CHECKED AND THE MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS FOR AWARDS ARE CHECKED FOR EVERY ENDOWMENT AWARDEE. PAPERWORK IS KEPT IN THE OFFICE FOR THREE YEARS AND THE AWARD LETTERS ELECTRONICALLY FOR FIVE YEARS. OUR ELECTRONIC SYSTEMS, BANNER AND EAS, HAVE THE RECORDS OF PAYMENTS.

IN RECOGNITION OF THE SERVICES THAT GW HILLEL PROVIDES TO STUDENTS AT GW, GW AND GW HILLEL CONDUCTED A JOINT FUNDRAISING CAMPAIGN FOR THE RENOVATION, MAINTENANCE, FURNISHINGS, AND ENDOWMENT OF GW HILLEL'S FACILITIES LOCATED ON THE GW CAMPUS. ALL RESTRICTED CONTRIBUTIONS RECEIVED BY GW UNDER THE CAMPAIGN ARE AWARDED AS GRANTS TO GW HILLEL UNDER THE TERMS OF THE JOINT FUNDRAISING AGREEMENT.

SCHEDULE I, PART 1, LINE 1 THE COLLEGE PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS MATRICULATING AT THE COLLEGE. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ISSUED ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY AGAINST THE STUDENT'S TUITION BALANCE; THEREFORE, THE STUDENT CAN EXERCISE NO DISCRETION IN THE USE OF THE FUNDS. SINCE ALL SCHOLARSHIPS DEFRAY THE COST OF TUITION, NO FURTHER MONITORING OF THE SCHOLARSHIPS IS REQUIRED.

Grant funds are monitored in two areas, depending on the use. Grant funds for financial aid are monitored by the Student Financial Services office, which oversees the awarding and compliance for all financial aid to University students. Grants for research and faculty development are monitored by the Assistant to the VPAA for Finance, Administration & Sponsored Programs. All grants are monitored for compliance and proper reporting by the Business Office of the University, overseen by the Vice President for Business & Finance.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS - PART I, LINE 2:
ExplntnTxt: All scholarships and grants are based on financial need or academic merit. Individuals receiving distributions from the University are chosen based upon objective and non-discriminatory criteria which are consistent with the overall tax-exempt purpose of the University. Scholarships are either applied to students' individual accounts at Denison, or sent directly to the off-campus program within the United States at which the student is studying.

and Schedule I, Part III, Line 1 - Southwestern Law School offers a number of scholarships from income provided by gifts from donors as well as its own general funds. Qualifications for amounts of scholarships vary, but the determination of awards is generally based on financial need and scholastic achievement, as well as the amount of funds available. Schedule I Part III, Line 2 - Federal Workstudy Grants are awarded to assist students in meeting their educational expenses through part-time employment, and to encourage them to participate in community service activities. Once funds have been approved by the Financial Aid office, the student must secure a position through an eligible employer. Schedule I Part III, Line 3 - Faculty Research Grants are awarded for faculty research in accord with written policies, based on annual written applications from full time members of the faculty. The applicant's record of compliance with the terms of previous stipend awards, assessment of the prior and proposed research and available funds are all considered. The Dean and the Dean of Research make recommendations to the Trustee Committee on Educational Policy, which makes its recommendation to the Board of Trustees. Schedule I Part III, Line 4 - Regarding Professorships, the Dean makes recommendations to the Board of Trustees of those Professors of Law to be named to Professorships and Endowed Chairs, and the Board acts to bestow the honor of this status, generally for a term of years. Distinction in research and quality teaching are essential. Where donor restrictions on a particular professorship or Chair call for subject matter expertise or other qualifications, those restrictions are taken into account as well.
Scholarships are awarded based on established criteria, including donor restrictions.

BASIS OF VERIFIED FINANCIAL NEED OR MERIT AND DOES NOT UNLAWFULLY DISCRIMINATE ON THE BASIS OF RACE, COLOR, NATIONAL OR ETHNIC ORIGIN, RELIGION, AGE, SEX DISABILITY OR PRIOR MILITARY SERVICE. FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE IS MONITORED SO THAT IT IS IN COMPLIANCE WITH AWARDING TERMS AND CONDITIONS. EXPENDITURES ARE REVIEWED FOR ALLOWABILITY AND COMPLIANCE. STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT APPROPRIATE DOCUMENTS PRIOR TO APPROVAL. PART III: CASH GRANTS ARE CREDITS TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS AND THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS REPRESENTS ONLY THE NUMBERS OF STUDENTS RECEIVING INSTITUTIONAL FUNDING. OUTSIDE GRANTS, OR APPLICATIONS OF FUNDS PROVIDED BY OUTSIDE AGENCIES (E.G. FEDERAL LOAN PROGRAMS) IS NOT INCLUDED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedure for Monitoring Use of Grant Funds Inside U.S.
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GRANTED TO STUDENTS BASED ON ACADEMIC MERIT, ATHLETIC MERIT AND ACADEMIC DISCIPLINE. STUDENT LOANS ARE AWARDED BASED ON FEDERAL ELIGIBILITY GUIDELINES AS PROVIDED BY THE US DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION DIRECT LENDING PROGRAM. STUDENT ATHLETICS MUST FOLLOW THE RULES SET FORTH BY THE NCAA. ONCE A SCHOLARSHIP HAS BEEN AWARDED, THE UNIVERSITY CHECKS THE RECIPIENTS' GRADE POINT AVERAGE AT THE END OF EACH SCHOOL YEAR TO DETERMINE IF THEY ARE MEETING THE ACADEMIC STANDARD SET FORTH BY THE SCHOOL OR DONOR. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AT JOHNSON C. SMITH UNIVERSITY IS RESPONSIBLE FOR CHECKING EACH ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENT'S GRADES BEFORE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED FOR THE NEXT SCHOOL YEAR. STUDENTS NOT MEETING SAP (SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS) WILL LOSE THEIR ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS. FOR NEEDS BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS, THE PARENTS OF THE RECIPIENTS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT A COPY OF THE TAX RETURN EACH YEAR TO THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE BEFORE NEW NEEDS BASED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED. STUDENTS RECEIVING ATHLETIC SCHOLARSHIPS MUST MAINTAIN A 2.0 OR HIGHER GRADE POINT AVERAGE AND MUST PASS AT LEAST 6 CREDIT HOURS IN THE FALL SEMESTER AND 24 CREDIT HOURS FOR THE SCHOOL YEAR. THE ATHLETICS COMPLIANCE COORDINATOR CHECKS THE GRADE REPORT FOR EACH STUDENT ATHLETE. EACH STUDENT ATHLETE'S GRADE REPORT IS EXAMINED AT THE END OF THE SEMESTER TO SEE IF HE OR SHE IS MEETING THE SET STANDARDS. IF THEY ARE NOT MEETING STANDARDS, THEY WILL LOSE THEIR SCHOLARSHIPS. FOR ALL SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS, IF A STUDENT WITHDREW FROM THE UNIVERSITY BEFORE COMPLETING 60 PERCENT OR MORE OF A SEMESTER, THEIR FINANCIAL AID INCLUDING INTERNAL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE PRORATED BASED THE R2T4 (RETURN OF TITLE 4 FUNDS) CALCULATION.
Grants are awarded to individuals based on compliance with eligibility requirements. Award grant and assistance amounts are applied by the University to the student tuition billing.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Wake Forest University carefully selects qualified exempt organizations for its contributions and provides support for worthy projects and events in which the University has an interest.Grants provided to students are monitored either through use -for University tuition and fees- or by requiring substantiation from the students for research projects or scholastic travel grants.Research subcontracts are awarded to qualifying research institutes able to complete research projects and monitored during such projects as well as by reviewing and collating the end results of the work.

PART I, LINE 2 USC Neighborhood Outreach funds are distributed through a competitive grant making process. A grant review committee comprised of university faculty and staff volunteers reviewS all grants and provideS funding recommendations based on a set of criteria. All final grant award decisions are made by Civic Engagement. USC Neighborhood Outreach monitors the grant awards through an interim report six months into the project and a final, cumulative report at the end of the project. We conduct adhoc site visits to observe the program and review EDUCATION CONSORTIUM OF CENTRAL LA (ECCLA) accounting records. THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA ADMINISTERS ONE OF THE NATION'S LARGEST FINANCIAL AID PROGRAMS THROUGH ITS FINANCIAL AID OFFICE, AWARDING $460 MILLION IN AID TO OVER TWO-THIRDS OF OUR UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS. WE WILL MEET THE FULL USC-DETERMINED FINANCIAL NEED OF ALL ADMITTED UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS WHO MEET ALL FEDERAL, STATE AND UNIVERSITY ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS AND DEADLINES. STUDENTS AND THEIR PARENTS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT ALL APPLICATIONS AND SUPPORT DOCUMENTS, MEETING ALL DEADLINES, IN ORDER TO MAKE THEIR CLAIM FOR FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND TO BE CONSIDERED FOR FINANCIAL AID. PART II THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA ALSO ADMINISTERS SUB-AWARDS FOR RESEARCH TO OTHER ORGANIZATIONS IN CONNECTION WITH RESEARCH GRANTS AWARDED TO THE UNIVERSITY. THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA DOES NOT REPORT THESE SUB-AWARDS AS GRANTS ON FORM 990, SCHEDULE I SINCE THE RECIPIENT ORGANIZATIONS PERFORM RESEARCH SERVICES FOR THE UNIVERSITY. PART III, COLUMN(C) THE CASH GRANT IS REFLECTED ON STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

FOR GRANTS RECEIVED BY THE COLLEGE, GRANTS ARE CONTROLLED BY A DESIGNATED RESPONSIBLE PERSON ON CAMPUS, WHO IS TYPICALLY THE PERSON WHO APPLIES FOR THE GRANT. ALL PROPOSED EXPENDITURES FROM THE GRANT MUST BE APPROVED BY THAT PERSON. THE ACCOUNTING DEPARTMENT REVIEWS THE INVOICE FOR APPROPRIATENESS WITH THE NATURE OF THE GRANT, REVIEWS THE ACTUAL TRANSACTION TO MAKE SURE THAT IT IS ADEQUATELY SUPPORTED, AND REVIEWS THE TRANSACTION TO BE SURE THAT IT IS AN ALLOWABLE EXPENSE UNDER FEDERAL LAW. EACH GRANT IS ASSIGNED ITS OWN SET OF GENERAL LEDGER ACCOUNTS TO SEGREGATE THE EXPENSES AND GRANT INCOME FROM OTHER EXPENDITURES AND REVENUES OF THE COLLEGE. IF THE GRANT IS A REIMBURSEMENT GRANT, THE COLLEGE PERIODICALLY DRAWS FUNDS DOWN FROM THE GRANTOR BASED ON THE ACTUAL EXPENSES INCURRED. WHEN REPORTS ARE DUE TO THE GOVERNMENT OR OTHER GRANTOR, THE RESPONSIBLE PERSON PREPARES THE REPORT WITH ASSISTANCE OF THE ACCOUNTING DEPARTMENT. TYPICALLY, THESE REPORTS ARE SIGNED BY THE RESPONSIBLE PERSON AND THE CFO OR PRESIDENT OF THE COLLEGE CERTIFYING THE ACCURACY OF THE REPORT. GRANTS SHOWN ON PART III ARE SCHOLARSHIPS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GRANTED IN TWO FORMS. FIRST, SOME SCHOLARSHIPS ARE FUNDED BY DONOR GIFTS OR INVESTMENT INCOME FROM DONOR GIFTS. THESE SCHOLARSHIPS MUST BE GRANTED AS THE DONOR HAS SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF THE GIFT. THE STUDENT MUST MEET THE DESIGNATED REQUIREMENTS OF THE DONOR. SECOND, THE COLLEGE ALSO AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS FROM GENERAL COLLEGE REVENUES. THESE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND FINANCIAL NEEDS WHICH IS CONSISTENT WITH INDUSTRY STANDARDS.
FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS AWARDS OF ALL FEDERAL FUNDS TO STUDENTS
THE COLLEGE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON STUDENT FINANCIAL NEED AND ABILITY. BOTH ARE BASED ON SET CRITERIA.

ORGANIZATIONS THAT RECEIVE GRANTS PROVIDE REPORTS INDICATING THAT THE FUNDS WERE USED EXCLUSIVELY FOR EXEMPT ACTIVITIES. ADDITIONALLY, FUNDS ARE ONLY GRANTED TO ORGANIZATIONS WHOSE STATED MISSION IS LIMITED TO EXEMPT ACTIVITIES COMPATIBLE WITH OLIVET UNIVERSITY'S MISSION.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: AWARDS TO STUDENTS ARE MONITORED THROUGH OUR FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

ALL GRANTS ARE SCHOLARSHIPS MADE TO STUDENTS AT THE UNIVERSITY. STUDENTS MUST MAINTAIN ENROLLMENT AND CERTAIN REQUIREMENTS TO MAINTAIN THEIR SCHOLARSHIPS. STUDENTS MUST SUBMIT FINANCIAL INFORMATION TO ESTABLISH QUALIFICATIONS FOR NEEDS BASED SCHOLARSHIPS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Grant amounts are paid based on a comprehensive application process.
Scholarships and other types of financial assistance are monitored through internal transfer of funds within the university.

All scholarships are awarded based upon specific criteria maintained by the financial aid office. Requirements for receiving scholarships depend upon other factors, such as grade point average, family income or economic need. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors the eligibility guidelines to ensure compliance. The College also undergoes the required OMB A-133 audit annually.

MANY OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS FOR THE ORGANIZATION ARE ALSO BOARD OF DIRECTORS FOR SALISH KOOTENAI COLLEGE FOUNDATION AND THEY OVERSEE AND ENSURE THAT FUNDS ARE UTILIZED PROPERLY. SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS OF THE COLLEGE BASED ON VARIOUS CRITERIA. THESE CRITERIA INCLUDE FINANCIAL NEED, GRADE POINT AVERAGE, AND OTHERS AS ESTABLISHED BY THE SCHOLARSHIP AND GRANT DOCUMENTS.
