FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: Students receiving scholarships and grants from Bethany College are monitored to ensure that they meet the academic requirements or other criteria associated with the respective designation of the award.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: Students receiving scholarships and grants from Bethany College are monitored to ensure that they meet the academic requirements or other criteria associated with the respective designation of the award.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Monitoring Uses of Grant Funds - PART I, LINE 2:
ExplntnTxt: All grant-related revenues and expenses awarded to the college are accounted for in separate and distinct restricted funds within the college's financial system. Within the accounting office, a grant file is established for each restricted grant fund which contains the grantor-approved budget and award letter among other pertinent information related to the grants, such as policies of the grantor. A full-time staff accountant is assigned to monitor the expenditure of the grant funds in terms of the grant budget, funds availability and allowability. Financial reports are prepared by the staff accountant and reviewed by the controller prior to submission to the granting agency. Lake Erie College's office of financial aid maintains records to comply with grantor's criteria for awarding funds to individual students. Student information is reviewed and maintained in a Powerfaids database and student files to determine eligibility for grants.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY HAS A FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT WHOSE STAFF IS TRAINED AND CONTINUOUSLY EDUCATED REGARDING FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID RULES AND REGULATIONS. THE STAFF OF THE UNIVERSITY DETERMINES THE FINANCIAL NEED OF THE STUDENT AND DETERMINES THE AMOUNT OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE THAT CAN BE AWARDED TO THE STUDENT BASED ON FEDERAL RULES AND REGULATIONS. THE FINANCIAL AID STAFF ALSO AWARDS GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON ENDOWED GIFTS THAT COMPLY WITH THE TERMS OF THE ENDOWED GIFTS.

THE MAJORITY OF INSTITUTIONAL AID AWARDED TO STUDENTS IS BASED ON ACADEMIC MERIT, FOR WHICH THE UNIVERSITY HAS A PREDETERMINED GRID THAT PROVIDES THE AMOUNTS TO BE AWARDED BASED ON THE STUDENTS ACTUAL GPA AND TEST SCORES AND AS NEEDED, EVALUATION BY THE UNIVERSITY'S SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE. OTHER INSTITUTIONAL AID CONSISTS OF RETURN MISSIONARY, TALENT AND OTHER NEED-BASED GRANTS. RETURNED MISSIONARY SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED IN THE AMOUNT OF $1,500 PER YEAR TO ALL FULL-TIME STUDENTS WHO HAVE COMPLETED A MISSION FOR THE CHURCH OF JESUS CHRIST OF LATTER-DAY SAINTS. TALENT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED IN VARIOUS AMOUNTS, NOT TO EXCEED $1,500 PER STUDENT, AND ARE AWARDED BASED ON THE NOMINATION OF THE UNIVERSITY FACULTY, THEATRE/MUSIC DIRECTOR, ETC. AND APPROVAL OF THE FINANCIAL AID COMMITTEE. UNIVERSITY GRANTS AND VARIOUS OTHER GRANTS ARE AWARDED AS DETERMINED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DIRECTOR. FEDERAL & STATE GRANTS, INCLUDING PELL, SEOG, SMART, AND VTAG ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO COMPLETE A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) AND MEET THE VARIOUS QUALIFICATIONS. FEDERAL AND STATE GRANTS ARE VERIFIED INTERNALLY BY OUR FINANCIAL AID STAFF. THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION (DOE) SELECTS A MINIMUM 30% OF ALL STUDENTS WHO COMPLETE A FAFSA TO VERIFY. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES THE APPROPRIATE VERIFICATION DOCUMENTATION TO THE DOE AND MAINTAINS A COPY OF THESE DOCUMENTS ON FILE.

GRANTS ARE PROCURED BY FACULTY WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF THE COLLEGE'S GRANT MANAGER. MONITORING IS DONE BY GRANTEE, GRANT MANAGER AND SENIOR ACCOUNTANT FOR COMPLIANCE. ACTIVITY IS AUDITED AND REPORTED ANNUALLY IN THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL STATEMENTS.

The University's Office of Financial Aid monitors all recipients of scholarship awards to determine both initial and continuing eligibility based on the criteria for each type of award, which may include academic performance, financial need, criteria established by donors of endowed scholarship funds, etc.

The organization uses congressional methodology from the U.S. Department of Education need analysis. It assigns student eligibility based on effective family contribution from the Pell Processing Center. All records on packaging as well as awarding are processed through the organization's PowerFAIDS system.

College funded scholarships and grants as well as scholarships and grants from restricted sources (need and merit based) provided to students of the four schools of the College. The scholarships are credited to student accounts and are monitored through the financial aid office in conjunction with the controller's office

ONCE THE SPECIFIC CRITERIA FOR EACH SCHOLARSHIP HAVE BEEN REVIEWED AND MET, GFU DISBURSES FINANCIAL AID FUNDS TO THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENT'S ACCOUNT DIRECTLY, ENSURING THAT THE FUNDS ARE USED AS INTENDED FOR TUITION AND EDUCATIONAL COSTS.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS ATTENDING BROOKLYN LAW SCHOOL AND ARE A DIRECT OFFSET OF TUITION. FELLOWSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS UNDER STRICT SELECTION CRITERIA. LOAN FORGIVENESS' ARE PAID DIRECTLY TO THE LENDER OR REQUIRES PROOF OF DEBT REDUCTION FROM THE STUDENT.

The College provides scholarships to students enrolled in its programs. Scholarships are awarded based upon student acheivements in academics and performing arts. To be considered for scholarship assistance, students must apply for admission and submit academic transcripts of prior education work, test scores (ACT/SAT), and an application for the scholarship program. Some scholarships require additional recommendations or certifications by third parties. Academic progress of scholarship recipients is monitored, and recipients must earn both a minimum amount of college credits and a minimum GPA each semester in order to maintain eligibility. The Seed Project Grant was established to foster and develop an entrepreneurial spirit amongst Covenant College students (including those who have been graduated for less than 1 year) and to create an opportunity for the students to develop real ideas and put them into action. Business plans are submitted by students for initial review by a committee of Covenant College faculty, staff, alumni, and other friends of the College. Once the business plan earns approval, the plan is presented to an independent panel of judges. The College awards the Seed Project Grant after the independent panel declares a winning idea. Recipients provide receipts to demonstrate that funds were used for legitimate and appropriate business expenses, and the College follows up with recipients at six month intervals following the award until the funds are depleted. Elevate is a national entrepreneurial competition, the College hosted one of their three regional competitions.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: The financial aid office notifies students when our comprehensive endowment scholarship application goes live (first week of february). Once notified, students fill out an application to apply for the respective scholarship. If the scholarship is for a specific program, the dean or other faculty member for that program will review the applications and make recommendations to the financial aid office and who should receive the award. Financial aid verifies again if the student is still eligible for the award and issues the funds to the recommended students. The financial aid office monitors the use of the funds to ensure that they are used for their intended purpose.

If the scholarship is for a specific program, the dean or other faculty member for that program will review the applications and make recommendations to the financial aid office and who should receive the award. Financial aid verifies again if the student is still eligible for the award and issues the funds to the recommended students. The financial aid office monitors the use of the funds to ensure that they are used for their intended purpose.

Students receiving scholarships are judged worthy thereof through the institution's assessment based on academic achievement, financial need and other similar standards. Use of funds is monitored according to standards as published in the student handbook which include satisfactory academic progress standards.

GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY VARIOUS AREAS. FINANCIAL AID GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DIRECTOR TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH ELIGIBILITY, SELECTION, AND DISTRIBUTION. DOCUMENTATION IS MAINTAINED AND AUDITED ANNUALLY. OTHER DEPARTMENT GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY THE RESPONSIBLE PARTY TO ENSURE THAT EXPENDITURES COMPLY WITH GRANT REQUIREMENTS AND ARE NOT DIVERTED FOR OTHER USES.

THE INSTITUTION AWARDS GRANTS TO STUDENTS BASED ON CRITERIA SET FORTH IN THE INDIVIDUAL SCHOLARSHIPS. THIS CRITERIA IS EXPLAINED IN THE 2014-15 COLLEGE CATALOG BEGINNING ON PAGE 38. ANY "NEED BASED" GRANT IS BASED ON THE INFORMATION OBTAINED FROM THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA).
FINANCIAL AID MONITORS ALL OF THE SCHOLARSHIPS THAT ARE AWARDED TO THE STUDENTS TO ENSURE THAT THEY MEET THE REQUIRED GUIDELINES.
FINANCIAL AID VERIFIES ELIGIBILITY AND AWARDS APPROPRIATELY. FUNDS ARE TRANSFERRED TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS TO COVER FEES. NO OVER-AWARDING IS PERMITTED.

ALL COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE AWARDED THROUGH THE FINANCIAL AID PROCESS AND ARE RECORDED AS CREDITS ON THE STUDENTS' INVOICES. THESE AWARDS HELP TO OFFSET THE COST OF TUITION, FEES AND ROOM AND BOARD. THE SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE TRACKED IN THE COLLEGE'S ERP SYSTEM AND MONITORED FOR COMPLIANCE WITHIN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE TO COMPLY WITH INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL REGULATIONS.

A NUMBER OF COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AVAILABLE TO DEGREE STUDENTS. COMPLETION OF A SCHOLARSHIP APPLICATION FORM IS REQUIRED. FORMS ARE AVAILABLE THROUGH THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. AN APPLICATION MUST BE SUBMITTED 30 DAYS PRIOR TO THE QUARTER FOR WHICH THE SCHOLARSHIP IS BEING REQUESTED.
THE SCHOLARSHIPS AND TUITION WAIVERS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS ATTENDING THE UNIVERSITY AND ARE APPLIED TOWARD THEIR TUITION.

ALL FUNDS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY FROM THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND THE BUSINESS OFFICE TO THE STUDENT'S OUTSTANDING BALANCE AT THE COLLEGE. USE IS INTERNALLY CONTROLLED BY THE COLLEGE. NECO SCHOLARSHIPS REQUIRE A MINIMUM 3.2 GRADE POINT AVERAGE.

The College uses a validation process to review eligibility to receive awards and to ensure compliance with grant requirements. Major grant programs are audited annually to ensure compliance with grant requirements and financial reporting.

EVERY FULL-TIME TRADITIONAL UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT IS CONSIDERED FOR MERIT-BASED FINANCIAL AID. MERIT-BASED AID IS DETERMINED BY THE ADMISSIONS AND FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT'S ANALYSIS OF A STUDENT'S ACADEMIC CREDENTIALS, SUCH AS STANDARDIZED TEST SCORES AND HIGH SCHOOL TRANSCRIPTS. A STUDENT INTERESTED IN RECEIVING NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID IS REQUIRED TO SUBMIT A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) FOR EACH SCHOOL YEAR. ONCE ALL THE ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA ARE MET AND ALL NECESSARY DOCUMENTS ARE OBTAINED, EITHER THROUGH REVIEW OF THE ISIR OR BY EFFORTS OF THE FINANCIAL AID COUNSELOR, THE FINANCIAL NEED OF THE STUDENT IS DETERMINED BY THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN THE COST OF ATTENDANCE AT XAVIER AND THE EFC TOWARD THOSE COSTS. AFTER THE FINANCIAL NEED FOR THE STUDENT IS CALCULATED, THE FINANCIAL AID PACKAGE FOR EACH STUDENT IS DETERMINED BY THE BANNER SYSTEM BASED ON THE STUDENT'S FINANCIAL NEED, ACADEMIC MERIT, TALENT, ENROLLMENT STATUS, LEVEL IN SCHOOL, AND DEPENDENCY STATUS. AWARD LETTERS (VIA E-MAIL OR REGULAR MAIL) ARE THEN PREPARED AND SENT TO EACH STUDENT, NOTIFYING THEM OF WHAT TYPES OF AWARDS THEY ARE DEEMED ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE. THE STUDENT THEN HAS THE OPTION TO DECLINE ANY AID THAT IS OFFERED TO THEM. XAVIER USES PASSIVE ACCEPTANCE OF AID OFFERED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS AND FINANCIAL AID TO STUDENTS BASED ON NEED AND MERIT. THE FUNDS ARE CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED IN ACCORDANCE WITH UNIVERSITY RETENTION AND DESTRUCTION POLICY. THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT ADHERES STRICTLY TO ALL FEDERAL AND STATE REGULATIONS AND IS SUBJECT TO THE COMPLIANCE AND INTERNAL CONTROLS OF OMB-A133 (IN WHICH THEY FOLLOW ALL APPLICABLE GUIDELINES).

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS AND FINANCIAL AID TO STUDENTS BASED ON NEED AND MERIT. THE FUNDS ARE CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED IN ACCORDANCE WITH UNIVERSITY RETENTION AND DESTRUCTION POLICY. THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT ADHERES STRICTLY TO ALL FEDERAL AND STATE REGULATIONS AND IS SUBJECT TO THE COMPLIANCE AND INTERNAL CONTROLS OF OMB-A133 (IN WHICH THEY FOLLOW ALL APPLICABLE GUIDELINES).

THE LYME ACADAMY OF FINE ARTS IS COMMITTED TO ASSISTING STUDENTS IN THE FINANCING THEIR EDUCATION. LYME ACADEMY OFFERS A COMPREHENSIVE FINANCIAL AID PROGRAM, WITH THE STUDENTS RECEIVING ASSISTANCE OF GRANTS, SCHOLARSHIPS, STUDENT LOANS, AND PART-TIME EMPLOYMENT WHICH ARE AVAILABLE FROM FEDERAL AND STATE GOVERNMENTS, PRIVATE SPONSORS, AND FROM UNIVERSITY RESOURCES. MOST FINANCIAL AID AWARDS ARE BASED ON AN INDIVIDUAL'S DEMONSTRATION OF NEED. AFTER CAREFUL CONSIDERATION OF THE APPLICATION CALCULATING NEED, THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE ATTEMPTS ASPECTS OF A STUDENT'S FINANCIAL CIRCUMSTANCES. NEED-ONLY AVAILABLE TO U.S. CITIZEN'S OR ELIGIBLE NON-CITIZENS. STUDENTS MUST BE MAKING SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS AND BE IN GOOD ACADEMIC STANDING IN ORDER TO BE ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE FINANCIAL AID. FEDERAL, STATE, PRIVATE GRANT FUNDS AND INSTITUTIONAL NORMALLY APPLIED AS CREDITS TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

HERITAGE UNIVERSITY PARTICIPATES IN FEDERAL GRANTS AND LOAN PROGRAMS. ALL OF THE STUDENT AWARDING PROCESS IS DOCUMENTED IN THE SOFTWARE USED TO DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY AND TRACK STUDENT AWARDS. FOR THOSE AWARDS WITH SUBJECTIVE SELECTION CRITERIA, THE DOCUMENTATION IS MAINTAINED BY THE PERSON RESPONSIBLE FOR SUCH AWARDS OR GRANTS. HERITAGE UNIVERSITY UNDERGOES A YEARLY AUDIT OF THE GRANTS AND OTHER FEDERAL FUNDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH A-133; A-87; AND OTHERS.

Scholarships and tuition discounts are awarded to students on an individual basis. Awards are based on demonstrated financial need, academic preparation, and mission compatability of the student. The financial aid department has primary responsibility for evaluating students for awards but collaborates with a wider range of colleagues throughout the institution.
THE ORGANIZATION MONITORS THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE UNITED STATES BY ONLY DONATING TO THE RELATED ORGANIZATIONS LISTED UNDER SCHEDULE R.
FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS IN ACCORDANCE WITH DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION REGULATIONS AND REQUIREMENTS, AND MOUNT CARMEL HEALTH SYSTEM FOUNDATION REQUIREMENTS.

Schedule I, Part 1, Line 2- The College provides scholarship assistance to enrolled students to defray costs of attendance. Such assistance is credited directly to Students' billing accounts in accordance with federal regulations or donor stipulations.

MONITORING: FORDHAM PROVIDES VARIOUS TYPES OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO PROMOTE ACCESS AND AFFFORDABILITY TO STUDENTS. FORDHAM'S FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT WORKS WITH STUDENTS TO HELP THEM DEVISE A PLAN TO FUND THEIR EDUCATION. ASSISTANCE MAY INCLUDE A COMBINATION OF GRANTS, LOANS AND PAYMENT PLANS DEPENDING ON INDIVIDUAL CIRCUMSTANCES AND RESOURCES. SCHOLARSHIP GRANTS ARE AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF FINANCIAL NEED AND/OR SCHOLASTIC ACHIEVEMENT, AND ON A NON-DISCRIMINATORY BASIS. STUDENTS MUST COMPLETE CERTAIN QUESTIONNAIRES AND APPLICATIONS TO DEMONSTRATE THEIR QUALIFICATION FOR VARIOUS TYPES OF FEDERAL, STATE, LOCAL, AND INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. THE VARIOUS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS HAVE PARTICULAR REQUIREMENTS FOR SELECTION CRITERIA AND MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS, SUCH AS THE CODE OF FEDERAL REGULATIONS. THESE REQUIREMENTS MAY INCLUDE A MINIMUM COURSE LOAD, DEMONSTRATED ACADEMIC PROGRESS, AND OTHER SIMILAR REQUIREMENTS.

ALL STUDENTS MUST BE ENROLLED IN COLLEGE COURSES TO RECEIVE SCHOLARSHIP ASSISTANCE. STUDENTS MUST ALSO MAINTAIN CERTAIN GRADE POINT AVERAGES AND MAKE SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS TO BE ELIGIBLE FOR SCHOLARSHIPS. OUR COMPUTER SYSTEM IS SET UP TO NOT AWARD ANY SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS TO NON-REGISTERED STUDENTS. A REPORT IS GENERATED AT THE END OF EACH SEMESTER BY THE REGISTRAR'S OFFICE SHOWING STUDENTS WHO ARE NOT MAINTAINING THE PROPER GRADE POINT AVERAGE OR WHO ARE NOT MAKING SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS. THIS REPORT IS REVIEWED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE, ANY STUDENTS WHO DO NOT QUALIFY ACADEMICALLY FOR THE SCHOLARSHIPS WILL NOT RECEIVE THE SCHOLARSHIPS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: ALL ASSISTANCE IS IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS USED FOR TUITION AND FEES.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: DOWLING COLLEGE AWARDS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO STUDENTS BOTH MERIT BASED AND NEED BASED. ALL STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO MAINTAIN GOOD ACADEMIC STANDING (SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS) AS A CONDITION OF ENROLLMENT AT DOWLING COLLEGE AND TO RECEIVE VARIOUS TYPES OF FINANCIAL AID. STUDENTS ARE REVIEWED EACH SEMESTER BY THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID TO ENSURE THEY ARE MEETING SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS.
PART III, LINE 1- ESTIMATED NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS BASED ON AN AVERAGE GRANT AMOUNT.

FORM 990, SCH I, PART I, LINE 2 SINCE ITS INCEPTION, MANAGEMENT REVIEWS REQUESTS FOR GRANTS. TOURO UNIVERSITY MONITORS ALL REQUESTS FOR USE OF GRANT FUNDS AGAINST THE SUBMITTED BUDGETS FOR THE RESPECTIVE GRANTS. PRIOR TO SUBMISSION OF REQUESTS FOR REIMBURSEMENT, ADDITIONAL REVIEW OF EXPENDED FUNDS IS PERFORMED TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH GRANT AND COLLEGE GUIDELINES.

THE DEAN'S OFFICE MONITORS THE GRADES FOR ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING GRANTS. STUDENTS WITH CUMULATIVE GRADE POINT AVERAGES BELOW THE REQUIREMENT FOR THEIR DEGREE PROGRAM RISK LOSING THEIR GRANTS. ALSO, THE DEAN'S OFFICE MONITORS THE NUMBER OF CLASSES TAKEN BY ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING GRANTS. GRANTS ARE ONLY AVAILABLE FOR THE REQUIRED NUMBER OF COURSES FOR THE STUDENT'S DEGREE PROGRAM. NO GRANT IS AVAILABLE FOR ANY STUDENT THAT EXCEEDS THE REQUIRED NUMBER OF COURSES. AN AUDIT IS PERFORMED ANNUALLY BY THE SEMINARY'S INDEPENDENT AUDITORS.
The college maintains detailed records in its database of all scholarships awarded.

SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2: THE COLLEGE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO QUALIFIED INDIVIDUALS ON THE BASIS OF FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. THE AWARDING OF FUNDS IS MONITORED BY THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE, WHERE A COMPLETE LISTING OF RECIPIENTS IS ALSO MAINTAINED.

ALL GRANTS AND AWARDS MADE BY CENTRAL CHRISTIAN COLLEGE IN KANSAS ARE ADMINISTERED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE UNDER THE GUIDELINES AND REGULATIONS ESTABLISHED BY THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION. ALL SUCH GRANTS, AWARDS, AND SCHOLARSHIPS APPEAR ON THE INDIVIDUAL AWARD LETTERS THAT ARE SIGNED BY THE STUDENT RECIPIENTS. THESE SAME GRANTS AND AWARDS CAN BE TRACED DIRECTLY TO EACH STUDENT'S ACCOUNT AND ON THROUGH THE COLLEGE'S ACCOUNTING SYSTEM.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: THE COLLEGE THROUGH ITS FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MAINTAINS RECORDS TO SUBSTANTIATE AMOUNTS, ELIGIBILITY, AND SELECTION CRITERIA USED FOR SCHOLARSHIPS. THE COLLEGE MONITORS THE ASSISTANCE BY REVIEWING GRADE TRANSCRIPTS AND ATTENDANCE RECORDS ON A QUARTERLY BASIS.

NATIONAL UNIVERSITY INTERNATIONAL IDENTIFIES ELIGIBLE RECIPIENTS RELATED TO EDUCATIONAL AND COMMUNITY PURPOSES TO PROMOTE STEM SUBJECT AREAS. RECIPIENTS ARE MONITORED AS APPROPRIATE THROUGH PERIODIC REPORTS AND STUDENT RECORDS.

THE SCHOLARSHIPS GRANTED BY ADRIAN COLLEGE ARE USED TO PAY TUITION AND FEE CHARGES ON STUDENT ACCOUNTS. THE SCHOOL IS ALSO ABLE TO MONITOR WHETHER STUDENTS REMAIN AT THE COLLEGE THROUGH THE REGISTRAR'S OFFICE, THE VICE PRESIDENT AND DEAN OF ACADEMIC AFFAIRS' OFFICE, CLASS ATTENDANCE TAKEN BY FACULTY, AND HOUSING RECORDS MAINTAINED BY THE STUDENT AFFAIRS'OFFICE

All financial aid grants and scholarships to students who are United States citizens are recorded in the financial aid management software, PowerFAIDS, by amount per semester. Student Financial Services staff determine student eligibility based on a consistently applied need analysis formula which calculates the expected family contribution (EFC). The EFC is subtracted from the total cost of attendance to equal the financial aid eligibility. The financial aid grant amount is determined based on consistently applied packaging formulas to meet the full calculated need of each student. In addition to the need based aid that the College awards, there are some grants that are awarded based on merit or other factors. Financial aid grant funds are monitored through the financial aid management software, PowerFAIDS. Staff who will be awarding financial aid grant funds are trained to adhere to these policies and procedures. The financial aid grant information is transferred from PowerFAIDS to the student information system, Ellucian Colleague, via a regularly scheduled interface. When all institutional grant disbursement requirements are met, the funds are disbursed to the student account in Colleague. The funds are credited against any billed charges that have been previously posted. If this transaction results in a credit balance, the credit may be refunded to the student in the form of a check. The student initiates this refund process by submitting a completed Disbursement Form or Credit Balance Request Form. Student eligibility is monitored throughout the period of enrollment and adjustments are made, as necessary, for changes in enrollment status according to the College's published refund policies. *During the fiscal year, the College conducted grant-funded research. Four of the research grants included collaboration with institutions whose faculty are accomplished in their respective fields of study. *Infrequently at the discretion of the President or Vice President for Finance and Administration, the College makes donations to support the town or nonprofit organizations. In these instances, the College generally does not monitor the ultimate use of the funds as these amounts are unrestricted grants to municipalities and organizations that are recognized as being described in Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(3). In certain instances when the College grants funds for use by the town, the College maintains a written agreement that such grant will be used for the designated purpose.
The College monitors enrollment and the Financial Aid Office of the College keeps the requisite records in either an electronic or hard copy form.

The University's Office of Financial Aid monitors all recipients of scholarship awards to determine both initial and confirming eligibility based on the criteria for each type of award, which may include academic performance, financial need, and criteria established by donors of endowed scholarship funds, etc.

Criteria is established for the awarding of individual scholarships. Students must complete an application and scholarships are awarded after all external scholarships and grants have been applied, not to exceed the cost of attendance.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: AT THE TIME OF APPLICATION, PARTICIPANTS REQUEST FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND MUST PROVIDE FINANCIAL INFORMATION (TAX RETURNS, WIC/WELFARE VERIFICATION, UNEMPLOYMENT VERIFICATION, A STUDENT AID REPORT OR COLLEGE FINANCIAL AID AWARD LETTER) TO DEMONSTRATE THEIR LEVEL OF NEED. COLLEGE HORIZONS USES THE METHODOLOGY OF THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT TO DETERMINE THE EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION (EFC) AND FEDERAL PELL GRANT ELIGIBILITY. DEPENDING ON INCOME LEVEL, STUDENTS ARE AWARDED FULL OR PARTIAL TUITION REMEDIATION AND FULL OR PARTIAL TRAVEL ASSISTANCE IN ACCORDANCE WITH BOARD APPROVED LEVELS. TO ENSURE FUNDS ARE NOT DIVERTED FROM THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE, TUITION DISCOUNTS ARE NON CASH ASSISTANCE IN THE FORM OF WAIVED TUITION AND TRAVEL ASSISTANCE IS GENERALLY PAID DIRECTLY TO THE AIRLINES FOR THE PARTICIPANTS TRAVEL TO THE PROGRAM.

DETAIL OF SUBAWARDS IN FURTHERANCE OF ITS RESEARCH ACTIVITIES, THE UNIVERSITY OF ROCHESTER MAKES SUB-AWARDS TO OTHER ORGANIZATIONS THAT PERFORM RESEARCH IN CONNECTION WITH RESEARCH GRANTS AWARDED TO THE UNIVERSITY. THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT CATEGORIZE THESE SUB-AWARDS AS "GRANTS" FOR FORM 990, SCHEDULE I REPORTING, SINCE THE RECIPIENT ORGANIZATIONS PERFORM RESEARCH SERVICES FOR THE UNIVERSITY AND ARE CONSIDERED INDEPENDENT CONTRACTORS WHICH SERVE THE DIRECT NEEDS OF THE UNIVERSITY.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 AND PART III
ExplntnTxt: STUDENT SCHOLARSHIP, FELLOWSHIPS AND STUDENT LOANS THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID MONITORS THE DISBURSEMENT OF GRANTS AND FEDERAL LOANS TO STUDENTS. STUDENTS WHO RECEIVE SCHOLARSHIPS, FELLOWSHIPS AND STUDENT LOANS FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF ROCHESTER ARE SELECTED AND THE AMOUNT OF GRANTS OR LOANS DETERMINED BY OBJECTIVE AND NON-DISCRIMINATORY PROCESSES APPLIED TO ALL SIMILARLY SITUATED INDIVIDUALS. THE DECISIONS ARE MADE ON A CASE BY CASE BASIS THROUGH EVALUATING THE ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND FINANCIAL NEED OF THE APPLICANT IN LIGHT OF THE FUNDS AVAILABLE FOR THIS PURPOSE. --------------------

THE UNIVERSITY ABIDES BY THE REGULATORY PROVISIONS SET ASIDE IN ALL GRANT AWARDS TO ENSURE PROPER FINANCIAL AND PROGRAMMATIC REPORTING. THE UNIVERSITY'S OFFICE OF SPONSORED PROGRAMS (OSP) PROVIDES OVERSIGHT AND MONITORING OF ALL GRANTS. OSP RECEIVED MONTHLY, QUARTERLY, AND ANNUAL REPORTS FROM ALL GRANTS FUNDED PROJECT DIRECTORS (PD) AND PROJECT INVESTIGATORS (PI) ASSOCIATED WITH THE IMPLEMENATION OF THE GRANT AWARDS. OSP MEETS WITH THE PDS AND PIS WEEKLY TO ENSURE THAT THE GRANTS ARE ON TARGET FOR COMPLETION. OSP WORKS CONJUNCTIVELY WITH THE DEPARTMENT OF ADMINISTRATION AND FINANCE TO MONITOR AND RECONCILE ALL FINANCIAL OBLIGATIONS WITHIN GRANTS AND CONTRACTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PART I, LINE 1:CRITERIA FOR RECEIVING A SCHOLARSHIP THROUGH THE UNIVERSITY
ExplntnTxt: THE MAIN DETERMINANT OF FINANCIAL AID IS NEED, AND ONE OF THE MAJOR ELEMENTS IN THE NEED EQUATION IS THE COST OF ATTENDING SCHOOL. STUDENTS HAVE DIFFERENT BUDGETS, DEPENDING ON WHETHER THE STUDENT LIVES ON OR OFF CAMPUS. STUDENT EXPENSE BUDGETS INCLUDE THE COST OF TUITION AND FEES, BOOKS AND SUPPLIES, A MONTHLY ALLOWANCE FOR ROOM AND BOARD, TRANSPORTATION TO AND FROM SCHOOL, AND PERSONAL EXPENSES SUCH AS CLOTHES AND ENTERTAINMENT. ALL STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO COMPLETE THE FAFSA, REGARDLESS OF INCOME, BEFORE NEED CAN BE DETERMINED. ONCE THE FAFSA IS COMPLETED AND THE RESULTS ARE RECEIVED AT THE INSTITUTION FROM THE FEDERAL CENTRAL PROCESSOR, THE INSTITUTION WILL USE THE EFC (EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION) TO AWARD FINANCIAL AID. ALL STUDENTS, WHOSE EFCS FALL WITHIN THE 0-5273 EFC RANGE WILL RECEIVE PELL GRANTS, RANGING FROM $400.00 TO $5,550.00.

GRANTS ARE ACCOUNTED FOR IN THE UNIVERSITY'S ACCOUNTING RECORDS, INCLUDING SUPPORTING DOCUMENTATION FOR ALL EXPENDITURES. GRANT MANAGERS ARE REQUIRED TO ASSERT THAT FUNDS HAVE BEEN SPENT IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE GRANT REQUIREMENTS.

ORGANIZATION'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN U.S. DUKE UNIVERSITY PERIODICALLY APPROVES GRANTS AND TRANSFERS GRANT FUNDS TO NUMEROUS ORGANIZATIONS WITHIN THE UNITED STATES. FOR SUBGRANT RECIPIENTS, A SERIES OF INTERNAL CONTROLS HAVE BEEN ESTABLISHED WHICH INCLUDE DETERMINATION OF WHETHER AN AUDIT WILL BE REQUIRED. DUKE UNIVERSITY HAS ESTABLISHED A DETAILED AND COMPETITIVE APPLICATION PROCESS WHICH ENSURES PROPER PURPOSE AND USE OF THESE GRANT FUNDS PRIOR TO ENGAGEMENT. FOLLOWING THE PROCUREMENT PROCESS, DUKE UNIVERSITY MONITORS SUBSEQUENT BILLING AND PERFORMANCE OF THE GRANT RECIPIENTS. INVOICES MUST BE SUBMITTED ACCORDING TO THE TERMS AND CONDITIONS WHICH MIRROR THE TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF THE ULTIMATE GRANTOR. PRIOR TO PAYMENT, CENTRALIZED DEPARTMENTS REVIEW DOCUMENTATION TO ENSURE THE EXPENSES ARE ALLOWABLE WITHIN THE TERMS OF THE GRANT. ULTIMATELY, THE ORGANIZATIONS AWARDED THESE GRANTS MUST MONITOR THE APPROPRIATE DISTRIBUTION OF THESE GRANT FUNDS IN THE ORDINARY COURSE OF BUSINESS AND REPORT SUCH INFORMATION TO DUKE UNIVERSITY. STUDENTS' INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS AND FINANCIAL AID IS POSTED DIRECTLY TO THEIR BURSAR ACCOUNTS. THEREFORE, SUCH FUNDS ARE DIRECTLY APPLIED TO APPROPRIATE CHARGES WITHIN THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS. GRANT/FELLOWSHIP PAYMENTS ARE PROCESSED ACCORDING TO AWARD LETTERS, WHICH ARE REVIEWED AND SUBMITTED TO THE RECIPIENT IN ADVANCE OF ACCEPTING FOR THE APPLICABLE SEMESTER. EACH PAYMENT IS PREPARED ACCORDING TO THE AWARD LETTER BY A DEPARTMENTAL REPRESENTATIVE, WHICH IS THEN REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY A DEPARTMENTAL SUPERVISOR. PRIOR TO ISSUANCE, A FINAL REVIEW AND APPROVAL IS PROCESSED BY THE CENTRAL PAYMENT PROCESSING DEPARTMENT.

THE SEMINARY PROVIDES FINANCIAL AID TO STUDENTS BY DIRECTLY CREDITING THEIR TUITION INVOICE WITH THE AMOUNT OF THE SCHOLARSHIP. FINANCIAL AID COMMITTEE MAINTAINS COPIES OF THE NEED-BASED APPLICATIONS, FAFSA'S AND AWARD LETTERS. THE LETTERS ARE SIGNED BY THE CHIEF BUSINESS OFFICER AND FORWARDED TO HIS ASSISTANT. AID IS THEN AWARDED AND APPLIED TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNTS. THE CHIEF BUSINESS OFFICER THEN COMPARES THE INFORMATION POSTED TO THE AWARD LETTERS FOR ACCURACY.

JOHN F KENNEDY UNIVERSITY IDENTIFIES ELIGIBLE GRANTEES AS PER REGULATIONS FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES AND COMMUNITY SERVICES. GRANT FUNDS AND GRANTEES ARE MONITORED AS APPROPRIATE PER REGULATIONS THROUGH PERIODIC AND ANNUAL REPORTS.

Grant funds are managed in accordance with both the sponsor and University rules and regulations. Expenditures are reviewed on a pre and post audit basis to ensure that the costs incurred and charged to a particular grant is in compliance with both the sponsor and University policies. Schedule I, Part III The cash grants are reflected on students' accounts.

SAINT PETER'S UNIVERSITY ("UNIVERSITY") PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS MATRICULATING AT THE UNIVERSITY FOR VARIOUS REASONS INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE, STUDENT INSTITUTIONAL AID AND ATHLETICS. THEREFORE, ALL FUNDS GRANTED ARE USED TO DEFRAY THE COST OF TUITION AND NO FURTHER MONITORING OF THE GRANTS IS REQUIRED.
HOPE SCHOLARSHIP/GRANT FUNDS ARE DISBURSED TO THE RECIPIENT UPON PROOF OF ELIGILIBITY (I.E. FINANCIAL NEED OR ACADEMIC MERIT) AND UPON PROOF OF EXPENSE INCURRED.

GRANT FUNDING IS AWARDED TO STUDENTS BY STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES WITHIN ESTABLISHED BUDGET LEVELS BASED ON UNIVERSITY POLICIES. GRANT FUNDS ARE CREDITED TO INDIVIDUAL STUDENT ACCOUNTS ELECTRONICALLY. STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES WORKS WITH ADVANCEMENT STAFF TO ENSURE THAT RESTRICTED FUNDS ARE AWARDED WITHIN ESTABLISHED CRITERIA, AND WITH FINANCE STAFF TO DETERMINE AVAILABILITY OF FUNDS. STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES MAINTAINS INTERNAL POLICIES AND PROCEDURES FOR THE CORRECT AWARDING AND ADJUSTING OF INSTITUTIONAL FUNDS. ANNUAL AUDITS ARE CONDUCTED TO ASSURE COMPLIANCE WITH ALL POLICIES AND PROCEDURES. NORTHEASTERN UNIVERSITY (NU) HAS A FULL TIME EMPLOYEE TO MONITOR SUBAWARDS. - NU FOLLOWS FEDERAL REGULATIONS AS PART OF THE SUBRECIPIENT MONITORING UNDER A-133 (now Uniform Guidance 2 CFR 200). - NU REVIEWS THE FEDERAL AUDIT CLEARINGHOUSE AND INSTITUTION'S A-133 REPORTS (now Uniform Guidance 2 CFR 200). - DESK REVIEWS ARE PERFORMED, AND PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS APPROVE ALL INVOICES.

Scholarships are awarded on the basis of academic achievement while grants are awarded on the basis of financial need, academic achievement, and other similar standards as designated by the U.S. Department of Education.

Part I Line 2 THE UNIVERSITY GRANTS LISTED ON SCHEDULE I REPRESENT SCHOLARSHIPS PROVIDED TO STUDENTS WHO MATRICULATE AT THE UNIVERSITY. AS SUCH, NO MONITORING OF THE GRANT FUNDS ARE REQUIRED BECAUSE THE STUDENT MAY ONLY USE THE SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS TO DEFRAY THE COST OF TUITION.

SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2: SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS OF THE COLLEGE BASED ON VARIOUS CRITERIA. THESE CRITERIA INCLUDE FINANCIAL NEED, GRADE POINT AVERAGE, AND OTHERS AS ESTABLISHED BY THE SCHOLARSHIP DOCUMENTS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED TO THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENT'S ACCOUNTS TO PAY TUITION, ROOM AND BOARD EXPENSES.THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS SHOWN FOR SCHEDULE I PART III IS BASED ON THE NUMBER OF GRANTS AWARDED. THIS AMOUNT IS USED AS A REASONABLE ESTIMATE OF THE TOTAL NUMBER OF STUDENTS AWARDED GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Process for Monitoring Use of Grant Funds in the United States:
ExplntnTxt: SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2: THUNDERBIRD AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS TO COMPETITIVE APPLICANTS WHO DEMONSTRATE A HIGH LEVEL OF ACADEMIC CREDENTIALS AND EVIDENCE THAT THEY MEET SPECIFIC CRITERIA ASSOCIATED WITH A SPECIFIC AWARD. THUNDERBIRD AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS FROM EVERY CONTINENT OF THE WORLD.

Disbursements in furtherance of the institution's exempt programs are made in accordance with procedures or subject to conditions established by the institutions governing board designed to insure that individuals and organizations receiving disbursements from the institution in furtherance of its exempt purpose are adequately investigated to insure that they are qualifying recipients. Students receiving scholarships and fellowships are judged worthy by the institution on the basis of criteria such as academic achievement (fellowships) and financial need (scholarships and fellowships).

Monterey College of Law provides scholarships to new and continuing students. The scholarships are awarded by a scholarship committee populated by members of the board of trustees. The scholarships are awarded each Fall and Spring semesters. Most scholarships are need-based or based on academic achievements. Monterey College of Law maintains complete records of the scholarship award amounts, evidence of good academic standing and criteria for scholarship selection.

INSTITUTIONAL MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF DEMONSTRATED ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE AND PROMISE FOR FUTURE SUCCESS AT THE COLLEGE. WHILE A NUMBER OF FACTORS ARE CONSIDERED, THE COLLEGE RELIES HEAVILY ON THE EVALUATION OF HIGH SCHOOL COURSEWORK, HIGH SCHOOL GRADE POINT AVERAGES AND CLASS RANK, STANDARDIZED TEST SCORES, WRITTEN WORK AND LETTERS OF RECOMMENDATION. EXTRACURRICULAR INVOLVEMENT THAT DEMONSTRATES A PROMISE FOR SUCCESS AT THE COLLEGIATE LEVEL IS ALSO CONSIDERED. SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS ARE APPLIED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT FOR PAYMENT TOWARD TUITION, ROOM, BOARD AND FEES.

Grants are made and monitored in accordance with Federal and institutional financial aid policies. Amounts are applied to student accounts as credits to the bill at the Bursar's office to offset academic charges.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Scholarship Funds, both budgeted and investments, are monitored by the Board of Directors and appointed staff, with dividends being awarded as scholarships by decision of the Financial Aid Office and/or the Scholarship Committee, and distributed through the Business Office.
The University awards financial aid to students based on certain eligibility requirements. The University's financial aid package is on file at the University and is available upon request.

MEDICAL AND GRADUATE SCHOOL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS AT MCW. MCW MAINTAINS RECORDS TO JUSTIFY THE AWARD DECISIONS, INCLUDING THE FINANCIAL AID ELIGIBILITY OF THE RECIPIENTS. In support of its research mission, MCW is the recipient of Federal and non-federal grant funds. Some of the grant awards are subawarded to qualified organizations (subrecipients) to assist or provide an intellectual contribution to the project based on the requirements of the prime award. MCW's community engagement mission is complemented by the Advancing a Healthier Wisconsin (AHW) endowment under which funds are awarded to qualified organizations to support initiatives that improve the health of the residents of the State of Wisconsin. To monitor the use of research subawards and AHW awarded funds, MCW enters into signed subaward agreements which contain the terms and conditions of the subaward relationship. The subaward agreements require that prior to reimbursement of expenses, the subrecipient provides a certified invoice to MCW. Before approval of an invoice for payment, MCW verifies that the invoice and any supporting documentation submitted by the subrecipient are in line with the approved subaward budget and that the cost detail presented provides reasonable assurance that costs to be reimbursed are allowable, allocable, and reasonable. Progress reports submitted by the subrecipient are reviewed to determine that progress is being made toward the goals and objectives of the subaward. MCW obtains an annual OMB Circular A-133 audit report, or a financial audit report or subrecipient questionnaire for organizations not subject to OMB Circular A-133, to ensure that audit findings do not exist which would impact awarded funds. In cases where an audit is not required or if audit findings are noted, MCW assesses the risk of the organization and performs additional monitoring tasks.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedure for Monitoring Grants in the U.S.
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2: Students who receive grants from the University are determined in accordance with the University's standard policies and procedures. In summary, a student is required to complete a FAFSA to be considered for financial aid assistance. Upon completion of the FAFSA, the university is provided the student's estimated family contributions (EFC). Based on the EFC and other criteria (i.e. enrollment status, academic standing, etc.), the Office of Financial Aid may award a student an institutional grant. There are systemic procedures in place to ensure that the grant is applied against tuition and meets the requirements of the specific grant. Student Accounts and the Office of Financial Aid are responsible for monitoring the student's financial aid status while at the University.
SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY EACH SCHOLARSHIP AND DETERMINED BY THE SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE.

The financial aid office determines student eligibility for federal, state, and institutional scholarships according to the University's established criteria which followss federal and state guidelines for awarding any grant funds. There is an annual audit to ensure compliance with these regulations.

ExplntnTxt: THE COLLEGE FOLLOWS GUIDELINES SET FORTH BY THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AND BY THE COLLEGE TO DETERMINE STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS. THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT HAS NUMEROUS POLICIES IN PLACE TO DETERMINE WHO RECEIVES, HOW THEY ARE ADMINISTERED, AND WHEN THE STUDENTS RECEIVE THE SCHOLARSHIPS.

STUDENT ENROLLMENT IS MONITORED ON A REGULAR BASIS. AFTER VERIFICATION OF ENROLLMENT EACH TERM, FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID GRANTS ARE APPLIED TO THE STUDENTS' EDUCATIONAL COSTS PER FEDERAL REGULATIONS. STUDENT WITHDRAWALS ARE ALSO MONITORED AND GRANT FUNDS ARE ADJUSTED AND RETURNED AS NECESSARY.

THE UNIVERSITY HAS A FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WITH THE NECESSARY STAFF, POLICIES AND PROCEDURES TO ENSURE THAT THE UNIVERSITY ADHERES TO AND COMPLIES WITH FEDERAL REGULATIONS REGARDING ELIGIBILITY FOR STUDENT FINANCIAL AID. THE UNIVERSITY HAS ADEQUATE STAFFING IN ITS OTHER GRANT PROGRAMS WITH ELIGIBILITY GUIDELINES TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE, THE UNIVERSITY ALSO UNDERGOES THE REQUIRED OMB CIRCULAR A-133 AUDITS.

THE $102,256,049 IN GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE REPRESENT STUDENT FINANCIAL AID, SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS, INCLUDING EMERGENCY STUDENT ASSISTANCE GRANTS. FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED BASED UPON FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. NEED BASED AID IS AWARDED BASED ON ELIGIBILITY DETERMINED BY THE US DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION'S FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL AID (FAFSA). ACADEMIC BASED AID IS AWARDED BY THE DISTINGUISHED SCHOLARS COMMITTEE. BOTH FACULTY AND ENROLLMENT SERVICES ADMINISTRATORS COMPRISE THE COMMITTEE.

GRANTS FOR SCHOLARSHIPS, FELLOWSHIPS AND STUDENT LOANS ARE MADE UPON FINANCIAL NEED AND THE ACADEMIC PROMISE OF STUDENTS APPLYING FOR FINANCIAL AID. ALL RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED TO SUBSTANTIATE THE AMOUNT OF GRANTS OR ASSISTANCE MADE TO STUDENTS.

St. John's University consistently strives to place an outstanding higher education within the financial reach of all qualified applicants. The University awards millions of dollars in federal and state financial aid funds each year based upon a student's financial need. Additionally, the University provides financial aid via University grants-in-aid, scholarships and tuition remission. Grants-in-aid are awarded on the basis of demonstrated financial need assessed by the use of a standard financial aid application, currently the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA), which analyzes the family income data provided on the FAFSA through the federally mandated Federal Methodology. All need-based financial aid must be awarded according to a student's calculated financial need. Scholarship awards are primarily provided on scholastic achievement. University scholarships are highly competitive and available to students through a combination of academic achievement and personal commitment, display of values, compassion and pursuit of excellence which embody the spirit and mission of the University. The University has many scholarships funded through special endowments and donations. In most instances, academic merit and financial need are considered along with the particular requirements of the scholarship selection process. Grants-in-aid are awarded to needy students and students who have special abilities or make significant contributions to the University. Additionally, various associations, corporations, foundations and unions provide scholarships for recipients whom they select.

All grants are awarded to enrolled students based on either financial need or merit. Grants are applied directly to the student's account. Scholarships for financial need are determined by the Financial Aid Office. Scholarships for merit are determined by the Admissions Office.

THE FINANCIAL AID COMMITTEE DETERMINES AND APPROVES ALL AWARDS ELIGIBILITY FOR A NEW YORK THEOLOGICAL SEMINARY SCHOLARSHIP. SCHOLARSHIP IS PRIMARILY BASED ON NEED AND AVAILABILITY OF FUNDS. APPLICANTS MUST BE REGISTERED FOR A MINIMUM OF EIGHT CREDITS PER SEMESTER. A CREDIT FOR THE AWARDED AMOUNT IS APPLIED TO THE RECIPIENT'S ACCOUNT, NO ACTUAL CASH IS AWARDED DIRECTLY TO RECIPIENTS.

The process of packaging financial aid is the culmination of the complete analysis of student need and the aid administration cycle, the process of preparation for packaging is completed accurately and confidentially to ensure effective use of all aid funds available, as well as fair and equitable treatment to all applicants.

The University has a detailed process for granting scholarships to individuals based on need. Once awarded, the scholarships are posted to the students' accounts for use toward the cost of tuition, fees, textbooks, on-campus housing and other educational costs.

THE UNIVERSITY MONITORS ITS GRANTS TO ENSURE THAT SUCH GRANTS ARE USED FOR PROPER PURPOSES AND ARE NOT OTHERWISE DIVERTED FROM THE INTENDED USE BY HAVING THE ENROLLMENT SERVICES OFFICE PROVIDE THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WITH A WEEKLY REPORT IDENTIFYING ANY FINANCIAL AID REFUNDS TO STUDENTS. THIS PROCESS ENSURES THAT ALL GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE BEING APPLIED AND USED FOR THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE. FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Scholarships are awarded to students based on the scholarship criteria. For example, a student may need to be an accounting major, with a GPA of 2.0 or higher. Students complete a scholarship application and the applications are given to a scholarship committee for review. The scholarship committee verifies the student meets the scholarship criteria and then determines the distribution.

All scholarships are awarded based upon specific criteria maintained by the financial aid office. Requirements for receiving scholarships depends on other factors such as grade point average, family income, or economic need. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors guidelines to ensure compliance. The College also under goes the required OMB A-133 audit annually.

THE PROCESS FOR MONITORING TUITION DISCOUNT OR GRANT/SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS AT LEES-MCRAE IS DONE BY UTILIZING A MATRIX THAT DETERMINES AND LIMITS THE AMOUNT OF ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIP AWARDED. THE VICE PRESIDENT OF ADMISSIONS AND ENROLLMENT AND THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID MEET REGULARLY TO REVIEW THE MOST CURRENT AMOUNT OF AWARDS BEING AWARDED TO ENSURE THE COLLEGE STAYS WITHIN BUDGE AND AWARD GUIDELINES. A FINAL REVIEW IS DONE BY THE VICE PRESIDENT OF ADMISSIONS AND ENROLLMENT AND THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID PRIOR TO AWARD LETTERS BEING MAILED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PART I, LINE 2 - PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANTS FUNDS IN U.S.
ExplntnTxt: ALL GRANTS AWARDED ARE BASED ON NEED AND CONFORM TO FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITYTIONAL REGULATIONS. ELIGIBILITY IS BASED ON A THOROUGH REVIEW AND VERIFICATION OF A FAMILY'S INCOME, ASSETS, SIZE AND NUMBER OF DEPENDENTS ENROLLED IN COLLEGE. ANNUAL EXPENDITURE REPORTS ARE SUBMITTED TO THE FEDERAL AND STATE GOVERNMENTS FOR REVIEW. THE FUND EXPENDITURES ARE REVIEWED FOR COMPLIANCE IN AN ANNUAL AUDIT CONDUCTED BY AN INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTING FIRM. The college does not further monitor the usage of scholarship funds as these amounts are credited directly against students tuition account and there is no opportunity for the student to divert these funds to non-educational uses.

THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE CLOSELY MONITORS ANY CHANGES IN THE STATUS OF FINANCIAL AWARD RECIPIENTS THAT WOULD RESULT IN A CORRESPONDING CHANGE IN THE AMOUNT OF AID AWARDED. ANY SUCH CHANGES ARE AUTOMATICALLY DETECTED AND REPORTED BY A SERIES OF SPECIAL REPORTS THAT ARE RUN ON A REGULAR BASIS. MOREOVER, THE OFFICE OF STUDENT ACCOUNTS ENSURES THAT THE CHARGES TO WHICH THE FINANCIAL AID AWARDS ARE APPLIED ARE CONSISTENT WITH THE INTENDED USE OF THE AWARDS.

PINCHOT UNIVERSITY PARTICIPATES WITH FEDERAL, STATE AND PRIVATE AGENCIES TO MAKE FINANCIAL AID PROGRAMS AVAILABLE TO STUDENTS. OTTAWA UNIVERSITY OFFERS ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS AND AWARDS. ALL FUNDS ARE AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, SERVICE TO COMMUNITY, LEADERSHIP AND INVOLVEMENT IN SCHOOL ACTIVITIES. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS AND AWARDS ARE OFFERED FOR FOUR YEARS OF STUDY FOR FRESHMEN AND UNTIL THE COMPLETION OF DEGREE REQUIREMENTS FOR TRANSFER STUDENTS. ALL STUDENTS MUST MEET THE STATED CRITERIA TO MAINTAIN ELIGIBILITY. GRANTS EARNED BY THE STUDENT FROM EXTERNAL FUNDING SOURCES ARE FULLY CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT WITHOUT REDUCING ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS AND AWARDS OFFERED BY OTTAWA UNIVERSITY. ACTIVITY AWARDS ARE OFFERED TO STUDENTS PARTICIPATING IN SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES BASED ON A COMPETITIVE REVIEW BY THE GRANTING DEPARTMENT. ACTIVITY AWARDS ARE AVAILABLE IN MUSIC, ART, THEATRE, FORENSICS, AND DEBATE. ATHLETIC AWARDS ARE OFFERED ON THE BASIS OF AN EVALUATION BY THE COACH OF EACH SPORT. OTTAWA UNIVERSITY OFFERS NEED BASED GRANTS TO STUDENTS WHO DEMONSTRATE AN EXCEPTIONAL LEVEL OF NEED AND THE POTENTIAL TO SUCCEED. OTTAWA UNIVERSITY IS COMMITTED TO BEING A RESIDENTIAL CAMPUS. FINANCIAL AID AWARDS ARE OFFERED TO ENCOURAGE STUDENTS TO LIVE ON-CAMPUS. OTTAWA UNIVERSITY IS ABLE TO HELP STUDENTS MEET A SIGNIFICANT PORTION OF THE DIRECT COST OF EDUCATION THROUGH A COMBINATION OF RESOURCES. STUDENTS ARE HIGHLY ENCOURAGED TO SUBMIT THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) TO DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY FOR ADDITIONAL GRANTS, WORK-STUDY PROGRAMS AND LOW-INTEREST LOANS. THE ADMINISTRATIVE SOFTWARE MONITORS FINANCIAL AID ON AN ONGOING BASIS FOR GRANTS, SCHOLARSHIPS AND OTHER AID THAT MAY BE PENDING, AWARDED, ETC. THIS INFORMATION IS THEN POSTED TO THE GENERAL LEDGER AS WELL FOR BALANCING/REPORTING PURPOSES.

All students who are applying for Federal financial aid are required to complete the FAFSA and the Gordon-Conwell financial aid application. The information obtained from these documents is used by the Financial Aid Office to determine eligibility of Federal and institutional aid. To assist with determining their eligibility, each student is assigned an institutional budget for the cost of attendance. This budget includes tuition, books and fees, room and board, health insurance, transportation, and a miscellaneous category. In general, Gordon-Conwell scholarships are either need-based or merit-based and any Gordon-Conwell aid that is awarded is factored into the eligibility for Federal aid.
All expenditures of Scholarships and Financial Aid grant funds are approved and monitored by the Financial Aid department for each student receiving funds.

Pitzer College awards scholarships only to individual undergraduate students. These scholarships are awarded based upon academic achievement and/or demonstrated financial need. The Financial Aid Office, with the assistance of the Registrar's Office, monitor student enrollment each semester to ensure that students remain qualified for financial aid. The College also awards tuition to dependents of its employees who meet the requirements of the College's Tuition Remission Program. Employee dependent's must be enrolled at one of the undergraduate schools of The Claremont Colleges. Tuition is paid directly to the undergraduate college after grades are submitted to the Human Resources Office as evidence of course completion.

The awards are based on factors including academic interest, demonstrated financial need and scholarly achievement that is made up to the student's financial need . Funds are provided by private donors (corporations, individuals and foundations) contributions or endowment funds, the Federal and State governments and also from the University's operating budget. Awards are monitored on an individual basis to ensure that awardees continue to maintain the criteria for qualification such as the minimum GPA, satisfactory academic progress and demonstrated need with adjustments to the aid made as appropriate

Funds are directly applied to eligible students accounts who are registered for sufficient tuition credits according to Federal Guidelines. Credit balances on students accounts are refunded automatically to either the student or to the original source of the funds.

THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIP, GRANT, LOAN, AND WORK STUDY OPPORTUNITIES TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS. THESE FUNDS ARE OFFERED TO STUDENTS ON AN OBJECTIVE AND NONDISCRIMINATORY BASIS. EACH PROGRAM HAS DIFFERENT CRITERIA AND EACH CASE IS CONSIDERED SEPARATELY. THERE IS A WRITTEN POLICY AND GUIDELINES TO ASSIST STUDENTS AS THEY SEEK THE APPROPRIATE FINANCIAL AID PACKAGE. RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED FOR THE GRANTED AWARDED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE US
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS FEDERAL AND STATE FINANCIAL AID FUNDS EACH YEAR BASED UPON A STUDENT'S FINANCIAL NEED. ADDITIONALLY, THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES INSTITUTIONAL AID VIA UNIVERSITY GRANTS ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENTS, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER STANDARDS. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID VERIFIES THE ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENTS AND THE PERSONAL INCOME DATA PROVIDED FOR ON THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) OF EACH STUDENT TO DETERMINE THE AMOUNT OF AID AWARDED ON AN AS NEEDED BASIS. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS FUNDED THROUGH SPECIAL ENDOWMENTS AND DONATIONS, WHICH ARE AWARDED BASED ON SIMILAR STANDARDS AS WELL AS DONOR'S CRITERIA. THE OFFICES OF FINANCIAL AID AND FINANCE CONTINUOUSLY MONITOR STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE AWARDS.

ALL STUDENT AID, GRANTS, WORK STUDY AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GIVEN ON BEHALF OF STUDENTS ATTENDING SITTING BULL COLLEGE. THE FUNDS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE TUITION, BOOKS, AND FEES FOR THE CORRESPONDING STUDENT TO ENSURE THAT IT IS USED FOR THE APPROPRIATE PURPOSES.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, LINE 2 AND PART III
ExplntnTxt: STUDENT FINANCIAL AID STUDENT FINANCIAL AID AWARDS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS BY THE COLLEGE'S OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES. AWARDS ARE BASED ON A NUMBER OF FACTORS INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, SCHOLARLY ACHIEVEMENT, DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED, AND ACADEMIC INTERESTS. FUNDS ARE PROVIDED BY SOURCES SUCH AS FEDERAL AND STATE GOVERNMENTS; PRIVATE DONORS SUCH AS CORPORATIONS, INDIVIDUALS AND FOUNDATIONS; THE COLLEGE'S ENDOWED FINANCIAL AID FUNDS; AND THE COLLEGE'S OPERATING BUDGET. FINANCIAL AID AWARDS ARE MADE UP TO A LIMIT OF THE STUDENT'S FINANCIAL NEED. INDIVIDUAL AWARDS ARE MONITORED EXTENSIVELY IN ORDER TO ENSURE THAT STUDENTS ARE MAKING SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS AND THAT THEY DO NOT RECEIVE MORE THAN THEIR DEMONSTRATED NEED. ADJUSTMENTS ARE MADE WHEN APPROPRIATE.

STUDENTS REQUESTING FINANCIAL AID ARE REQUIRED TO FILL OUT A FINANCIAL AID FORM FOR EACH ACADEMIC YEAR. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE USES THIS INFORMATION TO DETERMINE WHICH STUDENTS QUALIFY FOR CERTAIN PROGRAMS AND SCHOLARSHIPS (FOR EXAMPLE - PELL, PERKINS, COLLEGE WORK-STUDY, SUPPLEMENTAL EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITY GRANT, ETC.)

GRANTS ARE AWARDED BASED ON ESTABLISHED CRITERIA FOR EACH GRANT. THE AVAILABILITY OF FUNDS, THE NEED PER FAFSA, AND THE DATE OF THE APPLICATION ARE ALSO CONSIDERED. THE FUNDS ARE AWARDED AND DISBURSED AFTER ALL ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA HAVE BEEN CONFIRMED. TUITION WAIVERS MUST FOLLOW THE APPROVAL PROCESS OUTLINED IN THE HUMAN RESOURCES HANDBOOK. WAIVERS ARE AWARDED AND DISBURSED BASED ON THE SCHOOL YEAR AND SEMESTER REGISTRATION.
Grant recipients must complete and application and provide supporting documentation for their application for financial assistance.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PROCEDURE FOR MONITORING GRANTS IN THE US
ExplntnTxt: SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 THE COLLEGE MONITORS THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. PERSONNEL REVIEW STUDENT NEED ON A YEARLY BASIS AND AWARD GRANTS BASED ON NEED AND ELIGIBILITY.

The philosophy of student aid is to provide access and choices to students, who without financial assistance would not be able to attend an institution of higher learning. The Director of Financial Aid is responsible for establishing Institutional policy development surrounding the delivery of financial assistance Policy development adheres to federal and state laws and regulations as well as to the mission of the University. When appropriate, Financial Aid policy is reported to and approved by the Executive Vice President & Vice President for Business. The primary purpose of a collegiate financial aid program should be to provide financial assistance to accepted students who, without such aid, would be unable to attend that university. Each university has an obligation to assist in realizing the national goal of equality of educational opportunity The University, therefore, should work with schools, community groups, and other educational institutions in support of this goal. Parents are expected to contribute according to their means, taking into account their income, assets, number of dependents, and other relevant information Students themselves are expected to contribute from their own assets and earnings, including appropriate borrowing against future earnings Need-based financial aid should be offered only after determination that the resources of the family are insufficient to meet the student's educational expenses. The amount of need-based aid offered should not exceed the amount needed to meet the difference between the student's total educational expenses and the family's resources. The amount and type of self-help expected from students should be related to the circumstances of the individual In the assignment of funds to those students designated to receive financial aid, the largest amounts of total grant assistance should go to students with the least ability to pay The university should review its financial assistance awards annually and adjust them, if necessary, to reflect changes in the financial needs of students and the expenses of attending the institution. The university has an obligation to inform students and parents of the financial aid renewal policies for enrolled students at the time of the initial offer of financial assistance. Because the amount of financial assistance awarded reflects the economic circumstances of students and their families as well as available funding, the university should refrain from any public announcement of the amount of aid offered and encourage students, their secondary schools, and others to respect the confidentiality of this information. Selection of students to receive financial aid will be made without regard to age, sex, race, color, religion, national origin, disability or marital status. Priority consideration for aid is given to students whose files are complete by March 1 of each year. The institution will package each student according to the matrix (percentage) need assigned the student. This determination is made by the award year the student will enter Once the matrix year is determined the student is awarded a percentage of his or her (FAFSA) need with federal, state and institutional aid The student is then awarded work study followed with Perkins loan, Stafford (subsidized or unsubsidized) loan and the PLUS loan, as applicable Aid is "frozen" from one year to the next In extreme instances as defined by the Financial Aid Office, the amount of grant money may be adjusted accordingly to reflect a students' new need Honors scholarships are awarded based on the high school GPA, rank and either the SAT or ACT scores Students will continue to receive the scholarship as long as the student is in good academic standing Award letters are mailed or emailed to the student whenever there is a change to the financial aid award and the change affects federal or state awards.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO INSTITUTIONAL CHARGES. DIRECT COSTS INCURRED TO SUPPORT THE PRIMARY FUNCTIONS OF WALSH COLLEGE ARE SPECIFICALLY IDENTIFIED TO THE BENEFITING ACTIVITY. RESTRICTED FUNDS, INCLUDING FEDERAL AWARDS, ARE RECORDED IN SEPARATE FUNDS AND DIRECT EXPENDITURES OF THESE PROGRAMS ARE RESTRICTED TO THE EXCLUSIVE PURPOSE OF THE AWARD. ALL SPONSORED PROJECTS ARE INCLUDED IN THE DIRECT COST BASE. INDIRECT COSTS ARE ALLOCATED PROPORTIONALLY AS PRESCRIBED IN OMB CIRCULAR A-21. ANY UNDER RECOVERY OF INDIRECT COSTS FROM ANY SPONSORED ACTIVITY IS NOT CHARGED TO ANY OTHER SPONSORED PROJECT EITHER DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY.

SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE DETERMINED BY PROGRAM COMMITTEES AND ARE RECORDED ON STUDENT LEDGERS. EACH PROGRAM SELECTS ITS INTERNAL SCHOLARSHIP AWARDEES, SUBJECT TO REVIEW BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS SDS SCHOLARSHIPS. THE UNIVERSITY ACCOUNTING OFFICE MAINTAINS RECORDS OF AMOUNTS AWARDED AND DISBURSED.

THE MAJORITY OF GRANT FUNDS AWARDED BY THE UNIVERSITY ARE IN THE FORM OF FINANCIAL AID TO ITS STUDENTS. THE ORGANIZATION'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS NEED AND MERIT BASE AID BASED ON THE CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY THE UNIVERSITY. THE FINANCIAL AID PROGRAM AT SETON HILL UNIVERSITY ASSISTS STUDENTS WHO WOULD FIND IT DIFFICULT OR IMPOSSIBLE TO ATTEND COLLEGE WITHOUT SOME FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. THE UNIVERSITY OFFERS A COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAM OF FINANCIAL AID IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS, GRANTS, LOANS, PART-TIME EMPLOYMENT, AND DEFERRED PAYMENT SCHEDULES, AND COORDINATES ITS PROGRAMS WITH THE FEDERAL AND STATE FINANCIAL AND PROGRAMS. ANY OF THESE FORMS OF FINANCIAL AID MAY BE OFFERED INDEPENDENTLY OR IN VARIOUS COMBINATIONS TO A STUDENT. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE ESTIMATES THE COST OF ATTENDING SETON HILL UNIVERSITY BY ADDING TUITION, ROOM, BOARD AND FEES PLUS AN ESTIMATE FOR BOOKS, SUPPLIES, TRANSPORTATION FROM HOME TO SCHOOL AND PERSONAL EXPENSES. THE AMOUNT OF FINANCIAL AID AN APPLICANT RECEIVES IS BASED ON THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN THE TOTAL COSTS AND THE AMOUNT THE STUDENT AND FAMILY ARE ABLE TO CONTRIBUTE TOWARD COSTS AS DETERMINED BY THE NEEDS ANALYSIS FORM.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: BETHANY COLLEGE MAINTAINS RECORDS ON EVERY INDIVIDUAL WHO RECEIVES FUNDS. THESE RECORDS INCLUDE THE AMOUNT RECEIVED AND QUALIFICATIONS MET IN ORDER TO RECEIVE THOSE FUNDS. THEY ARE KEPT FOR THE DURATION OF TIME AS SPECIFIED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AND ARE PROPERLY DISPOSED OF AFTWRWARDS. THE COLLEGE ALSO HAS A POLICIES AND PROCEDURES MANUAL WHICH STATES HOW SPECIFIC GRANT MONIES, SUCH AS THE KANSAS COMPREHENSIVE GRANT AND THE SUPPLEMENTAL EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITY GRANT, ARE AWARDED.

Each charitable contribution or scholarship is monitored by Our Lady of the Lake College Inc. The College has set different levels of monitoring depending upon the amount of the contribution or scholarship. Donor restrictions, if applicable, are considered in the level of monitoring performed.

SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 FOR THE PERIOD JULY 1, 2014 THROUGH JUNE 30, 2015, DREW UNIVERSITY GRANTED FUNDS TO STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS, FELLOWSHIPS, STUDENT LOANS AS WELL AS OTHER FINANCIAL AID. FINANCIAL AID IS GRANTED TO STUDENTS BASED ON ELIGIBILITY GUIDELINES AS DEFINED BY THE FEDERAL DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AS WELL AS THE STATE OF NEW JERSEY. IF A STUDENT IS NOT ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE FEDERAL OR STATE BASED FINANCIAL AID, THE AID WILL NOT BE APPLIED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. IN ADDITION, DREW UNIVERSITY GRANTS FUNDS TO STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF INSTITUTIONAL AID BASED ON MERIT AND NEED CRITERIA.

NEUMANN UNIVERSITY'S PROCESS FOR MONITORING FINANCIAL AID AND MONITORING GRANT FUNDS IS A COMBINATION OF PROCEDURES INVOLVING THE FOLLOWING OFFICES - FINANCIAL AID, INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT, REGISTRAR, AND THE BUSINESS OFFICE. ALL GRANT EXPENDITURES ARE INITIALLY REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY GRANT PROJECT DIRECTORS. IF THE EXPENDITURE IS ABOVE $1,000, THEN IT IS ALSO REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY BOTH THE UNIT VICE PRESIDENT AND THE VICE PRESIDENT OF FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION. BEFORE ANY EXPENSES ARE SUBMITTED BY THE UNIVERSITY FOR REIMBURSEMENT FROM THE GRANTING AGENCY, IT IS REVIEWED AGAIN BY THE UNIVERSITY'S CONTRACTS & GRANTS ACCOUNTANT TO ENSURE THE GRANT FUNDS WERE EXPENDED IN COMPLIANCE WITH UNIVERSITY POLICIES AND PROCEDURES, APPLICABLE OMB CIRCULARS, AND ANY ADDITIONAL SPONSOR OR PROGRAMMATIC REGULATIONS. THESE EXPENSES ARE THEN SUBMITTED BACK TO THE PROJECT DIRECTOR AND THE UNIVERSITY'S CONTROLLER FOR FINAL REVIEW AND SIGNATURE OF APPROVAL. INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT AND THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARD SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ACCORDING TO THE SPECIFICATIONS/REQUIREMENTS OF THE SPECIFIC AWARD. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE, REGISTRAR, AND BUSINESS OFFICE COORDINATE THE AWARDING AND DOCUMENTATION OF FINANCIAL AID TO INCLUDE ELIGIBILITY OF FINANCIAL AID, NOTIFICATION OF STUDENTS, CHANGE OF STATUS, AND RECONCILEMENT OF STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

POEC gives need-based and merit-based scholarships. Need-based scholarships are monitored through the Department of Education FAFSA form. Students with $0 estimated family contribution (EFC), based on the Department of Education guidelines, will be automatically awarded a scholarship. Merit-based scholarships are granted to students who submit all required admissions documentation by certain deadlines and apply with good academic standing.

The Commonwealth Medical College provides financial aid to eligible students including scholarships and need-based financial aid. TCMC formed a scholarship committee to review and select scholarship recipients according to criteria specified by the donor. The admissions office identifies all students who meet the criteria and those student are then submitted for review by the committee. Need-based awards are determined and awarded by the Financial Aid Office after a review of qualified applicants. There is an extensive review process conducted by the financial aid office to determine the recipients of such aid. Financial aid, including scholarships, is supported by internal funds, gifts from private donors and income earned on endowment funds, donor restricted for scholarships and other student aid. All scholarships are applied only to TCMC's tuition and fees. No cash payments are made to students for these scholarships.

THE UNIVERSITY MAKES CONTRIBUTIONS TO NORTHWESTERN FOUNDATION, A RELATED ORGANIZATION UNDER COMMON MANAGEMENT. FOR THE GRANTS TO UNRELATED ORGANIZATIONS, SENIOR MANAGEMENT GENERALLY MONITORS RECIPIENT SPENDING VIA COMMUNICATION WITH THE ORGANIZATIONS TO SEE HOW OPERATIONS ARE RUNNING. A SITE VISIT BY SENIOR MANAGEMENT MAY ALSO BE CONDUCTED TO CHECK THE STATUS OF THE ORGANIZATION AND/OR MONITOR THE PROGRESS OF THE INTENDED PROJECT. SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS FOR STUDENTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO A STUDENT'S UNIVERSITY ACCOUNT AND APPLIED TO TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD. ALL FINANCIAL AID IS SUBJECT TO REVISION BASED ON AVAILABILITY, CHANGES IN FAMILY CONTRIBUTION AND/OR CREDIT LOAD. SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS MUST BE MAINTAINED ACCORDING TO STANDARDS PRESCRIBED BY THE UNIVERSITY. ANNUAL RENEWAL OF FINANCIAL AID IS CONTINUOUS IF INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL NEED REMAINS, ALL REQUIRED DOCUMENTS ARE COMPLETED BY THE PUBLISHED DEADLINE AND SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS IS MAINTAINED CONSISTENT WITH THE UNIVERSITY'S POLICY.

Gustavus offers both merit-based and need-based scholarship assistance. Merit-based scholarships do not require a student to demonstrate financial eligibility and must be awarded during the Admission process. They also may be awarded as part of a need-based financial aid package. To be renewed, the student needs to maintain the established minimum standards. Need-based scholarships are offered to students who demonstrate financial eligibility by filing the FAFSA. The offered amounts can vary from year to year as determined by the family's Estimated Family Contribution (EFC) on the FAFSA and availability of funds. The Registrar's office monitors any changes to a student's enrollment status. Any changes are communicated to the Student Accounts office and the Financial Assistance office to ensure funds are being properly disbursed. Also see Schedule F, Part V with respect to monitoring of students taking J-Term or semester studies outside of the United States.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: Federal and state programs are administered according to the laws, rules, statutes, and regulations as issued by the State of California and the U.S. Department of Education as well as the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. University scholarships and grants are administered according to the policies and procedures developed and implemented by the Financial Aid Office in support of the University's strategic enrollment plan. The Financial Aid Office uses the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) as well as a number of supporting documents of verification to determine a student's eligibility for all need based programs. In addition, students are reviewed based on academic qualifications and special talents for merit based programs such as music, athletics, regents scholarships and similar programs. Policies and Procedures ensure that the determination of aid eligibility and the subsequent delivery of aid from any and all programs are done in a fair and equitable manner and in accordance with the rules and regulations that govern the individual programs.

TLU FOLLOWS THE RULES AND REGULATIONS IN TERMS OF PROCEDURES PROVIDED BY THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION. ExplntnTxt: GRANT SUBSTANTIATION THE ORGANIZATION FOLLOWS FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL GUIDELINES AND METHODOLOGIES FOR DETERMINING ELIGIBILITY AND AWARDING OF NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID. THE ORGANIZATION MAINTAINS DETAILED RECORDS OF COMPLIANCE FOR ALL GRANTS DISPERSED. ASSISTANCE TO MOREHOUSE COLLEGE STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED FOR THE PURPOSE OF AIDING WITH THE COST OF ATTENDING THE UNIVERSITY, I.E. FOR TUITION, HOUSING, AND MEALS. TO ENSURE THAT THE GRANTS MADE TO INDIVIDUALS IN THE UNITED STATES, OTHER THAN WORK STUDY GRANTS, ARE USED FOR PROPER PURPOSES AND ARE NOT OTHERWISE DIVERTED FROM THE INTENDED USE, THE FACULTY DEPARTMENT THAT HAS BUDGETARY CONTROL OF THE FUNDS SELECTS AND MONITORS THE RECIPIENTS OF THESE GRANTS. FOR WORK STUDY GRANTS, THE FACULTY OR ADMINISTRATIVE DEPARTMENT WHERE THE STUDENT'S WORK WAS PERFORMED APPROVES ALL STUDENT WORK HOURS AND SUBMITS PAPERWORK TO THE PAYROLL OFFICE FOR PAYMENT TO THE STUDENT.
Senior management recommends to the Executive Committee grants to other organizations for approval.
Scholarship assistance is approved and monitored for individuals through campus scholarship committees.

Goucher College's grant funds are limited to need-based and merit-based financial assistance for attendance at the College. Goucher College's comprehensive program of need-based and merit-based financial assistance is managed by the Office of Student Financial Aid. As a member of the College Board and in keeping with the principles and practices of the College Scholarship Service, financial aid is awarded to properly qualified candidates on the basis of the financial need of students and their families. Financial need is determined by subtracting the Expected Family Contribution - as calculated on the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) and the Profile Form of the College Scholarship Service - from the student's total cost of attendance. Financial aid is awarded for one year only and must be renewed annually. Need-based aid is renewed to continuing students who demonstrate need and who are making satisfactory progress toward their degrees. Institutional merit-based scholarship requirements vary depending on the award. Compliance with those requirements are also overseen by the Office of Student Financial Aid.
SCHOLARSHIPS ARE ISSUED AND AMOUNTS ARE USED TO OFFSET STUDENT TUITION.

ALL FIRST-TIME STUDENTS TO MITCHELL COLLEGE ARE REVIEWED FOR MERIT AID. THERE IS NO SEPARATE APPLICATION PROCESS. IF STUDENTS ARE AWARDED MERIT AID, THE NOTIFICATION LETTER WILL BE SENT ABOUT TWO WEEKS AFTER THEIR ACCEPTANCE LETTER ARRIVES. MERIT AID IS BASED ON ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE AND/OR COMMUNITY SERVICE INVOLVEMENT. STUDENTS WHO ARE INTERESTED IN OBTAINING NEED BASED AID, EITHER FROM FEDERAL AND STATE RESOURCES OR MITCHELL COLLEGE'S OWN FUNDS MUST COMPLETE THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) AT WWW.FAFSA.ED.GOV. FINANCIAL AID, SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS AWARDED IS APPLIED TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS THROUGH A REDUCTION IN TUITION CHARGES.

NO CHECKS ARE ISSUED TO THE STUDENTS DIRECTLY. FUNDS ARE MONITORED TO ENSURE THEY ARE USED FOR THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE.
ALL STUDENT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE POSTED TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNTS BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND PAY FOR TUITION AND FEES. PER OTIS POLICY, BFA/MFA SCHOLARSHIPS DO NOT EXCEED TUITION AND FEES.
SCHOLARSHIP APPROVAL AND DOCUMENTATION IS MAINTAINED IN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

THE GRANTEE ALSO ACKNOWLEDGES IN WRITING THEREIN THE REQUIREMENT THAT ALL FUNDS BE USED FOR SUCH PURPOSES, PERIODIC REPORTING ON EXPENDITURES, AND THAT FUNDS WILL NEED TO BE RETURNED TO GRANTOR IF NOT USED OR TO BE USED IN FURTHERANCE OF THE CHARITABLE PURPOSE.
