MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS: ALL GRANTS ARE APPLIED TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS AFTER VERIFYING ENROLLMENT STATUS ON AN INDIVIDUAL BASIS.
SCHOLARSHIPS ARE MONITORED BY REGISTRAR AND FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND THE FINANCE OFFICE FOR GPA REQUIREMENTS, ENROLLMENT REQUIREMENTS AND OTHER ISSUES. REVIEWS ARE DONE REGULARLY.

THE THREE AREAS OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO STUDENTS ARE LOANS, GRANTS, AND EMPLOYMENT (WORK-STUDY). THESE ARE GENERALLY AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF FINANCIAL NEED, DETERMINED BY AN ANALYSIS OF FAMILY INCOME AND ASSETS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE ANOTHER SOURCE OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE, AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, ATHLETICS OR PERFORMING ARTS, COMMUNITY SERVICE OR LEADERSHIP. CRITERIA FOR MERIT BASED AWARDS MAY ALSO INCLUDE A FINANCIAL NEEDS REQUIREMENT. THE UNIVERSITY MONITORS THE AMOUNT ISSUED BY CALCULATING A COST OF ATTENDANCE, ASSESSING AN ESTIMATED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION (EFC), AND DERIVING A LEVEL OF FINANCIAL NEED. ONCE THE AMOUNT OF AID HAS BEEN DETERMINED FOR THE INDIVIDUAL, IT IS DISPERSED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT AND IS CONTROLLED BY THE BURSAR'S OFFICE. SEVERAL REPORTS/SURVEYS ARE USED ANNUALLY TO MONITOR THE DISTRIBUTION OF GRANT ASSISTANCE; FOR EXAMPLE, FISAP REPORT TO USDE, A-133 AUDIT, FEDERAL IPEDS REPORT, STATE ANNUAL AUDIT, AND VARIOUS SURVEYS THAT TYPICALLY USE INFORMATION FROM THE COMMON DATA SET (CDS).

DISBURSEMENTS IN FURTHERANCE OF THE INSTITUTION'S EXEMPT PROGRAMS ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH PROCEDURES OR SUBJECT TO CONDITIONS ESTABLISHED BY THE INSTITUTION'S GOVERNING BOARD DESIGNED TO INSURE THAT INDIVIDUALS AND ORGANIZATIONS RECEIVING DISBURSEMENTS FROM THIS ORGANIZATION IN FURTHERANCE OF ITS EXEMPT PROGRAMS ARE ADEQUATELY INVESTIGATED TO INSURE THAT THEY ARE QUALIFYING RECIPIENTS AS TO ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS.

GRANTS (FEDERAL/STATE) PASSED THROUGH TO STUDENTS ARE MONITORED USING OUR INTERNAL APPLICATION (POWERFAIDS), THE STATE(PHEAA) AND FEDERAL (COD - COMMON ORIGINATION AND DISBURSEMENT) ELECTRONIC SYSTEMS. A VALIDATION OF RECORDS AMONG ALL THREE SYSTEMS IS CONDUCTED PERIODICALLY THROUGHOUT THE ACADEMIC YEAR AND FOR SEMESTER END RECONCILIATIONS. THOSE SYSTEMS VERIFY THE CRITERIA FOR THE GRANTS HAVE BEEN MET AND THE DOLLAR AMOUNTS RECEIVED HAVE BEEN DISSTRIBUTED APPROPRIATELY.

A FILE IS CREATED FOR EACH GRANTEE. WE DETERMINE EACH STUDENT'S DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED BASED ON THEIR COST OF ATTENDANCE MINUS EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION ACCORDING TO THE INSTITUTIONAL STUDENT INFORMATION RECORD FROM THE FEDERAL PROCESSOR. WE ATTEMPT TO MEET EACH STUDENT'S DEMONSTRATED NEED WITH A COMBINATION OF MERIT-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS, NEED-BASED GRANTS, FEDERAL COLLEGE WORK-STUDY, AND STUDENT LOANS. FINANCIAL AID MAY BE AWARDED FROM FEDERAL, STATE, INSTITUTIONAL, AND PRIVATE SOURCES. WE MONITOR AND MAINTAIN COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FEDERAL, STATE, AND INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID POLICIES AND PROCEDURES. IN ADDITION, THE COLLEGE MONITORS AND MAINTAINS SEPARATE FUND ACCOUNTS FOR EACH AWARD CATEGORY AND PROVIDES THE NECESSARY REPORTS TO THE FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: JD Admission Scholarships:Admission scholarships are granted based on merit. This includes, but is not always limited to: LSAT score and undergraduate grade point average. Some scholarships are also awarded based on merit and diversity. There is no separate application beyond the admissions application required for most of the scholarships. Merit Based Scholarships:California Western School of Law (the School) offers two forms of merit based scholarships that are awarded to students at the completion of their first year of law school. The Academic Merit Scholarship is typically awarded to students with GPAs from 3.33 to 4.33. It is awarded based solely on the student's GPA. The Dean's Diversity Scholarship is typically awarded to students with GPAs from 2.80 to 4.33. It is awarded through a competitive application process. The number of scholarships offered each year varies, based on the number of eligible students and the availability of funds.LL.M./M.C.L. Scholarships:These scholarships are awarded to the School's most academically outstanding LL.M./M.C.L. applicants based upon academic credentials, relevant work experience, impressive academic and professional recommendations, and strong command of English (as evidenced by quality writing on the applicant's personal statement and by the applicant's "Test" of English as a Foreign Language score).Students enrolled in the School's Spanish on-line LL.M. program may apply for a scholarship if they can demonstrate long term commitment to trial advocacy, education, and justice system reforms. In addition, students in this program may also receive a small scholarship if they graduated from a school in Mexico that has a cooperation agreement (a "convenio") with the School.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PROCEDURE FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS INSIDE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 All financial aid grants are used for the intended purpose which is to provide aid to students with financial need to cover the students cost of attendance. These grants include federal pell grants, federal SEOG grants, and state PHEAA grants. The College also awards donor restricted grants that are provided from foundations, alumni scholarship donations, and other donors. Additionally, the College provides internal institutional grants to eligible students. These grants are awarded by the Financial Aid Office and posted to the eligible students accounts by the Business Office. These accounts are reconciled by the Business Office and Financial Aid Office on a monthly basis. The Financial Aid Office complies with the U.S. Department of Education guidelines as well as any donor restricted grant guidelines. The Financial Aid Office reports student grant awards to the U.S. Department of Education and PHEAA throughout the year and also submits the required annual FISAP report to the U.S. Department of Education. An annual A-133 audit (financial statements and report of independent certified public accounts in accordance with OMB Circular A-133) is conducted by the Colleges external independent auditors.

GRANTS ARE FOR TUITION AND FEES THAT ARE DISBURSED IN THE BUSINESS OFFICE TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE ENSURES THAT THE STUDENTS ARE WITHIN THEIR BUDGET ALLOWANCE. ADDITIONAL GRANTS ARE GIVEN TO PAY FOR BOOKS.

THE GRANTS MADE BY THE UNIVERSITY ARE PRIMARILY FOR STUDENT AID AND SCHOLARSHIPS. A LIST OF RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS IS ON FILE AT THE UNIVERSITY AND IS AVAILABLE UPON REQUEST. ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE UNIVERSITY ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC AND ATHLETIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS.

THE GRANTEE, AUBURN UNIVERSITY FOUNDATION, IS A SECTION 501(C)(3) ENTITY THAT IS THE SOLE MEMBER OF THE REAL ESTATE FOUNDATION. WITHIN ITS FINANCIAL SYSTEM, THE AUBURN UNIVERSITY FOUNDATION HAS FUNDS SPECIFICALLY ESTABLISHED FOR RECEIPTING AND ADMINISTERING THE GRANTS TO IT FROM THE REAL ESTATE FOUNDATION WHOSE SOLE PURPOSE IS TO BENEFIT AND SUPPORT THE AUBURN UNIVERSITY FOUNDATION. THE ADMINISTRATION/MANAGEMENT OF THE AUBURN UNIVERSITY FOUNDATION AND THE REAL ESTATE FOUNDATION ARE PERFORMED BY THE SAME PERSONNEL WHO HAVE ACCESS TO BOTH FINANCIAL SYSTEMS FOR MONITORING COMPLIANCE. PART I, LINE 2: THE GRANTEE, AUBURN UNIVERSITY, IS A SECTION 115 ENTITY. AS A LAND-GRANT INSTITUTION OF HIGHER EDUCATION, ITS MAJOR SOURCE OF FUNDS ARE FEDERAL AND STATE APPROPRIATIONS AND THEREFORE, ITS DISBURSEMENTS ARE GOVERNED BY FEDERAL AND ALABAMA STATE LAWS. ITS TRANSACTIONS ARE SUBJECT TO PUBLIC DISCLOSURE. THE AUBURN UNIVERSITY REAL ESTATE FOUNDATION, INC. HAS ACCESS TO THE FINANCIAL RECORDS. GRANTS DESIGNATED FOR A SPECIFIC PURPOSE ARE CREDITED TO A FUND ESTABLISHED FOR THAT PURPOSE. THE UNIVERSITY'S PROCUREMENT AND PAYMENT SERVICES OFFICE ENSURES COMPLIANCE WITH THE FUND'S RESTRICTIONS SUBJECT TO ANY APPLICABLE LAWS. PART I, LINE 2: THE GRANTEE, TIGERS UNLIMITED FOUNDATION, IS A SECTION 501(C)(3) ENTITY. ITS PRIMARY PURPOSE IS THE SUPPORT OF AUBURN UNIVERSITY'S INTERCOLLEGIATE ATHLETICS. TIGERS UNLIMITED FOUNDATION'S MANAGEMENT IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ITS EXPENDITURES AND REPORTS TO AN ACTIVE BOARD OF DIRECTORS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: DUE TO THE VARIOUS TYPES OF GRANT FUND EXPENDITURES THE UNIVERSITY USES MULTIPLE INTERNAL CONTROL PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF U.S. GRANT FUNDS AND ASSISTANCE. FELLOWSHIPS, PRIZES AND STIPEND PAYMENTS ARE MADE THROUGH OUR FINANCIAL SERVICES AND ACCOUNTS PAYABLE DEPARTMENT. THE PROCESS REQUIRES PRE-APPROVAL BY A PARTICULAR DEPARTMENT-HEAD AND SPECIFIC DOCUMENTATION AND AUTHORIZATIONS ARE NECESSARY IN ORDER TO PROCESS A PAYMENT. A MAJORITY OF PAYMENTS ARE MADE VIA CHECK. FOR DOMESTIC SCHOLARSHIPS, THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE (FAO) MAINTAINS AN INDEPENDENT FINANCIAL AID ACCOUNTING SYSTEM. THE FAO ADMINISTERS THE LISTING OF AWARD RECIPIENTS AND RECONCILES, ON A MONTHLY BASIS, THE CORRESPONDING EXPENSES WITH THE UNIVERSITY GENERAL LEDGER SYSTEM. THE CASH GRANTS ARE ALSO REFLECTED ON EACH INDIVIDUAL STUDENT ACCOUNT. THE FINANCIAL SERVICES OFFICE INDEPENDENTLY RECORDS THE TRANSACTIONS AFTER ALL REQUIRED SYSTEM-FEED DOCUMENTATION HAS BEEN RECEIVED. ADDITIONALLY, ALL FEDERAL SCHOLARSHIP ACTIVITIES ARE MONITORED SEPARATELY BY THE SPONSORED ACCOUNTING DEPARTMENT (SPA). FOR SUBCONTRACT RESEARCH GRANTS, THE UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS A SPONSORED RESEARCH ACCOUNTING (SPA) DEPARTMENT WHICH HAS FINANCIAL OVERSIGHT FOR ALL GRANT AND CONTRACT ACTIVITY. THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR (PI) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ALL ASPECTS OF A GRANT ALONG WITH THE COMPLIANCE ACTIVITIES. SPECIFIC GRANT-RELATED EXPENDITURE ACTIVITIES ARE PROCESSED BY THE UNIVERSITY ACCOUNTS PAYABLE DEPARTMENT. SUB-RECIPIENT MONITORING: A PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR (PI) NEGOTIATES SUBCONTRACTS WITH SUB-RECIPIENTS THROUGH THE OFFICE OF THE VICE PROVOST. WHEN AN AGREEMENT IS FULLY EXECUTED, IT MUST BE SUBMITTED TO THE OFFICE OF SPONSORED PROGRAMS ACCOUNTING (SPA) ALONG WITH A COMPLETED CONSULTANT PAYMENT FORM. ANY ISSUES REGARDING SUB-RECIPIENT PERFORMANCE ARE REPORTED TO THE OFFICE OF THE VICE PROVOST AND SPA. ALSO, SPA IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ENSURING THAT ALL SUB-RECIPIENTS ARE IN COMPLIANCE WITH OMB CIRCULAR A-133 REQUIREMENTS.

All scholarships are awarded based upon specific criteria maintained by the financial aid office. Requirements for receiving scholarships depend upon other factors, such as grade point average, family income or economic need. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors the eligibility guidelines to ensure compliance. The College also undergoes the required OMB A-133 audit annually.

Procedures and conditions are designed to ensure that individuals receiving disbursements are adequately investigated to ensure that they are qualifying recipients. Students receiving scholarships and fellowships are judged worthy based on the institution's assessment of academic achievement, financial need, and other similar standards.
Promotes literacy in the community & conducts workshops on printmaking & book arts
Cedarville University awards financial aid grants to students in accordance with the University's institutional financial aid policies.

THE COLLEGE GRANTS SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS ENROLLED IN THE COLLEGE'S DEGREE-GRANTING PROGRAM. THE COLLEGE DETERMINES STUDENT ELIGIBILITY BASED UPON THE STUDENT'S NEED. SOME SCHOLARSHIPS OR GRANTS ARE AWARDED BASED UPON ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. THE COLLEGE HAS A STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE OFFICE THAT ACCUMULATES ALL REQUIRED INFORMATION FROM THE STUDENTS. THE OFFICE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS BASED UPON CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY THE COLLEGE.

Federal and State Grants are awarded based on Federal title IV and state higher educational compliance requirements. Institutional Scholarships are awarded based upon parameters established by each endowment fund and are monitored by a university scholarship committee.Scholarships are awarded without respect to race, creed & color

With respect to scholarships, interested students complete an application which is reviewed by the scholarship committee to determine if they meet established criteria. Funds are then awarded to the applicants who best meet the criteria. The amount of money available will determine how many scholarships are awarded. A portion of these scholarships are awarded to students based on financial need and nationality. Students who are awarded scholarships are monitored with respect to their scholastic achievement as students must maintain certain grades to retain their scholarships.

Students submit an application for financial aid to the financial aid office. Applications are evaluated by the financial aid office and students are notified of awards they are to receive. The financial aid is applied directly against tuition. Scholarships are not refunded should the student fail to complete the required credit hours.

THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID DETERMINES A STUDENT'S ELIGIBILITY BASED ON THE FAMILY'S FINANCIAL STRENGTH, WHICH INCLUDES CONSIDERATION OF FAMILY INCOME AND ASSETS, NUMBER OF CHILDREN IN COLLEGE AND, IF APPROPRIATE, SPECIAL CIRCUMSTANCES. FINANCIAL AID WILL BE REVOKED WITHOUT ADEQUATE PROGRESS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PART I, LINE 2 - Grants and Allocations:
ExplntnTxt: APPROXIMATELY 45 PERCENT OF TRINITY COLLEGE UNDERGRADUATES ARE RECEIVING ASSISTANCE FROM THE COLLEGE, FEDERAL OR STATE FUNDS. GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS THE DISBURSEMENT OF FINANCIAL AID. SCHEDULE I, PART III: THE CASH GRANT INCLUDES CREDITS ON STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

CONCORDIA COLLEGE OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS TO HELP REDUCE THEIR OUT-OF-POCKET TUITION COSTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE OF THIS FORM MUST MEET SPECIFIC CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS WHETHER PUT IN PLACE BY THE COLLEGE OR BY DONORS OF RESTRICTED FUNDS.

Federal funds are monitored as follows: The Director of Financial Aid determines student eligibility for Pell, SEOG, FWS, and Federal loans. The Director of Financial Aid posts student awards into the integrated student record system. The Bursar prints and distributes the billing statement which lists Federal awards. The Bursar draws down funding from the Federal website. The Director of Financial Aid and Bursar post the Federal funds to the student account in the student record system. The Senior Accountant reviews and posts the journal entry to record the cash receipt in the general ledger. The Director of Finance reviews and reconciles the student accounts receivable and all student related revenue from the general ledger to the billing system.

THE OFFICE OF SPONSORED PROGRAMS IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ENSURING THAT AUDITABLE RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED IN SUPPORT OF ALL DIRECT AND INDIRECT CHARGES TO GRANTS, CONTRACTS, OR AGREEMENTS. THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR INITIALLY APPROVES ALL EXPENDITURES OF A SPONSORED PROJECT AND IS RESPONSIBLE FOR DETERMINING WHETHER THE SPONSOR WILL ALLOW AN ITEM OF DIRECT COST, BEFORE THE EXPENDITURE IS PROCESSED. IN ADDITION, THESE EXPENDITURES ARE ALSO CLOSELY REVIEWED AND MONITORED BY THE OFFICE OF SPONSORED PROGRAMS BEFORE THE EXPENDITURE REQUISITION IS APPROVED FOR PAYMENT TO ENSURE THAT THE GRANT FUNDS ARE PROPERLY UTILIZED FOR THE PURPOSES SPECIFIED IN THE GRANT CONTRACT/AGREEMENT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: BIOLA UNIVERSITY AWARDS BOTH MERIT AND NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS AT THE GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE LEVELS. MERIT AWARDS ARE BASED ON ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC, ATHLETIC, AND MUSIC ABILITIES. THESE TYPICALLY HAVE ACADEMIC OR PARTICIPATION REQUIREMENTS FOR RENEWAL. CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY BASED ON STATED REQUIREMENTS IS MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE OR BY THE OFFICE THAT MAKES THE AWARDS. NEED-BASED AWARDS ARE TYPICALLY AWARDED BASED ON SPECIFIC FORMULAS THAT ARE BASED ON AN INSTITUTIONAL OR FEDERAL COST AMOUNT COMBINED WITH THE FEDERAL EFC DETERMINED BY THE FAFSA. CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY IS NORMALLY CONTINGENT ON ONGOING NEED IN SUBSEQUENT YEARS. MOST OF THE GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED BY BIOLA ARE FUNDED FROM GENERAL FUNDS; HOWEVER, A PORTION ARE FUNDED FROM RESTRICTED FUNDS THAT HAVE BEEN PROVIDED BY DONORS, AND ARE AWARDED BASED ON THE ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY THE DONORS. SOME OF THESE FUNDS ARE AWARDED BY VARIOUS CAMPUS DEPARTMENTS, AND SOME THROUGH AN APPLICATION PROCESS ADMINISTERED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WORKS CLOSELY WITH ACCOUNTING AND FINANCE OFFICES TO MONITOR AVAILABILITY OF FUNDS FROM BOTH THE GENERAL FUND AND RESTRICTED FUND ACCOUNTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.

Part I, Line 2: The awarding of student financial aid grants under the U.S. Department of Education's Student Financial Assistance Program is monitored by NEC's Financial Aid Office, which ensures that NEC meets the compliance requirements of OMB Circular A-133. NEC's Financial Aid Office and Business Office are responsible for establishing and maintaining effective internal controls over compliance with the requirements of laws, regulations, contracts, and grants applicable to federal programs.Only current NEC students in good standing are provided scholarship grants or other financial assistance. Grants and assistance to NEC College students are in the form of institutional scholarships. All College scholarships are administered through NEC's financial aid system. Institutional scholarships are credited to the student's internal tuition account and represent an offset to tuition and other fees assessed by NEC.Preparatory program, continuing education program and summer session scholarships are tracked separately and administered through NEC's student billing system. Preparatory program, continuing education program and summer session scholarships are credited to the student's internal tuition account and represent an offset to tuition and other fees assessed by NEC.Grants and assistance to NEC staff and their eligible spouses and dependents are in the form of staff tuition waivers, pursuant to a written benefits plan. Staff tuition waivers are administered through the Conservatory's benefits system and, like institutional scholarships for students, are credited to the individual's internal account to offset tuition changes.All students receiving scholarships and fellowships are judged worthy by the institution's assessment on the basis of academic achievement, financial need and other similar standards.

ALL GRANTS PROVIDED BY THE UNIVERSITY ARE FOR FINANCIAL AID TO STUDENTS. GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE ARE RELATED TO INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID FOR WHICH STUDENTS APPLY THROUGH THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. ALL AID IS AWARDED BASED ON CERTAIN GUIDELINES AND IS CREDITED DIRECTLY TO STUDENTS' TUITION ACCOUNTS. ALL AWARDS ARE DIRECTLY RELATED TO THE STUDENTS' EDUCATION AT THE INSTITUTION'S PHYSICAL LOCATION AND ONLINE COURSES IN THE UNITED STATES. STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO MAINTAIN SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS IN ORDER TO CONTINUE TO RECEIVE FINANCIAL AID.

ExplntnTxt: BENNINGTON MONITORS THE USE OF FUNDS THROUGH THE ANALYSIS OF TRANSCRIPTS, GRADES, AND WRITTEN NARRATIVES BY BOTH FACULTY AND STUDENTS. PROGRESS TOWARD THE REQUIREMENTS TO COMPLETE A DEGREE IS CLOSELY MONITORED. GRANTS ARE ONLY PROVIDED TO CURRENTLY ENROLLED STUDENTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: BENNINGTON MONITORS THE USE OF FUNDS THROUGH THE ANALYSIS OF TRANSCRIPTS, GRADES, AND WRITTEN NARRATIVES BY BOTH FACULTY AND STUDENTS. PROGRESS TOWARD THE REQUIREMENTS TO COMPLETE A DEGREE IS CLOSELY MONITORED. GRANTS ARE ONLY PROVIDED TO CURRENTLY ENROLLED STUDENTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS - PART I, LINE 2:
ExplntnTxt: THE INSTITUTE ENSURES THAT ITS GRANTS OF FINANCIAL AID ARE USED BY STUDENTS FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES BY CREDITING THE AID DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS OR THROUGH ITS FINANCIAL AID COMPLIANCE PROCESSES. THE INSTITUTE ALSO PROVIDES FUNDING FOR TRAVEL EXPENSES, WHICH HAS BEEN INCLUDED IN THE TOTAL ABOVE, FOR STUDENTS WHOSE PROJECT PROPOSALS HAVE BEEN APPROVED BY THE PRESIDENT.

MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS TO ORGANIZATIONS IN THE UNITED STATES: THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID DETERMINES STUDENT ELIGIBILITY AND MAKES AWARDS FOR NEED BASED SCHOLARSHIPS. ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY AND AWARDS ACADEMIC MERIT BASED SCHOLARSHIPS WITH ASSISTANCE FROM THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID. BOTH OFFICES PERFORM POST AWARD MONITORING TO DETERMINE CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY. THE RESEARCH AND ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES OFFICE (RAS) PERFORMS SUB-RECIPIENT MONITORING IN ACCORDANCE WITH UNIVERSITY POLICY. RAS AND PRINCIPLE INVESTIGATORS MONITOR STATEMENT OF WORK COMPLETION, PROGRESS REPORTS, DELIVERABLES, CHANGE TO SCOPE AND BUDGETS. THEY ALSO REVIEW AND APROVE SUB-RECIPIENT INVOICES.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS THE ADMISSIONS OFFICE MAKES THE DETERMINATION FOR THE INSTITUTIONAL (SCHOLASTIC-ACADEMIC, CSRA, PRESIDENTIAL, TRANSFER) SCHOLARSHIPS. THE CRITERIA IS BASED ON HIGH SCHOOL GRADE POINT AVERAGE, ACT OR SAT SCORES, AND COLLEGE GPA AND EARNED HOURS. ONCE ADMISSIONS DETERMINES ELIGIBILITY, AWARDS ARE DISTRIBUTED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S. FUNDS ARE DISTRIBUTED BASED ON NEED AND MERIT. STUDENT AID IS HANDLED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT AND CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNT. EACH STUDENT APPLIES FOR FINANCIAL AID BY FILLING OUT A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA). THE AWARD IS BASED ON THE INFORMATION IN THIS APPLICATION. STUDENT CAN ALSO APPLY FOR GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON ELIGIBILITY.

Within the limits of available resources, the College makes every effort to make financial aid opportunities available to needy and academically eligible students. Traditional-age students must be enrolled in a full-time undergraduate degree program to be considered for College academic scholarships, grants and/or need-based financial aid. With the exception of some academic scholarships, students who wish to apply for grants, loans or work-study submit the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA). Awards are considered on the basis of financial need and/or a student's academic profile. Awards are packaged using a combination of grants and scholarships, loans and work-study assignments. Students must be in good academic standing and achieve the minimum standards of academic progress. We use College Board's Powerfaids software to manage our financial database and awarding procedures.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE UNITED STATES
ExplntnTxt: SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 BUTLER UNIVERSITY HAS WRITTEN QUALIFICATION CRITERIA FOR STUDENT FINANCIAL AID AND FOLLOWS A WRITTEN APPROVAL PROCESS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANTS:
ExplntnTxt: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 THE COLLEGE HAS DESIGNED AND IMPLEMENTED INTERNAL CONTROLS THAT INCLUDE FINANCIAL REPORTING AS WELL AS INTERNAL CONTROL OVER COMPLIANCE WITH REGULATIONS AND GRANT AGREEMENTS. INCLUDED IN THE INTERNAL CONTROL STRUCTURE IS A COMPREHENSIVE GRANTS AND CONTRACTS POLICY THAT PROVIDES THE ECKERD COLLEGE COMMUNITY GUIDELINES FOR GRANTS RECORDKEEPING, REPORTING AND MANAGEMENT. THE FINANCIAL AID AND BUSINESS OFFICES HAVE PRIMARY ROLES IN THE MONITORING OF GRANT FUNDS WHICH INCLUDES PROCEDURES FOR FINANCIAL REPORTING, FUNDS REQUESTS, INVOICING, REIMBURSEMENTS, PROGRAM ACTIVITY OVERSIGHT, PURCHASES, CLOSE OUT AND POST AWARD COMPLIANCE. THE BUSINESS OFFICE COMMUNICATES DIRECTLY AND FREQUENTLY WITH FACULTY AND STAFF MEMBERS TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH ALL COLLEGE POLICIES. THE COLLEGE IS ALSO SUBJECT TO EXTERNAL AUDITS WHICH ARE PERFORMED AT LEAST ANNUALLY.
SCHOLARSHIPS AND DISCOUNTS ARE BASED ON ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE AND FINANCIAL NEED AND ARE ADMINISTERED BY THE OFFICES OF ADMISSIONS AND STUDENT SERVICES.

ALL GRANT AND CONTRACT ACTIVITY IS MONITORED TO ASSURE THAT ACTIVITY IS IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE AWARDING AGENCIES' STIPULATED TERMS AND CONDITIONS. ALL EXPENDITURES ARE REVIEWED ON A WEEKLY BASIS FOR ALLOWABILITY.
IN THE 2014/2015 FISCAL YEAR, THE GRANTEES WERE APPROVED BY THE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT AND CONFIRMED WITH THE EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT.

IONA COLLEGE GIVES AID TO STUDENTS IN TWO FORMS: MERIT AID AND NEEDS BASED AID. THE AMOUNT OF MERIT AID A STUDENT RECEIVES IS BASED ON A CALCULATED ACADEMIC INDEX THAT IS DERIVED FROM THEIR GPA & SAT SCORES. NEED BASED AID IS DETERMINED FROM THE STUDENT EFC. STUDENTS ARE GIVEN THESE AWARDS UPON ACCEPTANCE TO THE COLLEGE AND THE AWARDS ARE RENEWED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS ASSUMING THE STUDENT MEETS THE REQUIRED CUMULATIVE GPA AND THEIR NEED AS DETERMINED BY THE FAFSA HAS NOT CHANGED. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ISSUED BY THE COLLEGE ARE INTENDED TO BE USED TO DEFRAY TUITION COSTS AND ENABLE STUDENTS TO MATRICULATE AT IONA COLLEGE, THE STUDENT HAS NO DISCRETION ON HOW TO EXPEND THOSE FUNDS. ACCORDINGLY, THE COLLEGE DOES NOT FORMALLY MONITOR THE USE OF THE SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS SINCE IT IS REQUIRED THAT SUCH FUNDS BE USED TO OFFSET TUITION COSTS.

Students requesting financial aid are screened for financial need, academic merit, and other scholarship criteria prior to the awarding of scholarships. The combined total of scholarships, grants and other tuition related awards may not exceed the cost of tuition. Students must meet the enrollment guidelines and maintain satisfactory academic progress to retain awards received. Monitoring of these criteria is a combined effort of the Financial Aid office, the Registrar's office and the Business office.

FINANCIAL AID DISBURSEMENTS ARE MADE TO STUDENTS QUALIFYING FOR FINANCIAL GRANTS AND ARE BASED ON DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED AS REPORTED THROUGH SCHOOL AND STUDENT SERVICE FOR FINANCIAL AID (SSSFA) APPLICATIONS. THEY ARE MONITORED IN ACCORDANCE WITH FEDERAL REGULATIONS.

SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE REPRESENT STUDENT FINANCIAL AID. WHEN AWARDING AID, BRANDMAN UNIVERSITY FOLLOWS ALL LAWS AND REGULATIONS OF FEDERAL AND STATE OF CALIFORNIA AID PROGRAMS. FOR MORE INFORMATION, VISIT OUR WEBSITE AT WWW.BRANDMAN.EDU.

DURING 2014-15, 68% OF THE TOTAL DICKINSON STUDENT BODY RECEIVED FINANCIAL AID FROM THE COLLEGE. SINCE MOST OF THE COLLEGE'S GRANT AWARDS ARE MADE TO STUDENTS WITH DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED, THE MAJORITY OF THESE FUNDS SUPPLEMENTED THE CONTRIBUTION THAT ELIGIBLE FAMILIES MADE TOWARD TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD CHARGES. THE COLLEGE'S INSTITUTIONAL METHODOLOGY USED TO DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY FOR GRANT FUNDS CONSIDERS ADDITIONAL FACTORS BEYOND THE DATA ITEMS REQUESTED ON THE FAFSA. THESE INCLUDE (BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO) HOME EQUITY, A CONTRIBUTION FROM THE NONCUSTODIAL PARENT, AND IN THE CASE OF A FAMILY WITH MORE THAN ONE STUDENT IN COLLEGE, AN EVALUATION OF THE ACTUAL COSTS INVOLVED IN SUPPORTING THE OTHER STUDENT(S). PARENTS IN COLLEGE AND SIBLINGS IN GRADUATE SCHOOL ARE NOT NORMALLY COUNTED AS OTHER FAMILY MEMBERS IN COLLEGE. DICKINSON EXPECTS EACH FINANCIAL AID RECIPIENT TO WORK DURING THE SUMMER AND CONTRIBUTE A MINIMUM OF $2,000 TOWARD COLLEGE COSTS. STUDENTS ARE ALSO EXPECTED TO CONTRIBUTE A PORTION OF THEIR ASSETS EACH YEAR FOR EDUCATIONAL EXPENSES. SOME STUDENTS RECEIVE EDUCATIONAL BENEFITS FROM GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES SUCH AS THE VETERANS' ADMINISTRATION AND STATE BUREAUS OF VOCATIONAL REHABILITATION OR FROM PARENTS' EMPLOYERS IN THE FORM OF TUITION REMISSION. SUCH BENEFITS MUST BE TAKEN INTO CONSIDERATION WHEN DETERMINING THE FINANCIAL AID PACKAGE. THE FINANCIAL AID AWARD NOTICE WILL LIST ALL THE FINANCIAL AID PROGRAMS FOR WHICH THE STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE. THE AMOUNT OF FINANCIAL AID THAT THE STUDENT RECEIVES FROM THESE PROGRAMS DEPENDS ON THE STUDENT'S COMPUTED NEED. THE AMOUNT OF DICKINSON GRANT AND SCHOLARSHIP AID MAY ALSO BE INFLUENCED BY THE ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND PROMISE OF THE APPLICANT. STUDENTS' FINANCIAL NEED IS RECALCULATED FOR EACH YEAR OF ATTENDANCE; AS A RESULT, AWARDED AMOUNTS OF NEED-BASED AID MAY VARY AS NEED CHANGES. THE COLLEGE ATTEMPTS TO MAINTAIN APPROXIMATELY THE SAME AMOUNT OF DICKINSON GRANT FUNDS FROM YEAR TO YEAR UNLESS NEED CHANGES SIGNIFICANTLY. THE STUDENT IS REQUIRED TO SUBMIT A PROFILE APPLICATION IF, AS A RESULT OF A SIGNIFICANT CHANGE IN FAMILY CIRCUMSTANCES, ADDITIONAL ASSISTANCE IS BEING REQUESTED.

GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE ARE APPLIED TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS AFTER THE START OF EACH SEMESTER OR TERM. DOMESTIC GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS REPORTED ON SCHEDULE I INCLUDE FINANCIAL AID PROVIDED TO STUDENTS STUDYING AT THE MAIN CAMPUS IN CARLISLE OR AT OTHER DOMESTIC PROGRAM LOCATIONS. FOREIGN GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS REPORTED ON SCHEDULE F INCLUDE FINANCIAL AID PROVIDED TO STUDENTS STUDYING ABROAD.
RECORDS VERIFYING ELIGIBILITY ARE MAINTAINED YEARLY FOR EACH ORGANIZATIION
SCHOLARSHIPS AND FINANCIAL AID ARE BASED ON APPLICATION PROCESS, EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTIONS AND COST OF TUITION.

The College's financial aid office awards scholarships to students based on eligibility criteria predetermined by donors and college policies. All awards are applied to tuition and related education expenses only.

The University monitors their respective grants by establishing a separate accounting for each individual grant. All transactions are reviewed and approved by appropriate personnel prior to submission for processing to ensure they meet the requirements of the grant.
THE COLLEGE PROVIDES GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS TO ITS FULL-TIME, DEGREE SEEKING STUDENTS, BY CREDITING SUCH AMOUNTS DIRECTLY TO THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNTS, TO BE ONLY USED AS AN OFFSET FOR TUITION.
All accepted students currently received a half Olin tuition scholarship which is credited directly to their student accounts. It is used only to offset tuition charges.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE EFFECTIVE DISCOUNTS OF TUITION COLLECTED FROM STUDENTS FOR PROGRAM SERVICES PROVIDED TO THEM. THE COLLEGE HAS A SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE THAT ALLOCATES INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS BASED UPON AN ASSESSMENT OF A COMBINATION OF FINANCIAL NEED AND MERIT. IN ADDITION, SOME SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GRANTED ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC AND/OR GEOGRAPHIC BACKGROUND. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE REVIEWED ANNUALLY WITH REGARD TO APPROPRIATE ASSESSMENT OF STUDENT FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC STANDING. ANNUAL RENEWAL OF FINANCIAL AID IS GENERALLY CONTINUOUS CONTINGENT UPON THE ANNUAL REVIEW PROCESS, CONSISTENT WITH THE COLLEGE'S POLICY.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PART I, LINE 2 - PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS
ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIP/DISCOUNTS ARE CREDITED TO EACH STUDENT'S ACCOUNT MAINTAINED WITH OLLU.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: Scholarships are provided to students based on needs assessments and/or performance. Once the student has been approved to receive the grant, the amount is credited to the student's Baker College account. The College's Financial Aid office monitors the student to make sure the award stays in compliance. If the student does not continue to meet the grant requirements, the student's account may be reduced. Grants and other assistance to organizations in the United States are budgeted each year by the Baker College campus. The campus President determines which organization benefits from a grant based on the community's needs. If the grant exceeds the budget, the Board of Regents must approve the funding. These grants and assistance are awarded to other tax-exempt organizations to be used in any way the recipients see fit to further their mission and tax exempt purpose; the use of these funds is not monitored by the Baker College campus.

A FILE IS CREATED FOR EACH GRANTEE, WHICH CONTAINS THE OFFICIAL INSTITUTIONAL STUDENT INFORMATION RECORD FROM THE FEDERAL PROCESSOR FROM WHICH ELIGIBILITY IS DETERMINED ACCORDING TO FEDERAL, STATE, AND INSTITUTIONAL GUIDELINES FOR THE AWARDING OF FINACIAL ASSISTANCE.

GRANTS TO ORGANIZATIONS REQUIRE QUARTERLY PROGRAM REPORTING INCLUDING A NARRATIVE AND FINANCIAL SUMMARY THAT IS REVIEWED BY THE PROGRAM DIRECTOR. SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS FOR STUDENTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO A STUDENT'S COLLEGE ACCOUNT AND APPLIED TO TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD. ALL FINANCIAL AID IS SUBJECT TO REVISION BASED ON AVAILABILITY, CHANGES IN FAMILY CONTRIBUTION AND/OR CREDIT LOAD. SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS MUST BE MAINTAINED ACCORDING TO STANDARDS PRESCRIBED BY THE COLLEGE. ANNUAL RENEWAL OF FINANCIAL AID IS CONTINUOUS IF INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL NEED REMAINS, ALL REQUIRED DOCUMENTS ARE COMPLETED BY THE PUBLISHED DEADLINE AND SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS IS MAINTAINED CONSISTENT WITH THE COLLEGE'S POLICY.

The College has a professionally staffed financial aid office charged with the responsibility of ensuring that all recipients meet all eligibility criteria ensuring that the College is in compliance with all government regulations pertaining to financial aid.

THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID AWARDS STUDENTS AID BASED ON ENROLLMENT, NEED BASED ON THE SUBMISSION OF THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) AND THE ABILITY TO MEET CERTAIN DONOR SPECIFIED CRITERIA.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedure for Monitoring Use of Grant Funds Inside United States
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Ripon College tracks all grants issued by grant, dollar amount, student, and term. Financial Aid awards grants based on the grantees eligibility for any grant. Eligibility may be based on need, grades, majors, etc. If need based, the FAFSA will be utilized. Each grant may have unique selection criteria which is documented by the Financial Aid Department.
PROCEDURE FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS: SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON NEED AND MONITORED ANNUALLY BASED ON STUDENTS' ACADEMIC PROFILES AND GUIDELINES AS PROVIDED TO STUDENTS.

GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY THE BUSINESS OFFICE AND OTHER VARIOUS AREAS. FINANCIAL AID GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH ELIGIBILITY, SELECTION, AND DISTRIBUTION. DOCUMENTATION IS MAINTAINED AND AUDITED ANNUALLY. OTHER DEPARTMENT GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY THE DEPARTMENT CHAIR AND THE BUSINESS OFFICE TO ENSURE THAT EXPENDITURES COMPLY WITH GRANT REQUIREMENTS AND ARE NOT DIVERTED FOR OTHER USES.

A LIST OF RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIPS, FELLOWSHIPS, AND GRANTS IS ON FILE AT THE INSTITUTION UPON REQUEST. ALTHOUGH THERE MAY BE RECIPIENTS WHO ARE RELATED TO PERSONS HAVING AN INTEREST IN THE ORGANIZATION, SUCH RECIPIENTS ARE ON AN EQUAL, OBJECTIVELY DETERMINABLE BASIS WITH OTHER RECIPIENTS; THAT IS ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING AID ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE INSTITUTION'S ASSESSMENT ON THE BASIS OF ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS.

LAFAYETTE COLLEGE MAINTAINS A POLICY DEFINING ITS PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF SPONSORED FUNDS BY SUB-RECIPIENTS WHO ARE PERFORMING A PORTION OF A SPONSORED PROJECT EXTERNALLY AWARDED TO LAFAYETTE. THIS POLICY PROVIDES GUIDANCE TO ENSURE THAT SUB-RECIPIENTS CONDUCT THEIR PORTION OF SPONSORED PROJECTS IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE LAWS, REGULATIONS, TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF AWARDS AND SUB AWARDS, AND THAT REIMBURSEMENT COST INCURRED BY SUB-RECIPIENTS ARE ALLOWED.

THE COLLEGE CONSIDERS THE AWARDING OF FINANCIAL AID (PRIMARILY GRANTS, SCHOLARSHIPS, LOANS, AND WORK-STUDY) TO ITS STUDENTS, INCLUDING NON-RESIDENT ALIEN STUDENTS, TO BE A U.S. BASED ACTIVITY AS STUDENTS OF THE COLLEGE ARE DEEMED TO BE LIVING IN THE UNITED STATES THROUGHOUT THEIR COMPLETION OF THE COLLEGE'S ACADEMIC CURRICULUM AND SUPPORTING PROGRAMS. THE COLLEGE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ON THE BASIS OF MERIT AND/OR FINANCIAL NEED. THE SELECTION CRITERIA ARE BASED ON THE CALCULATED EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION, WHICH IS DERIVED BY USING COMPLEX FORMULAS INVOLVING FAMILIES' INCOME, ASSETS, AND HOUSEHOLD SIZES INCLUDING, AMONG OTHER FACTORS, DEPENDENTS IN COLLEGE. THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE ADMINISTERS AND MONITORS THESE AWARDS TO HELP ENSURE THAT THESE FUNDS ARE AWARDED TO ELIGIBLE RECIPIENTS IN ACCORDANCE WITH APPLICABLE FEDERAL, STATE, AND OTHER REQUIREMENTS, AS WELL AS RELEVANT INTERNAL COLLEGE POLICIES AND OPERATIONAL GUIDELINES. ACADEMIC PRIZES, AWARDS, FELLOWSHIP, AND INTERNSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON A REVIEW BY THE APPLICABLE ACADEMIC DEPARTMENT. ALL AWARDED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT AT THE COLLEGE AND ARE APPLIED TO BILLED CHARGES.

AWARDS PAID TO INDIVIDUALS ARE NOT MONITORED BECAUSE THEY ARE AWARDED BASED ON MEETING THE SELECTION CRITERIA. TUITION ASSISTANCE IS NOT MONITORED BECAUSE PAYMENTS ARE MADE DIRECTLY TO THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN MISSISSIPPI. RESEARCH GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY THE CONTRIBUTORS WHO CONTRIBUTE MONEY BASED ON REACHING PREDEFINED MILESTONES AND REQUIRE PERIODIC REPORTING.

Most, if not all student scholarships are credited to the student accounts without the funds passing through the students hands. Sources outside the university that provide scholarships are encouraged to remit payment directly to the university, which credits the student account upon receipt. Institutional aid is almost always credited directly to the student accounts.
ORGANIZATIONS RECEIVING GRANT FUNDS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT INTERIM AND GRANT-END NARRATIVE AND FINANCIAL REPORTS.
THE COLLEGE HAS A SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTTEE THAT SELECTS ALL SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS. THE COLLEGE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO STUDENTS BASED ON NEED.
The funds are used as scholarships at Gratz College and are directly credited to the recipient's tuition.

ExplntnTxt: The College awards institutional grants and scholarships to enrolled students. Students file a FAFSA form to be considered for a grant award. The majority of the grant awards are need-based as defined by Federal Formula. Scholarships are awarded according to donor specifications.

THE ORGANIZATION TRACKS THE USE OF THE FUNDS AWARDED. AMOUNTS USED AND UNUSED ARE TRACKED ANNUALLY AND JUSTIFIED AT FISCAL YEAR END.

SCHOLARSIPS ARE AVAILABLE TO STUDENTS WHO ARE ACTIVE IN THE SCHOOL FUNCTIONS AND THE SOCIAL BETTERMENT OF THE PROFESSION OF CHIROPRACTORS AND ACUPUNCTURE. THE SCHOLARSHIPS REFLECT AN APPRECIATION OF THE SERVICE COMMITMENT AS WELL AS ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE GRANTS, LOANS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED, ACADEMIC STATUS, ABILITY TO BENEFIT AND OTHER CRITERIA. DOCUMENTATION OF STUDENT ELIGIBILITY IS MAINTAINED ON FILE IN THE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND IS SUBJECT TO ANNUAL INDEPENDENT AUDIT.

THE AWARDS ARE DETERMINED AND CANDIDATES SELECTED BY THE K-STATE GRADUATE SCHOOL. THE GRADUATE SCHOOL REQUESTS THE FUNDS FROM KSURF AS NEAR AS POSSIBLE TO THE BEGINNING OF APPLICABLE SCHOOL TERM AND THE FUNDS ARE DEPOSITED INTO A RESTRICTED FEES ACCOUNT. THE FUNDS USED FOR SCHOLARSHIPS ARE TRACKED IN A SEPARATE GL ACCOUNT FOR THE RESERVE AND THIS IS WHERE THE DETAIL OF USE OF THE FUNDS IS TRACKED.

FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 LONG ISLAND UNIVERSITY OFFERS A NUMBER OF INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS TO QUALIFYING STUDENTS ENROLLED IN BOTH DEGREE AND NON-DEGREE PROGRAMS. EACH GRANT OR OTHER FORMS OF ASSISTANCE HAVE SPECIFIC AWARDING CRITERIA AND INDIVIDUAL RULES FOR SELECTION BASED ON MERIT, NEED, AND/OR PERFORMANCE. THESE REQUIREMENTS ARE PUBLISHED EACH YEAR AND ARE ADMINISTERED BY THE CAMPUS FINANCIAL AID OFFICES WHICH ARE ALSO RESPONSIBLE FOR AWARDING AND POSTING TRANSACTIONS TO INDIVIDUAL STUDENT ACCOUNTS. THE DISBURSAL OF FUNDS IS SEGREGATED AND PERFORMED BY THE CENTRAL FINANCIAL AID OFFICE OF THE UNIVERSITY. IN ADDITION, INTERNAL CONTROLS ARE IN PLACE TO ENSURE AMOUNTS ARE AWARDED ACCURATELY TO STUDENTS WHO PROPERLY MEET AND MAINTAIN ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA. ACCOUNTING TRANSACTIONS ARE ROUTINELY RECONCILED THROUGH THE UNIVERSITY'S ERP SYSTEM AND STUDENT ACCOUNTS ARE CONSISTENTLY MONITORED BY ADMINISTRATIVE STAFF.

AWARD FUNDS ARE BALANCED PERIODICALLY ACCORDING TO THE AWARD YEAR TIME FRAME AND ANY DISCREPENCIES ARE INVESTIGATED IMMEDIATELY. EACH AWARD FUND MAINTAINS RECORDS OF ELIGIBILITY, SELECTION CRITERIA AND AMOUNT AWARDED. THESE PARAMETERS MAY BE ADJUSTED ANNUALLY AND STUDENTS ARE NOTIFIED ACCORDINGLY. MOST AWARDS ARE GRANTED FOR TUITION ONLY, BUT SOME MAY BE USED FOR BOOKS AND HOUSING, ETC. THE PARAMETERES ARE EITHER PUBLISHED IN THE HANDBOOK OR WITH THE AWARD PACKET AND APPLICATION.

The School awards scholarships to students which are funded from operations or from donations. The scholarships from operating funds are awarded on the basis of academic performance for continuing students or related parameters such as LSAT scores, GPA and completed application forms for entering students. Donor-funded scholarships are awarded based on criteria set forth by donors. The Associate Dean for Students and Admissions and The Office of Admissions communicate the availability of the scholarships, process the applications and determine which applicants have qualified based on information provided by the Registrar's office for those awarded on the basis of academic performance. Additionally for those that are donor-funded, a Committee established by the School may be called upon to determine which applicants qualify based on donor-requirements. Once awarded, the scholarships are posted to the individual students' accounts. The Financial Aid Office maintains records of scholarship awards and ensures that these are factored into the calculation of how much federally funded financial aid each student is eligible to receive. After the initial award letters are sent out, additional scholarships may be awarded. The posting of additional scholarships triggers a re-evaluation of the student's eligibility for federally funded student loans, which may result in adjustments to the student's loan awarded.
TUITION REDUCTIONS WERE GIVEN QUARTERLY TO ALL STUDENTS WHO ENROLLED IN THE LICENSE VOCATIONAL PROGRAM AT ANNENBERG SCHOOL OF NURSING AND HAD AN ACCEPTABLE GRADE IN THE IMMEDIATE PRIOR QUARTER.

THE COLLEGE'S ADMINISTRATIVE STAFF OVERSEE THAT THE PROVISIONS OF THE GRANTS ARE MET IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE GUIDELINES OR AGREEMENT SET FORTH, WHETHER THAT IS USE OF DONOR, GOVERNMENT OR INSTITUTIONAL SOURCES.
NEED-BASED GRANTS AWARDED BASED ON FINANCIAL AID NEEDS ANALYSIS. OTHER GRANTS/SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED BASED ON MEETING REQUIREMENTS SET FORTH BY THE DONOR.

Scholarships are awarded to students of the college based on various criteria. These criteria include financial need, grade point average, and others as established by the scholarship documents. Scholarships are applied to the individual student's accounts to pay tuition, room and board expenses. Part III - The number of recipients shown for Schedule I Part III is based on the number of grants awarded. The amount is used as a reasonable estimate of the total number of students awarded grants and scholarships.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF MERIT AND NEED. FIRST YEAR STUDENTS MAY BE AWARDED SPECIAL ASSISTANCE BASED ON NEED AND MERIT AS DETERMINED BY THE APPLICANT'S APPLICATION AND AUDITION. SECOND YEAR AND ACADEMY COMPANY STUDENTS MAY APPLY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS BY WRITING TO THE ACADEMY'S SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE WHICH MAKES ALL SCHOLARSHIP DECISIONS. DETAILS ARE AVAILABLE UPON REQUEST.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: After the initial review and approval by the appropriate employees at the grant department level, the paperwork for grant expenditures are then passed on to the next review and approval level by an applicable College or Departmental Administrator of grant expenditures. Upon approval, the paperwork is sent to the Senior Grants Accountant for review and approval prior to payment processing of the grant expenditures. The scholarships to students are administered by the financial aid office. The scholarship amounts are internally credited to the individual students' billed tuition to ensure funds are used for their intended purpose.

GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE AWARDED TO INDIVIDUALS IN THE UNITED STATES REPRESENT STUDENT FINANCIAL AID. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL AID ARE DETERMINED TO BE WORTHY BY THE UNIVERSITY'S ASSESSMENT ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID AND THE FINANCE OFFICE FOR EACH COLLEGE CONTINUOUSLY MONITOR STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE AWARDS.

THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS BOTH INSTITUTIONALLY-FUNDED FINANCIAL AID TO STUDENTS AS WELL AS FINANCIAL AID FUNDED FROM PRIVATE GIFTS AND VARIOUS FEDERAL, STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT AGENCIES. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED ON AN EQUAL, OBJECTIVE AND NONDISCRIMINATORY BASIS USING ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS. THE UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS SEPARATE ACCOUNTING FOR ALL GRANTS AND STRICTLY MONITORS THAT ANY DISBURSEMENTS ARE MADE ONLY FOR THE INTENDED PURPOSE OF THE GRANT AND IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE GRANT REQUIREMENTS. AN AUDIT OF THE UNIVERSITY'S FEDERALLY FUNDED PROGRAMS, IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE "US OFFICE OF MANAGEMENT AND BUDGET ("OMB") CIRCULAR A-133 COMPLIANCE SUPPLEMENT", IS CONDUCTED ANNUALLY BY THE UNIVERSITY'S EXTERNAL AUDITORS.
To be considered for need based aid, a student is required to complete a Free Application for Federal Student Aid. Financial aid awards are not automatically renewed each year.

The students complete applications for receipt of scholarship funds to be used for their education. These funds are then applied to their tuition balances. Awards are determined by a scholarship committee. Tuition discounts are also extended to qualified individuals.

OUR HONORS SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GIVEN TO CURRENT STUDENTS ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. YELLOW RIBBON IS A PARTIAL MATCH OF FUNDS RECEIVED FROM THE DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AS PART OF A FEDERAL PROGRAM FOR QUALIFIED STUDENTS. THE OTHER SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GIVEN TO CURRENT STUDENTS BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED, COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT AND/OR ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT.

WAGNER COLLEGE MONITORS THE USE OF SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS IN THE UNITED STATES BY ENSuRING THAT ALL STUDENTS WHO RECEIVE SCHOLARSHIP MONIES ARE ALWAYS REGISTERED AS STUDENTS OF THE COLLEGE. MANY DEPARTMENTS WITHIN THE COLLEGE WORK IN CONJUNCTION TO ENSURE THAT SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS ARE MONITORED EFFICIENTLY AND EFFECTIVELY. THE ADMISSIONS OFFICE REVIEWS ALL STUDENT APPLICATIONS, AND DETERMINES WHO IS ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE SCHOLARSHIPS. THE FINANCE AND BUSINESS OFFICE DRAWS DOWN FUNDS FOR SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO STUDENTS, AND THE REGISTRAR'S OFFICE MONITORS AND MAINTAINS ALL RECORDS REGARDING THE REGISTERED STATUS OF STUDENTS. PART III, LINE 1, COLUMN B WAGNER COLLEGE ESTIMATES THAT APPROXIMATELY 90% OF ALL FULL-TIME STUDENTS RECEIVE SOME SORT OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE from THE COLLEGE. THEREFORE, THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS OF GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE BY WAGNER COLLEGE IS ESTIMATED BY TAKING 90% OF THE TOTAL FTE ENROLLMENT FOR THE FALL 2014 SEMESTER (2,113 FTES), RESULTING IN APPROXIMATELY 1,900 RECIPIENTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: Explanation: Grants given to support of charitable community organizations. Such grants are extended only for charitable purposes to organizations that are exempt under Code Section 501(c)(3). After qualifications for the grant are met and the grant is disbursed to the charitable organization there is no subsequent monitoring by the University. Grants or other assistance are awarded to organizations or entities in the U.S. pursuant to the University policies and procedures for all grant subawards. Such subawards are monitored through the University's office for Sponsored Research (OSR) and the University's Office of Accounting Services for Research and Sponsored Programs (ASRSP). All subaward documentation including purchase orders, related charges and invoices are reviewed and monitored by ASRP and confirmed with the principal investigator. The principal investigator must certify that the subaward costs are in accordance with the OMB A-21 cost principles; also, ASRSP requests and collects audit reports from subaward recipients to monitor compliance. If the information is not furnished to ASRSP, payment may be withheld. Grants and other assistance are awarded to students on the basis of financial need following University policies developed to meet regulatory requirements (federal methodology) and guided by the College Board (institutional methodology). Merit scholarships are awarded based upon talent (eg, academic, music, and athletic). All of these awarded grants are allowed to be used by the students towards any type of costs; no subsequent monitoring is required.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part III PRIZES AND AWARDS
ExplntnTxt: PRIZES AND AWARDS REFLECT PRIZES AND AWARDS EXTENDED TO NON-EMPLOYEES IN RECOGNITION OF AN ACCOMPLISHMENT, ACTIVITY, OR EVENT. PRIZES AND AWARDS GIVEN TO EMPLOYEES ARE INCLUDED AS COMPENSATION AND REPORTED ON AN EMPLOYEE'S FORM W-2.

DECISIONS REGARDING FINANCIAL AID ARE MADE BY THE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. THE GOAL IS TO PROVIDE ADEQUATE FINANCIAL AID TO APPLICANTS WHO, WITHOUT SUCH AID, WOULD BE UNABLE TO ATTEND THE UNIVERSITY.

The King's College continuously monitors the academic progress of students receiving scholarship and financial aid funds. All scholarships and financial aid and housing grants are applied directly to the student accounts and therefore, no cash changes hands.

PART I, LINE 2 IN PART AS A RESULT OF ENDOWMENT SUPPORT OF STUDENT AID, STANFORD IS ABLE TO WAIVE THE TOTAL COST OF TUITION FOR MANY OF ITS DESERVING STUDENTS. STANFORD EXPECTS NO PARENTAL CONTRIBUTION TOWARD TUITION FROM PARENTS WITH ANNUAL INCOMES BELOW $125,000 AND TYPICAL ASSETS. THERE IS ZERO PARENTAL CONTRIBUTION TOWARD TUITION, ROOM OR BOARD FOR PARENTS WITH ANNUAL INCOMES BELOW $65,000 AND TYPICAL ASSETS. THE UNIVERSITY IS ALSO MINDFUL OF STUDENT DEBT, AND IT DOES NOT EXPECT STUDENTS TO BORROW TO MEET THEIR NEED. AS A RESULT, STANFORD STUDENTS GENERALLY INCUR LESS DEBT THAN THEIR PEERS AT OTHER UNIVERSITIES. FOR STUDENTS WHO CHOOSE TO BORROW, THE MEDIAN INDEBTEDNESS WAS $16,417 IN FY 15. THAT SAME YEAR, 78 PERCENT OF STANFORD UNDERGRADUATES RECEIVING DEGREES GRADUATED WITH NO DEBT - UP FROM 55 PERCENT IN FY 05 - EVIDENCE OF STANFORD'S GENEROUS AID PROGRAM. THIS FINANCIAL AID PROGRAM IS A DEMONSTRATION OF STANFORD'S COMMITMENT TO ACCESS FOR OUTSTANDING STUDENTS FROM ALL BACKGROUNDS - INCLUDING NOT ONLY THOSE FROM THE LOWEST SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS, BUT ALSO MIDDLE- AND UPPER-MIDDLE-CLASS FAMILIES WHO NEED OUR ASSISTANCE AS WELL. GRANTS AND ALLOCATIONS REFLECT NON-COMPENSATORY SUPPORT PROVIDED TO STUDENTS IN VARIOUS FORMS. STANFORD IS COMMITTED TO A NEED-BLIND ADMISSIONS POLICY, ADMITTING QUALIFIED UNDERGRADUATES WITHOUT REGARD TO THEIR ABILITY TO PAY AND PROVIDING A COMPREHENSIVE FINANCIAL AID PROGRAM FOR ALL ADMITTED UNDERGRADUATES WHO HAVE NEED AS DETERMINED BY THE UNIVERSITY AND WHO MEET OTHER REQUISITE CONDITIONS FOR FINANCIAL AID. MORE THAN 85% OF UNDERGRADUATES RECEIVED SOME FORM OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE DURING THE TAX YEAR AS WELL AS OVER 85% OF ALL GRADUATE STUDENTS FROM STANFORD AND OTHER SOURCES. THE TOTAL FINANCIAL AID INCLUDES $260,615,588 IN MERIT AND NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS. AN ADDITIONAL $143,102,635 REFLECTS AMOUNTS PAID FOR ADDITIONAL FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO STUDENTS, INCLUDING PAYMENTS FOR HEALTH INSURANCE, LIVING EXPENSES, AND SUPPORT OF POSTDOCTORAL FELLOWS. THESE AMOUNTS INCLUDE $2,523,359 IN GRANTS TO INDIVIDUALS OUTSIDE THE UNITED STATES. GRANTS LISTED IN PART II ARE PRIMARILY GRANTS MADE FROM DONOR ADVISED FUNDS MANAGED BY STANFORD AND ARE BASED ON RECOMMENDATIONS BY DONORS OF THOSE FUNDS AND REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY SENIOR OFFICIALS IN THE OFFICE OF DEVELOPMENT. SUB-GRANTS STANFORD OCCASIONALLY RECEIVES GRANT SUPPORT THAT IS DISBURSED TO OTHER INDIVIDUALS OR ENTITIES PER THE TERMS OF THE AWARD. IN MOST CASES, PRIOR TO THE GRANT TO STANFORD, THE UNIVERSITY WILL PROVIDE THE GRANTING ENTITY WITH A LIST OF SUCH CONTEMPLATED RECIPIENTS. GENERALLY, AS WORK ON THE GRANT PROGRESSES, CHANGES TO THESE RECIPIENTS MUST BE APPROVED BY THE GRANTING AGENCY. DUE TO THESE REVIEW REQUIREMENTS OF THE GRANTING AGENCY, STANFORD DOES NOT REPORT SUCH PAYMENTS ON FORM 990, SCHEDULE I.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: TO RECEIVE A STIPEND, THE INDIVIDUAL MUST BE A STUDENT AND MEET THE REQUIRED GUIDELINE FROM THE AWARDING AGENCY. EACH DEPARTMENT CHAIR VERIFIES THAT THE STUDENT MEETS THE AWARDING AGENCY'S GUIDELINES. THE BUSINESS OFFICE MONITORS THE PAYMENTS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON SPECIFIC GUIDELINES CREATED BY THE SOURCE OF FUNDING. THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT DETERMINES ELIGIBILITY AND MONITORS USE OF FUNDS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: form 990, schedule i, part i, line 2
ExplntnTxt: THE INSTITUTE'S GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE WITHIN THE UNITED STATES CONSISTS PRIMARILY OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS AWARDED TO STUDENTS. STUDENTS ARE SELECTED FOR SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS BASED ON ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND SIMILAR STANDARDS. VARIOUS INSTITUTE OFFICES MONITOR ELIGIBILITY AND SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS BY GRANTEES. THE INSTITUTE MAKES AN ANNUAL $75,000 GRANT TO THE CALTECH Y. IN ADDITION, THE INSTITUTE ALLOWS THE CALTECH Y THE USE OF FACILITIES ON CAMPUS FREE OF CHARGE. THE CALTECH Y IS A RELATED ORGANIZATION WHOSE MISSION IS TO SUPPORT THE STUDENTS OF CALTECH THROUGH VARIOUS ACTIVITIES. THE INSTITUTE MAKES AN ANNUAL DONATION (DESIGNATED ASSISTANCE) TO THE UNITED WAY OF GREATER LOS ANGELES. INSTITUTE OFFICES MONITOR THE GRANTEE'S PERFORMANCE ACCORDING TO THEIR RESPECTIVE PROGRAM SERVICES GOALS AND/OR PURSUANT TO OTHER AGREEMENTS. FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART III, COLUMN (C) CASH GRANTS REPRESENT CREDIT ON ACCOUNTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Student aid is based on academic achievement, financial need and other similar standards. The College evaluates student eligibility at the end of each semester for the following term and also before disbursement of financial aid.

All funds donated by individuals, corporations or foundations are recorded a temporarily restricted until funds are identified as applicable to financial aid for a student. All awards are under the direction of the Financial Aid Office to ensure compliance with donors' directions.

FINANCIAL AID AWARDS TO STUDENTS AT POINT PARK UNIVERSITY ARE DETERMINED ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, COMMUNITY SERVICE, ARTISTIC OR ATHLETIC TALENT AND FINANCIAL NEED ELIGIBILITY. GRANTS AND LOANS ARE DISTRIBUTED USING POWERFAIDS APPLICATION AND POSTED TO STUDENT'S ACCOUNTS IN JENZABAR (HIGHER EDUCATION INFORMATION SYSTEM). ANNUALLY THE FINANCIAL AID AREA IS AUDITED BY AN INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTING FIRM.

GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS ARE PROVIDED IN THE FORM OF STIPENDS TO RESIDENTS, POST-DOCTORAL, AND GRADUATE STUDENTS. THE STIPENDS ARE SUBJECT TO ALL OF THE PAYROLL SYSTEM CONTROLS, TIME SHEETS, TIME AND EFFORT REPORTING AND OTHER PAYROLL CONTROLS. THE REMAINING GRANTS USE TUITION SCHOLARSHIPS WHICH ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO TUITION AND FEES WITHIN THE ACCOUNTING SYSTEM TO WHICH THE STUDENT HAS NO ACCESS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: THE ORGANIZATION AWARDS GRANTS BASED ON NEED TO NEW AND CONTINUING STUDENTS WHO HAVE COMPLETED A FAFSA AND ARE CONSIDERED TO BE ELIGIBLE FOR FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID. THE DOCERE AND TOLEE TOTUM GRANT AWARDS ARE FUNDED BY INSTITUTIONAL FUNDRAISING EFFORTS. BOTH AWARDS EMBODY THE SPIRIT OF NATUROPATHIC MEDICINE, WHERE DOCERE IS A "DOCTOR AS TEACHER- AND TOLEE TOTUM IS "TREAT THE WHOLE PERSON". THE ENROLLMENT MANAGEMENT EXECUTIVE SERVES AS THE SCHOLARSHIP REVIEW COMMITTEE IN REVIEWING AND DETERMINING THE AWARDS. THE DOCERE AWARDS ARE BASED ON ACADEMIC MERIT AND NEED. THE TOLEE TOTUM AWARDS ARE ALSO BASED ON NEED AND AN ESSAY WHERE APPLICANTS IDENTIFY WHAT THE PRACTICE OF NATUROPATHIC MEDICINE MEANS TO THEM AND HOW A GRANT AWARDS WOULD AID THEM IN REACHING THEIR EDUCATIONAL GOALS. WHEN ESTABLISHING THESE GRANT AWARDS, THE ORGANIZATION SEEKS TO REWARD STUDENTS WHO HAVE ACHIEVED HIGH ACADEMIC SUCCESS AS WELL AS THOSE WHO WILL BENEFIT THE MOST FROM THE GRANT AWARD. AS STATED IN THE ORGANIZATION'S COURSE CATALOG, THE ORGANIZATION DOES NOT DISCRIMINATE ON THE BASIS OF RACE, DISABILITY, SEX, RELIGION, AGE, NATIONAL OR ETHNIC ORIGIN, SEXUAL ORIENTATION, OR MARITAL STATUS IN THE ADMINISTRATION OF EDUCATIONAL AND ADMISSION POLICIES, FINANCIAL AID, EMPLOYMENT OR ANY OTHER PROGRAM OR ACTIVITY. THIS STATEMENT APPLIES TO THE AWARDING OF SCNM SCHOLARSHIPS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: MONITORING THE USE OF GRANTS Emory University's student aid awards consist of need-based and merit-Based awards. Merit-based funding is awarded based upon donor preferences and restrictions or institutional academic criteria. Need-based aid is awarded based upon institutional methodology, a standard need analysis formula generally practiced by other private, non-profit peer institutions. Student financial aid is awarded to students for educational purposes. Award amounts are controlled by educational costs established by the institution and student progress is evaluated at key points in the student lifecycle if the award has contingencies that require such. Disbursement controls are in place that require direct costs be paid prior to providing refunds for non-direct educational expenses. Emory University is responsible for ensuring that it communicates the relevant and necessary information contained in subcontracted award documents to the subrecipients. The Office of Grants and Contracts Accounting maintains a copy of the Subcontract Agreement, which stipulates the terms of the award and is signed by representatives of both Emory University and the subrecipient organization. This agreement indicates that the subrecipient understands and is aware of the award requirements. In addition, if there are any further changes to the Agreement, an amendment to the agreement is generated and signed by the representative of Emory University and the subrecipient.

THE COLLEGE OFFERS SEVERAL SCHOLARSHIP OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS. THE PRIMARY SCHOLARSHIPS AND THE GUIDELINES FOR QUALIFYING ARE: FOUNDERS SCHOLARSHIPS - THESE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS UPON ACCEPTANCE TO A BACHELOR OF SCIENCE DEGREE PROGRAM AT VAUGHN. TO BE CONSIDERED, APPLICANTS MUST ATTAIN A CUMULATIVE HIGH SCHOOL AVERAGE OF AT LEAST A "B AND A COMBINED SAT1 SCORE OF AT LEAST 1000. STUDENTS WHO MEET THESE MINIMUM CRITERIAS WILL BE CONSIDERED FOR AWARDS, BASED ON THEIR GRADES AND EXAM SCORES, BY VAUGHN COLLEGE'S SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE. THE AWARDS MAY BE RENEWABLE FOR UP TO FOUR YEARS OF CONSECUTIVE STUDY, PROVIDING THE RECIPIENT MAINTAINS A 3.0 CUMULATIVE GRADE POINT AVERAGE (GPA). BOARD OF TRUSTEES GRANTS - THE BOARD OF TRUSTEE ALLOCATES FUNDS TO BE USED IN AWARDING GRANT-IN-AID ASSISTANCE TO NEW AND CONTINUING STUDENTS. GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO ARE MATRICULATING ON A FULL OR PART-TIME BASIS IN BACHELOR AND ASSOCIATE DEGREE PROGRAMS. RECIPIENTS ARE SELECTED ON THE BASIS OF THEIR ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE AND FINANCIAL AID STATUS. AWARDS ARE DESIGNATED FOR A SPECIFIC ACADEMIC YEAR AND ARE RENEWABLE EACH SEMESTER BASED ON SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE AND THE AVAILABILITY OF FUNDS. TRANSFER STUDENT SCHOLARSHIP - STUDENTS WHO TRANSFER TO THE COLLEGE HAVING COMPLETED 24 OR MORE CREDITS AT AN ACCREDITED COLLEGE OR UNIVERSITY, AND WHO HAVE ACHIEVED A CUMULATIVE GRADE POINT AVERAGE OF AT LEAST 3.0 (INCLUDING ALL COURSES AT EVERY INSTITUTION ATTENDED) MAY BE AWARDED SCHOLARSHIPS TO TRANSFER. THE AWARDS MAY BE RENEWABLE FOR UP TO THREE YEARS OF CONSECUTIVE STUDY, PROVIDING THE RECIPIENT MAINTAINS A 3.0 CUMULATIVE GPA. ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE SCHOLARSHIPS - ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED EACH YEAR TO CONTINUING STUDENTS ON THE BASIS OF OUTSTANDING ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND SELECTION FOR ACADEMIC HONORS. THE CRITERIA APPLIED IN DECIDING ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE AWARDS INCLUDE CUMULATIVE GPA AND SATISFACTORY COMPLETION OF AT LEAST TWO SEMESTERS (29 CREDITS/UNITS OR MORE) AS A MATRICULATED STUDENT.
They are monitored through different bank accounts.

Schedule I, Part I, Line 1 THE GRANTS DEPARTMENT AND THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE OVERSEE ALL GRANTS, GOVERNMENT LOANS AND SCHOLARSHIP EXPENDITURES. ALL GRANT EXPENSES ARE APPROVED AND REIMBURSED IN ACCORDANCE WITH UNIVERSITY POLICY. AN ANNUAL AUDIT IS CONDUCTED IN ACCORDANCE WITH GOVERNMENTAL REGULATIONS.

SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2: THE COLLEGE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO QUALIFIED INDIVIDUALS ON THE BASIS OF FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. THE AWARDING OF FUNDS IS MONITORED BY THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE, WHERE A COMPLETE LISTING OF RECIPIENTS IS ALSO MAINTAINED.

Monitoring the Use of Grants On rare occasion, the University will match funds raised by students for worthy charitable projects. All such funds are reviewed carefully by the VP for Student Life and approved by the President upon the recommendation of the Student Government Association.

Grants and Other Assistance to Individuals The University has financial aid available in many forms, including scholarships and grants. The eligibility for financial aid is based upon student's achievement and promise, academic credentials and financial need.
THE FINANCIAL AID DIRECTOR AT EACH CAMPUS IS GIVEN AN AMOUNT THAT MAY BE AWARDED AT THEIR CAMPUS FOR THE FISCAL YEAR, WITH A CHART OF HOW MANY STUDENTS AND THE AMOUNT FOR EACH TERM.

CBS SUBMITTED A GRANT PROPOSAL ON 1/22/2015 TO LATINO U INDICATING HOW THE GRANT WOULD BE UTILIZED TO FUND A MENTOR PROGRAM FOR FIRST GEN STUDENTS ENTERING FRESHMAN YEAR OF COLLEGE. UPON COMPLETION OF THE PROGRAM YEAR, DECEMBER 2015, CAMPUS BOUND SCHOLARS SUBMITTED A YEAR END REPORT DESCRIBING THE PROGRAM IMPLEMENTATION AND EXPENDITURES MADE WITH THE FUNDS. THE REPORT CLEARLY INDICATED THE GRANT WAS UTILIZED FOR ITS INTENDED PURPOSE PROVIDING SUPPORT AND COLLEGE SUPPLIES FOR 10 FIRST-GEN STUDENTS IN WESTCHESTER COUNTY.

ALL SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS MADE MY ALLIANT EDUCATIONAL FOUNDATION ARE TO STUDENTS OR FACULTY OF ALLIANT EDUCATIONAL FOUNDATION WHO HAVE COMPLETED AN APPLICATION PROCESS. THE AWARD IS BASED ON A WRITTEN SELECTION CRITERIA. ONCE THE GRANTS ARE DISTRIBUTED, EACH GRANT IS MONITORED ON AN INDIVIDUAL STUDENT ACCOUNT BASIS.

AN INDEPENDENT SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE REVIEWS ALL APPLICANTS AND AWARDS THE SCHOLARSHIP AMOUNTS. ALL APPLICATIONS FOR FINANCIAL AID AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE REVIEWED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. STUDENTS WHO ARE QUALIFIED FOR SCHOLARSHIPS ARE REVIEWED BY THE INDEPENDENT SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE FOR RECOMMENDATION, FINAL RECOMMENDATIONS ARE THEN REFERRED TO THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE FOR AWARDING.

GRANTS TO INDIVIDUALS. THE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS THAT ATTEND ONE OF THE COMPANY'S COLLEGES. THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT REVIEWS THE APPLICATIONS FOR THE SCHOLARSHIPS SUBMITTED BY STUDENTS OR PROSPECTIVE STUDENTS, COMPARES THE APPLICATIONS WITH THE WRITTEN ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA AND DETERMINES IF THE APPLICANT IS ELIGIBLE AND THEN APPROVES OR REJECTS AN APPLICATION. A WRITTEN RECORD OF THE APPROVALS AND THE AMOUNTS OF THE SCHOLARSHIPS IS MAINTAINED. THE ACCOUNTING AND FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENTS ARE THEN NOTIFIED OF THE AMOUNT OF ANY SCHOLARSHIP AWARDED AND A PRO RATA PORTION OF THE SCHOLARSHIP IS CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT ON A MONTHLY BASIS. IF A STUDENT WITHDRAWS FROM THE COLLEGE, THE UNUSED PORTION OF THE SCHOLARSHIP IS CANCELLED.

MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO WYOMING CATHOLIC COLLEGE STUDENTS BASED ON ACADEMIC MERIT, REGARDLESS OF FINANCIAL NEED. STUDENTS MUST SUBMIT ALL REQUIRED INFORMATION (INCLUDING A STANDARD APPLICATION FORM, ESSAYS, RECOMMENDATIONS, AND STANDARDIZED TEST SCORES) TO APPLY FOR A MERIT SCHOLARSHIP. APPLICATIONS ARE SCREENED BY A COMMITTEE. DETAILED RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED OF ALL APPLICATIONS AND AWARDS FOR MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS. NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO WYOMING CATHOLIC COLLEGE STUDENTS BASED SOLELY ON FAMILY FINANCIAL NEED. STUDENTS MUST SUBMIT ALL REQUIRED INFORMATION (INCLUDING A STANDARD APPLICATION FORM AND FEDERAL TAX INFORMATION) TO APPLY FOR A NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIP. APPLICATIONS ARE SCREENED BY A COLLEGE REPRESENTATIVE AND A STANDARD FINANCIAL AID CALCULATOR IS USED. DETAILED RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED OF ALL APPLICATIONS AND AWARDS FOR NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS. CREDITS AGAINST ROOM AND BOARD CHARGES ARE ISSUED TO WYOMING CATHOLIC COLLEGE STUDENTS WHO ARE ASSIGNED TO RESIDENT ASSISTANT POSITIONS. CREDITS ARE GIVEN IN STANDARD AMOUNTS. DETAILED RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED OF CREDITS GIVEN.

ELIGIBILITY FOR THE SCHOOLS SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS IS DETERMINED USING THE FEDERAL NEEDS ANALYSIS METHODOLGY AS SET FORTH BY THE US DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION. THE MONIES USED TO GRANT ASSISTANCE TO THE STUDENTS COME OUT OF THE GENERAL OPERATING FUND FROM UNRESTRICTED DONATIONS.

ALL ORGANIZATIONS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT PROOF OF TAX EXEMPT STATUS THAT'S VERIFIED BY THE IRS DATABASE BEFORE THEY CAN PROCEED WITH THEIR REQUEST. THEY MAY USE OUR ONLINE CHARITABLE REQUEST APPLICATION TO SUBMIT A REQUEST. IF THEY ARE NOT A 501 (C)(3) ORGANIZATION, THEY ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT A COPY OF THEIR DETERMINATION LETTER FROM THE IRS VALIDATING THEIR EXEMPT STATUS BEFORE WE CAN PROVIDE ANY IN-KIND GIVEAWAYS OR SERVICES. WE ALSO MONITOR THE FUNDS TO ENSURE THEY ARE USED FOR THE PURPOSE GRANTED. WE MAKE EVERY EFFORT TO DIRECT OUR FUNDING TO A PROGRAM FOR A SPECIFIC PURPOSE. ORGANIZATIONS ARE ASKED TO SHOW RESULTS AND DOCUMENTATION ANNUALLY BEFORE THEIR REQUEST CAN BE CONSIDERED FOR FUTURE FUNDING. THE REQUESTS ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY VARIOUS INDIVIDUALS DEPENDING UPON THE TYPE AND AMOUNT OF THE REQUEST. SMALL AMOUNTS MAY BE APPROVED BY THE SYSTEM COORDINATOR, CASH SPONSORSHIPS MAY BE APPROVED BY THE SYSTEM DIRECTOR OF COMMUNICATIONS, ANYTHING OVER $10,000 MAY BE APPROVED BY THE BAPTIST MEMORIAL HEALTH CARE FOUNDATION SENIOR V.P., AND ANYTHING OVER $50,000 NEEDS APPROVAL BY THE CORPORATE PRESIDENT/CEO. FOR MORE INFORMATION ABOUT BAPTIST CHARITABLE GIVING GUIDELINES, PLEASE VISIT HTTP://WWW.BAPTISTONLINE.ORG/SERVICES/COMMUNITY/INVOLVEMENT/GIVING.ASP.

GSSIMR PROVIDES FELLOWSHIP STIPENDS TO GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCHERS IN THEIR PROGRAMS TO AID THEM IN THEIR PURSUIT OF STUDY AND RESEARCH. THE FELLOWSHIP STIPENDS ARE PROVIDED DURING THEIR PERIOD OF STUDY AND RESEARCH AND ARE NOT COMPENSATION FOR ANY SERVICES PROVIDED TO GSSIMR.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PART III, LINE 1, COLUMN (F):
ExplntnTxt: NON-CASH ASSISTANCE IS PROVIDED TO RESEARCHERS IN THE FORM OF HOUSING, BOOKS, COMPUTERS, AND SIMILAR ITEMS RELATED TO THEIR EDUCATION.
